632 <path d="M19 8H5c-1.66 0-3 1.34-3 3v6h4v4h12v-4h4v-6c0-1.66-1.34-3-3-3zm-3 11H8v-5h8v5zm3-7c-.55 0-1-.45-1-1s.45-1 1-1 1 .45 1 1-.45 1-1 1zm-1-9H6v4h12V3z"/>

If you have questions or need additional information, we invite you to contact NCI's LiveHelp instant messaging service at https://livehelp.cancer.gov, or call the NCI's Contact Center 1-800-4-CANCER (1-800-422-6237) (toll-free from the United States).">

821

822 <h1>

823Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment (PDQ)Health Professional Version</h1>

824

825 <div id="cgvBody">

826

827 <div class="summary-sections">

828

829 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

830

831 <h6>

832On This Page</h6>

833

834 <ul>

835

836 <li>

838General Information About Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)</a>

839</li>

840

841 <li>

849</li>

854</li>

856 <li>

859</li>

860

910

911 <div class="accordion">

912

913

914

915 <section id="_1">

916

917 <h2>

918General Information About Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)</h2>

919

920 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

921<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

922<h6>

923In This Section</h6>

924<ul>

925<li>

926<a href="#_153_toc">

927Characteristics of Myeloid Leukemias and Other Myeloid Malignancies in Children</a>

928</li>

929<li>

930<a href="#_943_toc">

931Conditions Associated With Myeloid Malignancies</a>

932</li>

933</ul>

934</nav>

935<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

936<a href="/types/leukemia/patient/child-aml-treatment-pdq">

937Go to Patient Version</a>

938</div>

939<p id="_142" tabindex="-1">

940Dramatic improvements in survival have been achieved for children and adolescents with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9411</a>

942] Between 1975 and 2010, childhood cancer mortality decreased by more than 50%. For acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the 5-year survival rate increased over the same time from less than 20% to 68% for children younger than 15 years and from less than 20% to 57% for adolescents aged 15 to 19 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9431</a>

944] </p>

945<section id="_153">

946<h3 id="_153_toc">

947Characteristics of Myeloid Leukemias and Other Myeloid Malignancies in Children</h3>

948<p id="_154" tabindex="-1">

949Approximately 20% of childhood leukemias are of myeloid origin and they represent a spectrum of hematopoietic malignancies.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9502</a>

951] Most myeloid leukemias are acute, and the remainder include chronic and/or subacute myeloproliferative disorders such as chronic myelogenous leukemia and juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia. Myelodysplastic syndromes occur much less frequently in children than in adults and almost invariably represent clonal, preleukemic conditions that may evolve from congenital marrow failure syndromes such as Fanconi anemia and Shwachman-Diamond syndrome.</p>

952<p id="_945" tabindex="-1">

953The general characteristics of myeloid leukemias and other myeloid malignancies are described below:</p>

954<div class="pdq-content-list">

955<ul id="_946">

956<li>

957<strong>

958Acute myeloid leukemia (AML).</strong>

959 AML is defined as a clonal disorder caused by malignant transformation of a bone marrow&#8211;derived, self-renewing stem cell or progenitors, leading to accumulation of immature, nonfunctional myeloid cells. These events lead to increased accumulation in the bone marrow and other organs by these malignant myeloid cells. To be called acute, the bone marrow usually must include greater than 20% immature leukemic blasts, with some exceptions as noted in subsequent sections. For more information, see the sections on <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_46">

960Treatment Option Overview for Childhood AML</a>

961 and <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_52">

962Treatment of Childhood AML</a>

963.</li>

964<li>

965<strong>

966Transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM).</strong>

967 TAM is also termed transient myeloproliferative disorder or transient leukemia. The TAM observed in infants with Down syndrome represents a clonal expansion of myeloblasts that can be difficult to distinguish from AML. Most importantly, TAM spontaneously regresses in most cases within the first 3 months of life. TAM occurs in 4% to 10% of infants with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9683</a>

969-<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

9705</a>

971] <p id="_949" tabindex="-1">

972TAM blasts most commonly have megakaryoblastic differentiation characteristics and distinctive mutations involving the <em class="gene-name">

973GATA1</em>

974 gene in the presence of trisomy 21.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

9756</a>

976,<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

9777</a>

978] TAM may occur in phenotypically normal infants with genetic mosaicism in the bone marrow for trisomy 21. While TAM is generally not characterized by cytogenetic abnormalities other than trisomy 21, the presence of additional cytogenetic findings may predict an increased risk of developing subsequent AML.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

9798</a>

980] Approximately 20% of infants with TAM of Down syndrome eventually develop AML, with most cases diagnosed within the first 3 years of life.[<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

9817</a>

982,<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

9838</a>

984] </p>

985<p id="_950" tabindex="-1">

986Early death from TAM-related complications occurs in 10% to 20% of affected infants.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

9878</a>

988,<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

9899</a>

990] Infants with progressive organomegaly, visceral effusions, high blast count (&gt;100,000 cells/&#956;L) and laboratory evidence of progressive liver dysfunction are at a particularly high risk of early mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

9918</a>

992,<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

9939</a>

994] For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_69">

995Myeloid Proliferations Associated with Down Syndrome</a>

996 section.</p>

997</li>

998<li>

999<strong>

1000Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).</strong>

1001 MDS in children represents a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis, impaired maturation of myeloid progenitors with dysplastic morphological features, and cytopenias. Although the underlying cause of MDS in children is unclear, there is often an association with marrow failure syndromes. Most patients with MDS may have hypercellular bone marrows without increased numbers of leukemic blasts, but some patients may present with a very hypocellular bone marrow, making the distinction between severe aplastic anemia and MDS

1002difficult.[<a href="#cit/section_1.10">

100310</a>

1004,<a href="#cit/section_1.11">

100511</a>

1006]<p id="_951" tabindex="-1">

1007The presence of a karyotype abnormality in a hypocellular marrow is consistent with MDS and transformation to AML should be expected. Given the high association of MDS evolving into AML, patients with MDS are typically referred for stem cell transplantation before transformation to AML. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_74">

1008Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS)</a>

1009 section.</p>

1010</li>

1011<li>

1012 <strong>

1013Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML).</strong>

1014 JMML represents the most common myeloproliferative syndrome observed in young children. JMML occurs at a median age of 1.8 years. <p id="_948" tabindex="-1">

1015JMML characteristically presents with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever, and skin rash along with an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count and increased circulating monocytes.[<a href="#cit/section_1.12">

101612</a>

1017] In addition, patients often have an elevated hemoglobin F, hypersensitivity of the leukemic cells to granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF), monosomy 7, and leukemia cell mutations in a gene involved in RAS pathway signaling (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

1018NF1</em>

1019, <em class="gene-name">

1020KRAS</em>

1021, <em class="gene-name">

1022NRAS</em>

1023, <em class="gene-name">

1024PTPN11</em>

1025, or <em class="gene-name">

1026CBL</em>

1027).[<a href="#cit/section_1.12">

102812</a>

1029-<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

103014</a>

1031] For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_78">

1032Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML)</a>

1033 section.</p>

1034</li>

1035<li>

1036 <strong>

1037Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).</strong>

1038 CML is primarily an adult disease but represents the most common of the chronic myeloproliferative disorders in childhood, accounting for approximately 10% of childhood myeloid leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

10392</a>

1040] Although CML has been reported in very young children, most patients are aged 6 years and older. <p id="_947" tabindex="-1">

1041CML is a clonal panmyelopathy that involves all hematopoietic cell lineages. While the WBC count can be extremely elevated, the bone marrow does not show increased numbers of leukemic blasts during the chronic phase of this disease. CML is caused by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (i.e., t(9;22)) resulting in fusion of the <em class="gene-name">

1042BCR</em>

1043 and <em class="gene-name">

1044ABL1</em>

1045 genes. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_195">

1046Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)</a>

1047 section.</p>

1048<p id="_1167" tabindex="-1">

1049Other chronic myeloproliferative syndromes, such as polycythemia vera and essential thrombocytosis, are extremely rare in children.</p>

1050</li>

1051</ul>

1052</div>

1053</section>

1054<section id="_943">

1055<h3 id="_943_toc">

1056Conditions Associated With Myeloid Malignancies</h3>

1057<p id="_226" tabindex="-1">

1058Genetic abnormalities (cancer predisposition syndromes) are associated with the development of AML. There is a high concordance rate of AML in identical twins; however, this is not believed to be related to genetic risk, but rather to shared circulation and the inability of one twin to reject leukemic cells from the other twin during fetal development.[<a href="#cit/section_1.15">

105915</a>

1060-<a href="#cit/section_1.17">

106117</a>

1062] There is an estimated twofold to fourfold increased risk of developing leukemia for the fraternal twin of a pediatric leukemia patient up to about age 6 years, after which the risk is not significantly greater than that of the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_1.18">

106318</a>

1064,<a href="#cit/section_1.19">

106519</a>

1066] </p>

1067<p id="_944" tabindex="-1">

1068The development of AML has also been associated with a variety of inherited/familial syndromes, which are recognized as a unique category within the 2016 World Health Organization (WHO) Classification of Myeloid Neoplasms and Acute Leukemia. There are also several acquired conditions that increase the risk of developing AML. These inherited and acquired conditions can induce leukemogenesis through mechanisms that include chromosomal imbalances or instabilities, defects in DNA repair, altered cytokine receptor or signal transduction pathway activation, and altered protein synthesis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

106920</a>

1070,<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

107121</a>

1072]</p>

1073<div class="pdq-content-list">

1074<p class="pdq-list-title">

1075Inherited syndromes</p>

1076<ul id="_959">

1077<li>

1078Chromosomal imbalances:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1079<ul id="_963" class="list-dash">

1080<li>

1081Down syndrome.</li>

1082<li>

1083Familial monosomy 7.</li>

1084</ul>

1085</div>

1086</li>

1087<li>

1088Chromosomal instability syndromes:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1089<ul id="_962" class="list-dash">

1090<li>

1091Fanconi anemia.</li>

1092<li>

1093Dyskeratosis congenita.</li>

1094<li>

1095Bloom syndrome.</li>

1096</ul>

1097</div>

1098</li>

1099<li>

1100Syndromes of growth and cell survival signaling pathway defects:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1101<ul id="_964" class="list-dash">

1102<li>

1103Neurofibromatosis type 1 (particularly JMML

1104development).</li>

1105<li>

1106Noonan syndrome (particularly JMML development).</li>

1107<li>

1108Severe congenital neutropenia (Kostmann syndrome, <em class="gene-name">

1109HAX1</em>

1110 mutations) and cyclic neutropenia (<em class="gene-name">

1111ELANE</em>

1112 mutations).</li>

1113<li>

1114Shwachman-Diamond syndrome.</li>

1115<li>

1116Diamond-Blackfan anemia.</li>

1117<li>

1118Congenital amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia (<em class="gene-name">

1119MPL</em>

1120 mutations).</li>

1121<li>

1122<em class="gene-name">

1123CBL</em>

1124 germline syndrome (particularly in JMML).</li>

1125<li>

1126Li-Fraumeni syndrome (<em class="gene-name">

1127TP53</em>

1128 mutations).</li>

1129</ul>

1130</div>

1131</li>

1132<li>

1133Inherited thrombocytopenia and platelet disorders with germline predisposition to myeloid neoplasia (<em class="gene-name">

1134RUNX1</em>

1135, <em class="gene-name">

1136ANKRD26</em>

1137, and <em class="gene-name">

1138ETV6</em>

1139 mutations).</li>

1140<li>

1141GATA2 deficiency (<em class="gene-name">

1142GATA2</em>

1143 mutations).</li>

1144</ul>

1145</div>

1146<div class="pdq-content-list">

1147<p class="pdq-list-title">

1148Acquired syndromes</p>

1149<ul id="_960">

1150<li>

1151Severe aplastic anemia.</li>

1152<li>

1153Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.</li>

1154<li>

1155Amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia.</li>

1156<li>

1157Acquired monosomy 7.</li>

1158</ul>

1159</div>

1160<p id="_1983" tabindex="-1">

1161The 2016 WHO classification system has categorized the myeloid neoplasms with germline predisposition as follows:</p>

1162<div class="pdq-content-list">

1163<ul id="_1939">

1164<li>

1165Myeloid neoplasms with germline predisposition without a pre-existing disorder or organ dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

116622</a>

1167]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1168<ul id="_1940" class="list-dash">

1169<li>

1170AML with germline <em class="gene-name">

1171CEBPA</em>

1172 mutations.</li>

1173<li>

1174Myeloid neoplasms with germline <em class="gene-name">

1175DDX41</em>

1176 mutations.</li>

1177</ul>

1178</div>

1179</li>

1180<li>

1181Myeloid neoplasms with germline predisposition and pre-existing platelet disorders.[<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

118222</a>

1183]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1184<ul id="_1941">

1185<li>

1186Myeloid neoplasms with germline <em class="gene-name">

1187RUNX1</em>

1188 mutations.</li>

1189<li>

1190Myeloid neoplasms with germline <em class="gene-name">

1191ANKRD26</em>

1192 mutations.</li>

1193<li>

1194Myeloid neoplasms with germline <em class="gene-name">

1195ETV6</em>

1196 mutations.</li>

1197</ul>

1198</div>

1199</li>

1200<li>

1201Myeloid neoplasms with germline predisposition and other organ dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

120222</a>

1203]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1204<ul id="_1942">

1205<li>

1206Myeloid neoplasms with germline <em class="gene-name">

1207GATA2</em>

1208 mutations.</li>

1209<li>

1210Myeloid neoplasms associated with bone marrow failure syndromes (including Fanconi anemia, Diamond-Blackfan anemia, and Shwachman-Diamond syndrome).</li>

1211<li>

1212Myeloid neoplasms associated with telomere biology disorders (including dyskeratosis congenita).</li>

1213<li>

1214JMML associated with neurofibromatosis, Noonan syndrome or Noonan syndrome&#8211;like disorders (including germline <em class="gene-name">

1215CBL</em>

1216 mutations).</li>

1217<li>

1218Myeloid neoplasms associated with Down syndrome.</li>

1219</ul>

1220</div>

1221</li>

1222</ul>

1223</div>

1224<p id="_649" tabindex="-1">

1225Nonsyndromic genetic susceptibility to AML is also being studied. For example, homozygosity for a specific <em class="gene-name">

1226IKZF1</em>

1227 polymorphism has been associated with an increased risk of infant AML.[<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

122823</a>

1229]</p>

1230</section>

1333 <section id="_9">

1334

1335 <h2>

1336Classification of Pediatric Myeloid Malignancies</h2>

1337

1338 <div id="_section_9" class="pdq-sections">

1339<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1340<h6>

1341In This Section</h6>

1342<ul>

1343<li>

1344<a href="#_10_toc">

1345French-American-British (FAB) Classification System for Childhood AML</a>

1346</li>

1347<li>

1348<a href="#_144_toc">

1349World Health Organization (WHO) Classification System for Childhood AML<ul>

1350<li>

1351<a href="#_1090_toc">

13522016 WHO classification of AML and related neoplasms</a>

1353</li>

1354<li>

1355<a href="#_1091_toc">

13562016 WHO classification of acute leukemias of ambiguous lineage</a>

1357</li>

1358</ul>

1359</a>

1360</li>

1361<li>

1362<a href="#_30_toc">

1363WHO Classification of Bone Marrow and Peripheral Blood Findings for Myelodysplastic Syndromes </a>

1364</li>

1365<li>

1366<a href="#_1306_toc">

1367Histochemical, Immunophenotypic, and Molecular Evaluation for Childhood AML<ul>

1368<li>

1369<a href="#_21_toc">

1370Histochemical Evaluation</a>

1371</li>

1372<li>

1373<a href="#_163_toc">

1374Immunophenotypic Evaluation </a>

1375</li>

1376<li>

1377<a href="#_27_toc">

1378Molecular Evaluation </a>

1379</li>

1380</ul>

1381</a>

1382</li>

1383</ul>

1384</nav>

1385<section id="_10">

1386<h3 id="_10_toc">

1387French-American-British (FAB) Classification System for Childhood AML</h3>

1388<p id="_11" tabindex="-1">

1389The first comprehensive morphological-histochemical classification system for

1390acute myeloid leukemia (AML) was developed by the FAB

1391Cooperative Group.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

13921</a>

1393-<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

13945</a>

1395] This classification system, which has been replaced by the World Health Organization (WHO) system described below, categorized AML into major subtypes primarily on the basis of morphology and immunohistochemical detection of lineage markers.

1396</p>

1397<p id="_1087" tabindex="-1">

1398The major subtypes of AML include the following:</p>

1399<div class="pdq-content-list">

1400<ul id="_12">

1401<li>

1402<strong>

1403M0:</strong>

1404 Acute myeloblastic leukemia without differentiation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

14056</a>

1406,<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

14077</a>

1408] M0 AML, also referred to as minimally differentiated AML, does not express myeloperoxidase (MPO) at the light microscopy level but may show characteristic granules by electron microscopy. M0 AML can be defined by expression of cluster determinant (CD) markers such as CD13, CD33, and CD117 (c-KIT) in the absence of lymphoid differentiation. </li>

1409<li>

1410<strong>

1411M1:</strong>

1412 Acute myeloblastic leukemia with minimal differentiation but with the expression of MPO that is detected by immunohistochemistry or flow cytometry.

1413</li>

1414<li>

1415<strong>

1416M2:</strong>

1417 Acute myeloblastic leukemia with differentiation.

1418</li>

1419<li>

1420<strong>

1421M3:</strong>

1422 Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) hypergranular type. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_62">

1423Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL)</a>

1424 section.</li>

1425<li>

1426<strong>

1427M3v:</strong>

1428 APL, microgranular variant. Cytoplasm of promyelocytes demonstrates a fine granularity, and nuclei are often folded. M3v has the same clinical, cytogenetic, and therapeutic implications as FAB M3.</li>

1429<li>

1430<strong>

1431M4:</strong>

1432 Acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AMML).

1433</li>

1434<li>

1435<strong>

1436M4Eo:</strong>

1437 AMML with eosinophilia (abnormal eosinophils with dysplastic basophilic granules).</li>

1438<li>

1439<strong>

1440M5:</strong>

1441 Acute monocytic leukemia (AMoL).

1442<div class="pdq-content-list">

1443<ul id="_162" class="list-dash">

1444<li>

1445<strong>

1446M5a:</strong>

1447 AMoL without differentiation (monoblastic).</li>

1448<li>

1449<strong>

1450M5b:</strong>

1451 AMoL with differentiation.</li>

1452</ul>

1453</div>

1454</li>

1455<li>

1456<strong>

1457M6:</strong>

1458 Acute erythroid leukemia (AEL).

1459<div class="pdq-content-list">

1460<ul id="_554" class="list-dash">

1461<li>

1462<strong>

1463M6a:</strong>

1464 Erythroleukemia.</li>

1465<li>

1466<strong>

1467M6b:</strong>

1468 Pure erythroid leukemia (myeloblast component not apparent).</li>

1469<li>

1470<strong>

1471M6c:</strong>

1472 Presence of myeloblasts and proerythroblasts.</li>

1473</ul>

1474</div>

1475</li>

1476<li>

1477<strong>

1478M7:</strong>

1479 Acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AMKL).

1480</li>

1481</ul>

1482</div>

1483<p id="_13" tabindex="-1">

1484Other extremely rare subtypes of AML include acute eosinophilic leukemia and

1485acute basophilic leukemia.</p>

1486<p id="_1168" tabindex="-1">

1487The FAB classification was superseded by the WHO classification described below but remains relevant as it forms the basis of the WHO's subcategory of AML, not otherwise specified (AML, NOS).</p>

1488</section>

1489<section id="_144">

1490<h3 id="_144_toc">

1491World Health Organization (WHO) Classification System for Childhood AML</h3>

1492<p id="_145" tabindex="-1">

1493In 2001, the WHO proposed a new classification system that incorporated diagnostic cytogenetic information and that more reliably correlated with outcome. In this classification, patients with t(8;21), inv(16), t(15;17), or <em class="gene-name">

1494KMT2A</em>

1495 (<em class="gene-name">

1496MLL</em>

1497) translocations, which collectively constituted nearly half of the cases of childhood AML, were classified as AML with recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities. This classification system also decreased the bone marrow percentage of leukemic blast requirement for the diagnosis of AML from 30% to 20%; an additional clarification was made so that patients with recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities did not need to meet the minimum blast requirement to be considered an AML patient.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

14988</a>

1499-<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

150010</a>

1501] </p>

1502<p id="_732" tabindex="-1">

1503In 2008, the WHO expanded the number of cytogenetic abnormalities linked to AML classification and, for the first time, included specific gene mutations (<em class="gene-name">

1504CEBPA</em>

1505 and <em class="gene-name">

1506NPM</em>

1507) in its classification system.[<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

150811</a>

1509] In 2016, the WHO classification underwent revisions to incorporate the expanding knowledge of leukemia biomarkers that are significantly important to the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment of leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

151012</a>

1511] With emerging technologies aimed at genetic, epigenetic, proteomic, and immunophenotypic classification, AML classification will certainly continue to evolve and provide informative prognostic and biologic guidelines to clinicians and researchers.</p>

1512<section id="_1090">

1513<h4 id="_1090_toc">

15142016 WHO classification of AML and related neoplasms</h4>

1515<div class="pdq-content-list">

1516<ul id="_342">

1517<li>

1518AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1519<ul id="_343" class="list-dash">

1520<li>

1521AML with t(8;21)(q22;q22), <em class="gene-name">

1522RUNX1</em>

1523::<em class="gene-name">

1524RUNX1T1</em>

1525 gene fusion.</li>

1526<li>

1527AML with inv(16)(p13.1;q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22), <em class="gene-name">

1528CBFB</em>

1529::<em class="gene-name">

1530MYH11</em>

1531 gene fusion.</li>

1532<li>

1533APL with <em class="gene-name">

1534PML</em>

1535::<em class="gene-name">

1536RARA</em>

1537 gene fusion.</li>

1538<li>

1539AML with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3), <em class="gene-name">

1540MLLT3</em>

1541::<em class="gene-name">

1542KMT2A</em>

1543 gene fusion.</li>

1544<li>

1545AML with t(6;9)(p23;q34.1), <em class="gene-name">

1546DEK</em>

1547::<em class="gene-name">

1548NUP214</em>

1549 gene fusion. </li>

1550<li>

1551AML with inv(3)(q21.3;q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2), <em class="gene-name">

1552GATA2, MECOM</em>

1553. </li>

1554<li>

1555AML (megakaryoblastic) with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.3), <em class="gene-name">

1556RBM15</em>

1557::<em class="gene-name">

1558MKL1</em>

1559 gene fusion. </li>

1560<li>

1561AML with <em class="gene-name">

1562BCR</em>

1563::<em class="gene-name">

1564ABL1</em>

1565 gene fusion (provisional entity).</li>

1566<li>

1567AML with mutated <em class="gene-name">

1568NPM1</em>

1569.</li>

1570<li>

1571AML with biallelic mutations of <em class="gene-name">

1572CEBPA</em>

1573.</li>

1574<li>

1575AML with mutated <em class="gene-name">

1576RUNX1</em>

1577 (provisional entity).</li>

1578</ul>

1579</div>

1580</li>

1581<li>

1582AML with myelodysplasia-related features.</li>

1583<li>

1584Therapy-related myeloid neoplasms.</li>

1585<li>

1586AML, NOS:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1587<ul id="_344" class="list-dash">

1588<li>

1589AML with minimal differentiation.</li>

1590<li>

1591AML without maturation.</li>

1592<li>

1593AML with maturation.</li>

1594<li>

1595Acute myelomonocytic leukemia.</li>

1596<li>

1597Acute monoblastic/monocytic leukemia.</li>

1598<li>

1599Pure erythroid leukemia.</li>

1600<li>

1601Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia.</li>

1602<li>

1603Acute basophilic leukemia.</li>

1604<li>

1605Acute panmyelosis with myelofibrosis.</li>

1606</ul>

1607</div>

1608</li>

1609<li>

1610Myeloid sarcoma.</li>

1611<li>

1612Myeloid proliferations related to Down syndrome:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1613<ul id="_345" class="list-dash">

1614<li>

1615Transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM).</li>

1616<li>

1617Myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome.</li>

1618</ul>

1619</div>

1620</li>

1621</ul>

1622</div>

1623</section>

1624<section id="_1091">

1625<h4 id="_1091_toc">

16262016 WHO classification of acute leukemias of ambiguous lineage</h4>

1627<p id="_558" tabindex="-1">

1628For the group of acute leukemias that have characteristics of both AML and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the acute leukemias of ambiguous lineage, the WHO classification system is summarized in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_561">

1629Table 1</a>

1630.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

163113</a>

1632,<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

163314</a>

1634] The criteria for lineage assignment for a diagnosis of mixed phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL) are provided in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1086">

1635Table 2</a>

1636.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

163712</a>

1638,<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

163915</a>

1640]</p>

1641<table id="_561" class="table-default expandable-container">

1696BCR</em>

1706MLL</em>

1707) rearranged</td>

1708<td>

1710KMT2A</em>

1711 gene</td>

1716</td>

1719BCR</em>

1723KMT2A</em>

1731BCR</em>

1750</tbody>

1751</table>

1752<table id="_1086" class="table-default expandable-container">

1755a</span>

1776]</td>

1777</tr>

1780<span class="sup">

1781b</span>

1782Strong defined as equal to or brighter than the normal B or T cells in the sample.</td>

1783</tr>

1784</TFoot>

1785<tbody>

1786<tr>

1787<td>

1788<strong>

1789Myeloid Lineage</strong>

1790</td>

1791<td>

1792Myeloperoxidase (flow cytometry, immunohistochemistry, or cytochemistry); <strong>

1793or</strong>

1794 monocytic differentiation (at least two of the following: nonspecific esterase cytochemistry, CD11c, CD14, CD64, lysozyme)</td>

1795</tr>

1796<tr>

1797<td>

1798<strong>

1799T Lineage</strong>

1800</td>

1801<td>

1802Strong<span class="sup">

1803b</span>

1804 cytoplasmic CD3 (with antibodies to CD3 epsilon chain); <strong>

1805or</strong>

1806 surface CD3</td>

1807</tr>

1808<tr>

1809<td>

1810<strong>

1811B Lineage</strong>

1812</td>

1813<td>

1814Strong<span class="sup">

1815b</span>

1816 CD19 with at least one of the following strongly expressed: CD79a, cytoplasmic CD22, or CD10; <strong>

1817or</strong>

1818 weak CD19 with at least two of the following strongly expressed: CD79a, cytoplasmic CD22, or CD10</td>

1819</tr>

1820</tbody>

1821</table>

1822<p id="_559" tabindex="-1">

1823Leukemias of mixed phenotype may be seen in various presentations, including the following:</p>

1824<div class="pdq-content-list">

1825<ol id="_705">

1826<li>

1827Bilineal leukemias in which there are two distinct populations of cells, usually one lymphoid and one myeloid.</li>

1828<li>

1829Biphenotypic leukemias in which individual blast cells display features of both lymphoid and myeloid lineage.</li>

1830</ol>

1831</div>

1832<p id="_706" tabindex="-1">

1833Biphenotypic cases represent the majority of mixed phenotype leukemias.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

183416</a>

1835]

1836

1837B-myeloid biphenotypic leukemias lacking the <em class="gene-name">

1838TEL</em>

1839::<em class="gene-name">

1840AML1</em>

1841 fusion have a lower rate of complete remission (CR) and a significantly worse event-free survival (EFS) compared with patients with precursor B-cell ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

184216</a>

1843] Some studies suggest that patients with biphenotypic leukemia may fare better with a lymphoid, as opposed to a myeloid, treatment regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

184417</a>

1845-<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

184620</a>

1847]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

184821</a>

1849][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1850Level of evidence C1</a>

1851] A large retrospective study from the international Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) group demonstrated that initial therapy with an ALL-type regimen was associated with a superior outcome compared with AML-type or combined ALL/AML regimens, particularly in cases with CD19 positivity or other lymphoid antigen expression. In this study, hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in first CR was not beneficial, with the possible exception of cases with morphological evidence of persistent marrow disease (&#8805;5% blasts) after the first month of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

185220</a>

1853]</p>

1854</section>

1855</section>

1856<section id="_30">

1857<h3 id="_30_toc">

1858WHO Classification of Bone Marrow and Peripheral Blood Findings for Myelodysplastic Syndromes </h3>

1859<p id="_31" tabindex="-1">

1860The FAB classification of myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) was not completely applicable to children.[<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

186122</a>

1862,<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

186323</a>

1864] Traditionally, MDS classification systems have been divided into several distinct categories on the basis of the presence of the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

186523</a>

1866-<a href="#cit/section_2.26">

186726</a>

1868]

1869</p>

1870<div class="pdq-content-list">

1871<ul id="_709">

1872<li>

1873Myelodysplasia.</li>

1874<li>

1875Types of cytopenia.</li>

1876<li>

1877Specific chromosomal abnormalities.</li>

1878<li>

1879Percentage of myeloblasts.</li>

1880</ul>

1881</div>

1882<p id="_123" tabindex="-1">

1883A modified classification schema for MDS and myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs) was published by the WHO in 2008 and included subsections that focused on pediatric MDS and MPD.[<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

188427</a>

1885] This pediatric approach to the WHO classification of myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative diseases was initially proposed in 2003.[<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

188610</a>

1887] The 2016 revision to the WHO classification has removed focus on the specific lineage (anemia, thrombocytopenia, or neutropenia) and now distinguishes cases with dysplasia in single versus multiple lineages. The category of MDS with excess blasts (MDS-EB) now encompasses the pediatric cases previously classified as refractory anemia with excess blasts (RAEB) or RAEB in transformation (RAEB-T).[<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

188828</a>

1889] The category of refractory cytopenia of childhood is retained as a provisional entity. The bone marrow and peripheral blood findings for MDS according to the 2008 WHO classification schema are summarized in Tables <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_872">

18903</a>

1891 and <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_741">

18924</a>

1893.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

189412</a>

1895,<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

189627</a>

1897] When MDS-EB is associated with the recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities that are usually associated with AML, a diagnosis of AML is made and patients are treated accordingly.</p>

1898<p id="_1089" tabindex="-1">

1899Distinguishing MDS from similar-appearing, reactive causes of dysplasia and/or cytopenias is noted to be difficult. In general, the finding of more than 10% dysplasia in a cell lineage is a diagnostic criteria for MDS; however, the 2016 WHO guidelines caution that reactive etiologies, rather than clonal, may have more than 10% dysplasia and should be excluded especially when dysplasia is subtle and/or restricted to a single lineage.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

190012</a>

1901]</p>

1902<p id="_712" tabindex="-1">

1903The International Prognostic Scoring System is used to determine the risk of progression to AML and the outcome in adult patients with MDS. When this system was applied to children with MDS or juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML), only a blast count of less than 5% and a platelet count of more than 100 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

19049</span>

1905/L were associated with a better survival in MDS, and a platelet count of more than 40 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

19069</span>

1907/L predicted a better outcome in JMML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

190829</a>

1909] These results suggest that MDS and JMML in children may be significantly different disorders than adult-type MDS. </p>

1910<p id="_1289" tabindex="-1">

1911Pediatric MDS can be grouped into several general categories, each with distinctive clinical and biological characteristics, as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

191228</a>

1913]</p>

1914<div class="pdq-content-list">

1915<ul id="_1290">

1916<li>

1917MDS arising from an inherited bone marrow failure syndrome, such as Fanconi anemia, severe congenital neutropenia, and Shwachman-Diamond syndrome.</li>

1918<li>

1919MDS arising from severe aplastic anemia.</li>

1920<li>

1921Secondary MDS arising from cytotoxic insults, such as high-dose alkylating chemotherapy.</li>

1922<li>

1923Primary MDS includes cases of MDS beyond those listed above, acknowledging that some of the cases characterized as primary MDS are also associated with predisposition syndromes.</li>

1924</ul>

1925</div>

1926<p id="_1291" tabindex="-1">

1927Genomic characterization of pediatric primary MDS has identified specific subsets defined by alterations in selected genes. For example, germline mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1928GATA2</em>

1929,[<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

193030</a>

1931] <em class="gene-name">

1932SAMD9</em>

1933, or <em class="gene-name">

1934SAMD9L</em>

1935 [<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

193631</a>

1937-<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

193833</a>

1939] are especially common in children with deletions of all or part of chromosome 7. Genomic characterization has also shown that primary MDS in children differs from adult MDS at the molecular level.[<a href="#cit/section_2.32">

194032</a>

1941,<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

194234</a>

1943] For more information about MDS, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_981">

1944Molecular Abnormalities</a>

1945 section.</p>

1946<table id="_872" class="table-default expandable-container">

1947<caption>

1948Table 3. World Health Organization (WHO) Classification of Bone Marrow and Peripheral Blood Findings for Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS)<span class="sup">

1949a</span>

1950</caption>

1953<col width="32.18%">

1954<col width="34.99%">

1975</tr>

1980Note that cases with pancytopenia would be classified as MDS-U.</td>

1981</tr>

1982<tr>

1983<td colspan="4">

1984<span class="sup">

1985c</span>

1986When the marrow has &lt;5% myeloblasts, but the peripheral blood has 2%&#8211;4% myeloblasts, the diagnosis is MDS-EB-1.</td>

1987</tr>

1988<tr>

1989<td colspan="4">

1990<span class="sup">

1991d</span>

1992The diagnosis of MDS-EB-2 should be made if any one of the following criteria are met: marrow with 10%&#8211;19% blasts, peripheral blood with 5%&#8211;19% blasts, or presence of Auer rods.</td>

1993</tr>

1994<tr>

1995<td colspan="4">

1996<span class="sup">

1997e</span>

1998Recurring chromosomal abnormalities in MDS: Unbalanced: +8, -7 or del(7q), -5 or del(5q), del(20q), -Y, i(17q) or t(17p), -13 or del(13q), del(11q), del(12p) or t(12p), del(9q), idic(X)(q13); Balanced: t(11;16)(q23;p13.3), t(3;21)(q26.2;q22.1), t(1;3)(p36.3;q21.2), t(2;11)(p21;q23), inv(3)(q21q26.2), t(6;9)(p23;q34). The WHO classification notes that the presence of these chromosomal abnormalities in presence of persistent cytopenias of undetermined origin should be considered to support a presumptive diagnosis of MDS when morphological characteristics are not observed. </td>

1999</tr>

2000<tr>

2001<td colspan="4">

2002<span class="sup">

2003f</span>

2004The diagnostic criteria for childhood MDS (refractory cytopenia of childhood-provisional entry) include: 1) persistent cytopenia of 1&#8211;3 cell lines with &lt;5% bone marrow blasts, &lt;2% peripheral blood blasts, and no ringed sideroblasts and 2) dysplastic changes in 1&#8211;3 lineages should be present.</td>

2005</tr>

2006</TFoot>

2007<tbody>

2008<tr>

2009<td rowspan="3" colspan="2">

2010MDS with single lineage dysplasia </td>

2011<td>

2012Unilineage dysplasia:

2013

2014

2015

2016 &#8805;10% in one myeloid lineage</td>

2017<td>

20181&#8211;2 cytopenias<span class="sup">

2019b</span>

2020</td>

2021</tr>

2022<tr>

2023<td>

2024&lt;5% blasts </td>

2025<td>

2026Blasts &lt;1%<span class="sup">

2027c</span>

2028</td>

2029</tr>

2030<tr>

2031<td>

2032&lt;15% ring sideroblasts</td>

2033<td>

2034&#160;</td>

2035</tr>

2036<tr>

2037<td colspan="4">

2038&#160;</td>

2039</tr>

2040<tr>

2041<td rowspan="3" colspan="2">

2042MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS) </td>

2043<td>

2044Erythroid dysplasia only

2045

2046

2047</td>

2048<td>

2049

2050</td>

2051</tr>

2052<tr>

2053<td>

2054&lt;5% blasts</td>

2055<td>

2056No blasts

2057</td>

2058</tr>

2059<tr>

2060<td>

2061&#8805;15% ring sideroblasts</td>

2062<td>

2063&#160;</td>

2064</tr>

2065<tr>

2066<td colspan="4">

2067&#160;</td>

2068</tr>

2069<tr>

2070<td rowspan="5" colspan="2">

2071MDS with multilineage dysplasia </td>

2072<td>

2073Dysplasia in &#8805;10% of cells in &#8805;2 myeloid lineages

2074

2075

2076

2077</td>

2078<td>

20791&#8211;3 cytopenias

2080

2081

2082</td>

2083</tr>

2084<tr>

2085<td>

2086&lt;5% blasts</td>

2087<td>

2088Blasts (none or &lt;1%)<span class="sup">

2089c</span>

2090</td>

2091</tr>

2092<tr>

2093<td>

2112</tr>

2113<tr>

2218</td>

2225

2226</td>

2233</tr>

2239</tr>

2289<table id="_741" class="table-default expandable-container">

2312<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2321<tr>

2326</tr>

2327<tr>

2329<span class="sup">

2330c</span>

2332</tr>

2336d</span>

2337Presence of pseudo&#8211;Pelger-Huet cells, hypo- or agranular cytoplasm, giant <em>

2338band</em>

2339 forms.</td>

2340</tr>

2341<tr>

2342<td colspan="4">

2343<span class="sup">

2344e</span>

2346</tr>

2347</TFoot>

2445</table>

2446</section>

2447<section id="_1306">

2448<h3 id="_1306_toc">

2449Histochemical, Immunophenotypic, and Molecular Evaluation for Childhood AML</h3>

2450<section id="_21">

2451<h4 id="_21_toc">

2452Histochemical Evaluation</h4>

2453<p id="_22" tabindex="-1">

2454The treatment for children with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) differs significantly from that for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

2455As a consequence, it is critical to distinguish AML from ALL. Special

2456histochemical stains performed on bone marrow specimens of

2457children with acute leukemia can be helpful to confirm their diagnosis. The stains most

2458commonly used include myeloperoxidase, periodic acid-Schiff, Sudan Black B, and esterase. In

2459most cases, the staining pattern with these histochemical stains will

2460distinguish AML from acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AMML) and ALL (see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_120">

2461Table 5</a>

2462). Histochemical stains have been mostly replaced by flow cytometric immunophenotyping.</p>

2463<table id="_120" class="table-default expandable-container">

2464<caption>

2465Table 5. Histochemical Staining Patterns<span class="sup">

2466a</span>

2467</caption>

2468<colgroup>

2469<col width="8.21%">

2470<col width="34.26%">

2471<col width="8.21%">

2472<col width="8.21%">

2473<col width="8.21%">

2474<col width="8.21%">

2475<col width="8.21%">

2476<col width="8.21%">

2477<col width="8.21%">

2478</colgroup>

2479<THead>

2480<tr>

2481<th colspan="2">

2482&#160;</th>

2483<th>

2484M0</th>

2485<th>

2486AML, APL (M1-M3) </th>

2487<th>

2488AMML (M4)</th>

2489<th>

2490AMoL (M5)</th>

2491<th>

2492AEL (M6)</th>

2493<th>

2494AMKL (M7)</th>

2495<th>

2496ALL</th>

2497</tr>

2498</THead>

2499<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2500<tr>

2501<td colspan="9">

2502AEL = acute erythroid leukemia; ALL = acute lymphoblastic leukemia; AML = acute myeloid leukemia; AMKL = acute megakaryocytic leukemia; AMML = acute myelomonocytic leukemia; AMoL = acute monocytic leukemia; APL = acute promyelocytic leukemia; PAS = periodic acid-Schiff.</td>

2503</tr>

2504<tr>

2505<td colspan="9">

2506<span class="sup">

2507a</span>

2508For more information about the morphological-histochemical classification system for

2509AML, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_10">

2510French-American-British (FAB) Classification for Childhood AML</a>

2511 section.</td>

2512</tr>

2513<tr>

2514<td colspan="9">

2515<span class="sup">

2516b</span>

2517These reactions are inhibited by fluoride.</td>

2518</tr>

2519</TFoot>

2520<tbody>

2521<tr>

2522<td colspan="2">

2523Myeloperoxidase</td>

2524<td>

2528<td>

2529+</td>

2542 </td>

2543<td>

2545<td>

2547<td>

2550&#160;</td>

2551<td>

2553<td>

2557</tr>

2558<tr>

2559<td>

2561<td>

2562Chloracetate </td>

2563<td>

2564-</td>

2565<td>

2566+</td>

2567<td>

2568+</td>

2570&#177;</td>

2571<td>

2572-</td>

2573<td>

2574-</td>

2575<td>

2576-</td>

2577</tr>

2578<tr>

2579<td>

2580&#160;</td>

2581<td>

2582Alpha-naphthol acetate</td>

2583<td>

2584-</td>

2585<td>

2586-</td>

2587<td>

2588+ <span class="sup">

2589b</span>

2590</td>

2591<td>

2592+ <span class="sup">

2593b</span>

2594</td>

2595<td>

2596-</td>

2597<td>

2598&#177; <span class="sup">

2599b</span>

2600</td>

2601<td>

2602-</td>

2603</tr>

2604<tr>

2605<td colspan="2">

2606Sudan Black B</td>

2607<td>

2608-</td>

2609<td>

2610+</td>

2611<td>

2612+</td>

2613<td>

2614-</td>

2615<td>

2616-</td>

2617<td>

2618-</td>

2619<td>

2620-</td>

2621</tr>

2622<tr>

2623<td colspan="2">

2624PAS </td>

2625<td>

2626-</td>

2627<td>

2628-</td>

2629<td>

2630&#177;</td>

2631<td>

2632&#177;</td>

2633<td>

2634+</td>

2635<td>

2636-</td>

2637<td>

2638+</td>

2639</tr>

2640</tbody>

2641</table>

2642</section>

2643<section id="_163">

2644<h4 id="_163_toc">

2645Immunophenotypic Evaluation </h4>

2646<p id="_25" tabindex="-1">

2647The use of monoclonal antibodies to determine cell-surface antigens of AML

2648cells is helpful to reinforce the histologic diagnosis. Various

2649lineage-specific monoclonal antibodies that detect antigens on AML cells

2650should be used at the time of initial diagnostic workup, along with a battery of lineage-specific

2651T-lymphocyte and B-lymphocyte markers to help distinguish AML from ALL and acute leukemias of ambiguous lineage. The expression of various cluster determinant (CD) proteins that

2652are relatively lineage-specific for AML include CD33,

2653CD13, CD14, CDw41 (or platelet antiglycoprotein IIb/IIIa), CD15, CD11B, CD36,

2654and antiglycophorin A. Lineage-associated B-lymphocytic antigens CD10, CD19,

2655CD20, CD22, and CD24 may be present in 10% to 20% of AML cases, but monoclonal

2656surface immunoglobulin and cytoplasmic immunoglobulin heavy chains are usually

2657absent; similarly, CD2, CD3, CD5, and CD7 lineage-associated T-lymphocytic

2658antigens are present in 20% to 40% of AML cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

265936</a>

2660-<a href="#cit/section_2.38">

266138</a>

2662] The aberrant expression of lymphoid-associated antigens by AML cells is relatively common but generally has no prognostic

2663significance.[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

266436</a>

2665,<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

266637</a>

2667]

2668</p>

2669<p id="_26" tabindex="-1">

2670Immunophenotyping can also be helpful in distinguishing the following French-American-British (FAB) classification subtypes of

2671AML: </p>

2672<div class="pdq-content-list">

2673<ul id="_876">

2674<li>

2675Testing for the presence of HLA-antigen D related (HLA-DR) can be helpful in identifying acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

2676Overall, HLA-DR is expressed on 75% to 80% of AML cells but rarely expressed on APL cells.[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

267739</a>

2678,<a href="#cit/section_2.40">

267940</a>

2680]

2681In addition, APL is characterized by bright CD33 expression and by CD117 (c-KIT) expression in most cases, heterogeneous expression of CD13 with CD34, CD11a, and CD18 often negative or low.[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

268239</a>

2683,<a href="#cit/section_2.40">

268440</a>

2685] The APL microgranular variant M3v more commonly expresses CD34 along with CD2.[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

268639</a>

2687,<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

268841</a>

2689]</li>

2690<li>

2691Testing for the

2692presence of glycoprotein Ib, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa, or Factor VIII antigen

2693expression is helpful in making the diagnosis of M7 (megakaryocytic leukemia).</li>

2694<li>

2695Glycophorin expression is helpful in making the diagnosis of M6

2696(erythroid leukemia).</li>

2697</ul>

2698</div>

2699<p id="_423" tabindex="-1">

2700Less than 5% of cases of acute leukemia in children are of ambiguous lineage, expressing features of both myeloid and lymphoid lineage.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

270116</a>

2702-<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

270318</a>

2704] These cases are distinct from ALL with myeloid coexpression in that the predominant lineage cannot be determined by immunophenotypic and histochemical studies. The definition of leukemia of ambiguous lineage varies among studies, although most investigators now use criteria established by the European Group for the Immunological Characterization of Leukemias (EGIL) or the more stringent World Health Organization (WHO) criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

270514</a>

2706,<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

270742</a>

2708,<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

270943</a>

2710] In the WHO classification, the presence of myeloperoxidase (MPO) is required to establish myeloid lineage. This is not the case for the EGIL classification. The 2016 revision to the WHO classification also denotes that in some cases, leukemia with otherwise classic B-cell ALL immunophenotype may also express low-intensity MPO without other myeloid features, and the clinical significance of that finding is unclear such that one should be cautious before designating these cases as mixed phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL).[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

271112</a>

2712]</p>

2713</section>

2714<section id="_27">

2715<h4 id="_27_toc">

2716Molecular Evaluation </h4>

2717<section id="_sm_CDR0000779362_834">

2718<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000779362_834_toc">

2719Molecular features of acute myeloid leukemia</h5>

2720<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1910" tabindex="-1">

2721Comprehensive molecular profiling of pediatric and adult AML has shown that AML is a disease

2722demonstrating both commonalities and differences across the age spectrum.[<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

272344</a>

2724,<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

272545</a>

2726] </p>

2727<div class="pdq-content-list">

2728<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1929">

2729<li>

2730Pediatric AML, in contrast to AML in adults, is typically a disease of recurring chromosomal alterations. For a list of common gene fusions, see Table 6.[<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

273144</a>

2732,<a href="#cit/section_2.46">

273346</a>

2734] Within the pediatric age range, certain gene fusions occur primarily in children younger than 5 years (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

2735NUP98</em>

2736, <em class="gene-name">

2737KMT2A</em>

2738, and <em class="gene-name">

2739CBFA2T3</em>

2740::<em class="gene-name">

2741GLIS2</em>

2742 gene fusions), while others occur primarily in children aged 5 years and older (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

2743RUNX1</em>

2744::<em class="gene-name">

2745RUNX1T1</em>

2746, <em class="gene-name">

2747CBFB</em>

2748::<em class="gene-name">

2749MYH11</em>

2750, and <em class="gene-name">

2751NPM1</em>

2752::<em class="gene-name">

2753RARA</em>

2754 gene fusions).</li>

2755<li>

2756Pediatric patients with AML have low rates of mutations, with most cases showing less than one somatic change in protein-coding regions per megabase.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

275745</a>

2758] This mutation rate is somewhat lower than that observed in adult AML and is much lower than the mutation rate for cancers that respond to checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., melanoma).[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

275945</a>

2760]</li>

2761<li>

2762The pattern of gene mutations differs between pediatric and adult AML cases. For example, <em class="gene-name">

2763IDH1</em>

2764, <em class="gene-name">

2765IDH2</em>

2766, <em class="gene-name">

2767TP53</em>

2768, <em class="gene-name">

2769RUNX1</em>

2770, and <em class="gene-name">

2771DNMT3A</em>

2772 mutations are more common in adult AML than in pediatric AML, while <em class="gene-name">

2773NRAS</em>

2774 and <em class="gene-name">

2775WT1</em>

2776 mutations are significantly more common in pediatric AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

277744</a>

2778,<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

277945</a>

2780]</li>

2781</ul>

2782</div>

2783<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_28" tabindex="-1">

2784Genetic analysis of leukemia blast cells (using both conventional cytogenetic methods and molecular methods) is performed on children with AML because both chromosomal and molecular abnormalities are

2785important diagnostic and prognostic markers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.46">

278646</a>

2787-<a href="#cit/section_2.50">

278850</a>

2789] Clonal chromosomal

2790abnormalities are identified in the blasts of about 75% of children with

2791AML and are useful in defining subtypes with both prognostic and therapeutic significance. </p>

2792<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_869" tabindex="-1">

2793Detection of molecular abnormalities can also aid in risk stratification and treatment allocation. For example, mutations of <em class="gene-name">

2794NPM</em>

2795 and <em class="gene-name">

2796CEBPA</em>

2797 are associated with favorable outcomes while certain mutations of <em class="gene-name">

2798FLT3</em>

2799 portend a high risk of relapse, and identifying the latter mutations may allow for targeted therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

280051</a>

2801-<a href="#cit/section_2.54">

280254</a>

2803]</p>

2804<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_850" tabindex="-1">

2805The 2016 revision to the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia emphasizes that recurrent chromosomal translocations in pediatric AML may be unique or have a different prevalence than in adult AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

280612</a>

2807] The pediatric AML chromosomal translocations that are found by conventional chromosome analysis and those that are cryptic (identified only with fluorescence <em>

2808in situ</em>

2809 hybridization or molecular techniques) occur at higher rates than in adults. These recurrent translocations are summarized in Table 6.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

281012</a>

2811,<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

281245</a>

2813] Table 6 also shows, in the bottom three rows, additional relatively common recurrent translocations observed in children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

281445</a>

2815,<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

281648</a>

2817,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

281849</a>

2819,<a href="#cit/section_2.55">

282055</a>

2821]</p>

2822<table id="_sm_CDR0000779362_851" class="table-default expandable-container">

2823<caption>

2824Table 6. Common Pediatric Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) Chromosomal Translocations</caption>

2825<colgroup>

2826<col width="33.33%">

2827<col width="33.33%">

2828<col width="33.33%">

2829</colgroup>

2830<THead>

2831<tr>

2832<th>

2833Gene Fusion Product</th>

2834<th>

2835Chromosomal Translocation</th>

2836<th>

2837Prevalence in Pediatric AML (%)</th>

2838</tr>

2839</THead>

2840<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2841<tr>

2842<td colspan="3">

2843<span class="sup">

2844a</span>

2845Cryptic chromosomal translocation.</td>

2846</tr>

2847</TFoot>

2848<tbody>

2849<tr>

2850<td>

2851<em class="gene-name">

2852KMT2A</em>

2853 (<em class="gene-name">

2854MLL</em>

2855) translocated </td>

2856<td>

285711q23.3 </td>

2858<td>

285925.0</td>

2860</tr>

2861<tr>

2862<td>

2863<em class="gene-name">

2864NUP98</em>

2865::<em class="gene-name">

2866NSD1</em>

2867<span class="sup">

2868a</span>

2869</td>

2870<td>

2871t(5;11)(q35.3;p15.5)</td>

2872<td>

28737.0</td>

2874</tr>

2875<tr>

2876<td>

2877<em class="gene-name">

2878CBFA2T3</em>

2879::<em class="gene-name">

2880GLIS2</em>

2881<span class="sup">

2882a </span>

2883</td>

2884<td>

2885inv(16)(p13.3;q24.3)</td>

2886<td>

28873.0</td>

2888</tr>

2889<tr>

2890<td>

2891<em class="gene-name">

2892NUP98</em>

2893::<em class="gene-name">

2894KDM5A</em>

2895<span class="sup">

2896a</span>

2897 </td>

2898<td>

2899t(11;12)(p15.5;p13.5)</td>

2900<td>

29013.0</td>

2902</tr>

2903<tr>

2904<td>

2905<em class="gene-name">

2906DEK</em>

2907::<em class="gene-name">

2908NUP214</em>

2909</td>

2910<td>

2911t(6;9)(p22.3;q34.1)</td>

2912<td>

29131.7</td>

2914</tr>

2915<tr>

2916<td>

2917<em class="gene-name">

2918RBM15(OTT)</em>

2919::<em class="gene-name">

2920MKL1</em>

2921(<em class="gene-name">

2922MAL</em>

2923)</td>

2924<td>

2925t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.1)</td>

2926<td>

29270.8</td>

2928</tr>

2929<tr>

2930<td>

2931<em class="gene-name">

2932MNX1</em>

2933::<em class="gene-name">

2934ETV6</em>

2935</td>

2936<td>

2937 t(7;12)(q36.3;p13.2)</td>

2938<td>

29390.8</td>

2940</tr>

2941<tr>

2942<td>

2943<em class="gene-name">

2944KAT6A</em>

2945::<em class="gene-name">

2946CREBBP</em>

2947</td>

2948<td>

2949t(8;16)(p11.2;p13.3)</td>

2950<td>

29510.5</td>

2952</tr>

2953<tr>

2954<td>

2955<em class="gene-name">

2956RUNX1</em>

2957::<em class="gene-name">

2958RUNX1T1</em>

2959</td>

2960<td>

2961t(8;21)(q22;q22)</td>

2962<td>

296313&#8211;14</td>

2964</tr>

2965<tr>

2966<td>

2967<em class="gene-name">

2968CBFB</em>

2969::<em class="gene-name">

2970MYH11</em>

2971</td>

2972<td>

2973inv(16)(p13.1;q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22)</td>

2974<td>

29754&#8211;9</td>

2976</tr>

2977<tr>

2978<td>

2979<em class="gene-name">

2980PML</em>

2981::<em class="gene-name">

2982RARA</em>

2983</td>

2984<td>

2985t(15;17)(q24;q21)</td>

2986<td>

29876&#8211;11</td>

2988</tr>

2989</tbody>

2990</table>

2991<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1930" tabindex="-1">

2992The genomic landscape of pediatric AML cases can change from diagnosis to relapse, with mutations detectable at diagnosis dropping out at relapse and, conversely, with new mutations appearing at relapse. In a study of 20 cases for which sequencing data were available at diagnosis and relapse, a key finding was that the variant allele frequency at diagnosis strongly correlated with persistence of mutations at relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

299356</a>

2994] Approximately 90% of the diagnostic variants with variant allele frequency greater than 0.4 persisted to relapse, compared with only 28% with variant allele frequency less than 0.2 (<em>

2995P</em>

2996 &lt; .001). This observation is consistent with previous results showing that presence of a mutation in the <em class="gene-name">

2997FLT3</em>

2998 gene resulting from internal tandem duplications (ITD) predicted for poor prognosis only when there was a high <em class="gene-name">

2999FLT3</em>

3000 ITD allelic ratio.</p>

3001<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_543" tabindex="-1">

3002Specific recurring cytogenetic and molecular abnormalities are briefly described below. The abnormalities are listed by those in clinical use that identify patients with favorable or unfavorable prognosis, followed by other abnormalities. The nomenclature of the 2016 revision to the WHO classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia is incorporated for disease entities where relevant.</p>

3003</section>

3004<section id="_sm_CDR0000779362_861">

3005<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000779362_861_toc">

3006Genetic abnormalities associated with a favorable prognosis</h5>

3007<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_862" tabindex="-1">

3008Genetic abnormalities associated with a favorable prognosis include the following:</p>

3009<div class="pdq-content-list">

3010<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_138">

3011<li>

3012Core-binding factor (CBF) AML includes cases with <em class="gene-name">

3013RUNX1</em>

3014::<em class="gene-name">

3015RUNX1T1</em>

3016 and <em class="gene-name">

3017CBFB</em>

3018::<em class="gene-name">

3019MYH11</em>

3020 gene fusions that disrupt the activity of CBF, which contains <em class="gene-name">

3021RUNX1</em>

3022 and <em class="gene-name">

3023CBFB</em>

3024. These are specific entities in the 2016 revision to the WHO classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia.<div class="pdq-content-list">

3025<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_852" class="list-dash">

3026<li>

3027<strong>

3028AML with <em class="gene-name">

3029RUNX1</em>

3030::<em class="gene-name">

3031RUNX1T1</em>

3032 gene fusions (t(8;21)(q22;q22.1)).</strong>

3033 In leukemias with t(8;21), the <em class="gene-name">

3034RUNX1</em>

3035 (<em class="gene-name">

3036AML1</em>

3037) gene on chromosome 21 is fused with the <em class="gene-name">

3038RUNX1T1</em>

3039 (<em class="gene-name">

3040ETO</em>

3041) gene on chromosome 8. The t(8;21) translocation is associated with the FAB M2 subtype and with granulocytic sarcomas. Adults with t(8;21) have a more favorable prognosis than do adults with other types of AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

304247</a>

3043] Children with t(8;21) have a more favorable outcome than do children with AML characterized by normal or complex karyotypes,[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

304447</a>

3045,<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

304657</a>

3047-<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

304859</a>

3049] with 5-year overall survival (OS) rates of 74% to 90%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

305048</a>

3051,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

305249</a>

3053,<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

305460</a>

3055] The t(8;21) translocation occurs in approximately 12% of children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

305648</a>

3057,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

305849</a>

3059,<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

306060</a>

3061]</li>

3062<li>

3063<strong>

3064AML with <em class="gene-name">

3065CBFB</em>

3066::<em class="gene-name">

3067MYH11</em>

3068 gene fusions (inv(16)(p13.1;q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22)).</strong>

3069 In leukemias with inv(16), the <em class="gene-name">

3070CBFB</em>

3071 gene at chromosome band 16q22 is fused with the <em class="gene-name">

3072MYH11</em>

3073 gene at chromosome band 16p13. The inv(16) translocation is associated with the FAB M4Eo subtype. Inv(16) confers a favorable prognosis for both adults and children with AML,[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

307447</a>

3075,<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

307657</a>

3077-<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

307859</a>

3079] with a 5-year OS rate of about 85%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

308048</a>

3081,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

308249</a>

3083] Inv(16) occurs in 7% to 9% of children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

308448</a>

3085,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

308649</a>

3087,<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

308860</a>

3089] As noted above, cases with <em class="gene-name">

3090CBFB</em>

3091::<em class="gene-name">

3092MYH11</em>

3093 fusions and cases with <em class="gene-name">

3094RUNX1</em>

3095::<em class="gene-name">

3096RUNX1T1</em>

3097 fusions have distinctive secondary mutations, with <em class="gene-name">

3098CBFB</em>

3099::<em class="gene-name">

3100MYH11</em>

3101 secondary mutations primarily restricted to genes that activate receptor tyrosine kinase signaling (<em class="gene-name">

3102NRAS</em>

3103, <em class="gene-name">

3104FLT3</em>

3105, and <em class="gene-name">

3106KIT</em>

3107).[<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

310861</a>

3109,<a href="#cit/section_2.62">

311062</a>

3111]</li>

3112<li>

3113<strong>

3114AML with <em class="gene-name">

3115RUNX1</em>

3116::<em class="gene-name">

3117CBFA2T3</em>

3118 gene fusions (t(16;21)(q24;q22)).</strong>

3119 In leukemias with t(16;21)(q24;q22), the <em class="gene-name">

3120RUNX1</em>

3121 gene is fused with the <em class="gene-name">

3122CBFA2T3</em>

3123 gene, and the gene expression profile is closely related to that of AML cases with t(8;21) and <em class="gene-name">

3124RUNX1</em>

3125::<em class="gene-name">

3126RUNX1T1</em>

3127 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.63">

312863</a>

3129] These patients present at a median age of 7 years and are rare, representing approximately 0.1% to 0.3% of pediatric AML cases. Among 23 patients with <em class="gene-name">

3130RUNX1</em>

3131::<em class="gene-name">

3132CBFA2T3</em>

3133 fusions, five presented with secondary AML, including two patients who had a primary diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma. Outcome for the cohort of 23 patients was favorable, with a 4-year EFS rate of 77% and a cumulative incidence of relapse rate of 0%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.63">

313463</a>

3135]</li>

3136</ul>

3137</div>

3138<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_853" tabindex="-1">

3139Both <em class="gene-name">

3140RUNX1</em>

3141::<em class="gene-name">

3142RUNX1T1</em>

3143 and <em class="gene-name">

3144CBFB</em>

3145::<em class="gene-name">

3146MYH11</em>

3147 gene fusion subtypes commonly show mutations in genes that activate receptor tyrosine kinase signaling (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

3148NRAS</em>

3149, <em class="gene-name">

3150FLT3</em>

3151, and <em class="gene-name">

3152KIT</em>

3153); <em class="gene-name">

3154NRAS</em>

3155 and <em class="gene-name">

3156KIT</em>

3157 are the most commonly mutated genes for both subtypes. The prognostic significance of activating <em class="gene-name">

3158KIT</em>

3159 mutations in adults with CBF AML has been studied with conflicting results. A meta-analysis found that <em class="gene-name">

3160KIT</em>

3161 mutations appear to increase the risk of relapse without an impact on OS for adults with AML and <em class="gene-name">

3162RUNX1</em>

3163::<em class="gene-name">

3164RUNX1T1</em>

3165 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.64">

316664</a>

3167] <em class="gene-name">

3168KIT</em>

3169 mutations are often subclonal in children and adults with CBF AML;[<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

317065</a>

3171,<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

317266</a>

3173] and in adults with AML and <em class="gene-name">

3174RUNX1</em>

3175::<em class="gene-name">

3176RUNX1T1</em>

3177 fusions, higher <em class="gene-name">

3178KIT</em>

3179-mutant allele ratio appears to be associated with higher risk of treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

318061</a>

3181,<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

318265</a>

3183] The prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

3184KIT</em>

3185 mutations in pediatric CBF AML remains unclear; some studies have found no impact of <em class="gene-name">

3186KIT</em>

3187 mutations on outcome,[<a href="#cit/section_2.67">

318867</a>

3189-<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

319069</a>

3191] while other studies have reported a higher risk of treatment failure when <em class="gene-name">

3192KIT</em>

3193 mutations are present.[<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

319466</a>

3195,<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

319670</a>

3197-<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

319873</a>

3199]</p>

3200<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_854" tabindex="-1">

3201Although both <em class="gene-name">

3202RUNX1</em>

3203::<em class="gene-name">

3204RUNX1T1</em>

3205 and <em class="gene-name">

3206CBFB</em>

3207::<em class="gene-name">

3208MYH11</em>

3209 fusion genes disrupt the activity of CBF, cases with these genomic alterations have distinctive secondary mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

321061</a>

3211,<a href="#cit/section_2.62">

321262</a>

3213]</p>

3214<div class="pdq-content-list">

3215<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_855">

3216<li>

3217Patients with <em class="gene-name">

3218RUNX1</em>

3219::<em class="gene-name">

3220RUNX1T1</em>

3221 fusions also have frequent mutations in genes regulating chromatin conformation (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

3222ASXL1</em>

3223 and <em class="gene-name">

3224ASXL2</em>

3225) (40% of cases) and genes encoding members of the cohesin complex (20% of cases). Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

3226ASXL1</em>

3227 and <em class="gene-name">

3228ASXL2</em>

3229 and mutations in members of the cohesin complex are rare in cases with leukemia and <em class="gene-name">

3230CBFB</em>

3231::<em class="gene-name">

3232MYH11</em>

3233 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

323461</a>

3235,<a href="#cit/section_2.62">

323662</a>

3237]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1943" tabindex="-1">

3238A study of 204 adults with AML and <em class="gene-name">

3239RUNX1</em>

3240::<em class="gene-name">

3241RUNX1T1</em>

3242 fusions found that <em class="gene-name">

3243ASXL2</em>

3244 mutations (present in 17% of cases) and <em class="gene-name">

3245ASXL1</em>

3246 or <em class="gene-name">

3247ASXL2</em>

3248 mutations (present in 25% of cases) lacked prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_2.74">

324974</a>

3250] Similar results, albeit with smaller numbers, were reported for children with AML and <em class="gene-name">

3251RUNX1</em>

3252::<em class="gene-name">

3253RUNX1T1</em>

3254 fusions and <em class="gene-name">

3255ASXL1</em>

3256 and <em class="gene-name">

3257ASXL2</em>

3258 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.75">

325975</a>

3260]</p>

3261</li>

3262</ul>

3263</div>

3264</li>

3265<li>

3266<strong>

3267Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) with <em class="gene-name">

3268PML</em>

3269::<em class="gene-name">

3270RARA</em>

3271 gene fusions.</strong>

3272 APL represents about 7% of children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

327349</a>

3274,<a href="#cit/section_2.76">

327576</a>

3276] AML with t(15;17) is invariably associated with APL, a distinct subtype of AML that is treated differently than other types of AML because of its marked sensitivity to arsenic trioxide and the differentiating effects of tretinoin. The t(15;17) translocation or other more complex chromosomal rearrangements may lead to the production of a fusion protein involving the retinoid acid receptor alpha and PML. The 2016 revision to the WHO classification does not include the t(15;17) cytogenetic designation to stress the significance of the <em class="gene-name">

3277PML</em>

3278::<em class="gene-name">

3279RARA</em>

3280 fusion, which may be cryptic or result from complex karyotypic changes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

328112</a>

3282] <p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_860" tabindex="-1">

3283Utilization of quantitative reverse transcriptase&#8211;polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for PML::RARA transcripts has become standard practice.[<a href="#cit/section_2.77">

328477</a>

3285] Quantitative RT-PCR allows identification of the three common transcript variants and is used for monitoring response on treatment and early detection of molecular relapse. Other much less common translocations involving the retinoic acid receptor alpha can also result in APL (e.g., t(11;17)(q23;q21) involving the <em class="gene-name">

3286PLZF</em>

3287 gene).[<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

328878</a>

3289,<a href="#cit/section_2.79">

329079</a>

3291] Identification of cases with the t(11;17)(q23;q21) is important because of their decreased sensitivity to tretinoin.[<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

329278</a>

3293]</p>

3294</li>

3295<li>

3296<strong>

3297AML with mutated <em class="gene-name">

3298NPM1</em>

3299. </strong>

3300NPM1 is a protein that has been linked to ribosomal protein assembly and transport as well as being a molecular chaperone involved in preventing protein aggregation in the nucleolus. Immunohistochemical methods can be used to accurately identify patients with <em class="gene-name">

3301NPM1</em>

3302 mutations by the demonstration of cytoplasmic localization of <em class="gene-name">

3303NPM</em>

3304. Mutations in the NPM1 protein that diminish its nuclear localization are primarily associated with a subset of AML with a normal karyotype, absence of CD34 expression, and an improved prognosis in the absence of <em class="gene-name">

3305FLT3</em>

3306 ITD mutations in adults and younger adults.[<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

330780</a>

3308-<a href="#cit/section_2.85">

330985</a>

3310]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_544" tabindex="-1">

3311Studies of children with AML suggest a lower rate of occurrence of <em class="gene-name">

3312NPM1</em>

3313 mutations in children compared with adults with normal cytogenetics. <em class="gene-name">

3314NPM1</em>

3315 mutations occur in approximately 8% of pediatric patients with AML and are uncommon in children younger than 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

331651</a>

3317,<a href="#cit/section_2.52">

331852</a>

3319,<a href="#cit/section_2.86">

332086</a>

3321,<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

332287</a>

3323] <em class="gene-name">

3324NPM1</em>

3325 mutations are associated with a favorable prognosis in patients with AML characterized by a normal karyotype.[<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

332651</a>

3327,<a href="#cit/section_2.52">

332852</a>

3329,<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

333087</a>

3331] For the pediatric population, conflicting reports have been published regarding the prognostic significance of an <em class="gene-name">

3332NPM1</em>

3333 mutation when a <em class="gene-name">

3334FLT3</em>

3335 ITD mutation is also present. One study reported that an <em class="gene-name">

3336NPM1</em>

3337 mutation did not completely abrogate the poor prognosis associated with having a <em class="gene-name">

3338FLT3</em>

3339 ITD mutation,[<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

334051</a>

3341,<a href="#cit/section_2.88">

334288</a>

3343] but other studies showed no impact of a <em class="gene-name">

3344FLT3</em>

3345 ITD mutation on the favorable prognosis associated with an <em class="gene-name">

3346NPM1</em>

3347 mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

334845</a>

3349,<a href="#cit/section_2.52">

335052</a>

3351,<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

335287</a>

3353]</p>

3354</li>

3355<li>

3356<strong>

3357AML with biallelic mutations of <em class="gene-name">

3358CEBPA</em>

3359.</strong>

3360 Mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

3361CEBPA</em>

3362 gene occur in a subset of children and adults with cytogenetically normal AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

336389</a>

3364,<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

336590</a>

3366] In adults younger than 60 years, approximately 15% of cytogenetically normal AML cases have mutations in <em class="gene-name">

3367CEBPA</em>

3368.[<a href="#cit/section_2.84">

336984</a>

3370] Outcomes for adults with AML with <em class="gene-name">

3371CEBPA</em>

3372 mutations appear to be relatively favorable and similar to that of patients with CBF leukemias.[<a href="#cit/section_2.84">

337384</a>

3374,<a href="#cit/section_2.91">

337591</a>

3376] Studies in adults with AML have demonstrated that <em class="gene-name">

3377CEBPA</em>

3378 double-mutant, but not single-mutant, AML is independently associated with a favorable prognosis,[<a href="#cit/section_2.92">

337992</a>

3380-<a href="#cit/section_2.95">

338195</a>

3382] leading to the WHO 2016 revision that requires biallelic mutations for the disease definition.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

338312</a>

3384] However, a study of over 4,700 adults with AML found that patients with single <em class="gene-name">

3385CEBPA</em>

3386 mutations in the bZip C-terminal domain have clinical characteristics and favorable outcomes that are similar to those of patients with double-mutant AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.96">

338796</a>

3388]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_545" tabindex="-1">

3389<em class="gene-name">

3390CEBPA</em>

3391 mutations occur in approximately 5% of children with AML and have been preferentially found in the cytogenetically normal subtype of AML with FAB M1 or M2.</p>

3392<div class="pdq-content-list">

3393<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1946">

3394<li>

3395Patients with double <em class="gene-name">

3396CEBPA</em>

3397 mutations or with single <em class="gene-name">

3398CEBPA</em>

3399 bZip mutations have a median age of presentation of 12 to 13 years and have gene expression profiles that are highly related to each other.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

340090</a>

3401]</li>

3402<li>

3403Approximately 80% of pediatric patients have double-mutant alleles (i.e., cases with both a <em class="gene-name">

3404CEBPA</em>

3405 TAD domain and a <em class="gene-name">

3406CEBPA</em>

3407 bZip domain mutation), which is predictive of significantly improved survival, similar to the effect observed in adult studies.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

340890</a>

3409,<a href="#cit/section_2.97">

341097</a>

3411]</li>

3412<li>

3413In a study of nearly 3,000 children with AML, both patients with <em class="gene-name">

3414CEBPA</em>

3415 double mutations and those with only a bZip domain mutation were observed to have a favorable prognosis, compared with patients with wild-type <em class="gene-name">

3416CEBPA</em>

3417.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

341890</a>

3419]</li>

3420<li>

3421<em class="gene-name">

3422CSF3R</em>

3423 mutations occur in 10% to 15% of patients with <em class="gene-name">

3424CEBPA</em>

3425-mutated AML. When <em class="gene-name">

3426CSF3R</em>

3427 mutations are present, they appear to be associated with an increased risk of relapse, but without an impact on overall survival.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

342890</a>

3429,<a href="#cit/section_2.98">

343098</a>

3431]</li>

3432<li>

3433In newly diagnosed patients with double-mutant <em class="gene-name">

3434CEBPA</em>

3435 AML, germline screening should be considered in addition to usual family history queries, because 5% to 10% of these patients are reported to have a germline <em class="gene-name">

3436CEBPA</em>

3437 mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

343889</a>

3439]</li>

3440</ul>

3441</div>

3442</li>

3443<li>

3444<strong>

3445Myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome (<em class="gene-name">

3446GATA1</em>

3447 mutations).</strong>

3448 <em class="gene-name">

3449GATA1</em>

3450 mutations are present in most, if not all, Down syndrome children with either transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM) or acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AMKL).[<a href="#cit/section_2.99">

345199</a>

3452-<a href="#cit/section_2.102">

3453102</a>

3454] <em class="gene-name">

3455GATA1</em>

3456 mutations were also observed in 9% of non&#8211;Down syndrome children and 4% of adults with AMKL (with coexistence of amplification of the <em class="gene-name">

3457RCAN1</em>

3458 [<em class="gene-name">

3459DSCR1</em>

3460] gene on chromosome 21 in 9 of 10 cases).[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

3461103</a>

3462] <em class="gene-name">

3463GATA1</em>

3464 is a transcription factor that is required for normal development of erythroid cells, megakaryocytes, eosinophils, and mast cells.<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_870" tabindex="-1">

3465<em class="gene-name">

3466GATA1</em>

3467 mutations confer increased sensitivity to cytarabine by down-regulating cytidine deaminase expression, possibly providing an explanation for the superior outcome of children with Down syndrome and M7 AML when treated with cytarabine-containing regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_2.104">

3468104</a>

3469]</p>

3470</li>

3471</ul>

3472</div>

3473</section>

3474<section id="_sm_CDR0000779362_863">

3475<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000779362_863_toc">

3476Genetic abnormalities associated with an unfavorable prognosis</h5>

3477<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_864" tabindex="-1">

3478Genetic abnormalities associated with an unfavorable prognosis include the following:</p>

3479<div class="pdq-content-list">

3480<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_546">

3481<li>

3482<strong>

3483Chromosomes 5 and 7.</strong>

3484 Chromosomal abnormalities associated with poor prognosis in adults with AML include those involving chromosome 5 (del(5q)) and chromosome 7 (monosomy 7).[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

348547</a>

3486,<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

3487105</a>

3488,<a href="#cit/section_2.106">

3489106</a>

3490] These cytogenetic subgroups represent approximately 2% and 4% of pediatric AML cases, respectively, and are also associated with poor prognosis in children.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

349148</a>

3492,<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

3493105</a>

3494-<a href="#cit/section_2.109">

3495109</a>

3496] <p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_707" tabindex="-1">

3497In the past, patients with del(7q) were also considered to be at high risk of treatment failure, and data from adults with AML support a poor prognosis for both del(7q) and monosomy 7.[<a href="#cit/section_2.50">

349850</a>

3499] However, outcome for children with del(7q), but not monosomy 7, appears comparable to that of other children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

350049</a>

3501,<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

3502108</a>

3503] The presence of del(7q) does not abrogate the prognostic significance of favorable cytogenetic characteristics (e.g., inv(16) and t(8;21)).[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

350447</a>

3505,<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

3506108</a>

3507]</p>

3508<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_708" tabindex="-1">

3509Chromosome 5 and 7 abnormalities appear to lack prognostic significance in AML patients with Down syndrome who are aged 4 years and younger.[<a href="#cit/section_2.110">

3510110</a>

3511]</p>

3512</li>

3513<li>

3514<strong>

3515Hypodiploidy.</strong>

3516 Hypodiploidy is defined as a modal chromosome number of less than or equal to 45. This occurs rarely in pediatric patients with AML. In a retrospective cohort analysis, the International Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster AML Study Group aimed to characterize hypodiploidy in pediatric patients with AML.
