The study excluded several patient groups, including patients with APL, Down syndrome, or loss of chromosome 7.[<a href="#cit/section_2.111">

3517111</a>

3518] Their observations included the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

3519<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1954">

3520<li>

3521Hypodiploidy was observed in 1.3% of children with AML. Approximately 80% of patients had a modal chromosome number of 45, and the remaining 20% of patients had a modal chromosome number of either 43 or 44.</li>

3522<li>

3523Most patients (&gt;80%) with a modal chromosome number of 43 or 44 also met the criteria for complex karyotype. In this study, a complex karyotype was defined as at least three independent chromosomal abnormalities, regardless of whether these were structural abnormalities or defects in chromosome number, and an absence of recurrent aberrations as defined by the WHO.</li>

3524<li>

3525Patients with a modal chromosome number of 43 or 44 had decreased EFS rates and OS rates when compared with patients who had 45 chromosomes (EFS rate, 21% vs. 37%; <em>

3526P</em>

3527 = .07; OS rate, 33% vs. 56%; <em>

3528P</em>

3529 = .1).</li>

3530</ul>

3531</div>

3532</li>

3533<li>

3534<strong>

3535AML with <em class="gene-name">

3536GATA2</em>

3537 or <em class="gene-name">

3538MECOM</em>

3539 (inv(3)(q21.3;q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2)). </strong>

3540<em class="gene-name">

3541MECOM</em>

3542 at chromosome 3q26 codes for two proteins, EVI1 and MDS1::EVI1, both of which are transcription regulators. The inv(3) and t(3;3) abnormalities lead to overexpression of EVI1 and to reduced expression of GATA2.[<a href="#cit/section_2.112">

3543112</a>

3544,<a href="#cit/section_2.113">

3545113</a>

3546] These abnormalities are associated with poor prognosis in adults with AML,[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

354747</a>

3548,<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

3549105</a>

3550,<a href="#cit/section_2.114">

3551114</a>

3552] but are very uncommon in children (&lt;1% of pediatric AML cases).[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

355348</a>

3554,<a href="#cit/section_2.58">

355558</a>

3556,<a href="#cit/section_2.115">

3557115</a>

3558]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_871" tabindex="-1">

3559Abnormalities involving <em class="gene-name">

3560MECOM</em>

3561 can be detected in some AML cases with other 3q abnormalities and are also associated with poor prognosis.</p>

3562</li>

3563<li>

3564<strong>

3565<em class="gene-name">

3566FLT3</em>

3567 mutations.</strong>

3568 Presence of a <em class="gene-name">

3569FLT3</em>

3570 ITD mutation appears to be associated with poor prognosis in adults with AML,[<a href="#cit/section_2.116">

3571116</a>

3572] particularly when both alleles are mutated or there is a high ratio of the mutant allele to the normal allele.[<a href="#cit/section_2.117">

3573117</a>

3574] <em class="gene-name">

3575FLT3</em>

3576 ITD mutations also convey a poor prognosis in children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.54">

357754</a>

3578,<a href="#cit/section_2.88">

357988</a>

3580,<a href="#cit/section_2.118">

3581118</a>

3582-<a href="#cit/section_2.120">

3583120</a>

3584] The frequency of <em class="gene-name">

3585FLT3</em>

3586 ITD mutations in children is lower than that observed in adults, especially for children younger than 10 years, for whom 5% to 10% of cases have the mutation (compared with approximately 30% in adults).[<a href="#cit/section_2.119">

3587119</a>

3588,<a href="#cit/section_2.120">

3589120</a>

3590] <p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_881" tabindex="-1">

3591The prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

3592FLT3</em>

3593 ITD is modified by the presence of other recurring genomic alterations. The prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

3594FLT3</em>

3595 ITD is increased in certain genomic subtypes of pediatric AML, including those with the <em class="gene-name">

3596NUP98</em>

3597::<em class="gene-name">

3598NSD1</em>

3599 fusion gene, of which 80% to 90% have <em class="gene-name">

3600FLT3</em>

3601 ITD.[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

3602121</a>

3603,<a href="#cit/section_2.122">

3604122</a>

3605] Approximately 15% of patients with <em class="gene-name">

3606FLT3</em>

3607 ITD have <em class="gene-name">

3608NUP98</em>

3609::<em class="gene-name">

3610NSD1</em>

3611 fusions, and patients with both <em class="gene-name">

3612FLT3</em>

3613 ITD and <em class="gene-name">

3614NUP98</em>

3615::<em class="gene-name">

3616NSD1</em>

3617 fusions have a poorer prognosis than do patients who have <em class="gene-name">

3618FLT3</em>

3619 ITD without <em class="gene-name">

3620NUP98</em>

3621::<em class="gene-name">

3622NSD1</em>

3623 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.122">

3624122</a>

3625] For patients who have <em class="gene-name">

3626FLT3</em>

3627 ITD, the presence of either <em class="gene-name">

3628WT1</em>

3629 mutations or <em class="gene-name">

3630NUP98</em>

3631::<em class="gene-name">

3632NSD1</em>

3633 fusions is associated with poorer outcome (EFS rates below 25%) than for patients who have <em class="gene-name">

3634FLT3</em>

3635 ITD without these alterations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

363645</a>

3637] Conversely, when <em class="gene-name">

3638FLT3</em>

3639 ITD is accompanied by <em class="gene-name">

3640NPM1</em>

3641 mutations, the outcome is relatively favorable and is similar to that of pediatric AML cases without <em class="gene-name">

3642FLT3</em>

3643 ITD.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

364445</a>

3645]</p>

3646<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_547" tabindex="-1">

3647For APL, <em class="gene-name">

3648FLT3</em>

3649 ITD and point mutations occur in 30% to 40% of children and adults.[<a href="#cit/section_2.117">

3650117</a>

3651,<a href="#cit/section_2.119">

3652119</a>

3653,<a href="#cit/section_2.123">

3654123</a>

3655,<a href="#cit/section_2.124">

3656124</a>

3657] Presence of the <em class="gene-name">

3658FLT3</em>

3659 ITD mutation is strongly associated with the microgranular variant (M3v) of APL and with hyperleukocytosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.123">

3660123</a>

3661,<a href="#cit/section_2.125">

3662125</a>

3663-<a href="#cit/section_2.127">

3664127</a>

3665] It remains unclear whether <em class="gene-name">

3666FLT3</em>

3667 mutations are associated with poorer prognosis in patients with APL who are treated with modern

3668therapy that includes tretinoin and arsenic trioxide.[<a href="#cit/section_2.124">

3669124</a>

3670,<a href="#cit/section_2.126">

3671126</a>

3672,<a href="#cit/section_2.128">

3673128</a>

3674-<a href="#cit/section_2.131">

3675131</a>

3676]</p>

3677<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_548" tabindex="-1">

3678Activating point mutations of <em class="gene-name">

3679FLT3</em>

3680 have also been identified in both adults and children with AML, although the clinical significance of these mutations is not clearly defined. Some of these point mutations appear to be specific to pediatric patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

368145</a>

3682]</p>

3683</li>

3684<li>

3685<strong>

3686AML with t(16;21)(p11;q22); <em class="gene-name">

3687FUS</em>

3688::<em class="gene-name">

3689ERG</em>

3690 gene fusions. </strong>

3691In leukemias with t(16;21)(p11;q22), the <em class="gene-name">

3692FUS</em>

3693 gene is joined with the <em class="gene-name">

3694ERG</em>

3695 gene, producing a distinctive AML subtype with a gene expression profile that clusters separately from other cytogenetic subgroups.[<a href="#cit/section_2.63">

369663</a>

3697] These patients present at a median age of 8 to 9 years and are rare, representing approximately 0.3% to 0.5% of pediatric AML cases. For a cohort of 31 patients with AML and <em class="gene-name">

3698FUS</em>

3699::<em class="gene-name">

3700ERG</em>

3701 fusions, outcome was poor, with a 4-year EFS rate of 7% and a cumulative incidence of relapse rate of 74%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.63">

370263</a>

3703]</li>

3704</ul>

3705</div>

3706</section>

3707<section id="_sm_CDR0000779362_865">

3708<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000779362_865_toc">

3709Other genetic abnormalities observed in pediatric AML</h5>

3710<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_866" tabindex="-1">

3711Other genetic abnormalities observed in pediatric AML include the following:</p>

3712<div class="pdq-content-list">

3713<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_549">

3714<li>

3715<strong>

3716<em class="gene-name">

3717KMT2A</em>

3718 (<em class="gene-name">

3719MLL</em>

3720) gene rearrangements.</strong>

3721 <em class="gene-name">

3722KMT2A</em>

3723 gene rearrangement occurs in approximately 20% of children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

372448</a>

3725,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

372649</a>

3727] These cases, including most AMLs secondary to epipodophyllotoxin exposure,[<a href="#cit/section_2.132">

3728132</a>

3729] are generally associated with monocytic differentiation (FAB M4 and M5). <em class="gene-name">

3730KMT2A</em>

3731 rearrangements are also reported in approximately 10% of FAB M7 (AMKL) patients (see below).[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

3732103</a>

3733,<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3734133</a>

3735] <p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_856" tabindex="-1">

3736The most common translocation,

3737representing approximately 50% of <em class="gene-name">

3738KMT2A</em>

3739-rearranged cases in the pediatric AML population, is t(9;11)(p22;q23), in which the <em class="gene-name">

3740KMT2A</em>

3741 gene is fused with the <em class="gene-name">

3742MLLT3</em>

3743 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3744134</a>

3745] The 2016 revision to the WHO classification defined <strong>

3746AML with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3); <em class="gene-name">

3747MLLT3</em>

3748::<em class="gene-name">

3749KMT2A</em>

3750 gene fusions</strong>

3751 as a distinctive disease entity. However, more than 50 different fusion partners have been identified for the <em class="gene-name">

3752KMT2A</em>

3753 gene in patients with AML.</p>

3754<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_872" tabindex="-1">

3755The median age for 11q23/<em class="gene-name">

3756KMT2A</em>

3757-rearranged cases in children is approximately 2 years, and most translocation subgroups have a median age at presentation of younger than 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3758134</a>

3759] However, significantly older median ages are seen at presentation of pediatric cases with t(6;11)(q27;q23) (12 years) and t(11;17)(q23;q21) (9 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3760134</a>

3761]</p>

3762<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_550" tabindex="-1">

3763Outcome for patients with de novo AML and <em class="gene-name">

3764KMT2A</em>

3765 gene rearrangements is generally reported as being similar to or slightly worse than the outcome observed in other patients with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

376647</a>

3767,<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

376848</a>

3769,<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3770134</a>

3771-<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3772136</a>

3773] As the <em class="gene-name">

3774KMT2A</em>

3775 gene can participate in translocations with many different fusion partners, the specific fusion partner appears to influence prognosis, as demonstrated by a large international retrospective study evaluating outcome for 756 children with 11q23- or <em class="gene-name">

3776KMT2A</em>

3777-rearranged AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3778134</a>

3779,<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3780136</a>

3781] This was also seen in patients in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

3782AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

3783 trial (n = 215), which resulted in a wide range of outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3784136</a>

3785] This overall less-favorable outcome was abrogated in one arm of the AAML0531 trial, in patients whose treatment included gemtuzumab ozogamicin. The EFS rate for patients with <em class="gene-name">

3786KMT2A</em>

3787-rearranged AML was superior with gemtuzumab ozogamicin treatment (EFS rate, 48% with gemtuzumab ozogamicin vs. 29% without; <em>

3788P</em>

3789 = .003). Outcomes for patients with <em class="gene-name">

3790KMT2A</em>

3791-rearranged AML who received gemtuzumab ozogamicin are similar to the outcomes observed in patients without <em class="gene-name">

3792KMT2A</em>

3793-rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3794136</a>

3795]</p>

3796<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_857" tabindex="-1">

3797For patients with the most prevalent <em class="gene-name">

3798KMT2A</em>

3799-rearranged subtype of AML, t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3)/<em class="gene-name">

3800MLLT3</em>

3801::<em class="gene-name">

3802KMT2A</em>

3803 fusions, single clinical trial groups have variably described a more favorable prognosis; however, neither the international retrospective study nor the COG study confirmed the favorable prognosis for this subgroup.[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

380447</a>

3805,<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

380648</a>

3807,<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3808134</a>

3809,<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3810136</a>

3811] Furthermore, an international collaboration evaluating pediatric AMKL patients observed that the presence of t(9;11), which was seen in approximately 5% of AMKL cases, was associated with an inferior outcome compared with other AMKL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3812133</a>

3813]</p>

3814<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_551" tabindex="-1">

3815<em class="gene-name">

3816KMT2A</em>

3817-rearranged AML subgroups that are associated with poor outcome include the following:</p>

3818<div class="pdq-content-list">

3819<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_873">

3820<li>

3821Cases with the t(10;11) translocation are a group at high risk of relapse in bone marrow and the CNS.[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

382247</a>

3823,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

382449</a>

3825] Some cases with the t(10;11) translocation have fusion of the <em class="gene-name">

3826KMT2A</em>

3827 gene with the <em class="gene-name">

3828MLLT10</em>

3829 at 10p12, while others have fusion of <em class="gene-name">

3830KMT2A</em>

3831 with <em class="gene-name">

3832ABI1</em>

3833 at 10p11.2. An international retrospective study found that these cases, which present at a median age of approximately 1 to 3 years, have a 5-year EFS rate of 17% to 30%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3834134</a>

3835,<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3836136</a>

3837]</li>

3838<li>

3839Patients with t(6;11)(q27;q23) have a poor outcome, with a 5-year EFS rate of 11% to 15%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3840136</a>

3841]</li>

3842<li>

3843Patients with t(4;11)(q21;q23) often present with hyperleukocytosis and also have a poor outcome, with a 5-year EFS rate of 0% to 29%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3844134</a>

3845,<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3846136</a>

3847]</li>

3848<li>

3849Patients with t(11;19)(q23;p13.3) have a poor outcome, with a 5-year EFS rate of 14%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3850136</a>

3851]</li>

3852<li>

3853A follow-up study by the international collaborative group demonstrated that additional cytogenetic abnormalities further influenced outcome of children with <em class="gene-name">

3854KMT2A</em>

3855 translocations, with complex karyotypes and trisomy 19 predicting poor outcome and trisomy 8 predicting a more favorable outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.137">

3856137</a>

3857]</li>

3858<li>

3859The addition of gemtuzumab ozogamicin therapy improved the poor outcome of these patients with <em class="gene-name">

3860KMT2A</em>

3861-rearranged high-risk translocation partners (27% [95% confidence interval (CI), 14%&#8211;41%] vs. 6% [95% CI, 1%&#8211;18%]; <em>

3862P</em>

3863 = .013).[<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3864136</a>

3865]</li>

3866</ul>

3867</div>

3868</li>

3869<li>

3870<strong>

3871AML with <em class="gene-name">

3872DEK</em>

3873::<em class="gene-name">

3874NUP214</em>

3875 (t(6;9)(p23;q34.1)) gene fusions.</strong>

3876 t(6;9) leads to the formation of a leukemia-associated fusion protein DEK::NUP214.[<a href="#cit/section_2.138">

3877138</a>

3878,<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

3879139</a>

3880] This subgroup of AML has been associated with a poor prognosis in adults with AML,[<a href="#cit/section_2.138">

3881138</a>

3882,<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

3883140</a>

3884,<a href="#cit/section_2.141">

3885141</a>

3886] and occurs infrequently in children (less than 1% of AML

3887cases). The median age of children with AML and <em class="gene-name">

3888DEK</em>

3889::<em class="gene-name">

3890NUP214</em>

3891 fusions is 10 to 11 years, and approximately 40% of pediatric patients have <em class="gene-name">

3892FLT3</em>

3893 ITD.[<a href="#cit/section_2.142">

3894142</a>

3895,<a href="#cit/section_2.143">

3896143</a>

3897]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_874" tabindex="-1">

3898t(6;9) AML appears to be associated with a high risk of treatment failure in children, particularly for those not proceeding to allogeneic stem cell transplantation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

389948</a>

3900,<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

3901139</a>

3902,<a href="#cit/section_2.142">

3903142</a>

3904,<a href="#cit/section_2.143">

3905143</a>

3906]</p>

3907</li>

3908<li>

3909<strong>

3910Molecular subgroups of non&#8211;Down syndrome acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AMKL).</strong>

3911 AMKL accounts for approximately 10% of pediatric AML and includes substantial heterogeneity at the molecular level. Molecular subtypes of AMKL are listed below.<div class="pdq-content-list">

3912<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_858" class="list-dash">

3913<li>

3914<strong>

3915<em class="gene-name">

3916CBFA2T3</em>

3917::<em class="gene-name">

3918GLIS2</em>

3919 gene fusions.</strong>

3920 <em class="gene-name">

3921CBFA2T3</em>

3922::<em class="gene-name">

3923GLIS2</em>

3924 is a fusion resulting from a cryptic chromosome 16 inversion (inv(16)(p13.3;q24.3)).[<a href="#cit/section_2.144">

3925144</a>

3926-<a href="#cit/section_2.148">

3927148</a>

3928] It occurs commonly in non&#8211;Down syndrome AMKL, representing 16% to 27% of pediatric AMKL and presenting with a median age of 1 year.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

3929103</a>

3930,<a href="#cit/section_2.146">

3931146</a>

3932,<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

3933149</a>

3934,<a href="#cit/section_2.150">

3935150</a>

3936] It appears to be associated with unfavorable outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

3937103</a>

3938,<a href="#cit/section_2.144">

3939144</a>

3940,<a href="#cit/section_2.148">

3941148</a>

3942-<a href="#cit/section_2.150">

3943150</a>

3944]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1938" tabindex="-1">

3945In a study of approximately 2,000 children with AML, the <em class="gene-name">

3946CBFA2T3</em>

3947::<em class="gene-name">

3948GLIS2</em>

3949 fusion was identified in 39 cases (1.9%), with a median age at presentation of 1.5 years, and with all cases observed in children younger than 3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.151">

3950151</a>

3951] Approximately one-half of cases had M7 megakaryoblastic morphology, and 29% of patients were Black or African American (exceeding the 12.8% frequency in patients lacking the fusion). The <em class="gene-name">

3952CBFA2T3</em>

3953::<em class="gene-name">

3954GLIS2</em>

3955 fusion was an independent prognostic factor for both OS and EFS. The OS rate at 5 years was 22% for patients with <em class="gene-name">

3956CBFA2T3</em>

3957::<em class="gene-name">

3958GLIS2</em>

3959 fusions versus 63% for fusion-negative patients. Leukemia cells with <em class="gene-name">

3960CBFA2T3</em>

3961::<em class="gene-name">

3962GLIS2</em>

3963 fusions have a distinctive immunophenotype (initially reported as the RAM phenotype),[<a href="#cit/section_2.152">

3964152</a>

3965,<a href="#cit/section_2.153">

3966153</a>

3967] with high CD56, dim or negative expression of CD45 and CD38, and a lack of HLA-DR expression.</p>

3968</li>

3969<li>

3970<strong>

3971<em class="gene-name">

3972KMT2A</em>

3973 rearrangements.</strong>

3974 Cases with <em class="gene-name">

3975KMT2A</em>

3976 translocations represent 10% to 17% of pediatric AMKL, with <em class="gene-name">

3977MLLT3</em>

3978 being the most common <em class="gene-name">

3979KMT2A</em>

3980 fusion partner.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

3981103</a>

3982,<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3983133</a>

3984,<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

3985149</a>

3986] Patients with <em class="gene-name">

3987KMT2A</em>

3988 rearrangements appear to have an inferior outcome among children with AMKL, with OS rates at 4 to 5 years of approximately 30%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

3989103</a>

3990,<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3991133</a>

3992,<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

3993149</a>

3994] An international collaboration evaluating pediatric AMKL observed that the presence of t(9;11)/<em class="gene-name">

3995MLLT3</em>

3996::<em class="gene-name">

3997KMT2A</em>

3998 fusions, which was seen in approximately 5% of AMKL cases (n = 21), was associated with an inferior outcome (5-year OS rate, approximately 20%) compared with other AMKL cases and other <em class="gene-name">

3999KMT2A</em>

4000 rearrangements (n = 17), each with a 5-year OS rate of 50% to 55%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

4001133</a>

4002] Inferior outcome was not observed for patients (n = 17) with other <em class="gene-name">

4003KMT2A</em>

4004 rearrangements.</li>

4005<li>

4006<strong>

4007<em class="gene-name">

4008NUP98</em>

4009::<em class="gene-name">

4010KDM5A</em>

4011 gene fusions.</strong>

4012 <em class="gene-name">

4013NUP98</em>

4014::<em class="gene-name">

4015KDM5A</em>

4016 fusions are observed in approximately 10% of pediatric AMKL cases [<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

4017103</a>

4018,<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

4019149</a>

4020] and is seen at lower rates in non-AMKL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.150">

4021150</a>

4022] However, approximately two-thirds of children with <em class="gene-name">

4023NUP98</em>

4024::<em class="gene-name">

4025KDM5A</em>

4026 fusions have a non-AMKL FAB subtype (see below).[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

4027154</a>

4028] Patients with <em class="gene-name">

4029NUP98</em>

4030::<em class="gene-name">

4031KDM5A</em>

4032 fusions showed a trend towards inferior prognosis, although the small number of cases studied limits confidence in this assessment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

4033103</a>

4034,<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

4035149</a>

4036]</li>

4037<li>

4038<strong>

4039<em class="gene-name">

4040RBM15</em>

4041::<em class="gene-name">

4042MKL1</em>

4043 gene fusions.</strong>

4044 The t(1;22)(p13;q13) translocation that produces <em class="gene-name">

4045RBM15</em>

4046::<em class="gene-name">

4047MKL1</em>

4048 fusions is uncommon (&lt;1% of pediatric AML) and is restricted to acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AMKL).[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

404948</a>

4050,<a href="#cit/section_2.150">

4051150</a>

4052,<a href="#cit/section_2.155">

4053155</a>

4054-<a href="#cit/section_2.158">

4055158</a>

4056] Studies have found that t(1;22)(p13;q13) is observed in 10% to 18% of children with AMKL who have evaluable cytogenetics or molecular genetics.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

4057103</a>

4058,<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

4059133</a>

4060,<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

4061149</a>

4062] Most AMKL cases with t(1;22) occur in infants, with the median age at presentation (4&#8211;7 months) being younger than that for other children with AMKL.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

4063133</a>

4064,<a href="#cit/section_2.146">

4065146</a>

4066,<a href="#cit/section_2.159">

4067159</a>

4068] Cases with detectable <em class="gene-name">

4069RBM15</em>

4070::<em class="gene-name">

4071MKL1</em>

4072 fusion transcripts in the absence of t(1;22) have also been reported because these young patients usually have hypoplastic bone marrow.[<a href="#cit/section_2.156">

4073156</a>

4074] <p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_837" tabindex="-1">

4075An international collaborative retrospective study of 51 t(1;22) cases reported that patients with this abnormality had a 5-year EFS rate of 54.5% and an OS rate of 58.2%, similar to the rates for other children with AMKL.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

4076133</a>

4077] In another international retrospective analysis of 153 cases with non&#8211;Down syndrome AMKL who had samples available for molecular analysis, the 4-year EFS rate for patients with t(1;22) was 59% and the OS rate was 70%, significantly better than AMKL patients with other specific genetic abnormalities (<em class="gene-name">

4078CBFA2T3</em>

4079::<em class="gene-name">

4080GUS2</em>

4081 fusions, <em class="gene-name">

4082NUP98</em>

4083::<em class="gene-name">

4084KDM5A</em>

4085 fusions, <em class="gene-name">

4086KMT2A</em>

4087 rearrangements, monosomy 7).[<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

4088149</a>

4089]</p>

4090</li>

4091<li>

4092<strong>

4093HOX rearrangements.</strong>

4094 Cases with a gene fusion involving a HOX cluster gene represented 15% of pediatric AMKL in one report.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

4095103</a>

4096] This report observed that these patients appear to have a relatively favorable prognosis, although the small number of cases studied limits confidence in this assessment.</li>

4097<li>

4098<strong>

4099<em class="gene-name">

4100GATA1</em>

4101 mutations.</strong>

4102 <em class="gene-name">

4103GATA1</em>

4104-truncating mutations in non&#8211;Down syndrome AMKL arise in young children (median age, 1&#8211;2 years) and are associated with amplification of the <em class="gene-name">

4105RCAN1</em>

4106 (<em class="gene-name">

4107DSCR1</em>

4108) gene on chromosome 21.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

4109103</a>

4110] These patients represented approximately 10% of non&#8211;Down syndrome AMKL and appeared to have a favorable outcome if there were no prognostically unfavorable fusion genes also present, although the number of patients studied was small (n = 8).[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

4111103</a>

4112]</li>

4113</ul>

4114</div>

4115</li>

4116<li>

4117<strong>

4118<em class="gene-name">

4119MYST3</em>

4120::<em class="gene-name">

4121CREBBP</em>

4122 (t(8;16)).</strong>

4123 The t(8;16) translocation fuses the <em class="gene-name">

4124MYST3</em>

4125 gene on chromosome 8p11 to <em class="gene-name">

4126CREBBP</em>

4127 on chromosome 16p13. t(8;16) AML rarely occurs in children. In an International Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (iBFM) AML study of 62 children, presence of this translocation was associated with younger age at diagnosis (median, 1.2 years), FAB M4/M5 phenotype, erythrophagocytosis, leukemia cutis, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.160">

4128160</a>

4129] Outcome for children with t(8;16) AML appears similar to other types of AML.<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_875" tabindex="-1">

4130A substantial proportion of infants diagnosed with t(8;16) AML in the first month of life show spontaneous remission, although AML recurrence may occur months to years later.[<a href="#cit/section_2.160">

4131160</a>

4132-<a href="#cit/section_2.163">

4133163</a>

4134] These observations suggest that a watch and wait policy could be considered in cases of t(8;16) AML diagnosed in the neonatal period if close long-term monitoring can be ensured.[<a href="#cit/section_2.160">

4135160</a>

4136]</p>

4137</li>

4138<li>

4139<strong>

4140t(7;12)(q36;p13).</strong>

4141 The t(7;12)(q36;p13) translocation involves <em class="gene-name">

4142ETV6</em>

4143 on chromosome 12p13 and variable breakpoints on chromosome 7q36 in the region of <em class="gene-name">

4144MNX1</em>

4145. The translocation may be cryptic by conventional karyotyping and in some cases may be confirmed only by FISH.[<a href="#cit/section_2.164">

4146164</a>

4147,<a href="#cit/section_2.165">

4148165</a>

4149] This alteration occurs virtually exclusively in children younger than 2 years, is mutually exclusive with the <em class="gene-name">

4150KMT2A</em>

4151 rearrangement, and is associated with a high risk of treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

415248</a>

4153,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

415449</a>

4155,<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

415687</a>

4157,<a href="#cit/section_2.164">

4158164</a>

4159,<a href="#cit/section_2.166">

4160166</a>

4161,<a href="#cit/section_2.167">

4162167</a>

4163]</li>

4164<li>

4165<strong>

4166<em class="gene-name">

4167NUP98</em>

4168 gene fusions.</strong>

4169 <em class="gene-name">

4170NUP98</em>

4171 has been reported to form leukemogenic gene fusions with more than 20 different partners.[<a href="#cit/section_2.168">

4172168</a>

4173] In the pediatric AML setting, the two most common gene fusions are <em class="gene-name">

4174NUP98</em>

4175::<em class="gene-name">

4176NSD1</em>

4177 and <em class="gene-name">

4178NUP98</em>

4179::<em class="gene-name">

4180KDM5A</em>

4181, with the former observed in one report in approximately 15% of cytogenetically normal pediatric AML and the latter observed in approximately 10% of pediatric AMKL (see above).[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

4182103</a>

4183,<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4184121</a>

4185,<a href="#cit/section_2.146">

4186146</a>

4187] AML cases with either <em class="gene-name">

4188NUP98</em>

4189 gene fusion show high expression of <em class="gene-name">

4190HOXA</em>

4191 and <em class="gene-name">

4192HOXB</em>

4193 genes, indicative of a stem cell phenotype.[<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

4194139</a>

4195,<a href="#cit/section_2.146">

4196146</a>

4197]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_859" tabindex="-1">

4198The <em class="gene-name">

4199NUP98</em>

4200::<em class="gene-name">

4201NSD1</em>

4202 gene fusion, which is often cytogenetically cryptic, results from the fusion of <em class="gene-name">

4203NUP98</em>

4204 (chromosome 11p15) with <em class="gene-name">

4205NSD1</em>

4206 (chromosome 5q35).[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4207121</a>

4208,<a href="#cit/section_2.122">

4209122</a>

4210,<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

4211139</a>

4212,<a href="#cit/section_2.169">

4213169</a>

4214] This alteration occurs in approximately 4% to 7% of pediatric AML cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

421512</a>

4216,<a href="#cit/section_2.55">

421755</a>

4218,<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4219121</a>

4220,<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

4221139</a>

4222,<a href="#cit/section_2.170">

4223170</a>

4224]</p>

4225<div class="pdq-content-list">

4226<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1939">

4227<li>

4228 The highest frequency of <em class="gene-name">

4229NUP98</em>

4230::<em class="gene-name">

4231NSD1</em>

4232 fusions in the pediatric population is observed in children aged 5 to 9 years (approximately 8%), with a lower frequency in younger children (approximately 2% in children younger than 2 years).</li>

4233<li>

4234Patients with <em class="gene-name">

4235NUP98</em>

4236::<em class="gene-name">

4237NSD1</em>

4238 fusions present with a high white blood cell (WBC) count (median, 147 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

42399</span>

4240/L in one study).[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4241121</a>

4242,<a href="#cit/section_2.122">

4243122</a>

4244] Most patients with AML and <em class="gene-name">

4245NUP98</em>

4246::<em class="gene-name">

4247NSD1</em>

4248 fusions do not show cytogenetic aberrations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4249121</a>

4250,<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

4251139</a>

4252]</li>

4253<li>

4254 A high percentage of patients with <em class="gene-name">

4255NUP98</em>

4256::<em class="gene-name">

4257NSD1</em>

4258 fusions (74%&#8211;90%) have <em class="gene-name">

4259FLT3</em>

4260 ITD.[<a href="#cit/section_2.55">

426155</a>

4262,<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4263121</a>

4264,<a href="#cit/section_2.122">

4265122</a>

4266]</li>

4267<li>

4268A study that included 12 children with AML and <em class="gene-name">

4269NUP98</em>

4270::<em class="gene-name">

4271NSD1</em>

4272 fusions reported that although all patients achieved a complete response (CR), the presence of <em class="gene-name">

4273NUP98</em>

4274::<em class="gene-name">

4275NSD1</em>

4276 fusions independently predicted poor prognosis. Children with AML and <em class="gene-name">

4277NUP98</em>

4278::<em class="gene-name">

4279NSD1</em>

4280 fusions had a high risk of relapse, with a resulting 4-year EFS rate of approximately 10%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4281121</a>

4282] In another study that included children (n = 38) and adults (n = 7) with AML and <em class="gene-name">

4283NUP98</em>

4284::<em class="gene-name">

4285NSD1</em>

4286 fusions, presence of both <em class="gene-name">

4287NUP98</em>

4288::<em class="gene-name">

4289NSD1</em>

4290 fusions and <em class="gene-name">

4291FLT3</em>

4292 ITD independently predicted poor prognosis; patients with both lesions had a low CR rate (approximately 30%) and a low 3-year EFS rate (approximately 15%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.122">

4293122</a>

4294]</li>

4295<li>

4296In a study of children with refractory AML, <em class="gene-name">

4297NUP98</em>

4298 was overrepresented compared with a cohort who did achieve remission (21% [6 of 28 patients] vs. &lt;4%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

4299171</a>

4300]</li>

4301</ul>

4302</div>

4303<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1940" tabindex="-1">

4304The <em class="gene-name">

4305NUP98</em>

4306::<em class="gene-name">

4307KDM5A</em>

4308 gene fusion results from the fusion of the <em class="gene-name">

4309NUP98</em>

4310 gene with the <em class="gene-name">

4311KDM5A</em>

4312 gene, which results from a cytogenetically cryptic translocation, t(11;12)(p15;p13).[<a href="#cit/section_2.172">

4313172</a>

4314] Approximately 2% of pediatric AML patients have <em class="gene-name">

4315NUP98</em>

4316::<em class="gene-name">

4317KDM5A</em>

4318 fusions, and these cases tend to present at a young age (median age, 3 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

4319154</a>

4320]</p>

4321<div class="pdq-content-list">

4322<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1941">

4323<li>

4324Cases with <em class="gene-name">

4325NUP98</em>

4326::<em class="gene-name">

4327KDM5A</em>

4328 fusions tend to be AMKL (34%), followed by FAB M5 (21%), and FAB M6 (17%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

4329154</a>

4330] <em class="gene-name">

4331NUP98</em>

4332::<em class="gene-name">

4333KDM5A</em>

4334 fusions are observed in approximately 10% of pediatric AMKL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

4335103</a>

4336,<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

4337149</a>

4338]</li>

4339<li>

4340Other genetic aberrations associated with pediatric AML, including <em class="gene-name">

4341FLT3</em>

4342 mutations, are uncommon in patients with <em class="gene-name">

4343NUP98</em>

4344::<em class="gene-name">

4345KDM5A</em>

4346 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

4347154</a>

4348] </li>

4349<li>

4350Prognosis for children with <em class="gene-name">

4351NUP98</em>

4352::<em class="gene-name">

4353KDM5A</em>

4354 fusions is inferior to that of other children with AML (5-year EFS rate of 29.6% &#177; 14.6% and an OS rate of 34.1% &#177; 16.1%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

4355154</a>

4356]</li>

4357</ul>

4358</div>

4359</li>

4360<li>

4361<strong>

4362<em class="gene-name">

4363RUNX1</em>

4364 mutations.</strong>

4365 AML with mutated <em class="gene-name">

4366RUNX1</em>

4367, which is a provisional entity in the 2016 WHO classification of AML and related neoplasms, is more common in adults than in children. In adults, the <em class="gene-name">

4368RUNX1</em>

4369 mutation is associated with a high risk of treatment failure. In a study of children with AML, <em class="gene-name">

4370RUNX1</em>

4371 mutations were observed in 11 of 503 patients (approximately 2%). Six of 11 patients with <em class="gene-name">

4372RUNX1</em>

4373-mutated AML failed to achieve remission and their 5-year EFS rate was 9%, suggesting that the <em class="gene-name">

4374RUNX1</em>

4375 mutation confers a poor prognosis in both children and adults.[<a href="#cit/section_2.173">

4376173</a>

4377]</li>

4378<li>

4379<strong>

4380<em class="gene-name">

4381RAS</em>

4382 mutations.</strong>

4383 Although mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4384RAS</em>

4385 have been identified in 20% to 25% of patients with AML, the prognostic significance of these mutations has not been clearly shown.[<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

438687</a>

4387,<a href="#cit/section_2.174">

4388174</a>

4389] Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4390NRAS</em>

4391 are observed more commonly than mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4392KRAS</em>

4393 in pediatric AML cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

439487</a>

4395,<a href="#cit/section_2.175">

4396175</a>

4397] <em class="gene-name">

4398RAS</em>

4399 mutations occur with similar frequency for all Type II alteration subtypes, with the exception of APL, for which <em class="gene-name">

4400RAS</em>

4401 mutations are seldom observed.[<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

440287</a>

4403] </li>

4404<li>

4405<strong>

4406<em class="gene-name">

4407KIT</em>

4408 mutations.</strong>

4409 Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4410KIT</em>

4411 occur in approximately 5% of AML, but in 10% to 40% of AML with CBF abnormalities.[<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

441273</a>

4413,<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

441487</a>

4415,<a href="#cit/section_2.175">

4416175</a>

4417,<a href="#cit/section_2.176">

4418176</a>

4419]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_877" tabindex="-1">

4420The prognostic significance of activating <em class="gene-name">

4421KIT</em>

4422 mutations in adults with CBF AML has been studied with conflicting results. A meta-analysis found that <em class="gene-name">

4423KIT</em>

4424 mutations appear to increase the risk of relapse without an impact on OS for adults with AML and <em class="gene-name">

4425RUNX1</em>

4426::<em class="gene-name">

4427RUNX1T1</em>

4428 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.64">

442964</a>

4430] <em class="gene-name">

4431KIT</em>

4432 mutations are often subclonal in children and adults with CBF AML;[<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

443365</a>

4434,<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

443566</a>

4436] in adults with AML and <em class="gene-name">

4437RUNX1</em>

4438::<em class="gene-name">

4439RUNX1T1</em>

4440 mutations, higher <em class="gene-name">

4441KIT</em>

4442 mutant&#8211;allele ratio appears to be associated with higher risk of treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

444361</a>

4444,<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

444565</a>

4446] The prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

4447KIT</em>

4448 mutations in pediatric CBF AML remains unclear; some studies found no impact of <em class="gene-name">

4449KIT</em>

4450 mutations on outcome,[<a href="#cit/section_2.67">

445167</a>

4452-<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

445369</a>

4454] while other studies reported a higher risk of treatment failure when <em class="gene-name">

4455KIT</em>

4456 mutations were present.[<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

445766</a>

4458,<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

445970</a>

4460-<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

446173</a>

4462]</p>

4463</li>

4464<li>

4465<strong>

4466<em class="gene-name">

4467WT1</em>

4468 mutations.</strong>

4469 WT1, a zinc-finger protein regulating gene transcription, is mutated in approximately 10% of cytogenetically normal cases of AML in adults.[<a href="#cit/section_2.177">

4470177</a>

4471-<a href="#cit/section_2.180">

4472180</a>

4473] The <em class="gene-name">

4474WT1</em>

4475 mutation has been shown in some,[<a href="#cit/section_2.177">

4476177</a>

4477,<a href="#cit/section_2.178">

4478178</a>

4479,<a href="#cit/section_2.180">

4480180</a>

4481] but not all studies [<a href="#cit/section_2.179">

4482179</a>

4483] to be an independent predictor of worse disease-free survival, EFS, and OS of adults.<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_878" tabindex="-1">

4484In children with AML, <em class="gene-name">

4485WT1</em>

4486 mutations are observed in approximately 10% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.181">

4487181</a>

4488,<a href="#cit/section_2.182">

4489182</a>

4490] Cases with <em class="gene-name">

4491WT1</em>

4492 mutations are enriched among children with normal cytogenetics and <em class="gene-name">

4493FLT3</em>

4494 ITD, but are less common among children younger than 3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.181">

4495181</a>

4496,<a href="#cit/section_2.182">

4497182</a>

4498] AML cases with <em class="gene-name">

4499NUP98</em>

4500::<em class="gene-name">

4501NSD1</em>

4502 fusions are enriched for both <em class="gene-name">

4503FLT3</em>

4504 ITD and <em class="gene-name">

4505WT1</em>

4506 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4507121</a>

4508] In univariate analyses, <em class="gene-name">

4509WT1</em>

4510 mutations are predictive of poorer outcome in pediatric patients, but the independent prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

4511WT1</em>

4512 mutation status is unclear because of its strong association with <em class="gene-name">

4513FLT3</em>

4514 ITD and its association with <em class="gene-name">

4515NUP98</em>

4516::<em class="gene-name">

4517NSD1</em>

4518 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4519121</a>

4520,<a href="#cit/section_2.181">

4521181</a>

4522,<a href="#cit/section_2.182">

4523182</a>

4524] The largest study of <em class="gene-name">

4525WT1</em>

4526 mutations in children with AML observed that children with <em class="gene-name">

4527WT1</em>

4528 mutations in the absence of <em class="gene-name">

4529FLT3</em>

4530 ITD had outcomes similar to that of children without <em class="gene-name">

4531WT1</em>

4532 mutations, while children with both <em class="gene-name">

4533WT1</em>

4534 mutation and <em class="gene-name">

4535FLT3</em>

4536 ITD had survival rates less than 20%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.181">

4537181</a>

4538]</p>

4539<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_1935" tabindex="-1">

4540In a study of children with refractory AML, <em class="gene-name">

4541WT1</em>

4542 was overrepresented compared with a cohort who did achieve remission (54% [15 of 28 patients] vs. 15%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

4543171</a>

4544]</p>

4545</li>

4546<li>

4547<strong>

4548<em class="gene-name">

4549DNMT3A</em>

4550 mutations.</strong>

4551 Mutations of the <em class="gene-name">

4552DNMT3A</em>

4553 gene have been identified in approximately 20% of adult AML patients and are uncommon in patients with favorable cytogenetics but occur in one-third of adult patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.[<a href="#cit/section_2.183">

4554183</a>

4555] Mutations in this gene are independently associated with poor outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.183">

4556183</a>

4557-<a href="#cit/section_2.185">

4558185</a>

4559] <em class="gene-name">

4560DNMT3A</em>

4561 mutations are virtually absent in children.[<a href="#cit/section_2.186">

4562186</a>

4563]</li>

4564<li>

4565<strong>

4566<em class="gene-name">

4567IDH1</em>

4568 and

4569<em class="gene-name">

4570IDH2</em>

4571 mutations.</strong>

4572 Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4573IDH1</em>

4574 and <em class="gene-name">

4575IDH2</em>

4576, which code for isocitrate dehydrogenase, occur in approximately 20% of adults with AML,[<a href="#cit/section_2.187">

4577187</a>

4578-<a href="#cit/section_2.191">

4579191</a>

4580] and they are enriched in patients with <em class="gene-name">

4581NPM1</em>

4582 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.188">

4583188</a>

4584,<a href="#cit/section_2.189">

4585189</a>

4586,<a href="#cit/section_2.192">

4587192</a>

4588] The specific mutations that occur in <em class="gene-name">

4589IDH1</em>

4590 and <em class="gene-name">

4591IDH2</em>

4592 create a novel enzymatic activity that promotes conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate to 2-hydroxyglutarate.[<a href="#cit/section_2.193">

4593193</a>

4594,<a href="#cit/section_2.194">

4595194</a>

4596] This novel activity appears to induce a DNA hypermethylation phenotype similar to that observed in AML cases with loss of function mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4597TET2</em>

4598.[<a href="#cit/section_2.192">

4599192</a>

4600]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_879" tabindex="-1">

4601Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4602IDH1</em>

4603 and <em class="gene-name">

4604IDH2</em>

4605 are rare in pediatric AML, occurring in 0% to 4% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.186">

4606186</a>

4607,<a href="#cit/section_2.195">

4608195</a>

4609-<a href="#cit/section_2.199">

4610199</a>

4611] There is no indication of a negative prognostic effect for <em class="gene-name">

4612IDH1</em>

4613 and <em class="gene-name">

4614IDH2</em>

4615 mutations in children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.195">

4616195</a>

4617]</p>

4618</li>

4619<li>

4620<strong>

4621<em class="gene-name">

4622CSF3R</em>

4623 mutations.</strong>

4624 <em class="gene-name">

4625CSF3R</em>

4626 is the gene encoding the granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) receptor, and activating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4627CSF3R</em>

4628 are observed in 2% to 3% of pediatric AML cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.200">

4629200</a>

4630] These mutations lead to enhanced signaling through the G-CSF receptor, and they are primarily observed in AML with either <em class="gene-name">

4631CEBPA</em>

4632 mutations or with CBF abnormalities (<em class="gene-name">

4633RUNX1</em>

4634::<em class="gene-name">

4635RUNX1T1</em>

4636 and <em class="gene-name">

4637CBFB</em>

4638::<em class="gene-name">

4639MYH11</em>

4640 fusions).[<a href="#cit/section_2.200">

4641200</a>

4642] In a study of 2,150 pediatric patients with AML, 35 patients (1.6%) were found to have <em class="gene-name">

4643CSF3R</em>

4644 mutations; 30 (89%) of these cases were in patients with either <em class="gene-name">

4645RUNX1</em>

4646::<em class="gene-name">

4647RUNX1T1</em>

4648 fusions (n = 18) or with <em class="gene-name">

4649CEBPA</em>

4650 mutations (n = 12).[<a href="#cit/section_2.98">

465198</a>

4652] Risk of relapse was significantly higher for patients with co-occurring <em class="gene-name">

4653CSF3R</em>

4654 and <em class="gene-name">

4655CEBPA</em>

4656 mutations compared with patients with <em class="gene-name">

4657RUNX1</em>

4658::<em class="gene-name">

4659RUNX1T1</em>

4660 fusions and <em class="gene-name">

4661CSF3R</em>

4662 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.98">

466398</a>

4664]

4665

4666Although relapse rates are higher in patients with AML that have co-occurring <em class="gene-name">

4667CSF3R</em>

4668 and <em class="gene-name">

4669CEBPA</em>

4670 mutations, overall survival is not adversely impacted, reflecting a high salvage rate with reinduction therapy and stem cell transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

467190</a>

4672]<p id="_sm_CDR0000779362_838" tabindex="-1">

4673Activating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4674CSF3R</em>

4675 are also observed in patients with severe congenital neutropenia. These mutations are not the cause of severe congenital neutropenia, but rather arise as somatic mutations and can represent an early step in the pathway to AML.[<a href="#cit/section_2.201">

4676201</a>

4677] In one study of patients with severe congenital neutropenia, 34% of patients who had not developed a myeloid malignancy had <em class="gene-name">

4678CSF3R</em>

4679 mutations detectable in peripheral blood neutrophils and mononuclear cells, while 78% of patients who had developed a myeloid malignancy showed <em class="gene-name">

4680CSF3R</em>

4681 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.201">

4682201</a>

4683] A study of 31 patients with severe congenital neutropenia who developed AML or MDS observed <em class="gene-name">

4684CSF3R</em>

4685 mutations in approximately 80% of patients, and also observed a high frequency of <em class="gene-name">

4686RUNX1</em>

4687 mutations (approximately 60%), suggesting cooperation between <em class="gene-name">

4688CSF3R</em>

4689 and <em class="gene-name">

4690RUNX1</em>

4691 mutations for leukemia development within the context of severe congenital neutropenia.[<a href="#cit/section_2.202">

4692202</a>

4693]</p>

4694</li>

4695</ul>

4696</div>

4697</section>

4698</section>

4699</section>

4755[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4756</li>

4758Gerr H, Zimmermann M, Schrappe M, et al.: Acute leukaemias of ambiguous lineage in children: characterization, prognosis and therapy recommendations. 4759[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4760</li>

4761<li id="section_2.17">

4762Rubnitz JE, Onciu M, Pounds S, et al.: Acute mixed lineage leukemia in children: the experience of St Jude Children's Research Hospital. Blood 113 (21): 5083-9, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19131545&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19131545&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4763[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4764</li>

4765<li id="section_2.18">

4766Al-Seraihy AS, Owaidah TM, Ayas M, et al.: Clinical characteristics and outcome of children with biphenotypic acute leukemia. Haematologica 94 (12): 1682-90, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19713227&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19713227&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4767[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4768</li>

4769<li id="section_2.19">

4770Matutes E, Pickl WF, Van't Veer M, et al.: Mixed-phenotype acute leukemia: clinical and laboratory features and outcome in 100 patients defined according to the WHO 2008 classification. Blood 117 (11): 3163-71, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21228332&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21228332&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4771[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4772</li>

4773<li id="section_2.20">

4774Hrusak O, de Haas V, Stancikova J, et al.: International cooperative study identifies treatment strategy in childhood ambiguous lineage leukemia. Blood 132 (3): 264-276, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29720486&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29720486&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4775[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4776</li>

4777<li id="section_2.21">

4778Orgel E, Alexander TB, Wood BL, et al.: Mixed-phenotype acute leukemia: A cohort and consensus research strategy from the Children's Oncology Group Acute Leukemia of Ambiguous Lineage Task Force. Cancer 126 (3): 593-601, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31661160&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31661160&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4779[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4780</li>

Blood 113 (19): 4505-11, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19221039&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19221039&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5407[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5408</li>

5409<li id="section_2.180">

5410Renneville A, Boissel N, Zurawski V, et al.: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association. Cancer 115 (16): 3719-27, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19536888&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19536888&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5411[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5412</li>

5413<li id="section_2.181">

5414Ho PA, Zeng R, Alonzo TA, et al.: Prevalence and prognostic implications of WT1 mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group. Blood 116 (5): 702-10, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20413658&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20413658&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5415[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5416</li>

5417<li id="section_2.182">

5418Hollink IH, van den Heuvel-Eibrink MM, Zimmermann M, et al.: Clinical relevance of Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations in childhood acute myeloid leukemia. Blood 113 (23): 5951-60, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19171881&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19171881&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5419[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5420</li>

5423[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5424</li>

5425<li id="section_2.184">

5426Yan XJ, Xu J, Gu ZH, et al.: Exome sequencing identifies somatic mutations of DNA methyltransferase gene DNMT3A in acute monocytic leukemia. Nat Genet 43 (4): 309-15, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21399634&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21399634&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5427[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5428</li>

5429<li id="section_2.185">

5430Thol F, Damm F, L&#252;deking A, et al.: Incidence and prognostic influence of DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia. J Clin Oncol 29 (21): 2889-96, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21670448&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21670448&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5431[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5432</li>

5433<li id="section_2.186">

5434Ho PA, Kutny MA, Alonzo TA, et al.: Leukemic mutations in the methylation-associated genes DNMT3A and IDH2 are rare events in pediatric AML: a report from the Children's Oncology Group. Pediatr Blood Cancer 57 (2): 204-9, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21504050&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21504050&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5435[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5436</li>

5437<li id="section_2.187">

5438Green CL, Evans CM, Hills RK, et al.: The prognostic significance of IDH1 mutations in younger adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia is dependent on FLT3/ITD status. Blood 116 (15): 2779-82, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20651067&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20651067&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5439[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5440</li>

5441<li id="section_2.188">

5442Paschka P, Schlenk RF, Gaidzik VI, et al.: IDH1 and IDH2 mutations are frequent genetic alterations in acute myeloid leukemia and confer adverse prognosis in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia with NPM1 mutation without FLT3 internal tandem duplication. J Clin Oncol 28 (22): 3636-43, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20567020&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20567020&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5443[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5444</li>

5445<li id="section_2.189">

5446Abbas S, Lugthart S, Kavelaars FG, et al.: Acquired mutations in the genes encoding IDH1 and IDH2 both are recurrent aberrations in acute myeloid leukemia: prevalence and prognostic value. Blood 116 (12): 2122-6, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20538800&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20538800&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5447[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5448</li>

5449<li id="section_2.190">

5450Marcucci G, Maharry K, Wu YZ, et al.: IDH1 and IDH2 gene mutations identify novel molecular subsets within de novo cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study. J Clin Oncol 28 (14): 2348-55, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20368543&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20368543&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5451[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5452</li>

5453<li id="section_2.191">

5454Wagner K, Damm F, G&#246;hring G, et al.: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor. J Clin Oncol 28 (14): 2356-64, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20368538&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20368538&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5456</li>

5458Figueroa ME, Abdel-Wahab O, Lu C, et al.: Leukemic IDH1 and IDH2 mutations result in a hypermethylation phenotype, disrupt TET2 function, and impair hematopoietic differentiation. Cancer Cell 18 (6): 553-67, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21130701&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21130701&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5460</li>

5461<li id="section_2.193">

5472</li>

5480</li>

5481<li id="section_2.198">

5482Ho PA, Alonzo TA, Kopecky KJ, et al.: Molecular alterations of the IDH1 gene in AML: a Children's Oncology Group and Southwest Oncology Group study.
