5500</li>

5501</ol>

5502</div>

5503

5504 </section>

5505

5506

5507

5508 <section id="_46">

5509

5510 <h2>

5511Treatment Option Overview for Childhood AML</h2>

5512

5513 <div id="_section_46" class="pdq-sections">

5514<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5515<h6>

5516In This Section</h6>

5517<ul>

5518<li>

5519<a href="#_940_toc">

5520Treatment Approach</a>

5521</li>

5522<li>

5523<a href="#_183_toc">

5524Prognostic Factors in Childhood AML<ul>

5525<li>

5526<a href="#_1095_toc">

5527Host risk factors</a>

5528</li>

5529<li>

5530<a href="#_1097_toc">

5531Leukemia risk factors</a>

5532</li>

5533<li>

5534<a href="#_1099_toc">

5535Therapeutic response risk factors</a>

5536</li>

5537</ul>

5538</a>

5539</li>

5540<li>

5541<a href="#_440_toc">

5542Risk Classification Systems</a>

5543</li>

5544</ul>

5545</nav>

5546<p id="_933" tabindex="-1">

5547Leukemia is considered to be disseminated in the hematopoietic

5548system at diagnosis, even in children with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who

5549present with isolated chloromas (also called granulocytic or myeloid sarcomas). If these

5550children do not receive systemic chemotherapy, they invariably develop AML in

5551months or years. AML may invade nonhematopoietic (extramedullary) tissue such as meninges,

5552brain parenchyma, testes or ovaries, or skin (leukemia cutis). Extramedullary

5553leukemia is more common in infants than in older children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

55541</a>

5555]</p>

5556<p id="_935" tabindex="-1">

5557Childhood AML is diagnosed when bone marrow has 20% or greater blasts. The

5558blasts have the morphological and histochemical characteristics of one of the French-American-British (FAB)

5559subtypes of AML. It can also be diagnosed by biopsy of a chloroma. For

5560treatment purposes, patients with clonal cytogenetic abnormalities typically associated with AML, such as t(8;21)(<em class="gene-name">

5561RUNX1</em>

5562::<em class="gene-name">

5563RUNX1T1</em>

5564 gene fusions), inv(16)(<em class="gene-name">

5565CBFB</em>

5566::<em class="gene-name">

5567MYH11</em>

5568 gene fusions), t(9;11)(<em class="gene-name">

5569MLLT3</em>

5570::<em class="gene-name">

5571KMT2A</em>

5572 gene fusions) or t(15;17)(<em class="gene-name">

5573PML</em>

5574::<em class="gene-name">

5575RARA</em>

5576 gene fusions) and who have less than 20% bone marrow blasts, are considered to have AML rather than a myelodysplastic syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

55772</a>

5578]</p>

5579<p id="_937" tabindex="-1">

5580Complete remission (CR) has traditionally been defined in the United States using morphological criteria such as the following:</p>

5581<div class="pdq-content-list">

5582<ul id="_1169">

5583<li>

5584Peripheral blood counts (white blood cell [WBC]

5585count, differential [absolute neutrophil count &gt;1,000/&#956;L], and platelet count &gt;100,000/&#956;L) rising toward normal.</li>

5586<li>

5587Mildly

5588hypocellular to normal cellular marrow with fewer than 5% blasts.</li>

5589<li>

5590No

5591clinical signs or symptoms of the disease, including in the central nervous system (CNS) or at other extramedullary sites.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

55923</a>

5593] </li>

5594</ul>

5595</div>

5596<p id="_1170" tabindex="-1">

5597Alternative definitions of remission using morphology are used in AML because of the prolonged myelosuppression caused by intensive chemotherapy and include CR with incomplete platelet recovery (CRp) and CR with incomplete marrow recovery (typically absolute neutrophil count) (CRi). Whereas the use of CRp provides a clinically meaningful response, the traditional CR definition remains the gold standard because patients in CR were found to be more likely to survive longer than those in CRp.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

55984</a>

5599]</p>

5600<p id="_938" tabindex="-1">

5601Achieving a hypoplastic bone marrow (using morphology)

5602is usually the first step in obtaining remission in AML with the

5603exception of the M3 subtype (acute promyelocytic leukemia [APL]); a hypoplastic marrow

5604phase is often not necessary before the achievement of remission in APL.

5605Additionally, early recovery marrows in any of the subtypes of AML may be

5606difficult to distinguish from persistent leukemia, although the application of flow cytometric immunophenotyping and cytogenetic/molecular testing have made this less problematic. Correlation with blood

5607cell counts and clinical status is

5608imperative in passing final judgment on the results of early bone marrow

5609findings in AML.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

56105</a>

5611] If the findings are in doubt, the bone marrow

5612aspirate should be repeated in 1 to 2 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

56131</a>

5614]</p>

5615<p id="_939" tabindex="-1">

5616In addition to morphology, more precise methodology (e.g., multiparameter flow cytometry or quantitative reverse transcriptase&#8211;polymerase chain reaction [RT-PCR]) is used to assess response and has been shown to be of greater prognostic significance than morphology. For more information about these methodologies, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_183">

5617Prognostic Factors in Childhood AML</a>

5618 section.</p>

5619<section id="_940">

5620<h3 id="_940_toc">

5621Treatment Approach</h3>

5622<p id="_47" tabindex="-1">

5623 The mainstay of the therapeutic

5624approach is systemically administered combination chemotherapy. Approaches involving risk-group stratification and biologically targeted therapies are being tested to improve antileukemic treatment while sparing normal tissue. Optimal

5625treatment of AML requires control of bone marrow and systemic disease.

5626Treatment of the CNS, usually with intrathecal medication,

5627is a component of most pediatric AML protocols but has not yet been shown to

5628contribute directly to an improvement in survival. CNS irradiation is not necessary in patients, either as prophylaxis or for those presenting with cerebrospinal fluid leukemia that clears with intrathecal and systemic chemotherapy.</p>

5629<p id="_48" tabindex="-1">

5630Treatment is ordinarily divided into the following two phases:</p>

5631<div class="pdq-content-list">

5632<ul id="_941">

5633<li>

5634Induction (to induce

5635remission).</li>

5636<li>

5637Postremission consolidation/intensification (to reduce the risk of relapse).</li>

5638</ul>

5639</div>

5640<p id="_942" tabindex="-1">

5641Postremission

5642therapy may consist of varying numbers of courses of intensive chemotherapy

5643and/or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). For example, ongoing trials of the Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) and the United Kingdom Medical Research Council (MRC) use similar chemotherapy regimens consisting of two courses of induction chemotherapy followed by two to three additional courses of intensification chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

56446</a>

5645-<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

56468</a>

5647]</p>

5648<p id="_49" tabindex="-1">

5649Maintenance therapy is not part of most pediatric AML protocols because two randomized clinical trials failed to show a benefit for maintenance therapy when given after modern intensive chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

56509</a>

5651,<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

565210</a>

5653] The exception to this generalization is made for APL, because maintenance therapy was shown to improve event-free survival (EFS) and overall survival (OS) when tretinoin was combined with chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

565411</a>

5655] Some studies of adult APL patients, including studies incorporating arsenic trioxide treatment, have shown no benefit to maintenance.[<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

565612</a>

5657,<a href="#cit/section_3.13">

565813</a>

5659]</p>

5660<p id="_1092" tabindex="-1">

5661Attention to both acute and long-term complications is critical in children with AML. Modern AML treatment approaches are usually associated with severe, protracted myelosuppression with related complications. Children with AML should receive care under the direction of pediatric oncologists in cancer centers or hospitals with appropriate supportive care facilities (e.g., specialized blood products; pediatric intensive care; provision of emotional and developmental support). With improved supportive care, toxic death constitutes a smaller proportion of initial therapy failures than in the past.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

56626</a>

5663] Two COG trials reported an 11% to 13% incidence of remission failure, mainly because of resistant disease. Only 2% to 3% resulted from toxic death during the two induction courses.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

56648</a>

5665,<a href="#cit/section_3.14">

566614</a>

5667]</p>

5668<p id="_1093" tabindex="-1">

5669Children treated for AML are living longer and require close monitoring for cancer therapy side effects that may persist or develop months or years after treatment. The high cumulative doses of anthracyclines require long-term monitoring of cardiac function. The use of some modalities have declined, including total-body irradiation with HSCT because of its increased risk of growth failure, gonadal and thyroid dysfunction, cataract formation, and second malignancies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

567015</a>

5671] For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_201">

5672Survivorship and Adverse Late Sequelae</a>

5673 section or <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq">

5674Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

5675.</p>

5676</section>

5677<section id="_183">

5678<h3 id="_183_toc">

5679Prognostic Factors in Childhood AML</h3>

5680<p id="_184" tabindex="-1">

5681Prognostic factors in childhood AML can be categorized as follows: </p>

5682<div class="pdq-content-list">

5683<ul id="_1094">

5684<li>

5685<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1095">

5686Host risk factors</a>

5687.</li>

5688<li>

5689<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1097">

5690Leukemia risk factors</a>

5691.</li>

5692<li>

5693<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1099">

5694Therapeutic response risk factors</a>

5695.</li>

5696</ul>

5697</div>

5698<section id="_1095">

5699<h4 id="_1095_toc">

5700Host risk factors</h4>

5701<div class="pdq-content-list">

5702<ul id="_1096">

5703<li>

5704<strong>

5705Age:</strong>

5706 Several reports have identified older age as an adverse prognostic factor.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

57077</a>

5708,<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

570916</a>

5710-<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

571120</a>

5712] The age effect is not large with regard to OS, but in general, the adverse outcomes seen in adolescents compared with younger children appear to be primarily caused by increases in toxic mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_3.21">

571321</a>

5714] In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371981">

5715AAML1031 (NCT01371981)</a>

5716 trial, age older than 11 years was an independent predictor of more favorable EFS on multivariable analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

571722</a>

5718]<p id="_596" tabindex="-1">

5719While outcome for infants with ALL remains inferior to that of older children, outcome for infants with AML is similar to that of older children when they are treated with standard AML regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

572016</a>

5721,<a href="#cit/section_3.23">

572223</a>

5723-<a href="#cit/section_3.25">

572425</a>

5725] Infants have been reported to have a 5-year survival rate of 60% to 70%, although with increased treatment-associated toxicity, particularly during induction.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

572616</a>

5727,<a href="#cit/section_3.23">

572823</a>

5729-<a href="#cit/section_3.26">

573026</a>

5731]</p>

5732</li>

5733<li>

5734<strong>

5735Race and ethnicity:</strong>

5736 In both the Children's Cancer Group (CCG) CCG-2891 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002798">

5737COG-2961 (NCT00002798)</a>

5738 studies, White children had higher OS rates than did Black and Hispanic children.[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

573918</a>

5740,<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

574127</a>

5742,<a href="#cit/section_3.28">

574328</a>

5744] Black children also experienced lower survival rates than White children in St. Jude Children&#8217;s Research Hospital AML clinical trials.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

574529</a>

5746]</li>

5747<li>

5748<strong>

5749Down syndrome:</strong>

5750 For children with Down syndrome who develop AML, survival is generally favorable when diagnosed at a young age.[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

575130</a>

5752-<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

575332</a>

5754] The prognosis is particularly good (EFS rate exceeding 80%) for children younger than 4 years at diagnosis, the age group that accounts for the vast majority of Down syndrome patients with AML, whereas those older than 4 years have similar outcomes to those without Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

575532</a>

5756-<a href="#cit/section_3.36">

575736</a>

5758]</li>

5759<li>

5760<strong>

5761Body mass index:</strong>

5762 Obesity (body mass index more than 95th percentile for age) is predictive of inferior survival.[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

576318</a>

5764,<a href="#cit/section_3.37">

576537</a>

5766] Inferior survival was attributable to early treatment-related mortality that was primarily caused by infectious complications.[<a href="#cit/section_3.37">

576737</a>

5768,<a href="#cit/section_3.38">

576938</a>

5770]</li>

5771</ul>

5772</div>

5773</section>

5774<section id="_1097">

5775<h4 id="_1097_toc">

5776Leukemia risk factors</h4>

5777<div class="pdq-content-list">

5778<ul id="_1098">

5779<li>

5780<strong>

5781White blood cell (WBC) count:</strong>

5782 WBC count at diagnosis has been consistently noted to be inversely related to survival.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

57837</a>

5784,<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

578522</a>

5786,<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

578739</a>

5788,<a href="#cit/section_3.40">

578940</a>

5790] Patients with high presenting leukocyte counts have a higher risk of developing pulmonary and CNS complications and, historically, have a higher risk of induction death.[<a href="#cit/section_3.41">

579141</a>

5792]<p id="_894" tabindex="-1">

5793In patients with APL, WBC at initial diagnosis alone is used to distinguish standard-risk and high-risk APL. A WBC count of 10,000 cells/&#956;L or more denotes high risk, and these patients have an increased risk of both early death and relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

579442</a>

5795] However, more recent regimens that include arsenic trioxide result in low relapse rates that are not significantly different between the high-risk and low-risk groups.[<a href="#cit/section_3.43">

579643</a>

5797]</p>

5798</li>

5799<li>

5800<strong>

5801FAB subtype:</strong>

5802 Associations between FAB subtype and prognosis have been more variable. <div class="pdq-content-list">

5803<ul id="_856" class="list-dash">

5804<li>

5805<strong>

5806M3 subtype.</strong>

5807 The M3 (APL) subtype has a favorable outcome in studies using tretinoin in combination with chemotherapy and arsenic trioxide consolidation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

580842</a>

5809-<a href="#cit/section_3.45">

581045</a>

5811]</li>

5812<li>

5813<strong>

5814M6 subtype.</strong>

5815 In the 2016 WHO classification system, the M6 subtype was limited to pure erythroid leukemia. The combined COG AAML0531 and AAML1031 studies demonstrated that it is a rare subtype (5 of 1,934 cases; 0.2%), occurred in younger patients (median age, 2.3 years), and was associated with a poor outcome (5-year EFS and OS rates, 20% &#177; 36%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.46">

581646</a>

5817] </li>

5818<li>

5819<strong>

5820M7 subtype.</strong>

5821 Some studies have indicated a relatively poor outcome for M7 (megakaryocytic leukemia) in patients without Down syndrome,[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

582230</a>

5823] although reports suggest an intermediate prognosis for this group of patients when contemporary treatment approaches

5824are used.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

58256</a>

5826,<a href="#cit/section_3.47">

582747</a>

5828,<a href="#cit/section_3.48">

582948</a>

5830]<p id="_1085" tabindex="-1">

5831In a retrospective study of non&#8211;Down syndrome M7 patients with samples available for molecular analysis, the presence of specific genetic abnormalities (<em class="gene-name">

5832CBFA2T3</em>

5833::<em class="gene-name">

5834GLIS2</em>

5835 gene fusions [cryptic inv(16)(p13q24)], <em class="gene-name">

5836NUP98</em>

5837::<em class="gene-name">

5838KDM5A</em>

5839 gene fusions, t(11;12)(p15;p13), <em class="gene-name">

5840KMT2A</em>

5841 [<em class="gene-name">

5842MLL</em>

5843] rearrangements, monosomy 7) was associated with a significantly worse outcome than for other M7 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

584449</a>

5845,<a href="#cit/section_3.50">

584650</a>

5847] In contrast, 10% of non&#8211;Down syndrome AMKL patients with <em class="gene-name">

5848GATA1</em>

5849 mutations had favorable outcomes when there were no prognostically unfavorable gene fusions present. This was also true for patients with <em class="gene-name">

5850HOX</em>

5851 rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_3.50">

585250</a>

5853]</p>

5854</li>

5855<li>

5856<strong>

5857M0 subtype.</strong>

5858 The M0, or minimally differentiated subtype, has been associated with a poor outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.51">

585951</a>

5860]</li>

5861</ul>

5862</div>

5863</li>

5864<li>

5865<strong>

5866CNS disease:</strong>

5867 CNS involvement at diagnosis is categorized on the basis of the presence or absence of blasts in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). European cooperative groups have applied acute lymphoblastic leukemia&#8211;inspired definitions to AML, as follows:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5868<ul id="_564" class="list-dash">

5869<li>

5870<em>

5871CNS1:</em>

5872 CSF negative for blasts on cytospin, regardless of CSF WBC count.</li>

5873<li>

5874<em>

5875CNS2</em>

5876 is divided into the following three groups and defined as follows:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5877<ul id="_1972">

5878<li>

5879CNS2a: CSF with fewer than 5 WBC/&#956;L and cytospin positive for blasts in an atraumatic tap (&lt;10 red blood cells [RBC]/&#956;L).</li>

5880<li>

5881CNS2b: CSF with fewer than 5 WBC/&#956;L and cytospin positive for blasts in a traumatic tap (&#8805;10 RBC/&#956;L).</li>

5882<li>

5883CNS2c: CSF with 5 or more WBC/&#956;L and cytospin positive for blasts in a traumatic tap (&#8805;10 RBC/&#956;L) in which the WBC/RBC ratio in the CSF is less than twice that in the peripheral blood. </li>

5884</ul>

5885</div>

5886</li>

5887<li>

5888<em>

5889CNS3</em>

5890 includes the following three subgroups and is defined as follows:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5891<ul id="_1973">

5892<li>

5893CNS3a: CSF with 5 or more WBC/&#956;L and cytospin positive for blasts in an atraumatic tap (&lt;10 RBC/&#956;L).</li>

5894<li>

5895CNS3b: CSF with 5 or more WBC/&#956;L and cytospin positive for blasts in a traumatic tap (&#8805;10 RBC/&#956;L) in which the WBC/RBC ratio in the CSF is more than or equal to twice the ratio in the peripheral blood.</li>

5896<li>

5897CNS3c: Clinical signs of CNS leukemia (e.g., cranial nerve palsy, brain/eye involvement, or radiographic evidence of an intracranial, intradural chloroma).</li>

5898</ul>

5899</div>

5900<p id="_1943" tabindex="-1">

5901COG trials (including <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00070174">

5902AAML03P1 [NCT00070174]</a>

5903, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

5904AAML0531 [NCT00372593]</a>

5905, and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371981">

5906AAML1031 [NCT01371981]</a>

5907) used a modified version of the CNS disease definitions, in which patients were dichotomously classified for treatment purposes as CNS positive or negative. The CNS-positive group included all patients with blasts on cytospin (regardless of CSF WBC) unless there were more than 100 RBC/&#956;L in the CSF. Patients with 100 RBC/&#956;L in the CSF were CNS positive only if the WBC/RBC ratio in the CSF was greater than or equal to twice the ratio in the peripheral blood. CNS outcomes on COG studies were analyzed utilizing the more traditional CNS1/2/3 definitions.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

590852</a>

5909]</p>

5910<p id="_565" tabindex="-1">

5911CNS2 disease has been observed in approximately 13% to 16% of children with AML, and CNS3 disease has been observed in approximately 11% to 17% of children with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

591252</a>

5913,<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

591453</a>

5915] Studies have variably shown that patients with CNS2/CNS3 were younger, more often had hyperleukocytosis, and had higher incidences of t(9;11), t(8;21), or inv(16).[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

591652</a>

5917,<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

591853</a>

5919]</p>

5920<p id="_566" tabindex="-1">

5921While CNS involvement (CNS2 or CNS3) at diagnosis has not been shown to be correlated with OS in most studies, a COG analysis of children with AML enrolled from 2003 to 2010 on two consecutive and identical backbone trials found that CNS involvement, especially CNS3 status, was associated with inferior outcomes, including complete remission rate, EFS, disease-free survival, and an increased risk of relapse involving the CNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

592252</a>

5923] Another trial showed it to be associated with an increased risk of isolated CNS relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_3.54">

592454</a>

5925] Finally, the COG study did not find an adverse impact of traumatic lumbar punctures at diagnosis upon eventual outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

592652</a>

5927]</p>

5928</li>

5929</ul>

5930</div>

5931</li>

5932<li>

5933<strong>

5934Cytogenetic and molecular characteristics:</strong>

5935 Cytogenetic and molecular characteristics are also associated with prognosis. For detailed information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_27">

5936Molecular Evaluation </a>

5937 section. Cytogenetic and molecular characteristics that are currently used in the COG clinical trials for treatment assignment include the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5938<ul id="_448" class="list-dash">

5939<li>

5940<strong>

5941Favorable:</strong>

5942 inv(16)/t(16;16), t(8;21), t(15;17), biallelic <em class="gene-name">

5943CEBPA</em>

5944 mutations, and <em class="gene-name">

5945NPM1</em>

5946 mutations.</li>

5947<li>

5948<strong>

5949Unfavorable:</strong>

5950 monosomy 7, monosomy 5/del(5q), 3q abnormalities, <em class="gene-name">

5951FLT3</em>

5952 internal tandem duplications (ITD) with high-allelic

5953ratio, <em class="gene-name">

5954KMT2A</em>

5955 gene fusions with the following partners: t(4;11)(q21;q23), t(6;11)(q27;q23), t(10;11)(p11.2;q23), t(10;11)(p12;q23), or t(11;19)(q23;p13.3), <em class="gene-name">

5956NUP98</em>

5957 (11p15.5), 12p (<em class="gene-name">

5958ETV6</em>

5959 rearrangement or loss), t(16;21)(p11;q22)(<em class="gene-name">

5960FUS</em>

5961::<em class="gene-name">

5962ERG</em>

5963 gene fusions), <em class="gene-name">

5964CBFA2T3</em>

5965::<em class="gene-name">

5966GLIS2</em>

5967 gene fusions, <em class="gene-name">

5968KAT6A</em>

5969 (8p11.21) (if over 90 days of age), and non&#8211;<em class="gene-name">

5970KMT2A</em>

5971::<em class="gene-name">

5972MLLT10</em>

5973 gene fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_3.55">

597455</a>

5975,<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

597656</a>

5977] </li>

5978</ul>

5979</div>

5980</li>

5981<li>

5982<strong>

5983Immunophenotype:</strong>

5984 <div class="pdq-content-list">

5985<ul id="_2103">

5986<li>

5987A distinctive immunophenotype (initially reported as the RAM phenotype), with high CD56 levels, dim or negative expression of CD45 and CD38, and a lack of HLA-DR expression was associated with a poor prognosis (5-year EFS rate of approximately 20%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.57">

598857</a>

5989,<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

599058</a>

5991] Most patients with the RAM phenotype have the <em class="gene-name">

5992CBFA2T3</em>

5993::<em class="gene-name">

5994GLIS2</em>

5995 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

599658</a>

5997,<a href="#cit/section_3.59">

599859</a>

5999]</li>

6000<li>

6001High CD123 expression (quartile 4 vs. quartiles 1&#8211;3), in Cox multivariable regression, was shown to be an independent adverse prognostic risk factor for OS, EFS, and relapse risk (RR), although it did not impact remission success. High CD123 expression occurred more frequently in patients with many high-risk cytogenetic and molecular characteristics. High CD123 expression also adversely impacted OS and EFS, but not RR. In patients with low-risk cytogenetic and molecular characteristics, those with high CD123 expression (quartile 4) had significantly worse OS, EFS, and RR.[<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

600260</a>

6003]</li>

6004</ul>

6005</div>

6006</li>

6007</ul>

6008</div>

6009</section>

6010<section id="_1099">

6011<h4 id="_1099_toc">

6012Therapeutic response risk factors</h4>

6013<div class="pdq-content-list">

6014<ul id="_1100">

6015<li>

6016<strong>

6017Response to therapy/minimal residual disease (MRD):</strong>

6018 Early response to therapy, generally measured after the first course of induction therapy, is predictive of outcome and can be assessed by standard morphological examination of bone marrow,[<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

601939</a>

6020,<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

602161</a>

6022] cytogenetic analysis, fluorescence <em>

6023in situ</em>

6024 hybridization, or more sophisticated techniques to identify MRD (e.g., multiparameter flow cytometry, quantitative RT-PCR).[<a href="#cit/section_3.62">

602562</a>

6026-<a href="#cit/section_3.64">

602764</a>

6028] Multiple groups have shown that the level of MRD after one course of induction therapy is an independent predictor of prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.62">

602962</a>

6030-<a href="#cit/section_3.67">

603167</a>

6032]<p id="_453" tabindex="-1">

6033Molecular approaches to assessing MRD in AML (e.g., using quantitative RT-PCR) have been challenging to apply because of the genomic heterogeneity of pediatric AML and the instability of some genomic alterations. Quantitative RT-PCR detection of <em class="gene-name">

6034RUNX1</em>

6035::<em class="gene-name">

6036RUNX1T1</em>

6037 fusion transcripts can effectively predict higher risk of relapse for patients in clinical remission.[<a href="#cit/section_3.68">

603868</a>

6039-<a href="#cit/section_3.70">

604070</a>

6041] Other molecular alterations such as <em class="gene-name">

6042NPM1</em>

6043 mutations [<a href="#cit/section_3.71">

604471</a>

6045] and <em class="gene-name">

6046CBFB</em>

6047::<em class="gene-name">

6048MYH11</em>

6049 fusion transcripts [<a href="#cit/section_3.72">

605072</a>

6051] have also been successfully employed as leukemia-specific molecular markers in MRD assays; for these alterations, the level of MRD has shown prognostic significance. The presence of <em class="gene-name">

6052FLT3</em>

6053 ITD has been shown to be discordant between diagnosis and relapse, although when its presence persists (usually associated with a high-allelic ratio at diagnosis), it can be useful in detecting residual leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_3.73">

605473</a>

6055]</p>

6056<p id="_725" tabindex="-1">

6057For APL, MRD detection at the end of induction therapy lacks prognostic significance, likely related to the delayed clearance of differentiating leukemic cells destined to eventually die.[<a href="#cit/section_3.74">

605874</a>

6059,<a href="#cit/section_3.75">

606075</a>

6061] However, the kinetics of molecular remission after completion of induction therapy is prognostic, with the persistence of minimal disease after three courses of therapy portending increased risk of relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_3.75">

606275</a>

6063-<a href="#cit/section_3.77">

606477</a>

6065]</p>

6066<p id="_454" tabindex="-1">

6067Flow cytometric methods have been used for MRD detection and can detect leukemic blasts based on the expression of aberrant surface antigens that differ from the pattern observed in normal progenitors. In a COG analysis (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

6068AAML0531 [NCT00372593]</a>

6069) of 784 patients, 69% of patients (n = 544) were MRD negative (defined as &lt;0.02%) in their bone marrow at the end of induction 1 (EOI1). Those patients had better disease-free survival rates (57%; 95% CI, 53%&#8211;61%; <em>

6070P</em>

6071 &lt; .001) and overall survival rates (73%; 95% CI, 69%&#8211;76%; <em>

6072P</em>

6073 &lt; .001) than patients who were MRD positive (DFS: 30%; 95% CI, 25%&#8211;36% and OS: 48%; 95% CI, 42%&#8211;54%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.67">

607467</a>

6075] Additionally, in the 76% of patients who were in morphological remission at EOI1, 20% were MRD positive and had a significantly worse outcome than the patients who were MRD negative/morphology negative. In the 24% of patients who were not in morphological remission, 36% were actually MRD negative and had significantly better outcomes than the patients who were MRD positive/morphology positive. This was also true in patients with marrow blast percentages in excess of 15%, 27% of whom had MRD-negative bone marrow and significantly better outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.67">

607667</a>

6077] A CCG study of 252 pediatric patients with AML in morphological remission demonstrated that MRD as assessed by flow cytometry was the strongest prognostic factor predicting outcome in a multivariate analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.78">

607878</a>

6079] Other reports have confirmed both the utility of flow cytometric methods for MRD detection in the pediatric AML setting and the prognostic significance of MRD at various time points after treatment initiation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.62">

608062</a>

6081,<a href="#cit/section_3.63">

608263</a>

6083,<a href="#cit/section_3.65">

608465</a>

6085]

6086</p>

6087</li>

6088</ul>

6089</div>

6090</section>

6091</section>

6092<section id="_440">

6093<h3 id="_440_toc">

6094Risk Classification Systems</h3>

6095<p id="_879" tabindex="-1">

6096Risk classification for treatment assignment has been used by several cooperative groups performing clinical trials in children with AML. In the COG, stratifying therapeutic choices on the basis of risk factors is a relatively recent approach for the non-APL, non&#8211;Down syndrome patient. Classification is most directly derived from the observations of the MRC AML 10 trial for EFS and OS [<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

609761</a>

6098] and further applied based on the ability of the pediatric patient to undergo reinduction and obtain a second complete remission and their subsequent OS after first relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

609979</a>

6100] </p>

6101<p id="_895" tabindex="-1">

6102The following COG trials have used a risk classification system to stratify treatment choices:</p>

6103<div class="pdq-content-list">

6104<ol id="_896">

6105<li>

6106In COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

6107AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

6108, the first COG trial to stratify therapy by risk group, patients were stratified into three risk groups on the basis of diagnostic cytogenetics and response after induction 1.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

61098</a>

6110] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6111<ul id="_897">

6112<li>

6113Low-risk patients included those diagnosed with a core-binding factor AML (either t(8;21) or inv(16)).</li>

6114<li>

6115High-risk patients had either monosomy 7, monosomy 5 or del5q, chromosome 3 abnormalities, or a poor response to induction 1 therapy with morphological marrow leukemic blasts (&gt;15%).</li>

6116<li>

6117All other patients fell into the intermediate-risk category.</li>

6118<li>

6119This resulted in a risk distribution of 24% low risk, 59% intermediate risk, and 17% high risk.</li>

6120</ul>

6121</div>

6122</li>

6123<li>

6124In the subsequent COG trial <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371981">

6125COG-AAML1031 (NCT01371981)</a>

6126, the risk groups were reduced to two on the basis of the finding that those in the intermediate category could be more specifically and prognostically defined by adding the use of MRD by multiparameter flow cytometry.[<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

612722</a>

6128,<a href="#cit/section_3.80">

612980</a>

6130]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6131<ul id="_898">

6132<li>

6133Patients whose cytogenetics and/or molecular genetics were noninformative (i.e., traditional intermediate risk) and were negative for MRD (&lt;0.1%) were placed in the low-risk category.</li>

6134<li>

6135Patients who were positive for MRD (&#8805;0.1%) were placed in the high-risk category.</li>

6136</ul>

6137</div>

6138</li>

6139<li>

6140In the COG-AAML1031 trial, the study stratification was further based on cytogenetics, molecular markers, and MRD at bone marrow recovery postinduction 1, with patients being divided into a low-risk or high-risk group as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

614122</a>

6142]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6143<ol id="_899" class="lower-alpha">

6144<li>

6145The low-risk group represented 78% of patients, had a 3-year OS rate from the end of induction 1 of 74.1% (&#177;3.4%), and was defined by the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

6146<ul id="_900">

6147<li>

6148Inv(16), t(8;21), <em class="gene-name">

6149NPM1</em>

6150 mutations, or <em class="gene-name">

6151CEBPA</em>

6152 mutations regardless of MRD and other cytogenetics.</li>

6153<li>

6154Intermediate-risk cytogenetics (defined by the absence of either low-risk or high-risk cytogenetic characteristics) with negative MRD (&lt;0.1% by flow cytometry) at end of induction 1.</li>

6155</ul>

6156</div>

6157</li>

6158<li>

6159The high-risk group represented the remaining 22% of patients, had a 3-year OS rate from the end of induction 1 of 36.9% (&#177;7.6%), and was defined by the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

6160<ul id="_901">

6161<li>

6162High-allelic ratio <em class="gene-name">

6163FLT3</em>

6164 ITD positive with any MRD status.</li>

6165<li>

6166Monosomy 7 with any MRD status.</li>

6167<li>

6168Monosomy 5/del(5q) with any MRD status.</li>

6169<li>

6170Intermediate-risk cytogenetics with positive MRD at end of induction 1.</li>

6171</ul>

6172</div>

6173<p id="_880" tabindex="-1">

6174Where risk factors contradicted each other, the following evidence-based table was used (see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_886">

6175Table 7</a>

6176).</p>

6177<table id="_886" class="table-default expandable-container">

6178<caption>

6308<td>

6321</tbody>

6322</table>

6323</li>

6324</ol>

6325</div>

6326</li>

6327</ol>

6328</div>

6329<p id="_441" tabindex="-1">

6330The high-risk group of patients was guided to transplantation in first remission with the most appropriate available donor. Patients in the low-risk group were instructed to pursue transplantation if they relapsed.[<a href="#cit/section_3.63">

633163</a>

6332,<a href="#cit/section_3.81">

633381</a>

6334]</p>

6335<p id="_881" tabindex="-1">

6336Risk factors used for stratification vary by pediatric and adult cooperative clinical trial groups and the prognostic impact of a given risk factor may vary in their significance depending on the backbone of therapy used. Other pediatric cooperative groups use some or all of these same factors, generally choosing risk factors that have been reproducible across numerous trials and sometimes including additional risk factors previously used in their risk group stratification approach.</p>

6337</section>

6617<li id="section_3.70">

6618Weisser M, Haferlach C, Hiddemann W, et al.: The quality of molecular response to chemotherapy is predictive for the outcome of AML1-ETO-positive AML and is independent of pretreatment risk factors. Leukemia 21 (6): 1177-82, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17377588&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17377588&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6619[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6620</li>

6621<li id="section_3.71">

6622Kr&#246;nke J, Schlenk RF, Jensen KO, et al.: Monitoring of minimal residual disease in NPM1-mutated acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the German-Austrian acute myeloid leukemia study group. J Clin Oncol 29 (19): 2709-16, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21555683&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21555683&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6623[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6624</li>

6625<li id="section_3.72">

6626Corbacioglu A, Scholl C, Schlenk RF, et al.: Prognostic impact of minimal residual disease in CBFB-MYH11-positive acute myeloid leukemia. J Clin Oncol 28 (23): 3724-9, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20625124&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20625124&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6627[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6628</li>

6629<li id="section_3.73">

6630Cloos J, Goemans BF, Hess CJ, et al.: Stability and prognostic influence of FLT3 mutations in paired initial and relapsed AML samples. Leukemia 20 (7): 1217-20, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16642044&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16642044&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6631[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6632</li>

6633<li id="section_3.74">

6634Mandelli F, Diverio D, Avvisati G, et al.: Molecular remission in PML/RAR alpha-positive acute promyelocytic leukemia by combined all-trans retinoic acid and idarubicin (AIDA) therapy. Gruppo Italiano-Malattie Ematologiche Maligne dell'Adulto and Associazione Italiana di Ematologia ed Oncologia Pediatrica Cooperative Groups. Blood 90 (3): 1014-21, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9242531&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9242531&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6635[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6636</li>

6637<li id="section_3.75">

6638Burnett AK, Grimwade D, Solomon E, et al.: Presenting white blood cell count and kinetics of molecular remission predict prognosis in acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid: result of the Randomized MRC Trial. Blood 93 (12): 4131-43, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10361110&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10361110&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6639[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6640</li>

6641<li id="section_3.76">

6642Diverio D, Rossi V, Avvisati G, et al.: Early detection of relapse by prospective reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction analysis of the PML/RARalpha fusion gene in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia enrolled in the GIMEMA-AIEOP multicenter "AIDA" trial. GIMEMA-AIEOP Multicenter "AIDA" Trial. Blood 92 (3): 784-9, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9680345&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9680345&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6643[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6644</li>

6645<li id="section_3.77">

6646Martinelli G, Ottaviani E, Testoni N, et al.: Disappearance of PML/RAR alpha acute promyelocytic leukemia-associated transcript during consolidation chemotherapy. Haematologica 83 (11): 985-8, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9864917&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9864917&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6647[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6648</li>

6649<li id="section_3.78">

6650Sievers EL, Lange BJ, Alonzo TA, et al.: Immunophenotypic evidence of leukemia after induction therapy predicts relapse: results from a prospective Children's Cancer Group study of 252 patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Blood 101 (9): 3398-406, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12506020&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12506020&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6651[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6652</li>

6653<li id="section_3.79">

6654Webb DK, Wheatley K, Harrison G, et al.: Outcome for children with relapsed acute myeloid leukaemia following initial therapy in the Medical Research Council (MRC) AML 10 trial. MRC Childhood Leukaemia Working Party. Leukemia 13 (1): 25-31, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10049056&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10049056&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6655[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6656</li>

6657<li id="section_3.80">

6658Tarlock K, Meshinchi S: Pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: biology and therapeutic implications of genomic variants. Pediatr Clin North Am 62 (1): 75-93, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25435113&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25435113&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6659[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6660</li>

6661<li id="section_3.81">

6662Pui CH, Carroll WL, Meshinchi S, et al.: Biology, risk stratification, and therapy of pediatric acute leukemias: an update. J Clin Oncol 29 (5): 551-65, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21220611&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21220611&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6663[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6664</li>

6665</ol>

6666</div>

6667

6668 </section>

6669

6670

6671

6672 <section id="_873">

6673

6674 <h2>

6675Special Considerations for the Treatment of Children With Cancer</h2>

6676

6677 <div id="_section_873" class="pdq-sections">

6678<p id="_874" tabindex="-1">

6679Cancer in children and adolescents is rare, although the overall incidence has been slowly increasing since 1975.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

66801</a>

6681] Children and adolescents with

6682cancer should be referred to medical centers that have a multidisciplinary team

6683of cancer specialists with experience treating the cancers that occur during

6684childhood and adolescence.[<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

66852</a>

6686] This multidisciplinary team approach incorporates the skills

6687of the following pediatric specialists and others to ensure that children receive treatment, supportive care, and rehabilitation

6688that will achieve optimal survival and quality of life.</p>

6689<div class="pdq-content-list">

6690<ul id="_1048">

6691<li>

6692Primary care physicians.</li>

6693<li>

6694Pediatric surgical subspecialists.</li>

6695<li>

6696Radiation

6697oncologists.</li>

6698<li>

6699Pediatric medical oncologists/hematologists.</li>

6700<li>

6701Rehabilitation

6702specialists.</li>

6703<li>

6704Pediatric nurse specialists.</li>

6705<li>

6706Social workers.</li>

6707</ul>

6708</div>

6709<p id="_1049" tabindex="-1">

6710For specific information about supportive care for children and adolescents with cancer, see the summaries on <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/information-summaries/supportive-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/information-summaries/supportive-care">

6711Supportive and Palliative Care</a>

6712.</p>

6713<p id="_875" tabindex="-1">

6714The American Academy of Pediatrics has outlined guidelines for

6715pediatric cancer centers and their role in the treatment of children with

6716cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

67173</a>

6718] At these

6719pediatric cancer centers, clinical trials are available for most

6720types of cancer that occur in children and adolescents, and the opportunity to

6721participate is offered to most patients and their families. Clinical

6722trials for children and adolescents with cancer are generally designed to

6723compare potentially better therapy with current standard therapy. Most of the progress made in identifying curative therapies

6724for childhood cancers has been achieved through clinical trials. For more information

6725about ongoing clinical trials, see the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

6726NCI website</a>

6727.</p>

6728<h6 do-not-show="toc">

6729References</h6>

6730<ol>

6731<li id="section_4.1">

6732Smith MA, Altekruse SF, Adamson PC, et al.: Declining childhood and adolescent cancer mortality. Cancer 120 (16): 2497-506, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6733[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6734</li>

6735<li id="section_4.2">

6736Wolfson J, Sun CL, Wyatt L, et al.: Adolescents and Young Adults with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia and Acute Myeloid Leukemia: Impact of Care at Specialized Cancer Centers on Survival Outcome. Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev 26 (3): 312-320, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28209594&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28209594&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6737[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6738</li>

6739<li id="section_4.3">

6740American Academy of Pediatrics: Standards for pediatric cancer centers. Pediatrics 134 (2): 410-4, 2014. <a href="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410" title="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410">

6741Also available online</a>

6742. Last accessed May 19, 2023.</li>

6743</ol>

6744</div>

6745

6746 </section>

6747

6748

6749

6750 <section id="_52">

6751

6752 <h2>

6753Treatment of Childhood AML</h2>

6754

6755 <div id="_section_52" class="pdq-sections">

6756<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6757<h6>

6758In This Section</h6>

6759<ul>

6760<li>

6761<a href="#_54_toc">

6762Induction Therapy<ul>

6763<li>

6764<a href="#_902_toc">

6765Chemotherapy</a>

6766</li>

6767<li>

6768<a href="#_1066_toc">

6769Immunotherapeutic approaches</a>

6770</li>

6771<li>

6772<a href="#_1947_toc">

6773Targeted therapy</a>

6774</li>

6775<li>

6776<a href="#_916_toc">

6777Supportive care</a>

6778</li>

6779<li>

6780<a href="#_927_toc">

6781Induction failure (refractory AML)</a>

6782</li>

6783<li>

6784<a href="#_175_toc">

6785Granulocytic sarcoma/chloroma</a>

6786</li>

6787</ul>

6788</a>

6789</li>

6790<li>

6791<a href="#_60_toc">

6792Central Nervous System (CNS) Prophylaxis for AML</a>

6793</li>

6794<li>

6795<a href="#_176_toc">

6796 Postremission Therapy for AML <ul>

6797<li>

6798<a href="#_952_toc">

6799Chemotherapy</a>

6800</li>

6801<li>

6802<a href="#_954_toc">

6803HSCT</a>

6804</li>

6805<li>

6806<a href="#_TrialSearch_176_sid_7_toc">

6807Current Clinical Trials</a>

6808</li>

6809</ul>

6810</a>

6811</li>

6812<li>

6813<a href="#_94_toc">

6814Recurrent or Refractory Childhood AML and Other Myeloid Malignancies<ul>

6815<li>

6816<a href="#_1029_toc">

6817Recurrent childhood AML</a>

6818</li>

6819<li>

6820<a href="#_1031_toc">

6821Refractory childhood AML (induction failure)</a>

6822</li>

6823<li>

6824<a href="#_TrialSearch_94_sid_8_toc">

6825Current Clinical Trials</a>

6826</li>

6827</ul>

6828</a>

6829</li>

6830<li>

6831<a href="#_TrialSearch_52_sid_5_toc">

6832Current Clinical Trials</a>

6833</li>

6834</ul>

6835</nav>

6836<p id="_53" tabindex="-1">

6837The general principles of therapy for children and adolescents with acute

6838myeloid leukemia (AML) are discussed below, followed by a more specific

6839discussion of the treatment of children with Down syndrome and acute promyelocytic leukemia

6840(APL).

6841</p>

6842<p id="_357" tabindex="-1">

6843Overall survival (OS) rates have improved over the past three decades for children with AML, with 5-year survival rates now in the 55% to 65% range.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

68441</a>

6845-<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

68464</a>

6847] Overall remission-induction rates are approximately 85% to 90%, and event-free survival (EFS) rates from the time of diagnosis are in the 45% to 55% range.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

68482</a>

6849-<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

68505</a>

6851] There is, however, a wide range in outcome for different biological subtypes of AML; after taking specific biological factors of their leukemia into account, the predicted outcome for any individual patient may be much better or much worse than the overall outcome for the general population of children with AML. For more information, see the sections on <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_27">

6852Molecular Evaluation</a>

6853 and <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_440">

6854Risk Classification Systems</a>

6855.</p>

6856<section id="_54">

6857<h3 id="_54_toc">

6858Induction Therapy</h3>

6859<p id="_55" tabindex="-1">

6860Contemporary pediatric AML protocols result in 85% to 90% complete

6861remission (CR) rates.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

68626</a>

6863-<a href="#cit/section_5.8">

68648</a>

6865] Approximately 2% to 3% of patients die during the induction phase, most often caused by treatment-related complications.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

68666</a>

6867-<a href="#cit/section_5.9">

68689</a>

6869] To achieve a CR, inducing

6870profound bone marrow aplasia (with the exception of the M3 APL subtype) is

6871usually necessary with currently used combination-chemotherapy regimens. Because induction chemotherapy produces severe

6872myelosuppression, morbidity and mortality from infection or hemorrhage during

6873the induction period may be significant.</p>

6874<p id="_1064" tabindex="-1">

6875Treatment options for children with AML during the induction phase may include the following:</p>

6876<div class="pdq-content-list">

6877<ol id="_1065">

6878<li>

6879<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_902">

6880Chemotherapy</a>

6881.</li>

6882<li>

6883<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1066">

6884Immunotherapeutic approaches (e.g., gemtuzumab ozogamicin)</a>

6885.</li>

6886<li>

6887<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1947">

6888Targeted therapy (e.g., FLT3 inhibitors)</a>

6889.</li>

6890<li>

6891<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_916">

6892Supportive care</a>

6893.</li>

6894</ol>

6895</div>

6896<section id="_902">

6897<h4 id="_902_toc">

6898Chemotherapy</h4>

6899<p id="_56" tabindex="-1">

6900The two most effective and essential drugs used to induce remission in children with AML are cytarabine and an anthracycline. Commonly used

6901pediatric induction therapy regimens use cytarabine and an anthracycline in

6902combination with other agents such as etoposide and/or thioguanine.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

69033</a>

6904,<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

690510</a>

6906,<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

690711</a>

6908]</p>

6909<p id="_903" tabindex="-1">

6910Evidence (induction chemotherapy regimen):</p>

6911<div class="pdq-content-list">

6912<ol id="_904">

6913<li>

6914The United Kingdom Medical Research Council (MRC) AML10 trial compared induction with cytarabine, daunorubicin, and etoposide (ADE) versus cytarabine and daunorubicin administered with thioguanine (DAT).[<a href="#cit/section_5.12">

691512</a>

6916]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6917<ul id="_905">

6918<li>

6919The results showed no difference in remission rate or disease-free survival (DFS) between the thioguanine and etoposide arms, although the thioguanine-containing regimen was associated with increased toxicity.</li>

6920</ul>

6921</div>

6922</li>

6923<li>

6924The MRC AML15 trial demonstrated that induction with daunorubicin and cytarabine (DA) resulted in equivalent survival rates when compared with ADE induction.[<a href="#cit/section_5.13">

692513</a>

6926]</li>

6927</ol>

6928</div>

6929<p id="_57" tabindex="-1">

6930The anthracycline that has been most used in induction regimens for children

6931with AML is daunorubicin,[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

69323</a>

6933,<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

693410</a>

6935,<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

693611</a>

6937] although idarubicin and the anthracenedione mitoxantrone have also been used.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

69386</a>

6939,<a href="#cit/section_5.14">

694014</a>

6941,<a href="#cit/section_5.15">

694215</a>

6943] Randomized trials have attempted to determine whether any other anthracycline or anthracenedione is superior to daunorubicin as a component of induction therapy for children with AML.

6944In the absence of convincing data that another anthracycline

6945 or mitoxantrone produces superior outcome over daunorubicin when given at an equitoxic dose,

6946daunorubicin remains the anthracycline most commonly used during induction

6947therapy for children with AML in the United States.</p>

6948<p id="_906" tabindex="-1">

6949Evidence (anthracycline):</p>

6950<div class="pdq-content-list">

6951<ol id="_907">

6952<li>

6953The German Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) Group AML-BFM 93 study evaluated cytarabine plus etoposide with either daunorubicin or idarubicin (ADE or AIE).[<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

695411</a>

6955,<a href="#cit/section_5.14">

695614</a>

6957]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6958<ul id="_908">

6959<li>

6960Similar EFS and OS rates were observed for both induction treatments.</li>

6961</ul>

6962</div>

6963</li>

6964<li>

6965The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002658">

6966MRC-LEUK-AML12 (NCT00002658)</a>

6967 clinical trial studied induction with cytarabine, mitoxantrone, and etoposide (MAE) in children and adults with AML compared with a similar regimen using daunorubicin (ADE).[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

69686</a>

6969,<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

697016</a>

6971] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6972<ul id="_909">

6973<li>

6974For all patients, the MAE regimen produced a reduction in relapse risk, but the increased rate of treatment-related mortality observed for patients receiving MAE led to no significant difference in DFS or OS rates when compared with ADE.[<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

697516</a>

6976]</li>

6977<li>

6978Similar results were noted when analyses were restricted to pediatric patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

69796</a>

6980]</li>

6981</ul>

6982</div>

6983</li>

6984<li>

6985The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00111345">

6986AML-BFM 2004 (NCT00111345)</a>

6987 clinical trial compared liposomal daunorubicin (L-DNR) with idarubicin at a higher-than-equivalent dose (80 mg/m<span class="sup">

69882</span>

6989 vs. 12 mg/m<span class="sup">

69902</span>

6991 per day for 3 days) during induction.[<a href="#cit/section_5.17">

699217</a>

6993]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6994<ul id="_910">

6995<li>

6996 Five-year OS and EFS rates were similar in both treatment arms.</li>

6997<li>

6998Treatment-related mortality was significantly lower with L-DNR than with idarubicin (2 of 257 patients vs. 10 of 264 patients).</li>

6999</ul>

7000</div>

7001</li>

7002<li>

7003The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371981">

7004AAML1031 (NCT01371981)</a>

7005 trial used mitoxantrone with high-dose cytarabine in its two-cycle induction phase for patients with high-risk AML.[<a href="#cit/section_5.18">

700618</a>

7007]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7008<ul id="_2081">

7009<li>

7010 In a planned comparison with the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

7011AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

7012 trial, which used a standard ADE regimen in the second induction cycle for similar patients, neither response nor survival was improved, whereas toxicity was increased in patients who received mitoxantrone.</li>

7013</ul>

7014</div>

7015</li>

7016</ol>

7017</div>

7018<p id="_1352" tabindex="-1">

7019Evidence (reduced-anthracycline induction regimen):</p>

7020<div class="pdq-content-list">

7021<ol id="_1353">

7022<li>

7023Although the combination of an anthracycline and cytarabine is the basis of initial standard induction therapy for adults and children, there is evidence that alternative drugs can be used to reduce the use of anthracyclines when necessary. In the St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (SJCRH) <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00703820">

7024AML08 (NCT00703820)</a>

7025 protocol, patients were randomly assigned to receive either clofarabine/cytarabine (CA) or high-dose cytarabine combined with daunorubicin and etoposide (HD-ADE) for induction I; all patients then received the anthracycline-containing, standard-dose ADE regimen for induction II.[<a href="#cit/section_5.19">

702619</a>

7027]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7028<ul id="_1354">

7029<li>

7030Despite a higher rate of minimal residual disease (MRD) in the CA group at day 22 of induction I (47% vs. 35%; <em>

7031P</em>

7032 = .04), 3-year EFS and OS rates were similar between the two groups.</li>

7033</ul>

7034</div>

7035</li>

7036</ol>

7037</div>

7038<p id="_58" tabindex="-1">

7039The intensity of induction therapy influences the overall outcome of therapy.

7040The CCG-2891 study demonstrated that intensively timed induction therapy (4-day

7041treatment courses separated by only 6 days) produced better EFS than standard-timing induction therapy (4-day treatment courses separated by

70422 weeks or longer).[<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

704320</a>

7044] The MRC has intensified induction therapy by

7045prolonging the duration of cytarabine treatment to 10 days.[<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

704610</a>

7047] </p>

7048<p id="_911" tabindex="-1">

7049In adults, another method of

7050intensifying induction therapy is to use high-dose cytarabine. While

7051studies in nonelderly adults suggest an advantage for intensifying induction

7052therapy with high-dose cytarabine (2&#8211;3 g/m<span class="sup">

70532</span>

7054/dose) compared with standard-dose

7055cytarabine,[<a href="#cit/section_5.21">

705621</a>

7057] a benefit for the use of high-dose cytarabine in children was not observed using a cytarabine dose

7058of 1 g/m<span class="sup">

70592</span>

7060 given twice daily for 7 days with daunorubicin and thioguanine.[<a href="#cit/section_5.22">

706122</a>

7062] A second pediatric study also failed to detect a benefit for high-dose cytarabine over standard-dose cytarabine when used during induction therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.23">

706323</a>

7064]</p>

7065</section>

7066<section id="_1066">

7067<h4 id="_1066_toc">

7068Immunotherapeutic approaches</h4>

7069<p id="_831" tabindex="-1">

7070Because further intensification of induction regimens has increased toxicity with little improvement in EFS or OS, alternative approaches, such as the use of gemtuzumab ozogamicin, have been examined.</p>

7071<section id="_1945">

7072<h5 id="_1945_toc">

7073Antibody-drug conjugate therapy (gemtuzumab ozogamicin)</h5>

7074<p id="_1974" tabindex="-1">

7075Gemtuzumab ozogamicin is a CD33-directed monoclonal antibody linked to a calicheamicin, a cytotoxic agent.</p>

7076<p id="_912" tabindex="-1">

7077Evidence (gemtuzumab ozogamicin during induction):</p>

7078<div class="pdq-content-list">

7079<ol id="_913">

7080<li>

7081The Children's Oncology Group (COG) completed a series of trials&#8212;<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00070174">

7082AAML03P1 (NCT00070174)</a>

7083, a pilot study, and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

7084AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

7085, a randomized trial&#8212;that examined the incorporation of gemtuzumab ozogamicin into induction therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.8">

70868</a>

7087,<a href="#cit/section_5.9">

70889</a>

7089] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7090<ul id="_914">

7091<li>

7092With the use of gemtuzumab ozogamicin during induction cycle 1, dosed at 3 mg/m<span class="sup">

70932</span>

7094 on day 6, the randomized trial identified an improvement in EFS but not in OS; this was because of a reduction in postremission relapse overall and specifically in distinct subsets of patients. These subsets included patients with low-risk cytogenetics, patients with intermediate-risk <em class="gene-name">

7095KMT2A</em>

7096-rearranged AML (with both high-risk and nonhigh-risk translocations) who went on to receive stem cell transplantation (SCT) from a matched-related donor,[<a href="#cit/section_5.24">

709724</a>

7098] and patients with high-risk high-allelic ratio (&gt;0.4) <em class="gene-name">

7099FLT3</em>

7100 internal tandem duplication (ITD) AML who then received a SCT from any donor.[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

710125</a>

7102]</li>

7103<li>

7104The efficacy and safety of gemtuzumab ozogamicin in children, which included infants as young as 1 month, was established in these trials.[<a href="#cit/section_5.26">

710526</a>

7106]</li>

7107</ul>

7108</div>

7109</li>

7110<li>

7111 Fractionated gemtuzumab ozogamicin dosing (3 mg/m<span class="sup">

71122</span>

7113 per dose on days 1, 4, and 7; maximum dose, 5 mg), which has been shown to be safe and effective in adult patients with de novo AML, is an alternative option to single-dose administration during induction.[<a href="#cit/section_5.27">

711427</a>

7115] Because this is the recommended adult dosing method, this schedule is now being evaluated in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02724163">

7116MyeChild 01 (NCT02724163)</a>

7117 phase III study for pediatric patients with de novo AML in the United Kingdom.</li>

7118<li>

7119The characteristics of CD33, the target of gemtuzumab ozogamicin, have been examined to further identify the patients who will benefit most from this agent. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7120<ul id="_1946">

7121<li>

7122The expression intensity of CD33 on leukemic cells appeared to predict which patients benefited from gemtuzumab ozogamicin on the COG AAML0531 clinical trial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

712328</a>

7124][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7125Level of evidence B1</a>

7126] Patients whose CD33 intensity fell into the highest three population quartiles benefited from treatment with gemtuzumab ozogamicin (i.e., improved relapse risk, DFS, and EFS), whereas those in the lowest quartile had no reduction in relapse risk, EFS, or OS. This impact was seen for low-, intermediate-, and high-risk patients.</li>

7127<li>

7128In a retrospective analysis of the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00927498">

7129ALFA-0701 (NCT00927498)</a>

7130 trial of older adults, higher CD33 expression corresponded with greater benefit from treatment with gemtuzumab ozogamicin.[<a href="#cit/section_5.29">

713129</a>

7132]</li>

7133<li>

7134The CD33 receptor on AML cells exhibited architectural variability (polymorphism) that resulted in 51% of patients expressing the single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs12459419 (designated CC), and these patients had a significant reduction in relapse with the use of gemtuzumab ozogamicin compared with patients who were not treated with this drug (26% vs. 49%; <em>

7135P</em>

7136 &lt; .001). The alteration of this SNP resulted in a CD33 isoform lacking the CD33 IgV domain to which gemtuzumab ozogamicin binds and that is used in diagnostic immunophenotyping.[<a href="#cit/section_5.30">

713730</a>

7138]</li>

7139<li>

7140For patients with either a one or two allele C&gt;T mutation (CT and TT phenotypes, respectively) at this SNP, there was no reduction in relapse when adding gemtuzumab ozogamicin therapy (5-year cumulative incidence of relapse, 39% vs. 40%; <em>

7141P</em>

7142 = .85).</li>

7143</ul>

7144</div>

7145</li>

7146<li>

7147A meta-analysis of five randomized clinical trials that evaluated gemtuzumab ozogamicin for adults with AML observed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_5.31">

714831</a>

7149] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7150<ul id="_915">

7151<li>

7152The greatest OS benefit was for patients with low-risk cytogenetics (t(8;21)(q22;q22) and inv(16)(p13;q22)/t(16;16)(p13;q22)).</li>

7153<li>

7154Adult AML patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics who received gemtuzumab ozogamicin had a significant but more modest improvement in OS.</li>

7155<li>

7156There was no evidence of benefit for patients with adverse cytogenetics.</li>

7157<li>

7158The evidence for a benefit in patients with <em class="gene-name">

7159FLT3</em>

7160 ITD mutations was mixed; the French <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00927498">

7161ALFA-0701 (NCT00927498)</a>

7162 trial showed a trend towards a benefit, whereas the five-trial meta-analysis study did not find a benefit.[<a href="#cit/section_5.27">

716327</a>

7164,<a href="#cit/section_5.31">

716531</a>

7166] These trials did not examine the outcomes specifically for the combination of gemtuzumab ozogamicin followed by SCT, as was reported by the COG.[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

716725</a>

7168]</li>

7169</ul>

7170</div>

7171</li>

7172</ol>

7173</div>

7174</section>

7175</section>

7176<section id="_1947">

7177<h4 id="_1947_toc">

7178Targeted therapy</h4>

7179<p id="_1948" tabindex="-1">

7180Similar to immunotherapeutic approaches, the use of targeted therapy attempts to circumvent the severe toxicity of traditional chemotherapy by employing agents that target leukemia-specific mutations and/or their abnormal present or missing byproducts. As opposed to adult AML (except in APL as described in a later section), randomized clinical trials have not yet demonstrated that targeted therapies improve outcomes in children with newly diagnosed AML; therefore, targeted therapies have not been incorporated into the standard therapeutic induction regimens outside of clinical trials. Because most data on the use of targeted agents are from adult clinical trials, the adult experience is initially described, followed by a description of the more limited experience in children.</p>

7181<section id="_1949">

7182<h5 id="_1949_toc">

7183FLT3 inhibitors in de novo AML</h5>

7184<p id="_1950" tabindex="-1">

7185Because of the high prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

7186FLT3</em>

7187 mutations in adult AML and adverse impact in AML patients of all ages, the <em class="gene-name">

7188FLT3</em>

7189 target has received the greatest attention for target-specific drug development in AML. Among the various FLT3 inhibitors developed and clinically studied, midostaurin, a multikinase inhibitor, is the only one with U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval for adult de novo AML; it was approved in 2017 for use with conventional backbone chemotherapy but not as a single agent.[<a href="#cit/section_5.32">

719032</a>

7191]</p>

7192<section id="_1951">

7193<h6 id="_1951_toc">

7194Midostaurin</h6>

7195<p id="_1953" tabindex="-1">

7196Evidence (midostaurin for adults with de novo AML):</p>

7197<div class="pdq-content-list">

7198<ol id="_1954">

7199<li>

7200In a randomized, placebo-controlled, phase III study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00651261">

7201CALGB10603/RATIFY [NCT00651261]</a>

7202) of 717 adults aged 18 to 59 years with <em class="gene-name">

7203FLT3</em>

7204 ITD or TKD-mutated AML, standard chemotherapy was given with or without midostaurin (50 mg/dose twice daily) followed by maintenance midostaurin or placebo for patients who did not proceed to SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.33">

720533</a>

7206] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7207<ul id="_1965">

7208<li>

7209OS (the primary endpoint) was significantly better for patients who received midostaurin (median OS, 74.7 months [95% confidence interval (CI), 31.5&#8211;not reached] vs. 25.6 months [95% CI, 18.6&#8211;42.9]; hazard ratio [HR], 0.78 [95% CI, 0.63&#8211;0.96]; <em>

7210P</em>

7211 = .009), as was EFS (median EFS, 8.2 months [95% CI, 5.4&#8211;10.7] vs. 3.0 months [95% CI, 1.9&#8211;5.9]; HR, 0.78 [95% CI, 0.66&#8211;0.93]; <em>

7212P</em>

7213 = .002).</li>

7214<li>

7215This benefit was seen across all <em class="gene-name">

7216FLT3</em>

7217 subgroups regardless of whether allogeneic SCT was utilized in consolidation.</li>

7218</ul>

7219</div>

7220 </li>

7221<li>

7222A second single-arm trial in 284 adults (aged 18&#8211;70 years) with <em class="gene-name">

7223FLT3</em>

7224 ITD AML added midostaurin (50 mg/dose twice daily) to intensive chemotherapy followed by allogeneic SCT or consolidation, and all patients had a subsequent midostaurin maintenance phase.[<a href="#cit/section_5.34">

722534</a>

7226]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7227<ul id="_1966">

7228<li>

7229The 2-year EFS rate was 37.7% (95% CI, 32%&#8211;44.3%), and the OS rate was 50.9% (95% CI, 44.9%&#8211;57.6%). </li>

7230<li>

7231Using a historical-control comparison, significant improvement in EFS was reported (HR, 0.58; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.70; <em>

7232P</em>

7233 &lt; .001).</li>

7234</ul>

7235</div>

7236</li>

7237</ol>

7238</div>

7239<p id="_1969" tabindex="-1">

7240Midostaurin has been studied in children with relapsed/refractory AML,[<a href="#cit/section_5.35">

724135</a>

7242] but there is no experience with midostaurin in children with newly diagnosed AML. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1961">

7243Targeted therapy (FLT3 inhibitors)</a>

7244 section.</p>

7245</section>

7246<section id="_1955">

7247<h6 id="_1955_toc">

7248Sorafenib</h6>

7249<p id="_1986" tabindex="-1">

7250Sorafenib, another multikinase inhibitor, has been approved for the treatment of other malignancies, but it has not been approved for use in AML. This agent has been evaluated for use in adult and pediatric patients with de novo <em class="gene-name">

7251FLT3</em>

7252-mutated AML. </p>

7253<p id="_2141" tabindex="-1">

7254Evidence (sorafenib):</p>

7255<div class="pdq-content-list">

7256<ol id="_2142">

7257<li>

7258Sorafenib was shown to improve EFS in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371981">

7259AAML1031 (NCT01371981)</a>

7260 study of pediatric patients with de novo AML and high-allelic ratio (HAR) (i.e., &gt;0.4) <em class="gene-name">

7261FLT3</em>

7262 ITD mutations. Seventy-two patients who received sorafenib were evaluable for response. The patients in this study were compared with patients with AML and HAR <em class="gene-name">

7263FLT3</em>

7264 ITD (N = 76) in the AAML1031 and COG AAML0531 trials who did not receive sorafenib.[<a href="#cit/section_5.36">

726536</a>

7266] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7267<ul id="_2143">

7268<li>

7269 The morphological CR rate after induction cycle I significantly improved for patients who received sorafenib (75% vs. 57%; <em>

7270P</em>

7271 = .028). </li>

7272<li>

7273However, there was a similar prevalence of residual MRD in both groups of patients (48% vs. 45%; <em>

7274P</em>

7275 = .724).</li>

7276<li>

7277Patients who received sorafenib had significantly improved 3-year EFS rates (55.9% vs. 31.9%; <em>

7278P</em>

7279 = .001), DFS rates (70.9% vs. 49.4%; <em>

7280P</em>

7281 = .032), and relapses after CR (17.6% vs. 44.1%; <em>

7282P</em>

7283 = .012).</li>

7284<li>

7285 The OS rate did not improve after treatment with sorafenib (65.8% vs. 55.3%; <em>

7286P</em>

7287 = .244).</li>

7288<li>

7289 Although similar trends were seen in patients with AML harboring both HAR <em class="gene-name">

7290FLT3</em>

7291 ITD mutations and <em class="gene-name">

7292NPM1</em>

7293 mutations, they did not approach a significant level of benefit.</li>

7294<li>

7295Statistics showed that a benefit of sorafenib treatment remained after multivariable analyses that controlled for both <em class="gene-name">

7296NPM1</em>

7297 status and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) as a time-varying covariate.</li>

7298</ul>

7299</div>

7300</li>

7301</ol>

7302</div>

7303</section>

7304</section>

7305</section>

7306<section id="_916">

7307<h4 id="_916_toc">

7308Supportive care</h4>

7309<p id="_715" tabindex="-1">

7310In children with AML receiving modern intensive therapy, the estimated incidence of severe bacterial infections is 50% to 60%, and the estimated incidence of invasive fungal infections is 7.0% to 12.5%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.37">

731137</a>

7312-<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

731339</a>

7314] Several approaches have been examined to reduce the morbidity and mortality from infection in children with AML.</p>

7315<section id="_917">

7316<h5 id="_917_toc">

7317Hematopoietic growth factors</h5>

7318<p id="_59" tabindex="-1">

7319Hematopoietic growth factors such as

7320granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) or granulocyte

7321colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) during AML induction therapy have been

7322evaluated in multiple placebo-controlled studies in adults with AML in attempts to reduce the

7323toxicity associated with prolonged myelosuppression.[<a href="#cit/section_5.7">

73247</a>

7325] These studies have generally shown a reduction in the duration of neutropenia of several days with the use of either

7326G-CSF or GM-CSF [<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

732740</a>

7328] but have not shown significant effects on treatment-related mortality or OS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

732940</a>

7330] For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/adult-aml-treatment-pdq#_46">

7331Treatment Option Overview for AML</a>

7332 section in Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment.

7333</p>

7334<p id="_1171" tabindex="-1">

7335Routine prophylactic use of hematopoietic growth factors is not recommended for children with AML.</p>

7336<p id="_1172" tabindex="-1">

7337Evidence (against the use of hematopoietic growth factors):</p>

7338<div class="pdq-content-list">

7339<ol id="_1173">

7340<li>

7341A randomized study in children with AML that evaluated G-CSF administered after induction chemotherapy showed a reduction in duration of neutropenia but no difference in infectious complications or mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_5.41">

734241</a>

7343]</li>

7344<li>

7345A higher relapse rate has been reported for children with AML expressing the differentiation defective G-CSF receptor isoform IV.[<a href="#cit/section_5.42">

734642</a>

7347]</li>

7348</ol>

7349</div>

7350</section>

7351<section id="_919">

7352<h5 id="_919_toc">

7353Antimicrobial prophylaxis</h5>

7354<p id="_716" tabindex="-1">

7355The use of antibacterial prophylaxis in children undergoing treatment for AML has been supported by several studies. Studies, including one prospective randomized trial, suggest a benefit to the use of antibiotic prophylaxis.</p>

7356<p id="_920" tabindex="-1">

7357Evidence (antimicrobial prophylaxis):</p>

7358<div class="pdq-content-list">

7359<ol id="_921">

7360<li>

7361A retrospective study from SJCRH in patients with AML reported that the use of intravenous (IV) cefepime or vancomycin in conjunction with oral ciprofloxacin or a cephalosporin significantly reduced the incidence of bacterial infection and sepsis compared with patients receiving only oral or no antibiotic prophylaxis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

736243</a>

7363]</li>

7364<li>

7365 The SJCRH results were confirmed in a subsequent study.[<a href="#cit/section_5.44">

736644</a>

7367]</li>

7368<li>

7369A retrospective report from the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

7370AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

7371 trial demonstrated significant reductions in sterile-site bacterial infection and particularly gram-positive, sterile-site infections with the use of antibacterial prophylaxis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

737245</a>

7373] This study also reported that prophylactic use of G-CSF reduced bacterial and <em>

7374Clostridium difficile</em>

7375 infections.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

737645</a>

7377]</li>

7378<li>

7379In a study that compared the percentage of bloodstream infections or invasive fungal infections in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) or AML who underwent chemotherapy and received antibacterial and antifungal prophylaxis, a significant reduction in both variables was observed when compared with a historical control group that did not receive any prophylaxis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.46">

738046</a>

7381]</li>

7382<li>

7383In the prospective COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371656">

7384ACCL0934</a>

7385 trial for children receiving intensive chemotherapy, patients were enrolled in two separate groups&#8212;patients with acute leukemia (consisting of AML or relapsed ALL) and patients undergoing SCT. Patients with acute leukemia were randomly assigned to receive levofloxacin (n = 96) or no prophylactic antibiotic (n = 99) during the period of neutropenia in one to two cycles of chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.47">

738647</a>

7387] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7388<ul id="_1311">

7389<li>

7390Analysis of the 195 children with acute leukemia revealed a significant reduction in bacteremia (43.4% to 21.9%, <em>

7391P</em>

7392 = .001) and neutropenic fever (82.1% to 71.2%, <em>

7393P</em>

7394 = .002) in the levofloxacin prophylaxis group compared with the control group, without increases in fungal infections, <em>

7395C. difficile</em>

7396&#8211;associated diarrhea, or musculoskeletal toxicities.</li>

7397<li>

7398There was no significant decrease in severe infections (3.6% vs. 5.9%, <em>

7399P</em>

7400 = .20), and no bacterial infection&#8211;related deaths occurred in either group.</li>

7401<li>

7402Levofloxacin prophylaxis is consistent with the guidelines published by the American Society of Clinical Oncology and Infectious Diseases Society of America in 2018 for adult cancer patients considered at high risk of infection by virtue of neutropenia (&lt;100 neutrophils/&#181;L) in excess of 7 days.[<a href="#cit/section_5.48">

740348</a>

7404]</li>

7405</ul>

7406</div>

7407</li>

7408</ol>

7409</div>

7410</section>

7411<section id="_923">

7412<h5 id="_923_toc">

7413Antifungal prophylaxis</h5>

7414<p id="_717" tabindex="-1">

7415Antifungal prophylaxis is important in the management of patients with AML.</p>

7416<p id="_924" tabindex="-1">

7417Evidence (antifungal prophylaxis):</p>

7418<div class="pdq-content-list">

7419<ol id="_925">

7420<li>
