7421Two meta-analysis reports have suggested that antifungal prophylaxis in pediatric patients with AML during treatment-induced neutropenia or during bone marrow transplantation reduces the frequency of invasive fungal infections and, in some instances, nonrelapse mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_5.49">

742249</a>

7423,<a href="#cit/section_5.50">

742450</a>

7425]</li>

7426<li>

7427Another study surveyed institutions that enrolled patients on the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

7428AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

7429 trial and investigated if these institutions routinely prescribed antifungal prophylaxis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

743045</a>

7431] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7432<ul id="_2028">

7433<li>

7434The study found that antifungal prophylaxis did not reduce fungal infections or nonrelapse mortality.</li>

7435<li>

7436The study was limited, however, because the investigators did not analyze whether individual patients received antifungal prophylaxis, regardless of institutional guidance.</li>

7437</ul>

7438</div>

7439 </li>

7440<li>

7441Several randomized trials in adults with AML have reported significant benefit in reducing invasive fungal infection with the use of antifungal prophylaxis. Such studies have also balanced cost with adverse side effects; when effectiveness at reducing invasive fungal infection is balanced with these other factors, posaconazole, voriconazole, caspofungin, and micafungin are considered reasonable choices.[<a href="#cit/section_5.46">

744246</a>

7443,<a href="#cit/section_5.51">

744451</a>

7445-<a href="#cit/section_5.55">

744655</a>

7447]</li>

7448<li>

7449There is a single randomized study comparing two antifungal agents for prophylaxis in pediatric patients with AML. The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01307579">

7450ACCL0933 (NCT01307579)</a>

7451 trial randomly assigned patients to receive prophylactic treatment with either fluconazole or caspofungin (an echinocandin with broader antiyeast and antimold activity than fluconazole).[<a href="#cit/section_5.56">

745256</a>

7453] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7454<ul id="_1985">

7455<li>

7456Caspofungin was superior to fluconazole in achieving lower 5-month cumulative incidences of both proven or probable invasive fungal disease (3.1% vs. 7.2%; <em>

7457P</em>

7458 = .03) and proven or probable invasive aspergillosis (0.5% vs. 3.1%; <em>

7459P</em>

7460 = .046).</li>

7461</ul>

7462</div>

7463</li>

7464</ol>

7465</div>

7466</section>

7467<section id="_1307">

7468<h5 id="_1307_toc">

7469Cardiac monitoring</h5>

7470<p id="_1308" tabindex="-1">

7471Bacteremia or sepsis and anthracycline use have been identified as significant risk factors in the development of cardiotoxicity, manifested as reduced left ventricular function.[<a href="#cit/section_5.57">

747257</a>

7473,<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

747458</a>

7475] Monitoring of cardiac function through the use of serial exams during therapy is an effective method for detecting cardiotoxicity and adjusting therapy as indicated. The use of dexrazoxane in conjunction with bolus dosing of anthracyclines can be an effective method of reducing the risk of cardiac dysfunction during therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.59">

747659</a>

7477]</p>

7478<p id="_1309" tabindex="-1">

7479Evidence (cardiac monitoring/dexrazoxane impact):</p>

7480<div class="pdq-content-list">

7481<ol id="_1310">

7482<li>

7483In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

7484AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

7485 trial, 8.6% of enrolled patients experienced left ventricular systolic dysfunction (LVSD) during protocol therapy, with a cumulative incidence of LVSD of 12% within 5 years of completing therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.57">

748657</a>

7487]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7488<ul id="_1312">

7489<li>

7490Risk factors for LVSD during therapy included Black race, older age, underweight body mass, and bacteremia.</li>

7491<li>

7492The occurrence of LVSD adversely impacted 5-year EFS (HR, 1.57; 95% CI, 1.16&#8211;2.14; <em>

7493P</em>

7494 = .004) and OS (HR, 1.59; 95% CI, 1.15&#8211;2.19; <em>

7495P</em>

7496 = .005), which was primarily a result of nonrelapse mortality.</li>

7497<li>

7498In patients who experienced LVSD during therapy, there was a 12-fold greater risk of LVSD in the 5 years after the completion of therapy.</li>

7499</ul>

7500</div>

7501</li>

7502<li>

7503The use of dexrazoxane was assessed in patients enrolled on the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371981">

7504AAML1031 (NCT01371981)</a>

7505 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.59">

750659</a>

7507]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7508<ul id="_1313">

7509<li>

7510This trial mandated prospective cardiac monitoring with each cycle and in follow-up and found a higher LVSD incidence (39%) occurring at a median of 3.8 months from enrollment (interquartile range, 2&#8211;6.2 months) than was seen in the preceding trial.</li>

7511<li>

7512Among the approximately 10% of children (96 of 1,014) who electively received dexrazoxane with each dose of anthracycline, the incidence of LVSD (defined as ejection fraction &lt;55% or shortening fraction &lt;28%) was significantly less in these patients (26.5% vs. 42.2%; HR, 0.55; 95% CI, 0.36&#8211;0.86; <em>

7513P</em>

7514 = .009) than in the patients who did not elect to receive dexrazoxane. This was also evident for risk of LVSD grade 2 or higher (60% lower). Patients who received dexrazoxane also had persistently better cardiac function after therapy (median follow-up, 3.5 years).</li>

7515<li>

7516Patients who received dexrazoxane had a lower treatment-related mortality (5.7% vs. 12.7%; <em>

7517P</em>

7518 = .068), although the improved OS, EFS, and RR outcomes did not reach statistical significance.</li>

7519</ul>

7520</div>

7521</li>

7522</ol>

7523</div>

7524</section>

7525<section id="_926">

7526<h5 id="_926_toc">

7527Hospitalization</h5>

7528<p id="_882" tabindex="-1">

7529Hospitalization until adequate granulocyte (absolute neutrophil or phagocyte count) recovery has been used to reduce treatment-related mortality. The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002798">

7530COG-2961 (NCT00002798)</a>

7531 trial was the first to note a significant reduction in treatment-related mortality (19% before mandatory hospitalization was instituted in the trial along with other supportive care changes vs. 12% afterward); OS was also improved in this trial (<em>

7532P</em>

7533 &lt;.001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

75343</a>

7535] Another analysis of the impact of hospitalization using a survey of institutional routine practice found that those who mandated hospitalization had nonsignificant reduction in patients' treatment-related mortality (adjusted HR, 0.60 [0.26&#8211;1.36, <em>

7536P</em>

7537 = .22]) compared with institutions who had no set policy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

753845</a>

7539] Although there was no significant benefit seen in this study, the authors noted the limitations, including its methodology (survey), an inability to validate cases, and limited power to detect differences in treatment-related mortality. To avoid prolonged hospitalizations until count recovery, some institutions have used outpatient IV antibiotic prophylaxis effectively.[<a href="#cit/section_5.44">

754044</a>

7541]</p>

7542</section>

7543</section>

7544<section id="_927">

7545<h4 id="_927_toc">

7546Induction failure (refractory AML)</h4>

7547<p id="_928" tabindex="-1">

7548Induction failure (the morphological presence of 5% or greater marrow blasts at the end of all induction courses) is seen in 10% to 15% of children with AML. Subsequent outcomes for patients with induction failure are similar to those for patients with AML who relapse early (&lt;12 months after remission).[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

754960</a>

7550,<a href="#cit/section_5.61">

755161</a>

7552] </p>

7553</section>

7554<section id="_175">

7555<h4 id="_175_toc">

7556Granulocytic sarcoma/chloroma</h4>

7557<p id="_157" tabindex="-1">

7558Granulocytic sarcoma (chloroma) describes extramedullary collections of leukemia cells. These collections can occur, albeit rarely, as the sole evidence of leukemia. In a review of three AML studies conducted by the former Children's Cancer Group, fewer than 1% of patients had isolated granulocytic sarcoma, and 11% had granulocytic sarcoma along with marrow disease at the time of diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.62">

755962</a>

7560] This incidence was also seen in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00476541">

7561NOPHO-AML 2004 (NCT00476541)</a>

7562 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.63">

756363</a>

7564]</p>

7565<p id="_1174" tabindex="-1">

7566Importantly, the patient who presents with an isolated tumor, without evidence of marrow involvement, must be treated as if there is systemic disease. Patients with isolated granulocytic sarcoma have a good prognosis if treated with current AML therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.62">

756762</a>

7568]</p>

7569<p id="_567" tabindex="-1">

7570In a study of 1,459 children with newly diagnosed AML, patients with orbital granulocytic sarcoma and central nervous system (CNS) granulocytic sarcoma had better survival than did patients with marrow disease and granulocytic sarcoma at other sites and AML patients without any extramedullary disease.[<a href="#cit/section_5.63">

757163</a>

7572,<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

757364</a>

7574] Most patients with orbital granulocytic sarcoma have a t(8;21) abnormality, which has been associated with a favorable prognosis. The use of radiation therapy does not improve survival in patients with granulocytic sarcoma who have a complete response to chemotherapy, but may be necessary if the site(s) of granulocytic sarcoma do not show complete response to chemotherapy or for disease that recurs locally.[<a href="#cit/section_5.62">

757562</a>

7576]</p>

7577</section>

7578</section>

7579<section id="_60">

7580<h3 id="_60_toc">

7581Central Nervous System (CNS) Prophylaxis for AML</h3>

7582<p id="_883" tabindex="-1">

7583CNS involvement in patients with AML and its impact on prognosis has been discussed above in the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_183">

7584Prognostic Factors in Childhood AML</a>

7585 section. Therapy with either radiation or intrathecal chemotherapy has been used to treat CNS leukemia present at diagnosis and to prevent later development of CNS leukemia. The use of radiation has essentially been abandoned as a means of prophylaxis because of the lack of documented benefit and long-term sequelae.[<a href="#cit/section_5.65">

758665</a>

7587] The COG has used single-agent cytarabine for both CNS prophylaxis and therapy. Other groups have attempted to prevent CNS relapse by using additional intrathecal agents. </p>

7588<p id="_929" tabindex="-1">

7589Evidence (CNS prophylaxis):</p>

7590<div class="pdq-content-list">

7591<ol id="_930">

7592<li>

7593The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

7594AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

7595 trial used single-agent cytarabine for prophylaxis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

759666</a>

7597]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7598<ul id="_931">

7599<li>

7600As opposed to the low relapse rate associated with CNS1 disease (3.9%) seen in the 71% of enrolled patients, patients who had minimal evidence of CNS leukemia at diagnosis (CNS2 or blasts present when CSF WBC was &lt;5 cells/HPF; 16% of newly diagnosed patients) were given twice-weekly intrathecal cytarabine until the CSF cleared. For the 96% of CNS2 patients whose CSF (95.8%) was cleared of leukemic blasts, 11.7% later experienced CNS relapse.</li>

7601<li>

7602CNS3 involvement at diagnosis (13%) conferred even worse outcomes. Despite clearing of leukemic blasts in 90.7% of children, 17.7% later experienced a CNS relapse. In a multivariate analysis, the presence of CNS3 involvement significantly worsened isolated CNS relapse risk (HR, 7.82; <em>

7603P</em>

7604 = .003).</li>

7605</ul>

7606</div>

7607</li>

7608<li>

7609Another methodology uses additional intrathecal agents, including <em>

7610triples</em>

7611, a combination of intrathecal cytarabine, hydrocortisone, and methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_5.67">

761267</a>

7613]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7614<ul id="_932">

7615<li>

7616The SJCRH reported that after switching from <em>

7617triples</em>

7618 (their previous standard treatment) to single-agent cytarabine, the incidence of isolated CNS relapse increased from 0% (0 of 131 patients) to 9% (3 of 33 patients), prompting them to return to <em>

7619triples</em>

7620, which then reproduced a 0% (0 of 79 patients) CNS relapse rate.</li>

7621</ul>

7622</div>

7623</li>

7624</ol>

7625</div>

7626</section>

7627<section id="_176">

7628<h3 id="_176_toc">

7629 Postremission Therapy for AML </h3>

7630<p id="_177" tabindex="-1">

7631A major challenge in the treatment of children with AML is to prolong the duration of the initial remission with additional chemotherapy or HSCT.</p>

7632<p id="_1068" tabindex="-1">

7633Treatment options for children with AML in postremission may include the following:</p>

7634<div class="pdq-content-list">

7635<ol id="_1069">

7636<li>

7637<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_952">

7638Chemotherapy</a>

7639.</li>

7640<li>

7641<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_954">

7642HSCT</a>

7643.</li>

7644<li>

7645Targeted therapy (e.g., FLT3 inhibitors).[<a href="#cit/section_5.68">

764668</a>

7647]</li>

7648</ol>

7649</div>

7650<section id="_952">

7651<h4 id="_952_toc">

7652Chemotherapy</h4>

7653<p id="_953" tabindex="-1">

7654Postremission chemotherapy includes some of the drugs used in induction while also introducing non&#8211;cross-resistant drugs and, commonly, high-dose cytarabine. Studies in adults with AML have demonstrated that consolidation with a high-dose cytarabine regimen improves outcome compared with consolidation with a standard-dose cytarabine regimen, particularly in patients with inv(16) and t(8;21) AML subtypes.[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

765569</a>

7656] For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/adult-aml-treatment-pdq#_67">

7657Treatment of AML in Remission</a>

7658 section in Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment. Randomized studies evaluating the contribution of high-dose cytarabine to postremission therapy have not been conducted in children, but studies employing historical controls suggest that consolidation with a high-dose cytarabine regimen improves outcome compared with less-intensive consolidation therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

765911</a>

7660,<a href="#cit/section_5.70">

766170</a>

7662,<a href="#cit/section_5.71">

766371</a>

7664]</p>

7665<p id="_605" tabindex="-1">

7666The optimal number of postremission courses of therapy remains unclear, but appears to require at least two to three courses of intensive therapy after induction.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

76673</a>

7668]</p>

7669<p id="_1208" tabindex="-1">

7670Evidence (number of postremission courses of chemotherapy):</p>

7671<div class="pdq-content-list">

7672<ol id="_1209">

7673<li>

7674A United Kingdom Medical Research Council (MRC) study randomly assigned adult and pediatric patients to either four or five courses of intensive therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

76756</a>

7676,<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

767716</a>

7678][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7679Level of evidence A1</a>

7680]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7681<ul id="_1987">

7682<li>

7683 Five courses of therapy did not show an advantage for relapse-free survival and OS.</li>

7684</ul>

7685</div>

7686</li>

7687<li>

7688Based on this MRC data, in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371981">

7689AAML1031 (NCT01371981)</a>

7690 trial, non&#8211;high-risk patients treated without HSCT in first CR (73% of all patients) received four cycles of chemotherapy (two induction cycles and two consolidation cycles) rather than five cycles (two induction cycles and three consolidation cycles); in the previous COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372593">

7691AAML0531 (NCT00372593)</a>

7692 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00070174">

7693AAML03P1 (NCT00070174)</a>

7694 trials, patients who did not undergo HSCT received five cycles of chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.72">

769572</a>

7696] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7697<ul id="_1210">

7698<li>

7699In a retrospective analysis, non&#8211;high-risk patients treated without HSCT on the COG AAML1031 trial (four chemotherapy cycles) had significantly worse outcomes than did those who had received five cycles of chemotherapy on the AAML0531 trial (four- vs. five-cycle outcomes):<div class="pdq-content-list">

7700<ul id="_2084">

7701<li>

7702The OS rate was 77.0% for patients who received four chemotherapy cycles, compared with 83.5% for patients who received five chemotherapy cycles (HR, 1.45; 95% CI, 0.97&#8211;2.17; <em>

7703P</em>

7704 = .068).</li>

7705<li>

7706The DFS rate was 56% for patients who received four cycles, compared with 67% for patients who received five cycles (HR, 1.45; 95% CI, 1.10&#8211;1.91; <em>

7707P</em>

7708 = .009).</li>

7709<li>

7710The relapse rate was 40.9% for patients who received four cycles, compared with 31.4% for patients who received five cycles (HR, 1.40; 95% CI, 1.06&#8211;1.85; <em>

7711P</em>

7712 = .019).</li>

7713</ul>

7714</div>

7715</li>

7716<li>

7717An exception was found in the low-risk subgroup defined by favorable cytogenetics or molecular genetics who were MRD negative at the end of induction cycle 1. This subset of patients had similar outcomes regardless of whether they received four chemotherapy cycles (AAML1031) or five chemotherapy cycles (AAML0531).</li>

7718</ul>

7719</div>

7720<p id="_1211" tabindex="-1">

7721Additional study of the number of intensification courses and specific agents used will better address this issue, but these data suggest that four chemotherapy courses should only be administered to the favorable group described above, and that all other patients who do not undergo HSCT should receive five chemotherapy courses.</p>

7722</li>

7723</ol>

7724</div>

7725</section>

7726<section id="_954">

7727<h4 id="_954_toc">

7728HSCT</h4>

7729<p id="_178" tabindex="-1">

7730The use of HSCT in first remission has been under evaluation since the late 1970s, and evidence-based appraisals concerning indications for autologous and allogeneic HSCT have been published. Prospective trials of transplantation in children with AML suggest that overall, 60% to 70% of children with HLA-matched donors available who undergo allogeneic HSCT during their first remission experience long-term remissions,[<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

773110</a>

7732,<a href="#cit/section_5.73">

773373</a>

7734] with the caveat that outcome after allogeneic HSCT is dependent on risk-classification status.[<a href="#cit/section_5.74">

773574</a>

7736]</p>

7737<p id="_1102" tabindex="-1">

7738 In prospective trials that compared allogeneic HSCT with chemotherapy and/or autologous HSCT, superior DFS rates were observed for patients who were assigned to allogeneic HSCT on the basis of family 6/6 or 5/6 HLA-matched donors in adults and children.[<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

773910</a>

7740,<a href="#cit/section_5.73">

774173</a>

7742,<a href="#cit/section_5.75">

774375</a>

7744-<a href="#cit/section_5.79">

774579</a>

7746] However, the superiority of allogeneic HSCT over chemotherapy has not always been observed.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

774780</a>

7748] Several large cooperative group clinical trials for children with AML have found no benefit for autologous HSCT over intensive chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

774910</a>

7750,<a href="#cit/section_5.73">

775173</a>

7752,<a href="#cit/section_5.75">

775375</a>

7754,<a href="#cit/section_5.77">

775577</a>

7756]</p>

7757<p id="_179" tabindex="-1">

7758 Current application of allogeneic HSCT involves incorporation of risk classification to determine whether transplantation should be pursued in first remission. Because of the improved outcome in patients with favorable prognostic features (low-risk cytogenetic or molecular mutations) receiving contemporary chemotherapy regimens and the lack of demonstrable superiority for HSCT in this patient population, this group of patients typically receives matched-family donor (MFD) HSCT only after first relapse and the achievement of a second CR.[<a href="#cit/section_5.74">

775974</a>

7760,<a href="#cit/section_5.81">

776181</a>

7762-<a href="#cit/section_5.83">

776383</a>

7764] </p>

7765<p id="_2055" tabindex="-1">

7766An analysis from the Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research (CIBMTR) examined pretransplant variables to create a model for predicting leukemia-free survival (LFS) posttransplant in pediatric patients (aged &lt;18 years). All patients were first transplant recipients who had myeloablative conditioning, and all stem cells sources were included. For patients with AML, the predictors associated with lower LFS included age younger than 3 years, intermediate-risk or poor-risk cytogenetics, and second CR or higher with MRD positivity or not in CR. A scale was established to stratify patients on the basis of risk factors to predict survival. The 5-year LFS rate was 78% for the low-risk group, 53% for the intermediate-risk group, 40% for the high-risk group, and 25% for the very high-risk group.[<a href="#cit/section_5.84">

776784</a>

7768]</p>

7769<p id="_397" tabindex="-1">

7770There is conflicting evidence regarding the role of allogeneic HSCT in first remission for patients with intermediate-risk characteristics (neither low-risk or high-risk cytogenetics or molecular mutations):</p>

7771<p id="_955" tabindex="-1">

7772Evidence (allogeneic HSCT in first remission for patients with intermediate-risk AML):</p>

7773<div class="pdq-content-list">

7774<ol id="_956">

7775<li>

7776A study combining the results of the POG-8821, CCG-2891, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002798">

7777COG-2961 (NCT00002798)</a>

7778, and MRC AML10 studies identified a DFS and OS advantage for allogeneic HSCT in patients with intermediate-risk AML

7779but not favorable-risk (inv(16) and t(8;21)) or poor-risk AML (del(5q), monosomy 5 or 7, or more than 15% blasts after first induction for POG/CCG studies); the MRC study included patients with 3q abnormalities and complex cytogenetics in the high-risk category.[<a href="#cit/section_5.74">

778074</a>

7781] Weaknesses of this study include the large percentage of patients not assigned to a risk group and the relatively low EFS and OS rates for patients with intermediate-risk AML assigned to chemotherapy, as compared with results observed in more recent clinical trials.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

77826</a>

7783,<a href="#cit/section_5.17">

778417</a>

7785]</li>

7786<li>

7787The AML99 clinical trial from the Japanese Childhood AML Cooperative Study Group observed a significant difference in DFS for intermediate-risk patients assigned to MFD HSCT, but there was not a significant difference in OS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.85">

778885</a>

7789]</li>

7790<li>

7791The AML-BFM 99 clinical trial demonstrated no significant difference in either DFS or OS for intermediate-risk patients assigned to MFD HSCT versus those assigned to chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

779280</a>

7793]</li>

7794</ol>

7795</div>

7796<p id="_700" tabindex="-1">

7797Given the improved outcome for patients with intermediate-risk AML in recent clinical trials and the burden of acute and chronic toxicities associated with allogeneic transplantation, many childhood AML treatment groups (including the COG) employ chemotherapy for intermediate-risk patients in first remission and reserve allogeneic HSCT for use after potential relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

77986</a>

7799,<a href="#cit/section_5.85">

780085</a>

7801,<a href="#cit/section_5.86">

780286</a>

7803] </p>

7804<p id="_701" tabindex="-1">

7805There are conflicting data regarding the role of allogeneic HSCT in first remission for patients with <em>

7806high-risk</em>

7807 disease, complicated by the differing definitions of high risk used by different study groups.</p>

7808<p id="_957" tabindex="-1">

7809Evidence (allogeneic HSCT in first remission for patients with high-risk AML):</p>

7810<div class="pdq-content-list">

7811<ol id="_958">

7812<li>

7813A retrospective analysis from the COG and CIBMTR compared chemotherapy only with matched-related donor and matched-unrelated donor HSCT for patients with AML and high-risk cytogenetics, defined as monosomy 7/del(7q), monosomy 5/del(5q), abnormalities of 3q, t(6;9), or complex karyotypes.[<a href="#cit/section_5.87">

781487</a>

7815] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7816<ul id="_1175">

7817<li>

7818The analysis demonstrated no difference in the 5-year OS among the three treatment groups.</li>

7819</ul>

7820</div>

7821</li>

7822<li>

7823A Nordic Society for Pediatric Hematology and Oncology study reported that time-intensive reinduction therapy followed by transplant with best available donor for patients whose AML did not respond to induction therapy resulted in 70% survival at a median follow-up of 2.6 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.88">

782488</a>

7825][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7826Level of evidence B4</a>

7827]</li>

7828<li>

7829A single-institution retrospective study of 36 consecutive patients (aged 0&#8211;30 years) with high-risk AML (<em class="gene-name">

7830FLT3</em>

7831 ITD, 11q23 <em class="gene-name">

7832KMT2A</em>

7833 rearrangements, presence of chromosome 5 or 7 abnormalities, induction failure, persistent disease), who were in a morphological first remission before allogeneic transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

783489</a>

7835]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7836<ul id="_1176">

7837<li>

7838The investigators reported a 5-year OS rate of 72% and a LFS rate (from the time of transplant) of 69% with the use of a myeloablative conditioning regimen.</li>

7839<li>

7840They also reported a treatment-related mortality rate of 17%.</li>

7841<li>

7842These outcomes were similar to 14 standard-risk AML patients who underwent transplantation during the same time period.</li>

7843</ul>

7844</div>

7845</li>

7846<li>

7847A subgroup analysis from the AML-BFM 98 clinical trial demonstrated improved survival rates for patients with 11q23 aberrations allocated to allogeneic HSCT, but not for patients without 11q23 aberrations.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

784880</a>

7849]</li>

7850<li>

7851For children with <em class="gene-name">

7852FLT3</em>

7853 ITD (high-allelic ratio), patients who received MFD HSCT (n = 6) had higher OS rates than did patients who received standard chemotherapy (n = 28); however, the number of cases studied limited the ability to draw conclusions.[<a href="#cit/section_5.90">

785490</a>

7855] </li>

7856<li>

7857A subsequent retrospective report from three consecutive trials in young adults with AML found that patients with <em class="gene-name">

7858FLT3</em>

7859 ITD high-allelic ratio benefited from allogeneic HSCT (<em>

7860P</em>

7861 =.03), whereas patients with low-allelic ratio did not (<em>

7862P</em>

7863 = .64).[<a href="#cit/section_5.91">

786491</a>

7865] </li>

7866<li>

7867A subset analysis of the COG phase III trial evaluated gemtuzumab ozogamicin during induction therapy in children with newly diagnosed AML.[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

786825</a>

7869]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7870<ul id="_1177">

7871<li>

7872For patients with <em class="gene-name">

7873FLT3</em>

7874 ITD high-allelic ratio who received HSCT, a lower relapse rate was observed for those who also received gemtuzumab ozogamicin (15% vs. 53%, <em>

7875P</em>

7876 = .007).</li>

7877<li>

7878Conversely, patients who received gemtuzumab ozogamicin had higher rates of treatment-related mortality (19% vs. 7%, <em>

7879P</em>

7880 = .08), resulting in overall improved DFS (65% vs. 40%, <em>

7881P</em>

7882 = .08).</li>

7883</ul>

7884</div>

7885</li>

7886</ol>

7887</div>

7888<p id="_490" tabindex="-1">

7889Many, but not all, pediatric clinical trial groups prescribe allogeneic HSCT for high-risk patients in first remission.[<a href="#cit/section_5.83">

789083</a>

7891] For example, the COG frontline AML clinical trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01371981">

7892COG-AAML1031</a>

7893) prescribes allogeneic HSCT in first remission only for patients with predicted high risk of treatment failure based on unfavorable cytogenetic and molecular characteristics and elevated end-of-induction MRD levels. On the other hand, the AML-BFM trials restrict allogeneic HSCT to patients in second CR and to refractory AML. This was based on results from their AML-BFM 98 study, which found no improvement in DFS or OS for high-risk patients receiving allogeneic HSCT in first CR, as well as the successful treatment using HSCT for a substantial proportion of patients who achieved a second CR.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

789480</a>

7895,<a href="#cit/section_5.92">

789692</a>

7897] Additionally, late sequelae (e.g., cardiomyopathy, skeletal anomalies, and liver dysfunction or cirrhosis) were increased for children undergoing allogeneic HSCT in first remission on the AML-BFM 98 study.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

789880</a>

7899]</p>

7900<p id="_703" tabindex="-1">

7901Because definitions of high-, intermediate-, and low-risk AML are evolving because of the ongoing association of molecular characteristics of the tumor with outcome (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

7902FLT3</em>

7903 ITD, <em class="gene-name">

7904WT1</em>

7905 mutations, and <em class="gene-name">

7906NPM1</em>

7907 mutations) and response to therapy (e.g., MRD assessments postinduction therapy), further analysis of subpopulations of patients treated with allogeneic HSCT will be an ongoing need in current and future clinical trials.</p>

7908<p id="_648" tabindex="-1">

7909If transplant is chosen in first CR, the optimal preparative regimen and source of donor cells has not been determined, although alternative donor sources, including haploidentical donors, are being studied.[<a href="#cit/section_5.79">

791079</a>

7911,<a href="#cit/section_5.93">

791293</a>

7913,<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

791494</a>

7915] There are no data that suggest total-body irradiation (TBI) is superior to busulfan-based myeloablative regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

791680</a>

7917,<a href="#cit/section_5.81">

791881</a>

7919] Additionally, outstanding outcomes have been noted for patients who were treated with treosulfan-based regimens; however, trials comparing treosulfan with busulfan or TBI are lacking.[<a href="#cit/section_5.95">

792095</a>

7921]</p>

7922<p id="_1103" tabindex="-1">

7923Evidence (myeloablative regimen):</p>

7924<div class="pdq-content-list">

7925<ol id="_1104">

7926<li>

7927A randomized trial that compared busulfan plus fludarabine with busulfan plus cyclophosphamide as a preparative regimen for AML in first CR demonstrated that the former regimen was associated with less toxicity and comparable DFS and OS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.96">

792896</a>

7929]</li>

7930<li>

7931In addition, a large prospective CIBMTR cohort study of children and adults with AML, myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), and chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) showed superior survival of patients with <em>

7932early-stage</em>

7933 disease (chronic-phase CML, first CR AML, and MDS-refractory anemia) with busulfan-based regimens compared with TBI.[<a href="#cit/section_5.97">

793497</a>

7935]</li>

7936<li>

7937A CIBMTR study of 624 children with de novo AML who underwent transplantation between 2008 and 2016 and received either a TBI-based regimen (n = 199) or non-TBI&#8211;containing regimen (n = 425) demonstrated the following results:[<a href="#cit/section_5.98">

793898</a>

7939]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7940<ul id="_2082">

7941<li>

7942TBI recipients had a higher nonrelapse mortality (<em>

7943P</em>

7944 &lt; .0001) with lower relapse (<em>

7945P</em>

7946 &lt; .0001), culminating in equivalent LFS and OS rates. </li>

7947<li>

7948TBI recipients experienced more grades 2 to 3 acute GVHD (56% vs. 27%; <em>

7949P</em>

7950 &lt; .0001) but had equivalent chronic GVHD incidence.</li>

7951<li>

7952TBI recipient survivors had a greater incidence of gonadal or growth deficiency (24% vs. 8%; <em>

7953P</em>

7954 &lt; .0001), but there were no differences seen in pulmonary, cardiac, or renal impairment.</li>

7955</ul>

7956</div>

7957 </li>

7958</ol>

7959</div>

7960<p id="_180" tabindex="-1">

7961Other than the APL subtype, there are no data that demonstrate that maintenance therapy given after intensive postremission therapy significantly prolongs remission duration. Maintenance chemotherapy failed to show benefit in two randomized studies that used modern intensive consolidation therapy,[<a href="#cit/section_5.70">

796270</a>

7963,<a href="#cit/section_5.99">

796499</a>

7965] and maintenance therapy with interleukin-2 also proved ineffective.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

79663</a>

7967]</p>

7968</section>

7969<section id="_TrialSearch_176_sid_7">

7970<h4 id="_TrialSearch_176_sid_7_toc">

7971Current Clinical Trials</h4>

7972<p id="_TrialSearch_176_22" tabindex="-1">

7973Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

7974advanced clinical trial search</a>

7975 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

7976General information</a>

7977 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

7978</section>

7979</section>

7980<section id="_94">

7981<h3 id="_94_toc">

7982Recurrent or Refractory Childhood AML and Other Myeloid Malignancies</h3>

7983<p id="_739" tabindex="-1">

7984The diagnosis of recurrent or relapsed AML according to COG criteria is essentially the same as the criteria for making the diagnosis of AML. Usually this is defined as patients having more than 5% bone marrow blasts who were in previous remission after therapy for a diagnosis of AML according to WHO classification criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_5.100">

7985100</a>

7986,<a href="#cit/section_5.101">

7987101</a>

7988]</p>

7989<p id="_1028" tabindex="-1">

7990Despite second remission induction in over one-half of children with AML treated with drugs similar to drugs used in initial

7991induction therapy, the prognosis for a child with recurrent or progressive AML

7992is generally poor.[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

799360</a>

7994,<a href="#cit/section_5.102">

7995102</a>

7996] </p>

7997<section id="_1029">

7998<h4 id="_1029_toc">

7999Recurrent childhood AML</h4>

8000<p id="_1030" tabindex="-1">

8001Approximately 50% to 60% of relapses occur within the

8002first year after diagnosis, with most relapses occurring by 4 years from

8003diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.102">

8004102</a>

8005] The <strong>

8006vast</strong>

8007 majority of relapses occur in the bone marrow, and CNS

8008relapse is very uncommon.[<a href="#cit/section_5.102">

8009102</a>

8010] </p>

8011<section id="_1035">

8012<h5 id="_1035_toc">

8013Prognosis and prognostic factors</h5>

8014<p id="_1036" tabindex="-1">

8015Factors affecting the ability to attain a second remission include the following:</p>

8016<div class="pdq-content-list">

8017<ul id="_1037">

8018<li>

8019<strong>

8020Length of first remission.</strong>

8021 Length of first remission is an important

8022factor affecting the ability to attain a second remission; children with a

8023first remission of less than 1 year have substantially lower rates of

8024second remission (50%&#8211;60%) than children whose first remission is greater than 1 year (70%&#8211;90%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

802560</a>

8026,<a href="#cit/section_5.103">

8027103</a>

8028,<a href="#cit/section_5.104">

8029104</a>

8030] Survival for children with shorter first

8031remissions is also substantially lower (approximately 10%) than that for

8032children with first remissions exceeding 1 year (approximately 40%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

803360</a>

8034,<a href="#cit/section_5.103">

8035103</a>

8036-<a href="#cit/section_5.105">

8037105</a>

8038] The Therapeutic Advances in Childhood Leukemia and Lymphoma Consortium also identified duration of previous remission as a powerful prognostic factor, with 5-year OS rates of 54% (&#177; 10%) for patients with greater than 12 months first remission duration and 19% (&#177; 6%) for patients with shorter periods of first remission.[<a href="#cit/section_5.106">

8039106</a>

8040] In this same analysis, outcomes, primarily in early relapsing patients, declined with each attempt to reinduce remission (56% &#177; 5%, 25% &#177; 8%, and 17% &#177; 7% for each consecutive attempt).</li>

8041<li>

8042<strong>

8043Molecular alterations.</strong>

8044 In addition, specific molecular alterations at the time of relapse have been reported to impact subsequent survival. For instance, the presence of either <em class="gene-name">

8045WT1</em>

8046 or <em class="gene-name">

8047FLT3</em>

8048 ITD mutations at first relapse were associated, as independent risk factors, with worse OS in patients achieving a second remission.[<a href="#cit/section_5.107">

8049107</a>

8050]</li>

8051</ul>

8052</div>

8053<p id="_1038" tabindex="-1">

8054Additional prognostic factors were identified in the following studies:</p>

8055<div class="pdq-content-list">

8056<ul id="_1039">

8057<li>

8058In a report of 379 children with AML who relapsed after initial treatment on the German BFM group protocols, a second complete remission rate was 63% and the OS rate was 23%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.108">

8059108</a>

8060][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8061Level of evidence C1</a>

8062] The most significant prognostic factors associated with a favorable outcome after relapse included achieving second complete remission, a relapse greater than 12 months from initial diagnosis, no allogeneic bone marrow transplant in first remission, and favorable cytogenetics (t(8;21), t(15;17), and inv(16)).</li>

8063<li>

8064The international <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00186966">

8065Relapsed AML 2001/01 (NCT00186966)</a>

8066 trial also found that early response to salvage therapy was highly prognostic.[<a href="#cit/section_5.109">

8067109</a>

8068][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8069Level of evidence C2</a>

8070]</li>

8071<li>

8072A retrospective study of 71 patients with relapsed AML from Japan reported a 5-year OS rate of 37%. Patients who had an early relapse had a 27% second remission rate compared with 88% for patients who had a late relapse. The 5-year OS rate was higher in patients who underwent HSCT after achieving a second complete remission (66%) than in patients not in remission (17%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.105">

8073105</a>

8074]</li>

8075<li>

8076Patients who relapsed on two consecutive Nordic Society of Pediatric Hematology and Oncology (NOPHO) AML trials between 1993 to 2012 were analyzed for survival (208 patients relapsed of 543 children initially treated). Second remissions were achieved in 146 children (70%) with a variety of reinduction regimens. The 5-year OS rate was 39%. Favorable prognostic factors included late relapse (&#8805;1 year from diagnosis), no HSCT in first remission, and a core-binding factor AML subtype. For the children in second remission who underwent HSCT, the 5-year OS rate was 61%, as opposed to a 5-year OS rate of 18% for those who did not include HSCT in their therapy (<em>

8077P</em>

8078 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.110">

8079110</a>

8080]</li>

8081</ul>

8082</div>

8083</section>

8084<section id="_1040">

8085<h5 id="_1040_toc">

8086Treatment of recurrent AML</h5>

8087<p id="_1070" tabindex="-1">

8088Treatment options for children with recurrent AML may include the following:</p>

8089<div class="pdq-content-list">

8090<ol id="_1071">

8091<li>

8092<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1341">

8093Chemotherapy</a>

8094.</li>

8095<li>

8096<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1958">

8097Immunotherapeutic approaches</a>

8098.</li>

8099<li>

8100<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1961">

8101Targeted therapy (FLT3 inhibitors)</a>

8102.</li>

8103<li>

8104<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1346">

8105HSCT</a>

8106.</li>

8107<li>

8108<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1350">

8109Second transplant after relapse following a first transplant</a>

8110.</li>

8111</ol>

8112</div>

8113<section id="_1341">

8114<h6 id="_1341_toc">

8115Chemotherapy</h6>

8116<p id="_1342" tabindex="-1">

8117Regimens that have been successfully used to induce remission in children with

8118recurrent AML have commonly included high-dose cytarabine given in combination

8119with the following agents:</p>

8120<div class="pdq-content-list">

8121<ul id="_1343">

8122<li>

8123Mitoxantrone.[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

812460</a>

8125]</li>

8126<li>

8127Fludarabine and idarubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_5.111">

8128111</a>

8129]</li>

8130<li>

8131L-asparaginase.[<a href="#cit/section_5.112">

8132112</a>

8133]</li>

8134<li>

8135Etoposide.</li>

8136<li>

8137Liposomal daunorubicin. A study by the International BFM group compared fludarabine, cytarabine, and G-CSF (FLAG) with FLAG plus liposomal daunorubicin. The 4-year OS rate was 38%, with no difference in survival for the total group; however, the addition of liposomal daunorubicin increased the likelihood of obtaining a remission and led to significant improvement in OS in patients with core-binding factor mutations (82%, FLAG plus liposomal daunorubicin vs. 58%, FLAG; <em>

8138P</em>

8139 = .04).[<a href="#cit/section_5.113">

8140113</a>

8141][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8142Level of evidence A1</a>

8143]</li>

8144<li>

8145CPX-351. The liposomal combination agent CPX-351, which utilizes a fixed combination of daunorubicin and cytarabine, has been evaluated in the phase I/II COG trial <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02642965">

8146AAML1421 (NCT02642965)</a>

8147 for children with relapsed AML. CPX-351 (135 units/m<span class="sup">

81482</span>

8149/day and containing 60 mg/m<span class="sup">

81502</span>

8151 of daunorubicin) was administered without dexrazoxane in cycle 1 on days 1, 3, and 5 followed by a FLAG cycle. CPX-351 was well tolerated, with no unexpected toxicity, one dose-limiting toxicity (grade 3 ejection fraction decline that resolved), and no toxic mortality. A maculopapular rash occurred in 40% of patients. Among 37 evaluable patients, 75.7% had a CR/CRp/CRi response after the CPX-351 cycle, with 21 of 25 CR/CRp patients having no MRD after cycle 2, and 20 of 25 patients without MRD before HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.114">

8152114</a>

8153][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8154Level of evidence B4</a>

8155] </li>

8156<li>

8157Venetoclax. The SJCRH VENAML trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03194932">

8158NCT03194932</a>

8159) evaluated venetoclax, a selective inhibitor of BCL-2, in combination with cytarabine with or without idarubicin in pediatric patients with relapsed or refractory AML. The combination was well tolerated; the most common grades 3 and 4 adverse events were febrile neutropenia (66% of patients), blood stream infections (16% of patients), and invasive fungal infections (16% of patients). Among the 20 patients treated at the recommended phase II dose, 14 patients (70%) achieved a complete response with or without complete hematological recovery, and 2 patients (10%) achieved a partial response.</li>

8160</ul>

8161</div>

8162<p id="_1344" tabindex="-1">

8163Regimens built upon clofarabine and [<a href="#cit/section_5.115">

8164115</a>

8165-<a href="#cit/section_5.117">

8166117</a>

8167][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8168Level of evidence B4</a>

8169] 2-chloroadenosine have been used.[<a href="#cit/section_5.118">

8170118</a>

8171] The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00372619">

8172AAML0523 (NCT00372619)</a>

8173 trial evaluated the combination of clofarabine plus high-dose cytarabine in patients with relapsed AML; the response rate was 48% and the OS rate, with 21 of 23 responders undergoing HSCT, was 46%. MRD before HSCT was a strong predictor of survival.[<a href="#cit/section_5.119">

8174119</a>

8175][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8176Level of evidence B4</a>

8177]</p>

8178<p id="_1345" tabindex="-1">

8179The standard-dose cytarabine regimens used in the

8180United Kingdom MRC AML10 study for newly diagnosed children with AML (cytarabine and

8181daunorubicin plus either etoposide or thioguanine) have, when used in the setting of relapse, produced remission

8182rates similar to those achieved with high-dose cytarabine regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_5.104">

8183104</a>

8184]

8185In a COG phase II study, the addition of bortezomib to idarubicin plus low-dose cytarabine resulted in an overall CR rate of 57%, and the addition of bortezomib to etoposide and high-dose cytarabine resulted in an overall CR rate of 48%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.120">

8186120</a>

8187]</p>

8188</section>

8189<section id="_1958">

8190<h6 id="_1958_toc">

8191Immunotherapeutic approaches</h6>

8192<p id="_1959" tabindex="-1">

8193Before its FDA approval for use in children with de novo AML in 2020, gemtuzumab ozogamicin was approved for children with relapsed or refractory AML in patients aged 2 years and older. </p>

8194<div class="pdq-content-list">

8195<ul id="_1960">

8196<li>

8197The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00028899">

8198AAML00P2 (NCT00028899)</a>

8199 study established the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of gemtuzumab ozogamicin, when combined with mitoxantrone and high-dose cytarabine, as 3 mg/m<span class="sup">

82002</span>

8201; the MTD of gemtuzumab ozogamicin, when combined with Capizzi II based high-dose cytarabine, was 2 mg/m<span class="sup">

82022</span>

8203. [<a href="#cit/section_5.61">

820461</a>

8205]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8206<ul id="_2040">

8207<li>

8208These regimens produced an overall remission response rate of 45% (&#177;15%), a 1-year EFS rate of 38% (&#177;14%), and a 1-year OS rate of 53% (&#177;15%).</li>

8209<li>

8210Sinusoidal occlusion syndrome was seen in one patient with a previous SCT during the cycle containing gemtuzumab ozogamicin and in 4 of 28 patients during subsequent SCT (grade 1 in 2 patients, grade 3 in 1 patient, and grade 4 in 1 patient), all of whom recovered.</li>

8211<li>

8212In the dose-escalation portion of the U.K. Medical Research Council <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00006122">

8213AML15 (NCT00006122)</a>

8214 study for adults, the dose of gemtuzumab ozogamicin was escalated beyond 3 mg/m<span class="sup">

82152</span>

8216 per dose (the same MTD that was established in the AAML00P2 study) and administered with a conventional intensive chemotherapy backbone; this regimen was not feasible because of hepatotoxicity and delayed hematopoietic recovery. Gemtuzumab ozogamicin at 3 mg/m<span class="sup">

82172</span>

8218 per dose, when given with consecutive courses of intensive chemotherapy, was also not tolerated.[<a href="#cit/section_5.121">

8219121</a>

8220]</li>

8221</ul>

8222</div>

8223</li>

8224<li>

8225The Relapsed AML 2001/02 study was a single-arm trial for children (n = 30) who experienced a second relapse or had refractory AML after they did not respond to a second induction regimen. Gemtuzumab ozogamicin as a single agent was dosed at 7.5 mg/dose (children younger than 3 years received 0.25 mg/kg) given every 14 days for two total doses. CR or CRp was seen in 37% of patients; nine patients subsequently underwent SCT, and three of these patients remained in continuous CR. All patients received prophylactic defibrotide during SCT without experiencing any sinusoidal occlusion syndrome (SOS).[<a href="#cit/section_5.122">

8226122</a>

8227]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8228<ul id="_2041">

8229<li>

8230In a prior study of children who received single-agent gemtuzumab ozogamicin, administered at 6 to 9 mg/m<span class="sup">

82312</span>

8232 per dose, patients did not receive defibrotide prophylaxis during subsequent SCT. These studies demonstrated an increased risk of SOS, particularly for patients who underwent SCT less than 3.5 months after the last dose of gemtuzumab ozogamicin.[<a href="#cit/section_5.123">

8233123</a>

8234] </li>

8235</ul>

8236</div>

8237</li>

8238<li>

8239Two prospective studies from the Acute Leukemia French Association (ALFA) group examined fractionated gemtuzumab ozogamicin (3 mg/m<span class="sup">

82402</span>

8241/dose on days 1, 4, and 7) in the relapsed adult AML setting. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8242<ul id="_2042" class="list-dash">

8243<li>

8244The MYLOFRANCE 1 trial evaluated single-agent fractionated dosing in 57 adults with AML in first relapse, which resulted in a CR rate of 26% and a CRp rate of 7%. No sinusoidal occlusion syndrome occurred during or in subsequent SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

8245124</a>

8246]</li>

8247<li>

8248Subsequently, the MYLOFRANCE 2 trial was a phase I/II study (n = 20) that combined the same fractionated dose of gemtuzumab ozogamicin with a dose-finding backbone of daunomycin and cytarabine. Nine patients achieved CR and two patients achieved a CRp. The recommended phase II dose was found to be 60 mg/m<span class="sup">

82492</span>

8250 per day for 3 days for daunomycin and 200 mg/m<span class="sup">

82512</span>

8252 per day for 7 days for cytarabine. No sinusoidal occlusion syndrome was experienced.[<a href="#cit/section_5.125">

8253125</a>

8254] Fractionated gemtuzumab ozogamicin dosing has been shown to be safe and effective in adults with de novo AML;[<a href="#cit/section_5.27">

825527</a>

8256] it is now being evaluated in the MyeChild01 (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02724163">

8257NCT02724163</a>

8258) phase III study for pediatric patients with de novo AML in the United Kingdom.</li>

8259</ul>

8260</div>

8261 </li>

8262</ul>

8263</div>

8264</section>

8265<section id="_1961">

8266<h6 id="_1961_toc">

8267Targeted therapy (FLT3 inhibitors)</h6>

8268<p id="_1977" tabindex="-1">

8269<strong>

8270Midostaurin.</strong>

8271 There is limited experience with midostaurin in pediatric patients with AML.</p>

8272<div class="pdq-content-list">

8273<ul id="_1978">

8274<li>

8275A phase I/II dose-escalation, single-agent trial in 22 children with refractory or relapsed AML (9 with <em class="gene-name">

8276FLT3</em>

8277 mutations) was reported. Seven patients received the initial dose level of 30 mg/m<span class="sup">

82782</span>

8279 given twice daily, and 15 patients received the higher dose level of 60 mg/m<span class="sup">

82802</span>

8281 twice daily, with a median dose duration of 16 days.[<a href="#cit/section_5.35">

828235</a>

8283]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8284<ul id="_1968">

8285<li>

8286Overall, 72.7% of patients experienced treatment-related adverse events, with only one patient experiencing a dose-limiting toxicity (grades 3&#8211;4 ALT elevation).</li>

8287<li>

8288In patients with <em class="gene-name">

8289FLT3</em>

8290-mutated AML, 55.5% (21.2%&#8211;86.3%) had some clinical response at a median time of 14 days (range, 8&#8211;22 days), with one patient achieving a complete remission with incomplete count recovery who was able to proceed to SCT; this patient was the only long-term survivor in this study.</li>

8291</ul>

8292</div>

8293</li>

8294<li>

8295A phase II trial is under way in Europe, beginning with the 30 mg/m<span class="sup">

82962</span>

8297 twice-daily dosing (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03591510">

8298NCT03591510</a>

8299).</li>

8300</ul>

8301</div>

8302<p id="_1962" tabindex="-1">

8303<strong>

8304Gilteritinib.</strong>

8305 As in de novo AML, most of the focus and published experience with FLT3 inhibitors is in adults with AML and this applies to the relapsed and refractory setting as well. In relapsed or refractory AML, gilteritinib, a type 1 selective FLT3 inhibitor with activity against both <em class="gene-name">

8306FLT3</em>

8307 mutations (ITD and D835/I836 tyrosine kinase domain [TKD]), is the first and only FLT3 inhibitor that has received FDA approval for single-agent use in adults based on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02421939">

8308ADMIRAL (NCT02421939)</a>

8309 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.126">

8310126</a>

8311] </p>

8312<div class="pdq-content-list">

8313<ul id="_1995">

8314<li>

8315In the phase III ADMIRAL trial of adults (aged 18 years and older) with relapsed or refractory <em class="gene-name">

8316FLT3</em>

8317-mutated AML, 247 patients were randomly assigned to receive either single-agent gilteritinib (120 mg/day given once daily) or one of four salvage chemotherapy regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_5.126">

8318126</a>

8319] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8320<ul id="_2029">

8321<li>

8322Median OS was significantly better in patients who received gilteritinib (9.3 months vs. 5.6 months; HR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;0.83; <em>

8323P</em>

8324 &lt; .001), with 37.1% versus 16.7% of patients alive at 1 year.</li>

8325<li>

8326Importantly, because SCT is felt to be essential for long-term survival in patients with <em class="gene-name">

8327FLT3</em>

8328-mutated AML, a higher percentage of gilteritinib recipients underwent a SCT (25.5% vs. 15.3%). It had equal efficacy in both <em class="gene-name">

8329FLT3</em>

8330 ITD and <em class="gene-name">

8331FLT3</em>

8332 TKD AML cohorts.</li>

8333<li>

8334There were fewer adverse events in patients who received gilteritinib than in patients who received salvage chemotherapy regimens; however, some patients who received gilteritinib had elevated hepatic transaminase levels. The main toxic effect was myelosuppression.</li>

8335</ul>

8336</div>

8337 </li>

8338</ul>

8339</div>

8340<p id="_2030" tabindex="-1">

8341Gilteritinib is now being studied in children with <em class="gene-name">

8342FLT3</em>

8343-positive de novo AML in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT04293562">

8344AAML1831 (NCT04293562)</a>

8345 trial.</p>

8346<p id="_1996" tabindex="-1">

8347<strong>

8348Sorafenib.</strong>

8349 Sorafenib has been evaluated in pediatric patients with relapsed and refractory AML. </p>

8350<div class="pdq-content-list">

8351<ul id="_1997">

8352<li>

8353In a phase I dose de-escalation trial of oral sorafenib in pediatric patients with relapsed or refractory acute leukemia, sorafenib was administered alone on days 1 to 7, and then in combination with clofarabine and high-dose cytarabine for 5 days, followed by single-agent sorafenib use until day 28.[<a href="#cit/section_5.127">

8354127</a>

8355]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8356<ul id="_2031">

8357<li>

8358The recommended phase II dose of sorafenib was determined to be 150 mg/m<span class="sup">

83592</span>

8360 per dose (maximum dose, 300 mg) twice daily (n = 6) after patients experienced significant hand-foot skin reactions (grades 2&#8211;3 in 4 of 4 patients; grade 3 dose-limiting toxicities [DLTs] in 2 of 4 patients) at the initial 200 mg/m<span class="sup">

83612</span>

8362 per dose, twice daily level (n = 4).</li>

8363<li>

8364Marrow blast reduction was seen in 10 of 12 total patients (4 of 5 patients with <em class="gene-name">

8365FLT3</em>

8366 ITD AML) at day 8.</li>

8367<li>

8368Of the 11 patients with AML, 6 patients achieved complete remissions (CR), 2 patients achieved complete remissions with incomplete blood count recovery (CRi), and 1 patient achieved a partial remission (PR) on or after day 22.</li>

8369<li>

8370All five patients with <em class="gene-name">

8371FLT3</em>

8372 ITD achieved either CR or CRi.</li>

8373</ul>

8374</div>

8375</li>

8376<li>

8377A retrospective analysis examined 15 children with AML who received sorafenib for either prophylaxis (n = 6) or relapse (n = 9) after SCT. Doses of sorafenib varied from 75 to 340 mg/m<span class="sup">

83782</span>

8379 per day (median dose, 230 mg/m<span class="sup">

83802</span>

8381) and was given alone in 11 of 15 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.128">

8382128</a>

8383]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8384<ul id="_2032">

8385<li>

8386Toxicity was seen in 11 patients, 7 of whom received doses higher than 200 mg/m<span class="sup">

83872</span>

8388; adverse events included count suppression (n = 6), hand-foot skin reactions (n = 6), cardiac dysfunction (n = 2), and others. </li>

8389<li>

8390Of the seven patients who experienced DLTs, six patients were able to restart or continue sorafenib treatment after dose adjustments.</li>

8391<li>

8392Sorafenib had the greatest efficacy in patients with MRD pre- or post-SCT (five of five patients remained disease free), whereas only one of the six patients who began sorafenib treatment for morphological recurrence remained in CR.</li>

8393<li>

8394Graft-versus-host disease was not exacerbated with sorafenib therapy.</li>

8395</ul>

8396</div>

8397</li>

8398</ul>

8399</div>

8400</section>

8401<section id="_1346">

8402<h6 id="_1346_toc">

8403HSCT</h6>

8404<p id="_1347" tabindex="-1">

8405The selection of additional treatment after the achievement of a second

8406complete remission depends on previous treatment and individual considerations.

8407Consolidation chemotherapy followed by HSCT is conventionally recommended, although there are no controlled prospective data regarding the contribution of additional courses of therapy once a second complete remission is obtained.[<a href="#cit/section_5.102">

8408102</a>

8409]</p>

8410<p id="_1348" tabindex="-1">

8411Evidence (HSCT after second complete remission):</p>

8412<div class="pdq-content-list">

8413<ol id="_1355">

8414<li>

8415The BFM group examined outcomes of children with AML over a 35-year period and found that the greatest improvement in overall outcome was the improvement in survival after relapse. This improved EFS after relapse or refractory disease was only seen in patients who received a SCT as part of their salvage therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.129">

8416129</a>

8417]</li>

8418<li>

8419Unrelated donor HSCT has been reported to result in 5-year probabilities of LFS of 45%, 20%, and 12% for patients with AML transplanted in second complete remission, overt relapse, and primary induction failure, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_5.130">

8420130</a>

8421][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8422Level of evidence C1</a>

8423]</li>

8424<li>

8425A number of studies, including a large, prospective CIBMTR cohort study of children and adults with myeloid diseases, have shown similar or superior survival with busulfan-based regimens compared with TBI.[<a href="#cit/section_5.97">

842697</a>

8427,<a href="#cit/section_5.98">

842898</a>

8429,<a href="#cit/section_5.131">

8430131</a>

8431,<a href="#cit/section_5.132">

8432132</a>

8433]</li>

8434<li>

8435Matched-sibling donor transplantation has generally led to the best outcomes, but use of single-antigen mismatched related or matched unrelated donors results in very similar survival at the cost of increased rates of GVHD and nonrelapse mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_5.133">

8436133</a>

8437] Umbilical cord outcomes are similar to other unrelated donor outcomes, but matching patients at a minimum of 7/8 alleles (HLA A, B, C, DRB1) leads to less nonrelapse mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_5.134">

8438134</a>

8439] Haploidentical approaches are being used with increasing frequency and have shown comparable outcomes to other stem cell sources in pediatrics.[<a href="#cit/section_5.135">

8440135</a>

8441] Direct comparison of haploidentical and other unrelated donor sources has not been performed in pediatrics, but studies in adults have shown similar outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_5.136">

8442136</a>

8443]</li>

8444<li>

8445Reduced-intensity approaches have been used successfully in pediatrics, but mainly in children unable to undergo myeloablative approaches.[<a href="#cit/section_5.137">

8446137</a>

8447] A randomized trial in adults showed superior outcomes with myeloablative approaches compared with reduced-intensity regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_5.138">

8448138</a>

8449]</li>

8450</ol>

8451</div>

8452</section>

8453<section id="_1350">

8454<h6 id="_1350_toc">

8455Second transplant after relapse following a first transplant</h6>

8456<p id="_1351" tabindex="-1">

8457There is evidence that long-term survival can be achieved in a portion of pediatric patients who undergo a second transplant subsequent to relapse after a first myeloablative transplant. Survival was associated with late relapse (&gt;6&#8211;12 months from first transplant), achievement of complete response before the second procedure, and use of a second myeloablative regimen if possible.[<a href="#cit/section_5.139">

8458139</a>

8459-<a href="#cit/section_5.142">

8460142</a>

8461]</p>

8462</section>

8463</section>

8464<section id="_363">

8465<h5 id="_363_toc">

8466CNS relapse</h5>

8467<p id="_366" tabindex="-1">

8468Isolated CNS relapse occurs in 3% to 6% of pediatric AML patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

846966</a>

8470,<a href="#cit/section_5.143">

8471143</a>

8472,<a href="#cit/section_5.144">

8473144</a>

8474] Factors associated with an increased risk of isolated CNS relapse include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_5.143">

8475143</a>

8476] </p>

8477<div class="pdq-content-list">

8478<ul id="_568">

8479<li>

8480Age younger than 2 years at initial diagnosis.</li>

8481<li>

8482M5 leukemia.</li>

8483<li>

848411q23 abnormalities.</li>

8485<li>

8486CNS2 or CNS3 involvement at initial diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

848766</a>

8488]</li>

8489</ul>

8490</div>

8491<p id="_569" tabindex="-1">

8492The risk of CNS relapse increases with more CNS leukemic involvement at initial AML diagnosis (CNS1: 0.6%, CNS2: 2.6%, CNS3: 5.8% incidence of isolated CNS relapse, <em>

8493P</em>

8494 &lt; .001; multivariate HR for CNS3: 7.82, <em>

8495P</em>

8496 = .0003).[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

849766</a>

8498] The outcome of isolated CNS relapse when treated as a systemic relapse is similar to that of bone marrow relapse. In one study, the 8-year OS rate for a cohort of children with an isolated CNS relapse was 26% (&#177; 16%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.143">

8499143</a>

8500] CNS relapse may also occur in the setting of bone marrow relapse and its likelihood increases with CNS involvement at diagnosis (CNS1: 2.7%, CNS2: 8.5%, CNS3: 9.2% incidence of concurrent CNS relapse, <em>

8501P</em>

8502 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

850366</a>

8504]</p>

8505</section>

8506</section>

8507<section id="_1031">

8508<h4 id="_1031_toc">

8509Refractory childhood AML (induction failure)</h4>

8510<p id="_1072" tabindex="-1">

8511Treatment options for children with refractory AML may include the following:</p>

8512<div class="pdq-content-list">

8513<ol id="_1073">

8514<li>

8515Chemotherapy.</li>

8516<li>

8517Gemtuzumab ozogamicin.</li>

8518</ol>

8519</div>

8520<p id="_1067" tabindex="-1">

8521Like patients with relapsed AML, induction failure patients are typically directed towards HSCT once they attain a remission, because studies suggest a better EFS than in patients treated with chemotherapy only (31.2% vs. 5%, <em>

8522P</em>

8523 &lt; .0001). Attainment of morphological CR for these patients is a significant prognostic factor for DFS after HSCT (46% vs. 0%; <em>

8524P</em>

8525 = .02), with failure primarily resulting from relapse (relapse risk, 53.9% vs. 88.9%; <em>

8526P</em>

8527 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_5.145">

8528145</a>

8529]</p>

8530<p id="_1046" tabindex="-1">

8531Evidence (treatment of refractory childhood AML with gemtuzumab ozogamicin):</p>

8532<div class="pdq-content-list">

8533<ol id="_1047">

8534<li>

8535In the SJCRH trial <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00136084">

8536AML02 (NCT00136084)</a>

8537, gemtuzumab ozogamicin was given alone (n = 17), typically where MRD was low but still detectable (0.1%&#8211;5.6%), or in combination with chemotherapy (n = 29) to those patients with high residual MRD (1%&#8211;97%) after the first induction cycle.[<a href="#cit/section_5.146">

8538146</a>

8539] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8540<ul id="_1074">

8541<li>

8542When given alone, 13 of 17 patients became MRD negative.</li>

8543<li>

8544When given in combination with chemotherapy, 13 of 29 patients became MRD negative and 28 of 29 patients had reductions in MRD.</li>

8545<li>

8546Compared with a nonrandomized cohort of patients with 1% to 25% MRD after induction 1, addition of gemtuzumab ozogamicin to chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone resulted in significant differences in MRD (<em>

8547P</em>

8548 = .03); MRD was eliminated or reduced in all patients who received gemtuzumab ozogamicin versus in only 82% of patients who did not receive gemtuzumab ozogamicin. This was seen despite higher postinduction 1 MRD levels in the cohort of patients who received gemtuzumab ozogamicin (median, 9.5% vs. 2.9% in the no gemtuzumab ozogamicin group, <em>

8549P</em>

8550 &lt; .01). There was a nonstatistically significant improvement in 5-year OS rates (55% &#177; 13.9% vs. 36.4% &#177; 9.7%, <em>

8551P</em>

8552 = .28) and EFS rates (50% &#177; 9.3% vs. 31.8% &#177; 13.4%, <em>

8553P</em>

8554 = .28).</li>

8555<li>

8556No impact on HSCT treatment-related mortality was seen.</li>

8557</ul>

8558</div>

8559</li>

8560<li>

8561In a phase II trial of gemtuzumab ozogamicin alone for children with relapsed/refractory AML failing previous reinduction attempts, 11 of 30 patients achieved a CR or partial CR, with a 27% versus 0% (<em>

8562P</em>

8563 = .001) 3-year OS rate for responders versus nonresponders.[<a href="#cit/section_5.122">

8564122</a>

8565]</li>

8566</ol>

8567</div>

8568<section id="_867">

8569<h5 id="_867_toc">

8570Treatment options under clinical evaluation</h5>

8571<p id="_868" tabindex="-1">

8572Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

8573NCI website</a>

8574. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

8575ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

8576.</p>

8577<p id="_1105" tabindex="-1">

8578The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

8579<div class="pdq-content-list">

8580<ol id="_893">

8581<li>

8582<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT04293562">

8583AAML1831 (NCT04293562)</a>

8584 (A Study to Compare Standard Chemotherapy to Therapy With CPX-351 and/or Gilteritinib for Patients With Newly Diagnosed AML With or Without <em class="gene-name">

8585FLT3</em>

8586 Mutations)<strong>

8587:</strong>

8588 This joint industry/COG study is a randomized trial examining whether the liposomal agent CPX-351, which contains daunomycin and cytarabine, improves EFS compared with standard daunomycin and cytarabine. An additional arm for patients with <em class="gene-name">

8589FLT3</em>

8590 ITD AML without favorable cytomolecular characteristics (<em class="gene-name">

8591NPM1</em>

8592 or <em class="gene-name">

8593CEBPA</em>

8594) evaluates the impact of the selective FLT3 inhibitor gilteritinib.</li>

8595</ol>

8596</div>

8597</section>

8598</section>

8599<section id="_TrialSearch_94_sid_8">

8600<h4 id="_TrialSearch_94_sid_8_toc">

8601Current Clinical Trials</h4>

8602<p id="_TrialSearch_94_22" tabindex="-1">

8603Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8604advanced clinical trial search</a>

8605 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8606General information</a>

8607 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8608</section>

8609</section>

8610<section id="_TrialSearch_52_sid_5">

8611<h3 id="_TrialSearch_52_sid_5_toc">

8612Current Clinical Trials</h3>

8613<p id="_TrialSearch_52_22" tabindex="-1">

8614Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8615advanced clinical trial search</a>

8616 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8617General information</a>

8618 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8619</section>

8653[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8654</li>

8655<li id="section_5.9">

8656Gamis AS, Alonzo TA, Meshinchi S, et al.: Gemtuzumab ozogamicin in children and adolescents with de novo acute myeloid leukemia improves event-free survival by reducing relapse risk: results from the randomized phase III Children&#8217;s Oncology Group trial AAML0531. J Clin Oncol 32 (27): 3021-32, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25092781&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25092781&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8657[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8658</li>

8659<li id="section_5.10">

8660Stevens RF, Hann IM, Wheatley K, et al.: Marked improvements in outcome with chemotherapy alone in paediatric acute myeloid leukemia: results of the United Kingdom Medical Research Council's 10th AML trial. MRC Childhood Leukaemia Working Party. Br J Haematol 101 (1): 130-40, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9576193&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9576193&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8661[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8662</li>

8663<li id="section_5.11">

8664Creutzig U, Ritter J, Zimmermann M, et al.: Improved treatment results in high-risk pediatric acute myeloid leukemia patients after intensification with high-dose cytarabine and mitoxantrone: results of Study Acute Myeloid Leukemia-Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster 93. J Clin Oncol 19 (10): 2705-13, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11352963&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11352963&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8665[PUBMED Abstract]</a>
