9134Rasche M, Zimmermann M, Borschel L, et al.: Successes and challenges in the treatment of pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a retrospective analysis of the AML-BFM trials from 1987 to 2012. Leukemia 32 (10): 2167-2177, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29550834&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29550834&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9135[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9136</li>

9137<li id="section_5.130">

9138Bunin NJ, Davies SM, Aplenc R, et al.: Unrelated donor bone marrow transplantation for children with acute myeloid leukemia beyond first remission or refractory to chemotherapy. J Clin Oncol 26 (26): 4326-32, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18779619&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18779619&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9139[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9140</li>

9141<li id="section_5.131">

9142Woodard P, Carpenter PA, Davies SM, et al.: Unrelated donor bone marrow transplantation for myelodysplastic syndrome in children. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 17 (5): 723-8, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20813197&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20813197&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9143[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9144</li>

9145<li id="section_5.132">

9146Uberti JP, Agovi MA, Tarima S, et al.: Comparative analysis of BU and CY versus CY and TBI in full intensity unrelated marrow donor transplantation for AML, CML and myelodysplasia. Bone Marrow Transplant 46 (1): 34-43, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20400989&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20400989&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9147[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9148</li>

9149<li id="section_5.133">

9150Shaw PJ, Kan F, Woo Ahn K, et al.: Outcomes of pediatric bone marrow transplantation for leukemia and myelodysplasia using matched sibling, mismatched related, or matched unrelated donors. Blood 116 (19): 4007-15, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20671124&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20671124&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9151[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9152</li>

9153<li id="section_5.134">

9154Eapen M, Klein JP, Ruggeri A, et al.: Impact of allele-level HLA matching on outcomes after myeloablative single unit umbilical cord blood transplantation for hematologic malignancy. Blood 123 (1): 133-40, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24141369&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24141369&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9155[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9156</li>

9157<li id="section_5.135">

9158Locatelli F, Merli P, Pagliara D, et al.: Outcome of children with acute leukemia given HLA-haploidentical HSCT after &#945;&#946; T-cell and B-cell depletion. Blood 130 (5): 677-685, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28588018&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28588018&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9159[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9160</li>

9161<li id="section_5.136">

9162Rashidi A, DiPersio JF, Westervelt P, et al.: Comparison of Outcomes after Peripheral Blood Haploidentical versus Matched Unrelated Donor Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation in Patients with Acute Myeloid Leukemia: A Retrospective Single-Center Review. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 22 (9): 1696-1701, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27223108&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27223108&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9163[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9164</li>

9165<li id="section_5.137">

9166Pulsipher MA, Boucher KM, Wall D, et al.: Reduced-intensity allogeneic transplantation in pediatric patients ineligible for myeloablative therapy: results of the Pediatric Blood and Marrow Transplant Consortium Study ONC0313. Blood 114 (7): 1429-36, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19528536&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19528536&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9167[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9168</li>

9169<li id="section_5.138">

9170Scott BL, Pasquini MC, Logan BR, et al.: Myeloablative Versus Reduced-Intensity Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation for Acute Myeloid Leukemia and Myelodysplastic Syndromes. J Clin Oncol 35 (11): 1154-1161, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28380315&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28380315&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9171[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9172</li>

9173<li id="section_5.139">

9174Meshinchi S, Leisenring WM, Carpenter PA, et al.: Survival after second hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for recurrent pediatric acute myeloid leukemia. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 9 (11): 706-13, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14652854&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14652854&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9175[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9176</li>

9177<li id="section_5.140">

9178Nishikawa T, Inagaki J, Nagatoshi Y, et al.: The second therapeutic trial for children with hematological malignancies who relapsed after their first allogeneic SCT: long-term outcomes. Pediatr Transplant 16 (7): 722-8, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22694185&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22694185&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9179[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9180</li>

9181<li id="section_5.141">

9182Yaniv I, Krauss AC, Beohou E, et al.: Second Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation for Post-Transplantation Relapsed Acute Leukemia in Children: A Retrospective EBMT-PDWP Study. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 24 (8): 1629-1642, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29548831&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29548831&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9183[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9184</li>

9185<li id="section_5.142">

9186Uden T, Bertaina A, Abrahamsson J, et al.: Outcome of children relapsing after first allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation for acute myeloid leukaemia: a retrospective I-BFM analysis of 333 children. Br J Haematol 189 (4): 745-750, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32012224&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32012224&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9187[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9188</li>

9189<li id="section_5.143">

9190Johnston DL, Alonzo TA, Gerbing RB, et al.: Risk factors and therapy for isolated central nervous system relapse of pediatric acute myeloid leukemia. J Clin Oncol 23 (36): 9172-8, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16361619&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16361619&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9191[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9192</li>

9193<li id="section_5.144">

9194Abbott BL, Rubnitz JE, Tong X, et al.: Clinical significance of central nervous system involvement at diagnosis of pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a single institution's experience. Leukemia 17 (11): 2090-6, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14523477&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14523477&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9195[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9196</li>

9197<li id="section_5.145">

9198Quarello P, Fagioli F, Basso G, et al.: Outcome of children with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) experiencing primary induction failure in the AIEOP AML 2002/01 clinical trial. Br J Haematol 171 (4): 566-73, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26223157&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26223157&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9199[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9200</li>

9201<li id="section_5.146">

9202O'Hear C, Inaba H, Pounds S, et al.: Gemtuzumab ozogamicin can reduce minimal residual disease in patients with childhood acute myeloid leukemia. Cancer 119 (22): 4036-43, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24006085&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24006085&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9203[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9204</li>

9205</ol>

9206</div>

9207

9208 </section>

9209

9210

9211

9212 <section id="_62">

9213

9214 <h2>

9215Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL)</h2>

9216

9217 <div id="_section_62" class="pdq-sections">

9218<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

9219<h6>

9220In This Section</h6>

9221<ul>

9222<li>

9223<a href="#_1109_toc">

9224Molecular Abnormality<ul>

9225<li>

9226<a href="#_1111_toc">

9227Clinical Presentation</a>

9228</li>

9229</ul>

9230</a>

9231</li>

9232<li>

9233<a href="#_1115_toc">

9234Risk Classification for Treatment Stratification</a>

9235</li>

9236<li>

9237<a href="#_1118_toc">

9238The Central Nervous System (CNS) and APL</a>

9239</li>

9240<li>

9241<a href="#_1120_toc">

9242Treatment of APL<ul>

9243<li>

9244<a href="#_861_toc">

9245Treatment options under clinical evaluation</a>

9246</li>

9247<li>

9248<a href="#_1135_toc">

9249Complications unique to APL therapy</a>

9250</li>

9251<li>

9252<a href="#_1139_toc">

9253Minimal disease monitoring</a>

9254</li>

9255</ul>

9256</a>

9257</li>

9258<li>

9259<a href="#_496_toc">

9260Molecular Variants of APL Other Than <em class="gene-name">

9261PML</em>

9262::<em class="gene-name">

9263RARA</em>

9264 and Therapeutic Impact</a>

9265</li>

9266<li>

9267<a href="#_364_toc">

9268Treatment of Recurrent APL<ul>

9269<li>

9270<a href="#_1054_toc">

9271Arsenic trioxide</a>

9272</li>

9273<li>

9274<a href="#_1057_toc">

9275Gemtuzumab ozogamicin</a>

9276</li>

9277<li>

9278<a href="#_1060_toc">

9279HSCT</a>

9280</li>

9281</ul>

9282</a>

9283</li>

9284<li>

9285<a href="#_TrialSearch_62_sid_6_toc">

9286Current Clinical Trials</a>

9287</li>

9288</ul>

9289</nav>

9290<p id="_1106" tabindex="-1">

9291Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a distinct subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) because of several factors, including the following:</p>

9292<div class="pdq-content-list">

9293<ul id="_1107">

9294<li>

9295Clinical presentation of universal coagulopathy (disseminated intravascular coagulation) and unique morphological characteristics (French-American-British [FAB] M3 or its variants).</li>

9296<li>

9297Unique molecular etiology as a result of the involvement of the <em class="gene-name">

9298RARA</em>

9299 oncogene.</li>

9300<li>

9301Unique sensitivity to the differentiating agent tretinoin and to the proapoptotic agent arsenic trioxide.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

93021</a>

9303]</li>

9304</ul>

9305</div>

9306<p id="_1108" tabindex="-1">

9307These unique features of APL mandate a high index of suspicion at diagnosis so as to initiate proper supportive care measures to avoid coagulopathic complications during the first days of therapy. It is also critical to institute a different induction regimen of therapy to minimize the risk of coagulopathic complications and to provide a much improved long-term relapse-free survival and overall survival (OS) than with past approaches to treating APL and compared with outcomes for patients with the other forms of AML.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

93082</a>

9309,<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

93103</a>

9311]</p>

9312<section id="_1109">

9313<h3 id="_1109_toc">

9314Molecular Abnormality</h3>

9315<p id="_1110" tabindex="-1">

9316The characteristic chromosomal abnormality associated with APL is t(15;17). This translocation involves a breakpoint that includes the retinoic acid receptor and leads to production of the promyelocytic leukemia (PML)::retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) fusion protein.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

93171</a>

9318]</p>

9319<p id="_1178" tabindex="-1">

9320Patients with a suspected diagnosis of APL can have their diagnosis confirmed by detection of the PML::RARA fusion protein (e.g., through fluorescence <em>

9321in situ</em>

9322 hybridization [FISH], reverse transcriptase&#8211;polymerase chain reaction [RT-PCR], or conventional cytogenetics). An immunofluorescence method using an anti-PML monoclonal antibody can rapidly establish the presence of the PML::RARA fusion protein based on the characteristic distribution pattern of PML that occurs in the presence of the fusion protein.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

93234</a>

9324-<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

93256</a>

9326]</p>

9327<section id="_1111">

9328<h4 id="_1111_toc">

9329Clinical Presentation</h4>

9330<p id="_1112" tabindex="-1">

9331Clinically, APL is characterized by severe coagulopathy that is often present at the time of diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

93327</a>

9333] This is typically manifested with thrombocytopenia, prolonged prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, elevated d-dimers, and hypofibrinogenemia.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

93348</a>

9335] Mortality during induction (particularly with cytotoxic agents used alone) caused by bleeding complications is more common in this subtype than in other FAB or World Health Organization (WHO) classifications.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

93369</a>

9337,<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

933810</a>

9339] A multicooperative group analysis of children with APL who were treated with tretinoin and chemotherapy reported that early induction coagulopathic deaths occurred in 25 of 683 children (3.7%); 23 deaths resulted from hemorrhage (19 CNS, 4 pulmonary), and 2 resulted from CNS thrombosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

934011</a>

9341] A lumbar puncture at diagnosis should not be performed until evidence of coagulopathy has resolved. </p>

9342<p id="_1113" tabindex="-1">

9343Tretinoin therapy is initiated as soon as APL is suspected on the basis of morphological and clinical presentation,[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

93442</a>

9345,<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

934612</a>

9347] because tretinoin has been shown to ameliorate bleeding risk for patients with APL.[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

934813</a>

9349] A retrospective analysis identified an increase in early death resulting from hemorrhage in patients with APL in whom tretinoin introduction was delayed.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

93508</a>

9351] This emergent need led to the early administration of tretinoin while not precluding participation in other AML clinical trials if the APL diagnosis proves to be incorrect. Additionally, initiation of supportive measures such as replacement transfusions directed at correction of the coagulopathy is critical during these initial days of diagnosis and therapy. Patients at greatest risk of coagulopathic complications are those presenting with high white blood cell (WBC) counts, high body mass index, hypofibrinogenemia, molecular variants of APL, and the presence of <em class="gene-name">

9352FLT3</em>

9353 internal tandem duplication (ITD) mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

93548</a>

9355,<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

935611</a>

9357]</p>

9358<p id="_1114" tabindex="-1">

9359APL in children is generally similar to APL in adults, although children have a higher incidence of hyperleukocytosis (defined as WBC count higher than 10 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

93609</span>

9361/L) and a higher incidence of the microgranular morphological subtype.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

936214</a>

9363-<a href="#cit/section_6.17">

936417</a>

9365] As in adults, children with WBC counts less than 10 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

93669</span>

9367/L at diagnosis have significantly better outcomes than do patients with higher WBC counts.[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

936815</a>

9369,<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

937016</a>

9371,<a href="#cit/section_6.18">

937218</a>

9373]</p>

9374</section>

9375</section>

9376<section id="_1115">

9377<h3 id="_1115_toc">

9378Risk Classification for Treatment Stratification</h3>

9379<p id="_1116" tabindex="-1">

9380The prognostic significance of WBC count is used to define high-risk and low-risk patient populations and to assign postinduction treatment, with high-risk patients most commonly defined by WBC count of 10 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

93819</span>

9382/L or greater.[<a href="#cit/section_6.19">

938319</a>

9384,<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

938520</a>

9386] <em class="gene-name">

9387FLT3</em>

9388 mutations (either ITD or tyrosine kinase domain [TKD] mutations) are observed in 40% to 50% of APL cases, with the presence of <em class="gene-name">

9389FLT3</em>

9390 mutations correlating with higher WBC counts and the microgranular variant (M3v) subtype.[<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

939121</a>

9392-<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

939325</a>

9394] The <em class="gene-name">

9395FLT3</em>

9396 mutation has been associated with an increased risk of induction death and, in some reports, an increased risk of treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

939721</a>

9398-<a href="#cit/section_6.27">

939927</a>

9400]</p>

9401<p id="_1117" tabindex="-1">

9402In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00866918">

9403AAML0631 (NCT00866918)</a>

9404 trial, which included treatment with chemotherapy, tretinoin, and arsenic trioxide, risk classification primarily defined early death risk rather than relapse risk (standard risk, 0 of 66 patients vs. high risk, 4 of 35 patients).[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

940528</a>

9406] In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00866918">

9407AAML0631 (NCT00866918)</a>

9408 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02339740">

9409AAML1331 (NCT02339740)</a>

9410 trials, relapse risk after remission induction was 4% and 2% overall, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

941128</a>

9412,<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

941329</a>

9414] High-risk patients in these trials had earlier initiation of idarubicin, with the first dose on day 1 rather than day 3 to reduce leukemic burden more rapidly.[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

941528</a>

9416]</p>

9417</section>

9418<section id="_1118">

9419<h3 id="_1118_toc">

9420The Central Nervous System (CNS) and APL</h3>

9421<p id="_1119" tabindex="-1">

9422CNS involvement at the time of diagnosis is not ascertained in most patients with APL because of the presence of disseminated intravascular coagulation. The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00866918">

9423AAML0631 (NCT00866918)</a>

9424 trial identified 28 patients out of 101 enrolled children who had cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) exams at diagnosis, and in 7 of these children, blasts were identified in atraumatic taps.[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

942528</a>

9426] None of the patients experienced a CNS relapse with intrathecal treatment during induction and prophylactic doses during therapy.</p>

9427<p id="_1179" tabindex="-1">

9428Overall, CNS relapse is uncommon for patients with APL, particularly for those with WBC counts of less than 10 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

94299</span>

9430/L.[<a href="#cit/section_6.30">

943130</a>

9432,<a href="#cit/section_6.31">

943331</a>

9434] In two clinical trials enrolling more than 1,400 adults with APL in which CNS prophylaxis was not administered, the cumulative incidence of CNS relapse was less than 1% for patients with WBC counts of less than 10 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

94359</span>

9436/L, while it was approximately 5% for those with WBC counts of 10 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

94379</span>

9438/L or greater.[<a href="#cit/section_6.30">

943930</a>

9440,<a href="#cit/section_6.31">

944131</a>

9442] In addition to high WBC counts at diagnosis, CNS hemorrhage during induction is also a risk factor for CNS relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_6.31">

944331</a>

9444] A review of published cases of pediatric APL also observed low rates of CNS relapse. Because of the low incidence of CNS relapse among children with APL presenting with WBC counts of less than 10 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

94459</span>

9446/L, CNS surveillance and prophylactic CNS therapy may not be needed for this group of patients,[<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

944732</a>

9448] although there is no consensus on this topic.[<a href="#cit/section_6.33">

944933</a>

9450]</p>

9451</section>

9452<section id="_1120">

9453<h3 id="_1120_toc">

9454Treatment of APL</h3>

9455<p id="_1121" tabindex="-1">

9456Modern treatment programs for APL are based on the sensitivity of leukemia cells from APL patients to the differentiation-inducing and apoptotic effects of tretinoin and arsenic trioxide. APL therapy first diverged from the therapy of other non-APL subtypes of AML with the addition of tretinoin to chemotherapy. With the incorporation of arsenic trioxide into modern treatment regimens, the use of traditional chemotherapy in adults and children is increasingly restricted to the induction phase for high-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

945729</a>

9458,<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

945934</a>

9460,<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

946135</a>

9462] </p>

9463<p id="_1122" tabindex="-1">

9464Treatment options for children with APL may include the following:</p>

9465<div class="pdq-content-list">

9466<ol id="_1123">

9467<li>

9468Tretinoin.</li>

9469<li>

9470Arsenic trioxide.</li>

9471<li>

9472Chemotherapy.</li>

9473<li>

9474Supportive care.</li>

9475</ol>

9476</div>

9477<p id="_1124" tabindex="-1">

9478Given the very high level of activity for the combination of arsenic trioxide and tretinoin for adults with APL,[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

947934</a>

9480,<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

948135</a>

9482] and given data indicating that children with APL have a similar response to these agents,[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

948329</a>

9484,<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

948536</a>

9486-<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

948739</a>

9488] the use of these two agents alone in standard-risk patients, and with short-course chemotherapy during induction in high-risk patients, is the optimal therapeutic approach for this disease. </p>

9489<p id="_1988" tabindex="-1">

9490Before this approach was discovered, chemotherapy was used in all or most phases of therapy including induction, consolidation, and maintenance for pediatric trials like <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00866918">

9491AAML0631 (NCT00866918)</a>

9492. The regimens that use chemotherapy are now primarily of historical interest. They can also be used as a reference in refractory cases because of the findings from randomized clinical trials that compared regimens with the combination of tretinoin and arsenic trioxide with or without chemotherapy. Results from the completed cooperative group trial (COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02339740">

9493AAML1331 [NCT02339740]</a>

9494) verified the benefit of treatment with tretinoin and arsenic trioxide for children with newly diagnosed APL,[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

949529</a>

9496] similar to results reported by other groups.[<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

949739</a>

9498] The dramatic efficacy of tretinoin against APL results from the ability of pharmacological doses of tretinoin to overcome the repression of signaling caused by the PML::RARA fusion protein at physiological tretinoin concentrations. Restoration of signaling leads to differentiation of APL cells and then to postmaturation apoptosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

949940</a>

9500] Most patients with APL achieve a complete remission (CR) when treated with tretinoin, although single-agent tretinoin is generally not curative.[<a href="#cit/section_6.41">

950141</a>

9502,<a href="#cit/section_6.42">

950342</a>

9504]</p>

9505<p id="_1125" tabindex="-1">

9506 Almost all children with APL who were treated with tretinoin, arsenic trioxide, and modern supportive care (outlined below) achieved CR in the absence of coagulopathy-related mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

950715</a>

9508,<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

950916</a>

9510,<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

951129</a>

9512,<a href="#cit/section_6.43">

951343</a>

9514-<a href="#cit/section_6.45">

951545</a>

9516]</p>

9517<p id="_1180" tabindex="-1">

9518Assessment of response to induction therapy in the first month of treatment using morphological and molecular criteria may provide misleading results because delayed persistence of differentiating leukemia cells can occur in patients who will ultimately achieve CR.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

95192</a>

9520,<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

95213</a>

9522] Alterations in planned treatment based on these early observations are not appropriate because resistance of APL to tretinoin plus arsenic trioxide is rare.[<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

952320</a>

9524,<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

952529</a>

9526,<a href="#cit/section_6.46">

952746</a>

9528]</p>

9529<p id="_1126" tabindex="-1">

9530For patients with APL, consolidation therapy may include repeated cycles of tretinoin and arsenic trioxide without additional chemotherapy, based on the adult and pediatric experience.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

953129</a>

9532,<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

953334</a>

9534,<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

953535</a>

9536,<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

953739</a>

9538] Studies using arsenic trioxide&#8211;based consolidation have demonstrated excellent survival without cytarabine consolidation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.26">

953926</a>

9540,<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

954129</a>

9542,<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

954334</a>

9544,<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

954539</a>

9546,<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

954747</a>

9548]</p>

9549<p id="_1182" tabindex="-1">

9550Maintenance therapy is likely unnecessary for patients with APL who are treated with tretinoin and arsenic trioxide based on data from adult trials and the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02339740">

9551AAML1331 (NCT02339740)</a>

9552 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

955329</a>

9554] Because of the favorable outcomes with tretinoin and arsenic trioxide, hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is not recommended in first CR.</p>

9555<p id="_66" tabindex="-1">

9556Arsenic trioxide is the most active agent in the treatment of APL, and while initially used in relapsed APL, it is now incorporated into the treatment of newly diagnosed patients. Data supporting the use of arsenic trioxide initially came from trials that included adult patients only, but more recently, its efficacy has been seen in trials that included pediatric patients. </p>

9557<p id="_1128" tabindex="-1">

9558Evidence (arsenic trioxide therapy):</p>

9559<div class="pdq-content-list">

9560<ol id="_1129">

9561<li>

9562In adults with newly diagnosed APL treated on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003934">

9563CALGB-C9710 (NCT00003934)</a>

9564 trial, the addition of two consolidation courses of arsenic trioxide to a standard APL treatment regimen resulted in the following:[<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

956547</a>

9566]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9567<ul id="_1130">

9568<li>

9569A significant improvement in EFS (80% vs. 63% at 3 years; <em>

9570P</em>

9571 &lt; .0001) and disease-free survival (DFS) rates (90% vs. 70% at 3 years; <em>

9572P</em>

9573 &lt; .0001), although the outcome of patients who did not receive arsenic trioxide was inferior to the results obtained in the Gruppo Italiano Malattie EMatologiche dell&#8217;Adulto (GIMEMA) or PETHEMA trials.</li>

9574</ul>

9575</div>

9576</li>

9577<li>

9578In children and adolescents with newly diagnosed APL treated on the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00866918">

9579AAML0631 (NCT00866918)</a>

9580 trial, two consolidation cycles of arsenic trioxide were incorporated into a chemotherapy regimen with lower cumulative anthracycline doses compared with historical controls.[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

958128</a>

9582] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9583<ul id="_1131">

9584<li>

9585The 3-year OS rate was 94%, and the EFS rate was 91%.</li>

9586<li>

9587Patients with standard-risk APL had an OS rate of 98% and an EFS rate of 95%.</li>

9588<li>

9589High-risk patients had an OS rate of 86% and an EFS rate of 83%. This lower survival compared with standard-risk patients was primarily caused by early death events.</li>

9590<li>

9591The relapse risk after arsenic trioxide consolidation was 4% and was similar for standard-risk and high-risk APL.</li>

9592</ul>

9593</div>

9594</li>

9595<li>

9596The concurrent use of arsenic trioxide and tretinoin in newly diagnosed patients with APL results in high rates of CR.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

959748</a>

9598-<a href="#cit/section_6.50">

959950</a>

9600] Early experience in children with newly diagnosed APL showed high rates of CR to arsenic trioxide, either as a single agent or given with tretinoin.[<a href="#cit/section_6.51">

960151</a>

9602][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9603Level of evidence C1</a>

9604] Results of a meta-analysis of seven published studies in adult patients with APL suggested that using a combination of arsenic trioxide and tretinoin may be more effective than using arsenic trioxide alone to induce CR.[<a href="#cit/section_6.52">

960552</a>

9606]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9607<ul id="_1183">

9608<li>

9609In early trials in children, the impact of arsenic added to induction (either alone or with tretinoin) on EFS and OS had appeared promising.[<a href="#cit/section_6.51">

961051</a>

9611,<a href="#cit/section_6.53">

961253</a>

9613,<a href="#cit/section_6.54">

961454</a>

9615]</li>

9616</ul>

9617</div>

9618</li>

9619<li>

9620Arsenic trioxide was evaluated as a component of induction therapy with idarubicin and tretinoin in the APML4 clinical trial, which enrolled both children and adults (N = 124 evaluable patients).[<a href="#cit/section_6.26">

962126</a>

9622] Patients received two courses of consolidation therapy with arsenic trioxide and tretinoin (but no anthracycline) and maintenance therapy with tretinoin, mercaptopurine, and methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_6.55">

962355</a>

9624]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9625<ul id="_1132">

9626<li>

9627The 2-year freedom-from-relapse rate was 97.5%, the failure-free survival (FFS) rate was 88.1%, and the OS rate was 93.2%.</li>

9628<li>

9629These outcome results are superior to those reported for patients who did not receive arsenic trioxide in the predecessor clinical trial (APML3).</li>

9630</ul>

9631</div>

9632</li>

9633<li>

9634A German and Italian phase III clinical trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00482833">

9635APL0406 [NCT00482833]</a>

9636) compared tretinoin plus chemotherapy with tretinoin plus arsenic trioxide in adults with APL classified as low to intermediate risk (WBC &#8804;10 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

96379</span>

9638/L).[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

963934</a>

9640] Patients were randomly assigned to receive either tretinoin plus arsenic trioxide for induction and consolidation therapy or standard tretinoin-idarubicin induction therapy followed by three cycles of consolidation therapy with tretinoin plus chemotherapy and maintenance therapy with low-dose chemotherapy and tretinoin.<div class="pdq-content-list">

9641<ul id="_1133">

9642<li>

9643All patients who received tretinoin plus arsenic trioxide (n = 77) achieved CR at the end of induction therapy, while 95% of patients who received tretinoin plus chemotherapy (n = 79) achieved CR.</li>

9644<li>

9645EFS rates were 97% in the tretinoin-arsenic trioxide group compared with 86% in the tretinoin-chemotherapy group (<em>

9646P</em>

9647 = .02).</li>

9648<li>

9649Two-year OS probability was 99% (95% confidence interval [CI], 96%&#8211;100%) in the tretinoin-arsenic trioxide group and 91% (95% CI, 85%&#8211;97%) in the tretinoin-chemotherapy group (<em>

9650P</em>

9651 = .02).</li>

9652<li>

9653An updated longer-term analysis demonstrated that at 50 months, the tretinoin-arsenic trioxide arm showed even greater superiority, with OS rates of 97% versus 80% (<em>

9654P</em>

9655 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

965634</a>

9657,<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

965835</a>

9659]</li>

9660<li>

9661These results indicate that low-risk to intermediate-risk APL is curable for a high percentage of patients without conventional chemotherapy.</li>

9662</ul>

9663</div>

9664</li>

9665<li>

9666The historically controlled noninferiority COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02339740">

9667AAML1331 (NCT02339740)</a>

9668 trial was conducted between 2015 and 2019. The study included pediatric patients (age range, 1&#8211;21 years) with APL. The study examined whether the addition of arsenic trioxide to induction therapy, and continued through consolidation, could sustain the excellent outcomes seen in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00866918">

9669AAML0631 (NCT00866918)</a>

9670 trial. Additionally, chemotherapy was eliminated entirely, except when patients with high-risk APL were given short courses of idarubicin during induction therapy. Patients with standard-risk APL had idarubicin eliminated from the induction cycle. Mitoxantrone, high-dose cytarabine, and idarubicin were eliminated from the consolidation cycles. Then, mercaptopurine and methotrexate were eliminated from the maintenance cycles. Intrathecal doses of cytarabine were also eliminated. The AAML1331 study included 158 patients, 98 of whom were classified as standard risk and 56 of whom were classified as high risk.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

967129</a>

9672] <p id="_2099" tabindex="-1">

9673Standard-risk patients received tretinoin plus arsenic trioxide on days 1 to 28, with the possibility of continuing treatment up to day 70 to achieve a CR. High-risk patients received the same induction therapy schedule as standard-risk patients, with the addition of idarubicin on induction days 1, 3, 5, and 7. High-risk patients also received daily dexamethasone as a prophylactic treatment to prevent differentiation syndrome on days 1 to 14. All patients received the same consolidation therapy, which consisted of tretinoin on days 1 to 14 and days 29 to 42. Patients were also given arsenic trioxide 5 days each week for 4 consecutive weeks in every 8-week cycle (three rounds). The fourth consolidation therapy cycle concluded on day 28. There was no maintenance therapy phase.</p>

9674<div class="pdq-content-list">

9675<ul id="_2120">

9676<li>

9677The median duration of induction therapy for all patients (standard risk and high risk) was 47 days. Induction therapy included a 14-day rest period before starting consolidation therapy. All standard-risk and high-risk patients who completed their induction therapy achieved a hematologic CR or a CR with incomplete hematologic recovery before day 70. </li>

9678<li>

9679During induction therapy, one standard-risk patient died of complications from coagulopathy, differentiation syndrome, and subsequent organ failure. No high-risk patients died of complications.</li>

9680<li>

9681All patients who received quantitative PCR testing after completing their second round of consolidation therapy were in molecular remission. </li>

9682<li>

9683No patients experienced a relapse while on therapy. One standard-risk patient (1%, CNS recurrence) and two high-risk patients (4%) experienced relapses after therapy completion. These patients were successfully salvaged.</li>

9684<li>

9685The AAML1331 and AAML0631 trials were compared and the following was reported:<div class="pdq-content-list">

9686<ul id="_2101" class="list-dash">

9687<li>

9688Standard-risk patients had equivalent 2-year EFS rates (98% vs. 97%) and OS rates (99% vs. 98.5%). </li>

9689<li>

9690High-risk patients who enrolled in the AAML1331 trial had a significantly improved 2-year EFS rate (96.4% vs. 82.9%, <em>

9691P</em>

9692 = 0.05) and OS rate (100% vs. 85.7%, <em>

9693P</em>

9694 = .02).</li>

9695<li>

9696In the AAML1331 trial, patients with CNS symptoms or hemorrhage were examined and treated using triple intrathecal chemotherapy, whereas in the AAML0631 study, standard-risk patients received three prophylactic doses of intrathecal chemotherapy, and high-risk patients received four prophylactic doses of intrathecal chemotherapy.</li>

9697<li>

9698The length of therapy was significantly shorter in the AAML1331 trial (9 months) than in the AAML0631 trial (&gt;2 years).</li>

9699<li>

9700Hospitalizations during consolidation therapy were significantly reduced in the AAML1331 trial, when compared with the AAML0631 trial (0 days vs. 13 days, respectively; <em>

9701P</em>

9702 &lt; .001). </li>

9703<li>

9704In the AAML1331 trial, early death was significantly lower in high-risk patients (0 vs. 4 in AAML0631, <em>

9705P</em>

9706 = .02), and not significantly different for standard-risk patients (1 vs. 0 in AAML0631, <em>

9707P</em>

9708 = .16).</li>

9709</ul>

9710</div>

9711</li>

9712</ul>

9713</div>

9714</li>

9715</ol>

9716</div>

9717<p id="_1134" tabindex="-1">

9718In summary, survival rates for children with APL exceeding 90% are achievable using treatment programs that prescribe the rapid initiation of tretinoin with appropriate supportive care measures and that combine arsenic trioxide with tretinoin for induction and consolidation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

971929</a>

9720,<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

972139</a>

9722] Cytotoxic chemotherapy is required only for high-risk patients, and its use is restricted to induction therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

972329</a>

9724] For patients in CR for more than 5 years, relapse is extremely rare.[<a href="#cit/section_6.56">

972556</a>

9726][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9727Level of evidence B1</a>

9728]</p>

9729<section id="_861">

9730<h4 id="_861_toc">

9731Treatment options under clinical evaluation</h4>

9732<p id="_862" tabindex="-1">

9733Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

9734NCI website</a>

9735. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

9736ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

9737.</p>

9738</section>

9739<section id="_1135">

9740<h4 id="_1135_toc">

9741Complications unique to APL therapy</h4>

9742<p id="_1136" tabindex="-1">

9743In addition to the previously mentioned universal presence of coagulopathy in patients newly diagnosed with APL (further described below), several other unique complications occur in patients with APL for which the clinician should be aware. These include two tretinoin-related conditions, pseudotumor cerebri and differentiation syndrome (also called retinoic acid syndrome), and an arsenic trioxide&#8211;related complication, QT interval prolongation.</p>

9744<div class="pdq-content-list">

9745<ul id="_1137">

9746<li>

9747<strong>

9748Pseudotumor cerebri.</strong>

9749 Pseudotumor cerebri is typically manifested by headache, papilledema, sixth nerve palsy, visual field cuts, and normal intracranial imaging in the face of an elevated opening lumbar puncture pressure (not often obtained in APL patients). Pseudotumor cerebri is known to be associated with tretinoin, presumably by the same mechanism of vitamin A toxicity that leads to increased production of cerebrospinal fluid.<p id="_1155" tabindex="-1">

9750The incidence of pseudotumor cerebri has been reported to be as low as 1.7% with very strict definitions of the complication and as high as 6% to 16% in pediatric trials.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

975114</a>

9752,<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

975315</a>

9754,<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

975528</a>

9756,<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

975729</a>

9758,<a href="#cit/section_6.57">

975957</a>

9760] Pseudotumor cerebri is thought to be more prevalent in children receiving tretinoin, leading to lower dosing in contemporary pediatric APL clinical trials.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

976114</a>

9762,<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

976329</a>

9764] Pseudotumor cerebri most typically occurs during induction at a median of 15 days (range, 1&#8211;35 days) after starting tretinoin, but is known to occur in other phases of therapy as well.[<a href="#cit/section_6.57">

976557</a>

9766] Pseudotumor cerebri incidence and severity may be exacerbated with the concurrent use of azoles via inhibition of cytochrome P450 metabolism of tretinoin.</p>

9767<p id="_1156" tabindex="-1">

9768When a diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri is suspected, tretinoin is with held until symptoms abate and then is slowly escalated to full dose as tolerated.[<a href="#cit/section_6.57">

976957</a>

9770]</p>

9771</li>

9772<li>

9773<strong>

9774Differentiation syndrome.</strong>

9775 Differentiation syndrome (also known as retinoic acid syndrome or tretinoin syndrome) is a life-threatening syndrome thought to be an inflammatory response&#8211;mediated syndrome manifested by weight gain, fever, edema, pulmonary infiltrates, pleuro-pericardial effusions, hypotension, and, in the most severe cases, acute renal failure.[<a href="#cit/section_6.58">

977658</a>

9777] In the contemporary COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00866918">

9778AAML0631 (NCT00866918)</a>

9779 study, it was present in 20% of patients during induction and was more prevalent in high-risk children (31%) than in low-risk children (13%), a risk factor also seen in adults with APL.[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

978028</a>

9781,<a href="#cit/section_6.59">

978259</a>

9783] There is a bimodal peak with this syndrome seen in the first and third weeks of induction therapy.<p id="_1157" tabindex="-1">

9784 Since differentiation syndrome occurs more often in high-risk patients, dexamethasone is given with tretinoin and/or arsenic trioxide to prevent this complication.[<a href="#cit/section_6.58">

978558</a>

9786] Prophylaxis with dexamethasone and hydroxyurea (for cytoreduction) is also administered to standard-risk patients if their WBC count rises to greater than 10,000/&#181;L after the start of tretinoin or arsenic. If differentiation syndrome occurs, the patient's dexamethasone dose may be escalated with temporary with holding of tretinoin and arsenic trioxide and, similar to pseudotumor cerebri, restarted at a lower dose and escalated as tolerated. When this approach was used in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02339740">

9787AAML1331 (NCT02339740)</a>

9788 trial, 24.5% of standard-risk patients and 30.4% of high-risk patients presented with differentiation syndrome. Only one standard-risk patient died from differentiation syndrome and coagulopathy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

978929</a>

9790]</p>

9791</li>

9792<li>

9793<strong>

9794Coagulopathy.</strong>

9795 Along with differentiation syndrome, coagulopathy complications result in a higher risk of death during induction (early death in APL). APL blasts induce coagulopathy by activation of the coagulation cascade (caused by the expression of tissue factor and other procoagulants) with concomitant increase in primary and secondary fibrinolysis resulting from expression of annexin II on the APL blasts. Risk of death caused by coagulopathy is associated with an elevated WBC count, decreased platelet count, and abnormal coagulation studies (fibrinogen, prothrombin time).[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

979612</a>

9797] Studies of both adult and pediatric patients have demonstrated that scoring systems using clinical characteristics and laboratory values can help predict the risk of developing severe or lethal coagulopathy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.60">

979860</a>

9799,<a href="#cit/section_6.61">

980061</a>

9801] Aggressive supportive care to correct coagulopathy, even before clinical signs and symptoms of bleeding or thrombosis occur, is important to prevent early death.</li>

9802<li>

9803<strong>

9804QT interval prolongation.</strong>

9805 Arsenic

9806trioxide is associated with QT interval prolongation that can lead to life-threatening

9807arrhythmias (e.g., torsades de pointes).[<a href="#cit/section_6.62">

980862</a>

9809] It is essential to monitor

9810electrolytes closely in patients receiving arsenic trioxide and to maintain

9811potassium and magnesium values at midnormal ranges, as well as to be cognizant of other agents known to prolong the QT interval.[<a href="#cit/section_6.63">

981263</a>

9813]</li>

9814</ul>

9815</div>

9816</section>

9817<section id="_1139">

9818<h4 id="_1139_toc">

9819Minimal disease monitoring</h4>

9820<p id="_362" tabindex="-1">

9821The induction and consolidation therapies currently employed result in molecular remission, as measured by RT-PCR for PML::RARA fusion protein, in most APL patients, with 1% or fewer showing molecular evidence of disease at the end of consolidation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

982220</a>

9823,<a href="#cit/section_6.46">

982446</a>

9825] While two negative RT-PCR assays after completion of therapy are associated with long-term remission,[<a href="#cit/section_6.64">

982664</a>

9827] conversion from negative to positive RT-PCR is highly predictive of subsequent hematologic relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_6.65">

982865</a>

9829]</p>

9830<p id="_1212" tabindex="-1">

9831Patients with persistent or relapsing disease on the basis of PML::RARA fusion protein RT-PCR measurement may benefit from intervention with relapse therapies [<a href="#cit/section_6.66">

983266</a>

9833,<a href="#cit/section_6.67">

983467</a>

9835]. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_364">

9836Treatment of Recurrent APL</a>

9837 section.</p>

9838</section>

9839</section>

9840<section id="_496">

9841<h3 id="_496_toc">

9842Molecular Variants of APL Other Than <em class="gene-name">

9843PML</em>

9844::<em class="gene-name">

9845RARA</em>

9846 and Therapeutic Impact</h3>

9847<p id="_497" tabindex="-1">

9848Uncommon molecular variants of APL produce fusion proteins that join distinctive gene partners (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

9849ZBTB16</em>

9850, <em class="gene-name">

9851NPM1</em>

9852, <em class="gene-name">

9853STAT5B</em>

9854, and <em class="gene-name">

9855NUMA1</em>

9856) to RARA.[<a href="#cit/section_6.68">

985768</a>

9858,<a href="#cit/section_6.69">

985969</a>

9860] Recognition of these rare variants is important because they differ in their sensitivity to tretinoin and to arsenic trioxide.[<a href="#cit/section_6.70">

986170</a>

9862] </p>

9863<div class="pdq-content-list">

9864<ul id="_1140">

9865<li>

9866<strong>

9867<em class="gene-name">

9868ZBTB16</em>

9869::<em class="gene-name">

9870RARA</em>

9871 fusion variant.</strong>

9872 The <em class="gene-name">

9873ZBTB16</em>

9874::<em class="gene-name">

9875RARA</em>

9876 fusion variant, characterized by t(11;17)(q23;q21), represents about 0.8% of APL, expresses surface CD56, and has very fine granules compared with t(15;17) APL.[<a href="#cit/section_6.71">

987771</a>

9878-<a href="#cit/section_6.73">

987973</a>

9880] Patients with APL and <em class="gene-name">

9881ZBTB16</em>

9882::<em class="gene-name">

9883RARA</em>

9884 fusions have a poor prognosis and do not usually respond to tretinoin or arsenic trioxide.[<a href="#cit/section_6.70">

988570</a>

9886-<a href="#cit/section_6.73">

988773</a>

9888]</li>

9889<li>

9890<strong>

9891<em class="gene-name">

9892NPM1</em>

9893::<em class="gene-name">

9894RARA</em>

9895 or <em class="gene-name">

9896NUMA1</em>

9897::<em class="gene-name">

9898RARA</em>

9899 fusion variant.</strong>

9900 The rare APL variants with <em class="gene-name">

9901NPM1</em>

9902::<em class="gene-name">

9903RARA</em>

9904 fusions (t(5;17)(q35;q21)) or <em class="gene-name">

9905NUMA1</em>

9906::<em class="gene-name">

9907RARA</em>

9908 fusions (t(11;17)(q13;q21)) may still be responsive to tretinoin.[<a href="#cit/section_6.70">

990970</a>

9910,<a href="#cit/section_6.74">

991174</a>

9912-<a href="#cit/section_6.77">

991377</a>

9914]</li>

9915</ul>

9916</div>

9917</section>

9918<section id="_364">

9919<h3 id="_364_toc">

9920Treatment of Recurrent APL</h3>

9921<p id="_527" tabindex="-1">

9922Historically, 10% to 20% of patients with APL relapsed; however, current studies that incorporated arsenic trioxide therapy showed a cumulative incidence of relapse of less than 5%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

992328</a>

9924,<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

992529</a>

9926,<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

992735</a>

9928]</p>

9929<p id="_1050" tabindex="-1">

9930In patients who initially received chemotherapy-based treatments, the duration of their first remission was prognostic in APL, with patients who relapsed within 12 to 18 months of initial diagnosis having a worse outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_6.78">

993178</a>

9932-<a href="#cit/section_6.80">

993380</a>

9934]</p>

9935<p id="_1051" tabindex="-1">

9936Many children with APL who relapsed were exposed to anthracyclines in previous trials (exposures ranged from 400 mg/m<span class="sup">

99372</span>

9938 to 750 mg/m<span class="sup">

99392</span>

9940).[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

99412</a>

9942] Thus, regimens containing anthracyclines were often not optimal for children with APL who relapsed.</p>

9943<p id="_1052" tabindex="-1">

9944Treatment options for children with recurrent APL may include the following:</p>

9945<div class="pdq-content-list">

9946<ol id="_1053">

9947<li>

9948<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1054">

9949Arsenic trioxide</a>

9950 or tretinoin.</li>

9951<li>

9952<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1057">

9953Gemtuzumab ozogamicin</a>

9954.</li>

9955<li>

9956<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1060">

9957Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</a>

9958.</li>

9959</ol>

9960</div>

9961<section id="_1054">

9962<h4 id="_1054_toc">

9963Arsenic trioxide</h4>

9964<p id="_365" tabindex="-1">

9965For children with recurrent APL, the use of

9966arsenic trioxide as a single agent or in regimens including tretinoin should be

9967considered, depending on the therapy given during first remission. Arsenic

9968trioxide is an active agent in patients with recurrent APL, with approximately 85% to 94% of

9969patients achieving remission after treatment with this agent.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

997048</a>

9971,<a href="#cit/section_6.81">

997281</a>

9973-<a href="#cit/section_6.85">

997485</a>

9975] Arsenic trioxide is even capable of inducing remissions in patients who relapse after having received arsenic trioxide with or without other agents during initial therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.85">

997685</a>

9977,<a href="#cit/section_6.86">

997886</a>

9979] APL cells, however, may become resistant to arsenic trioxide through mechanisms including mutation of the PML domain of the <em class="gene-name">

9980PML</em>

9981::<em class="gene-name">

9982RARA</em>

9983 fusion oncogene.[<a href="#cit/section_6.87">

998487</a>

9985]</p>

9986<p id="_1055" tabindex="-1">

9987For adults with relapsed APL, approximately 85% to 94% achieve morphological remission after treatment with arsenic trioxide.[<a href="#cit/section_6.82">

998882</a>

9989,<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

999083</a>

9991,<a href="#cit/section_6.85">

999285</a>

9993,<a href="#cit/section_6.88">

999488</a>

9995] Data, although more limited in children, suggest that children with relapsed APL have a response to arsenic trioxide

9996similar to that of adults.[<a href="#cit/section_6.81">

999781</a>

9998,<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

999983</a>

10000,<a href="#cit/section_6.85">

1000185</a>

10002,<a href="#cit/section_6.89">

1000389</a>

10004] Arsenic trioxide is well tolerated in children with relapsed APL. The toxicity profile and response rates in children are similar to that observed in adults.[<a href="#cit/section_6.81">

1000581</a>

10006,<a href="#cit/section_6.85">

1000785</a>

10008]</p>

10009<p id="_1056" tabindex="-1">

10010Because arsenic trioxide causes QT-interval

10011prolongation that can lead to life-threatening arrhythmias,[<a href="#cit/section_6.62">

1001262</a>

10013] it is essential to monitor electrolytes closely in patients

10014receiving arsenic trioxide and to maintain potassium and magnesium values at

10015midnormal ranges.[<a href="#cit/section_6.63">

1001663</a>

10017]</p>

10018</section>

10019<section id="_1057">

10020<h4 id="_1057_toc">

10021Gemtuzumab ozogamicin</h4>

10022<p id="_1058" tabindex="-1">

10023The use of gemtuzumab ozogamicin, an anti-CD33/calicheamicin monoclonal antibody, as a single agent resulted in a 91% (9 of 11 patients) molecular remission after two doses and a 100% (13 of 13 patients) molecular remission after three doses, thus, demonstrating excellent activity of this agent in patients with relapsed APL.[<a href="#cit/section_6.90">

1002490</a>

10025]</p>

10026</section>

10027<section id="_1060">

10028<h4 id="_1060_toc">

10029HSCT</h4>

10030<p id="_528" tabindex="-1">

10031 Retrospective pediatric studies have reported 5-year EFS rates after either autologous or allogeneic transplantation approaches to be similar, at approximately 70%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.91">

1003291</a>

10033,<a href="#cit/section_6.92">

1003492</a>

10035] </p>

10036<p id="_1061" tabindex="-1">

10037Evidence (autologous HSCT):</p>

10038<div class="pdq-content-list">

10039<ol id="_1062">

10040<li>

10041When considering autologous transplantation, a study in adult patients demonstrated improved 7-year EFS rates (77% vs. 50%) when both the patient and the stem cell product had negative promyelocytic leukemia/retinoic acid receptor alpha fusion transcript by polymerase chain reaction (molecular remission) before transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_6.93">

1004293</a>

10043] </li>

10044<li>

10045Another study demonstrated that among seven patients undergoing autologous HSCT and whose cells were MRD positive, all relapsed in less than 9 months after transplantation; however, only one of eight patients whose autologous donor cells were MRD negative relapsed.[<a href="#cit/section_6.94">

1004694</a>

10047] </li>

10048<li>

10049Another report demonstrated that the 5-year EFS rate was 83.3% for patients who underwent autologous HSCT in second molecular remission and was 34.5% for patients who received only maintenance therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.95">

1005095</a>

10051] </li>

10052<li>

10053Another retrospective report found that 94% of pediatric and adult patients (64 of 67) with relapsed APL, after primarily receiving single-agent arsenic trioxide, achieved a molecular remission after treatment with arsenic-containing reinduction regimens. For patients (n = 35) who received postremission consolidation with HSCT, the 5-year OS rate was 90.3% (&#177; 5.3%), and the EFS rate was 87.1% (&#177; 6.0%). These outcomes were significantly superior to the outcomes of patients who received an arsenic-containing maintenance regimen (n = 28); these patients had a 5-year OS rate of 58.6% (&#177; 10.4%) and an EFS rate of 47.7% (&#177; 10.3%).[<a href="#cit/section_6.85">

1005485</a>

10055]</li>

10056</ol>

10057</div>

10058<p id="_1063" tabindex="-1">

10059Such data support the use of autologous transplantation in patients who are MRD negative in second CR and have MRD-negative stem cell collections.</p>

10060<p id="_871" tabindex="-1">

10061Because of the rarity of APL in children and the favorable outcome for this disease, clinical trials in relapsed APL to compare treatment approaches are likely not feasible. However, an international expert panel provided recommendations for the treatment of relapsed APL on the basis of the reported pediatric and adult experience.[<a href="#cit/section_6.96">

1006296</a>

10063]</p>

10064</section>

10065</section>

10066<section id="_TrialSearch_62_sid_6">

10067<h3 id="_TrialSearch_62_sid_6_toc">

10068Current Clinical Trials</h3>

10069<p id="_TrialSearch_62_22" tabindex="-1">

10070Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

10071advanced clinical trial search</a>

10072 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

10073General information</a>

10074 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

10075</section>

10159<li id="section_6.21">

10160Callens C, Chevret S, Cayuela JM, et al.: Prognostic implication of FLT3 and Ras gene mutations in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL): a retrospective study from the European APL Group. Leukemia 19 (7): 1153-60, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15889156&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15889156&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10161[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10162</li>

10163<li id="section_6.22">

10164Gale RE, Hills R, Pizzey AR, et al.: Relationship between FLT3 mutation status, biologic characteristics, and response to targeted therapy in acute promyelocytic leukemia. Blood 106 (12): 3768-76, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16105978&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16105978&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10165[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10166</li>
