10467

10468

10469

10470 <section id="_69">

10471

10472 <h2>

10473Myeloid Proliferations Associated With Down Syndrome</h2>

10474

10475 <div id="_section_69" class="pdq-sections">

10476<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10477<h6>

10478In This Section</h6>

10479<ul>

10480<li>

10481<a href="#_966_toc">

10482Transient Abnormal Myelopoiesis (TAM) Associated With Down Syndrome</a>

10483</li>

10484<li>

10485<a href="#_1237_toc">

10486Myeloid Leukemia Associated With Down Syndrome</a>

10487</li>

10488<li>

10489<a href="#_972_toc">

10490Prognosis and Treatment of Children With Down Syndrome and AML<ul>

10491<li>

10492<a href="#_864_toc">

10493Treatment options under clinical evaluation</a>

10494</li>

10495</ul>

10496</a>

10497</li>

10498<li>

10499<a href="#_626_toc">

10500Refractory Disease or Relapse in Children With Down Syndrome</a>

10501</li>

10502</ul>

10503</nav>

10504<p id="_1964" tabindex="-1">

10505Myeloid leukemias that arise in children with Down syndrome, particularly in patients younger than 4 years, are a distinct subset of AML characterized by the co-existence of trisomy 21 and <em class="gene-name">

10506GATA1</em>

10507 mutations within the leukemic blasts that are often, but not always, megakaryoblastic. This distinct leukemia is further subdivided into two versions: a transient newborn and young-infant version called transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM), which spontaneously remits over time; and an unremitting but chemosensitive version that appears later, between the ages of 90 days and 3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

105081</a>

10509] It is important to recognize the possibility of these versions in both children with Down syndrome phenotypes and in those who have mosaic trisomy 21, which can be solely present in the leukemic blasts. If possible, newborns with apparent AML should not have therapy initiated until genetic testing results have been returned.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

105102</a>

10511] In older children with megakaryocytic AML, it is important to rule out the presence of co-existing trisomy 21 and <em class="gene-name">

10512GATA1</em>

10513 mutations; these children may be successfully treated on the lower-intensity chemotherapy regimens that are used for children with myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

105143</a>

10515]</p>

10516<section id="_966">

10517<h3 id="_966_toc">

10518Transient Abnormal Myelopoiesis (TAM) Associated With Down Syndrome</h3>

10519<p id="_274" tabindex="-1">

10520Approximately 10% of neonates with Down syndrome develop a TAM (also termed <em>

10521transient myeloproliferative disorder</em>

10522 [TMD]).[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

105232</a>

10524] This disorder mimics congenital AML but typically improves spontaneously within the first 3 months of life (median, 49 days), although TAM has been reported to remit as late as 20 months.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

105254</a>

10526] The late remissions likely reflect a persistent hepatomegaly from TAM-associated hepatic fibrosis rather than active disease.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

105275</a>

10528]</p>

10529<p id="_967" tabindex="-1">

10530 Although TAM is usually a self-resolving condition, it can be associated with significant morbidity and may be fatal in 10% to 17% of affected infants.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

105314</a>

10532-<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

105338</a>

10534] Infants with progressive organomegaly, visceral effusions, preterm delivery (less than 37 weeks of gestation), bleeding diatheses, failure of spontaneous remission, laboratory evidence of progressive liver dysfunction (elevated direct bilirubin), renal failure, and very high white blood cell (WBC) count are at particularly high risk of early mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

105355</a>

10536,<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

105376</a>

10538,<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

105398</a>

10540] Death has been reported to occur in 21% of these patients with high-risk TAM, although only 10% were attributable to TAM and the remaining deaths were caused by coexisting conditions known to be more prominent in neonates with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

105415</a>

10542]</p>

10543<p id="_968" tabindex="-1">

10544The following three risk groups have been identified on the basis of the diagnostic clinical findings of hepatomegaly with or without life-threatening symptoms:[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

105455</a>

10546]</p>

10547<div class="pdq-content-list">

10548<ul id="_969">

10549<li>

10550 <strong>

10551Low risk</strong>

10552 includes those with neither hepatomegaly nor life-threatening symptoms (38% of patients and an overall survival [OS] rate of 92% &#177; 8%).</li>

10553<li>

10554<strong>

10555Intermediate risk</strong>

10556 includes those with hepatomegaly alone (40% of patients and an OS rate of 77% &#177; 12%).</li>

10557<li>

10558<strong>

10559High risk</strong>

10560 includes those with hepatomegaly and life-threatening symptoms (21% of patients and an OS rate of 51% &#177; 19%).</li>

10561</ul>

10562</div>

10563<p id="_970" tabindex="-1">

10564Therapeutic intervention is warranted in patients with apparent severe hydrops or organ failure. Because TAM eventually spontaneously remits, treatment is short in duration and primarily aimed at the reduction of leukemic burden and resolution of immediate symptoms. Several treatment approaches have been used, including the following:</p>

10565<div class="pdq-content-list">

10566<ul id="_971">

10567<li>

10568Exchange transfusion.</li>

10569<li>

10570Leukapheresis.</li>

10571<li>

10572Low-dose cytarabine. Of these approaches, only cytarabine has been shown to consistently reduce TAM complications and related mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

105735</a>

10574,<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

105758</a>

10576]; [<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

105779</a>

10578][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10579Level of evidence B4</a>

10580] Cytarabine dosing has ranged from 0.4 to 1.5 mg/kg per dose given intravenously (IV) or subcutaneously (SC) once to twice daily for 4 to 12 days,[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

105818</a>

10582] with similar efficacies and less toxicity than higher, continuous 5-day infusions, which led to prolonged severe neutropenia.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

105835</a>

10584] A prospective trial that utilized cytarabine at 1.5 mg/kg per day IV or SC for 7 days for symptomatic patients reported a significant reduction in early death compared with similar historical controls (12% &#177; 5% vs. 33% &#177; 7%, respectively; <em>

10585P</em>

10586 = .2).[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

105879</a>

10588][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10589Level of evidence B4</a>

10590]</li>

10591</ul>

10592</div>

10593<p id="_1334" tabindex="-1">

10594Subsequent development of myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome is seen in 10% to 30% of children who have a spontaneous remission of TAM and has been reported at a mean age of 16 months (range, 1&#8211;30 months).[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

105954</a>

10596,<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

105975</a>

10598,<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

1059910</a>

10600] While TAM is generally not characterized by cytogenetic abnormalities other than trisomy 21, the presence of additional cytogenetic findings may connote an increased risk of developing subsequent myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

106016</a>

10602] An additional risk factor reported in two studies is the late resolution of TAM, measured by either time to complete resolution of signs of TAM (defined as resolution beyond the median, 47 days from diagnosis) or by persistence of minimal residual disease (MRD) in the peripheral blood at week 12 of follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

106035</a>

10604]; [<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

106059</a>

10606][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10607Level of evidence B4</a>

10608] The use of cytarabine for TAM symptoms or persistent MRD in TAM has failed to show a reduction in later myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome, as reported in large observational cohort studies.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

106095</a>

10610,<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

106118</a>

10612] In a prospective single-arm trial designed to assess whether cytarabine treatment for TAM could prevent the development of later myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome, no benefit was found when compared with historical controls (19% &#177; 4% vs. 22% &#177; 4%, respectively; <em>

10613P</em>

10614 = .88).[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

106159</a>

10616][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10617Level of evidence B4</a>

10618]</p>

10619</section>

10620<section id="_1237">

10621<h3 id="_1237_toc">

10622Myeloid Leukemia Associated With Down Syndrome</h3>

10623<p id="_1238" tabindex="-1">

10624Children

10625with Down syndrome have a 10-fold to 45-fold increased risk of leukemia when compared with children without Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

1062611</a>

10627] However, the ratio of acute

10628lymphoblastic leukemia to acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is typical for

10629childhood acute leukemia. The exception is during the first 3 years of life,

10630when AML, particularly the megakaryoblastic subtype, predominates and exhibits a distinctive biology characterized by <em class="gene-name">

10631GATA1</em>

10632 mutations and increased sensitivity to cytarabine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

1063312</a>

10634-<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

1063517</a>

10636] Importantly, these risks appear to be similar whether a child has phenotypic characteristics of Down syndrome or whether a child has only genetic bone marrow mosaicism.[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

1063718</a>

10638]</p>

10639</section>

10640<section id="_972">

10641<h3 id="_972_toc">

10642Prognosis and Treatment of Children With Down Syndrome and AML</h3>

10643<p id="_276" tabindex="-1">

10644Outcome is generally favorable for children with Down syndrome who develop AML (called myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome in the World Health Organization classification).[<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

1064519</a>

10646-<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

1064721</a>

10648] </p>

10649<p id="_1184" tabindex="-1">

10650Prognostic factors for children with Down syndrome and AML include the following:</p>

10651<div class="pdq-content-list">

10652<ul id="_1185">

10653<li>

10654<strong>

10655Age.</strong>

10656 The prognosis is particularly good (EFS rates exceeding 85%) in children aged 4 years or younger at diagnosis; this age group accounts for the vast majority of Down syndrome patients with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1065720</a>

10658-<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1065923</a>

10660] Children with Down syndrome who are older than 4 years have a significantly worse prognosis and warrant therapy utilized in children with AML without Down syndrome unless a <em class="gene-name">

10661GATA1</em>

10662 mutation is found.[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

1066324</a>

10664]</li>

10665<li>

10666<strong>

10667White blood cell count.</strong>

10668 A large international Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) retrospective study of 451 children with AML and Down syndrome (aged &gt;6 months and &lt;5 years) observed a 7-year EFS rate of 78% and a 7-year OS rate of 79%. In multivariate analyses, WBC count (&#8805;20 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

106699</span>

10670/L) and age (&gt;3 years) were independent predictors of lower EFS. The 7-year EFS rate for the older population (&gt;3 years) and for the higher WBC-count population still exceeded 60%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

1067125</a>

10672] </li>

10673<li>

10674<strong>

10675AML karyotype.</strong>

10676 Normal karyotypic AML (other than trisomy 21), which was observed in 29% of patients, independently predicted for inferior OS and EFS (7-year EFS rate of 65% compared with 82% for patients with aberrant karyotypes).[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

1067725</a>

10678] However, this was not seen in a later trial.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1067923</a>

10680] In this same trial, the presence of trisomy 8 was shown to adversely impact prognosis. In another study, complex karyotypes (&#8805;3 independent abnormalities) were prognostic of an increased cumulative incidence of relapse at 2 years (30.8% compared with 7.5% in patients without complex karyotypes; <em>

10681P</em>

10682 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

1068326</a>

10684]</li>

10685<li>

10686<strong>

10687MRD.</strong>

10688 MRD at the end of induction 1 was found to be a strong prognostic factor;[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

1068921</a>

10690,<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

1069127</a>

10692] this was consistent with the BFM finding that early response correlated with improved OS.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1069323</a>

10694] However, negative MRD at the end of induction 1 did not identify a group of patients who could receive reduced chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

1069526</a>

10696]</li>

10697</ul>

10698</div>

10699<p id="_1186" tabindex="-1">

10700Approximately 29% to 47% of Down syndrome patients present with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) (&lt;20% blasts) but their outcomes are similar to those with AML.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1070120</a>

10702,<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

1070321</a>

10704,<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1070523</a>

10706]</p>

10707<p id="_1141" tabindex="-1">

10708Treatment options for newly diagnosed children with Down syndrome and AML include the following:</p>

10709<div class="pdq-content-list">

10710<ol id="_1142">

10711<li>

10712Chemotherapy.</li>

10713</ol>

10714</div>

10715<p id="_974" tabindex="-1">

10716Appropriate therapy for younger children (aged &#8804;4 years) with Down syndrome and AML is less intensive than current standard childhood AML therapy. Hematopoietic stem cell transplant is not indicated in first remission.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

1071710</a>

10718,<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

1071914</a>

10720,<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

1072119</a>

10722-<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

1072324</a>

10724,<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

1072528</a>

10726]</p>

10727<p id="_1143" tabindex="-1">

10728Evidence (chemotherapy):</p>

10729<div class="pdq-content-list">

10730<ol id="_975">

10731<li>

10732In a Children's Oncology Group (COG) trial for newly diagnosed children with Down syndrome and AML (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00369317">

10733AAML0431 [NCT00369317]</a>

10734), 204 children were enrolled on a regimen that substituted high-dose cytarabine for the second of four induction cycles (thereby reducing cumulative anthracycline exposure from 320 mg to 240 mg), moving this cycle from intensification where it was used in the previous COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003593">

10735A2971 (NCT00003593)</a>

10736 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1073720</a>

10738,<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

1073921</a>

10740] Intrathecal doses were reduced from seven to two total injections and intensification included two cycles of cytarabine/etoposide. <div class="pdq-content-list">

10741<ul id="_976">

10742<li>

10743When compared with the previous trial, these changes resulted in an overall improvement of approximately 10%.</li>

10744<li>

10745The EFS rate was 89.9%, and the OS rate was 93%.</li>

10746<li>

10747Relapse occurred in 14 patients and there were two treatment-related deaths, both related to pneumonia, neither of which occurred during induction 2.</li>

10748<li>

10749No patient had central nervous system (CNS) involvement on this trial or the preceding COG A2971 (NCT00003593) trial.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1075020</a>

10751]</li>

10752<li>

10753The only prognostic factor identified was MRD using flow cytometry on day 28 of induction 1. Among those who were MRD negative (&#8804;0.01%), the DFS rate was 92.7%; in the 14.4% of patients who were MRD positive, the DFS rate was 76.2% (<em>

10754P</em>

10755 = .011).</li>

10756</ul>

10757</div>

10758</li>

10759<li>

10760In a joint trial (ML-DS 2006) from the BFM, Dutch Childhood Oncology Group (DCOG), and Nordic Society of Pediatric Hematology and Oncology (NOPHO), 170 children with Down syndrome were enrolled in a trial that focused on reducing therapy by eliminating etoposide during consolidation, reducing the number of intrathecal doses from 11 to 4, and the elimination of maintenance from the reduced therapy Down syndrome arm of AML-BFM 98.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1076123</a>

10762] As in the COG trials, no patient had CNS disease at diagnosis. <div class="pdq-content-list">

10763<ul id="_977">

10764<li>

10765Outcomes were no worse despite reduction in chemotherapy. The OS rate was 89% (&#177; 3%) and the EFS rate was 87% (&#177; 3%), similar to that observed in AML-BFM 98 (OS rate, 90% &#177; 4% [<em>

10766P</em>

10767 = NS]; EFS rate, 89% &#177; 4% [<em>

10768P</em>

10769 = NS]). The cumulative incidence of relapse (CIR) rate was 6% in both trials.</li>

10770<li>

10771Nine patients relapsed, and seven of those patients died.</li>

10772<li>

10773Patients with a good early response (&lt;5% blasts by morphology before induction cycle 2, n = 123 [72%]) had better outcomes (OS rate, 92% &#177; 3% vs. 57% &#177; 16%, <em>

10774P</em>

10775 &lt; .0001; EFS rate, 88% &#177; 3% vs. 58% &#177; 16%, <em>

10776P</em>

10777 = .0008; and CIR rate, 3% &#177; 2% vs. 27% &#177; 18%, <em>

10778P</em>

10779 = .003). </li>

10780<li>

10781Less toxicity was seen in this new trial, and treatment-related mortality remained low (2.9% vs. 5%, <em>

10782P</em>

10783 = .276).</li>

10784</ul>

10785</div>

10786<p id="_978" tabindex="-1">

10787The following two prognostic factors were identified:[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1078823</a>

10789]</p>

10790<div class="pdq-content-list">

10791<ul id="_979">

10792<li>

10793Trisomy 8 was an adverse factor (n = 37; OS rate, 77% vs. 95%, <em>

10794P</em>

10795 = .07; EFS rate, 73% &#177; 8% vs. 91% &#177; 4%, <em>

10796P</em>

10797 = .018; CIR rate, 16% &#177; 7% vs. 3% &#177; 2%, <em>

10798P</em>

10799 = .02).</li>

10800<li>

10801This was confirmed in multivariate analysis, where lack of good early response and trisomy 8 maintained their adverse impact on relapse, with relative risks of 8.55 (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.96&#8211;37.29, <em>

10802P</em>

10803 = .004) and 4.36 (1.24&#8211;15.39, <em>

10804P</em>

10805 = .022), respectively.</li>

10806</ul>

10807</div>

10808</li>

10809</ol>

10810</div>

10811<p id="_498" tabindex="-1">

10812Children with mosaicism for trisomy 21 are treated similarly to those children with clinically evident Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

108135</a>

10814,<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

1081518</a>

10816,<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1081720</a>

10818] Although an optimal treatment for these children has not been defined, they are usually treated on AML regimens designed for children without Down syndrome.</p>

10819<section id="_864">

10820<h4 id="_864_toc">

10821Treatment options under clinical evaluation</h4>

10822<p id="_865" tabindex="-1">

10823Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

10824NCI website</a>

10825. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

10826ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

10827.</p>

10828</section>

10829</section>

10830<section id="_626">

10831<h3 id="_626_toc">

10832Refractory Disease or Relapse in Children With Down Syndrome</h3>

10833<p id="_627" tabindex="-1">

10834A small number of publications address outcomes in children with Down syndrome who relapse after initial therapy or who have refractory AML. In three prospective trials of children with Down Syndrome and newly diagnosed AML, outcomes were poor for those who relapsed (4 of 11, 2 of 9, and 2 of 12 patients who relapsed survived).[<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

1083519</a>

10836,<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1083723</a>

10838,<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

1083926</a>

10840] Thus, these children are treated similarly to children without Down syndrome, with an intensive reinduction chemotherapy regimen, and if a remission is achieved, therapy is followed by an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).</p>

10841<p id="_1144" tabindex="-1">

10842Treatment options for children with Down syndrome with refractory or relapsed AML include the following:</p>

10843<div class="pdq-content-list">

10844<ol id="_1145">

10845<li>

10846Chemotherapy, which may be followed by an allogeneic HSCT.</li>

10847</ol>

10848</div>

10849<p id="_1032" tabindex="-1">

10850Evidence (treatment of children with Down syndrome with refractory or relapsed AML):</p>

10851<div class="pdq-content-list">

10852<ol id="_1033">

10853<li>

10854The Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group reported the outcomes of 29 patients with Down syndrome and relapsed (n = 26) or refractory (n = 3) AML. As expected with Down syndrome, the children in this cohort were very young (median age, 2 years); relapses were almost all early (median, 8.6 months; 80% &lt;12 months from diagnosis); and 89% had M7 French-American-British classification.[<a href="#cit/section_7.29">

1085529</a>

10856][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10857Level of evidence C1</a>

10858] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10859<ul id="_1034">

10860<li>

10861In contrast to the excellent outcomes achieved after initial therapy, only 50% of the children attained a second remission, and the 3-year OS rate was 26%.</li>

10862<li>

10863Approximately one-half of the children underwent allogeneic transplant, and no advantage was noted with transplant compared with chemotherapy, but the number of patients was small.</li>

10864</ul>

10865</div>

10866</li>

10867<li>

10868A Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research study of children with Down syndrome and AML who underwent HSCT reported the following results:[<a href="#cit/section_7.30">

1086930</a>

10870][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10871Level of evidence C1</a>

10872]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10873<ul id="_1989">

10874<li>

10875A similarly poor outcome, with a 3-year OS rate of 19%.</li>

10876<li>

10877The main cause of failure after transplant was relapse, which exceeded 60%; transplant-related mortality was approximately 20%.</li>

10878</ul>

10879</div>

10880 </li>

10881<li>

10882A Japanese registry study reported better survival after transplant of children with Down Syndrome using reduced-intensity conditioning regimens compared with myeloablative approaches, but the number of patients was very small (n = 5) and the efficacy of reduced-intensity approaches in children with Down syndrome and AML requires further study.[<a href="#cit/section_7.31">

1088331</a>

10884][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10885Level of evidence C2</a>

10886]</li>

10887</ol>

10888</div>

10889</section>

10890<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10891References</h6>

10896</li>

10899[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10900</li>

10901<li id="section_7.3">

10902de Rooij JD, Branstetter C, Ma J, et al.: Pediatric non-Down syndrome acute megakaryoblastic leukemia is characterized by distinct genomic subsets with varying outcomes. Nat Genet 49 (3): 451-456, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28112737&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28112737&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10903[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10904</li>

10905<li id="section_7.4">

10906Homans AC, Verissimo AM, Vlacha V: Transient abnormal myelopoiesis of infancy associated with trisomy 21. Am J Pediatr Hematol Oncol 15 (4): 392-9, 1993.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8214361&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8214361&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10907[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10908</li>

10909<li id="section_7.5">

10910Gamis AS, Alonzo TA, Gerbing RB, et al.: Natural history of transient myeloproliferative disorder clinically diagnosed in Down syndrome neonates: a report from the Children's Oncology Group Study A2971. Blood 118 (26): 6752-9; quiz 6996, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21849481&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21849481&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10911[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10912</li>

11021

11022

11023

11024 <section id="_74">

11025

11026 <h2>

11027Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS)</h2>

11028

11029 <div id="_section_74" class="pdq-sections">

11030<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

11031<h6>

11032In This Section</h6>

11033<ul>

11034<li>

11035<a href="#_982_toc">

11036Risk Factors</a>

11037</li>

11038<li>

11039<a href="#_980_toc">

11040Clinical Presentation</a>

11041</li>

11042<li>

11043<a href="#_981_toc">

11044Molecular Abnormalities<ul>

11045<li>

11046<a href="#_sm_CDR0000796536_1929_toc">

11047Molecular features of myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS)</a>

11048</li>

11049</ul>

11050</a>

11051</li>

11052<li>

11053<a href="#_983_toc">

11054Classification of MDS</a>

11055</li>

11056<li>

11057<a href="#_984_toc">

11058Treatment of Childhood MDS<ul>

11059<li>

11060<a href="#_1161_toc">

11061HSCT</a>

11062</li>

11063<li>

11064<a href="#_1162_toc">

11065Other therapies</a>

11066</li>

11067</ul>

11068</a>

11069</li>

11070<li>

11071<a href="#_217_toc">

11072Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation </a>

11073</li>

11074<li>

11075<a href="#_TrialSearch_74_sid_8_toc">

11076Current Clinical Trials</a>

11077</li>

11078</ul>

11079</nav>

11080<p id="_499" tabindex="-1">

11081Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and myeloproliferative syndromes (MPS) represent between 5% and 10% of all myeloid malignancies in children. They are a heterogeneous group of disorders, with MDS usually presenting with cytopenias and MPS presenting with increased peripheral white blood cell, red blood cell, or platelet counts. MDS is characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis and increased cell death, while MPS is associated with increased progenitor proliferation and survival. Because they both represent disorders of very primitive, multipotential hematopoietic stem cells, curative therapeutic approaches nearly always require allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).</p>

11082<section id="_982">

11083<h3 id="_982_toc">

11084Risk Factors</h3>

11085<p id="_719" tabindex="-1">

11086Patients with the following germline mutations or inherited disorders have a significantly increased risk of developing MDS:</p>

11087<div class="pdq-content-list">

11088<ul id="_737">

11089<li>

11090<strong>

11091Fanconi anemia:</strong>

11092 Caused by germline mutations in DNA repair genes.</li>

11093<li>

11094<strong>

11095Dyskeratosis congenita:</strong>

11096 Resulting from mutations in genes regulating telomere length. Genes mutated in dyskeratosis congenita include <em class="gene-name">

11097ACD</em>

11098, <em class="gene-name">

11099CTC1</em>

11100, <em class="gene-name">

11101DKC1</em>

11102, <em class="gene-name">

11103NHP2</em>

11104, <em class="gene-name">

11105NOP10</em>

11106, <em class="gene-name">

11107PARN</em>

11108, <em class="gene-name">

11109RTEL1</em>

11110, <em class="gene-name">

11111TERC</em>

11112, <em class="gene-name">

11113TERT</em>

11114, <em class="gene-name">

11115TINF2</em>

11116, and <em class="gene-name">

11117WRAP53</em>

11118.</li>

11119<li>

11120<strong>

11121Shwachman-Diamond syndrome, Diamond-Blackfan anemia, and other bone marrow failure syndromes:</strong>

11122 Resulting from mutations in genes encoding ribosome-associated proteins.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

111231</a>

11124,<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

111252</a>

11126] <em class="gene-name">

11127GATA1</em>

11128 mutations have been linked to Diamond-Blackfan anemia and MDS predisposition.[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

111293</a>

11130]</li>

11131<li>

11132<strong>

11133Severe congenital neutropenia:</strong>

11134 Caused by mutations in the gene encoding elastase. The 15-year cumulative risk of MDS in patients with severe congenital neutropenia, also known as Kostmann syndrome, has been estimated to be 15%, with an annual risk of MDS/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) of 2% to 3%. It is unclear how mutations affecting this protein and how the chronic exposure of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) contribute to the development of MDS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

111354</a>

11136]</li>

11137<li>

11138<strong>

11139Trisomy 21 syndrome:</strong>

11140 <em class="gene-name">

11141GATA1</em>

11142 mutations are nearly always present in the transient leukemia associated with Trisomy 21 and MDS in children younger than 3 years with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

111435</a>

11144] </li>

11145<li>

11146<strong>

11147Congenital amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia (CAMT):</strong>

11148 Inherited mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

11149RUNX1</em>

11150 or <em class="gene-name">

11151CEPBA</em>

11152 genes are associated with CAMT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

111536</a>

11154,<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

111557</a>

11156] Mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

11157MPL</em>

11158 gene are the underlying genetic cause of CAMT; there is a less than 10% risk of developing MDS/AML in patients with CAMT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.8">

111598</a>

11160]</li>

11161<li>

11162<strong>

11163<em class="gene-name">

11164GATA2</em>

11165 mutations:</strong>

11166 Germline mutations of <em class="gene-name">

11167GATA2</em>

11168 have been reported in patients with MDS/AML in conjunction with monocytopenia, B cell and natural killer cell deficiency, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, and susceptibility to opportunistic infections.[<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

111699</a>

11170,<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

1117110</a>

11172]</li>

11173<li>

11174<strong>

11175<em class="gene-name">

11176RUNX1</em>

11177 or <em class="gene-name">

11178CEPBA</em>

11179 mutations:</strong>

11180 Inherited mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

11181RUNX1</em>

11182 or <em class="gene-name">

11183CEPBA</em>

11184 genes are associated with familial MDS/AML.[<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

111856</a>

11186,<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

111877</a>

11188]</li>

11189<li>

11190<strong>

11191<em class="gene-name">

11192SAMD9</em>

11193 and <em class="gene-name">

11194SAMD9L</em>

11195 mutations:</strong>

11196 Inherited mutations in <em class="gene-name">

11197SAMD9</em>

11198 and <em class="gene-name">

11199SAMD9L</em>

11200 are associated with familial MDS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1120111</a>

11202-<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

1120316</a>

11204]</li>

11205</ul>

11206</div>

11207<p id="_1206" tabindex="-1">

11208A retrospective analysis that used a capture assay to target mutations known to predispose to marrow failure and MDS was performed on genomic DNA from peripheral blood mononuclear cell samples from patients undergoing HSCT for MDS and aplastic anemia. Among the 46 children aged 18 years and younger with MDS, 10 patients (22%) harbored constitutional predisposition genetic mutations (5 <em class="gene-name">

11209GATA2</em>

11210, 1 each of <em class="gene-name">

11211MPL</em>

11212, <em class="gene-name">

11213RTEL1</em>

11214, <em class="gene-name">

11215SBDS</em>

11216, <em class="gene-name">

11217TINF2</em>

11218, and <em class="gene-name">

11219TP53</em>

11220), of which only 2 were suspected before transplant. This is considered a high incidence of genetic mutations compared with only 8% (4 of 64) in patients aged 18 to 40 years.[<a href="#cit/section_8.17">

1122117</a>

11222]</p>

11223</section>

11224<section id="_980">

11225<h3 id="_980_toc">

11226Clinical Presentation</h3>

11227<p id="_500" tabindex="-1">

11228Patients usually present with signs of cytopenias, including pallor, infection, or bruising.</p>

11229<p id="_1187" tabindex="-1">

11230The bone marrow is usually characterized by hypercellularity and dysplastic changes in myeloid precursors. Clonal evolution can eventually lead to the development of AML. The percentage of abnormal blasts is less than 20% and lack common AML recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities (t(8;21), inv(16), t(15;17), or <em class="gene-name">

11231KMT2A</em>

11232 translocations).</p>

11233<p id="_1188" tabindex="-1">

11234The less common hypocellular MDS can be distinguished from aplastic anemia in part by its marked dysplasia, clonal nature, and higher percentage of CD34-positive precursors.[<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

1123518</a>

11236,<a href="#cit/section_8.19">

1123719</a>

11238]</p>

11239</section>

11240<section id="_981">

11241<h3 id="_981_toc">

11242Molecular Abnormalities</h3>

11243<section id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1929">

11244<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1929_toc">

11245Molecular features of myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS)</h4>

11246<p id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1920" tabindex="-1">

11247Compared with MDS in adults, pediatric MDS is associated with a distinctive constellation of genetic alterations. In adults, MDS often evolves from clonal hematopoiesis and is characterized by mutations in <em class="gene-name">

11248TET2</em>

11249, <em class="gene-name">

11250DNMT3A</em>

11251, and <em class="gene-name">

11252TP53</em>

11253. In contrast, mutations in these genes are rare in pediatric MDS, while mutations in <em class="gene-name">

11254GATA2</em>

11255, <em class="gene-name">

11256SAMD9</em>

11257, <em class="gene-name">

11258SAMD9L</em>

11259, <em class="gene-name">

11260SETBP1</em>

11261, <em class="gene-name">

11262ASXL1</em>

11263, and RAS/MAPK pathway genes are observed in subsets of children with MDS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1126411</a>

11265,<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

1126620</a>

11267]</p>

11268<p id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1921" tabindex="-1">

11269A report of the genomic landscape of pediatric MDS described the results of whole-exome sequencing for 32 pediatric patients with primary MDS and targeted sequencing for another 14 cases.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1127011</a>

11271] These 46 cases were equally divided between refractory cytopenia of childhood and MDS with excess blasts (MDS-EB). The results from the report include the following:</p>

11272<div class="pdq-content-list">

11273<ul id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1922">

11274<li>

11275Mutations in RAS/MAPK pathway genes were observed in 43% of primary MDS cases, with mutations most commonly involving <em class="gene-name">

11276PTPN11</em>

11277 and <em class="gene-name">

11278NRAS</em>

11279 but with mutations also observed in other pathway members (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

11280BRAF</em>

11281 [non&#8211;<em class="gene-name">

11282BRAF</em>

11283 V600E], <em class="gene-name">

11284CBL</em>

11285, and <em class="gene-name">

11286KRAS</em>

11287). RAS/MAPK mutations were more common in patients with MDS-EB (65%) than in patients with refractory cytopenia of childhood (17%). </li>

11288<li>

11289Germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

11290SAMD9</em>

11291 (n = 4) or <em class="gene-name">

11292SAMD9L</em>

11293 (n = 4) were observed in 17% of patients with primary MDS, with seven of eight mutations occurring in patients with refractory cytopenia of childhood. These cases all showed loss of material on chromosome 7. Approximately 40% of patients with deletions of part or all of chromosome 7 had germline <em class="gene-name">

11294SAMD9</em>

11295 or <em class="gene-name">

11296SAMD9L</em>

11297 variants. </li>

11298<li>

11299<em class="gene-name">

11300GATA2</em>

11301 mutations were observed in three cases (7%), and all cases were confirmed or presumed to be germline. </li>

11302<li>

11303Deletions involving chromosome 7 were the most common copy number alteration and were observed in 41% of cases. Loss of part or all of chromosome 7 was most commonly observed in <em class="gene-name">

11304SAMD9</em>

11305 and <em class="gene-name">

11306SAMD9L</em>

11307 cases (100%) and in MDS-EB patients with a RAS/MAPK mutation (71%).</li>

11308<li>

11309Other genes that were mutated in more than 1 of the 46 cases studied included <em class="gene-name">

11310SETBP1</em>

11311, <em class="gene-name">

11312ETV6</em>

11313, and <em class="gene-name">

11314TP53</em>

11315. </li>

11316</ul>

11317</div>

11318<p id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1923" tabindex="-1">

11319A second report described the application of a targeted sequencing panel of 105 genes to 50 pediatric patients with MDS (refractory cytopenia of childhood = 31 and MDS-EB = 19) and was enriched for cases with monosomy 7 (48%).[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1132011</a>

11321,<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

1132220</a>

11323] <em class="gene-name">

11324SAMD9</em>

11325 and <em class="gene-name">

11326SAMD9L</em>

11327 were not included in the gene panel. The second report described the following results:</p>

11328<div class="pdq-content-list">

11329<ul id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1924">

11330<li>

11331Germline <em class="gene-name">

11332GATA2</em>

11333 mutations were observed in 30% of patients, and <em class="gene-name">

11334RUNX1</em>

11335 mutations were observed in 6% of patients.</li>

11336<li>

11337Somatic mutations were observed in 34% of patients and were more common in patients with MDS-EB than in patients with refractory cytopenia of childhood (68% vs. 13%).</li>

11338<li>

11339The most commonly mutated gene was <em class="gene-name">

11340SETBP1</em>

11341 (18%); less commonly mutated genes included <em class="gene-name">

11342ASXL1</em>

11343, <em class="gene-name">

11344RUNX1</em>

11345, and RAS/MAPK pathway genes (<em class="gene-name">

11346PTPN11</em>

11347, <em class="gene-name">

11348NRAS</em>

11349, <em class="gene-name">

11350KRAS</em>

11351, <em class="gene-name">

11352NF1</em>

11353). Twelve percent of cases showed mutations in RAS/MAPK pathway genes.</li>

11354</ul>

11355</div>

11356<p id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1925" tabindex="-1">

11357Patients with germline <em class="gene-name">

11358GATA2</em>

11359 mutations, in addition to MDS, show a wide range of hematopoietic and immune defects as well as nonhematopoietic manifestations.[<a href="#cit/section_8.21">

1136021</a>

11361] The former defects include monocytopenia with susceptibility to atypical mycobacterial infection and DCML deficiency (loss of dendritic cells, monocytes, and B and natural killer lymphoid cells). The resulting immunodeficiency leads to increased susceptibility to warts, severe viral infections, mycobacterial infections, fungal infections, and human papillomavirus&#8211;related cancers. The nonhematopoietic manifestations include deafness and lymphedema. </p>

11362<p id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1933" tabindex="-1">

11363Germline <em class="gene-name">

11364GATA2</em>

11365 mutations were studied in 426 pediatric patients with primary MDS and 82 cases with secondary MDS who were enrolled in consecutive studies of the European Working Group of MDS in Childhood (EWOG-MDS).[<a href="#cit/section_8.22">

1136622</a>

11367] The study had the following results:</p>

11368<div class="pdq-content-list">

11369<ul id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1926">

11370<li>

11371Germline <em class="gene-name">

11372GATA2</em>

11373 mutations were identified in 7% of pediatric patients with primary MDS. While the median age of patients presenting with <em class="gene-name">

11374GATA2</em>

11375 mutations was 12.3 years in the EWOG-MDS pediatric population, most cases of germline <em class="gene-name">

11376GATA2</em>

11377-related myeloid neoplasms occur during adulthood.[<a href="#cit/section_8.23">

1137823</a>

11379]</li>

11380<li>

11381<em class="gene-name">

11382GATA2</em>

11383 mutations were more common in patients with MDS-EB (15%) than in patients with refractory cytopenia of childhood (4%).</li>

11384<li>

11385Among patients with <em class="gene-name">

11386GATA2</em>

11387 mutations, 46% presented with MDS-EB, and 70% showed monosomy 7.</li>

11388<li>

11389Familial MDS/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) was identified in 12 of 53 patients with <em class="gene-name">

11390GATA2</em>

11391 mutations for whom detailed family histories were available.</li>

11392<li>

11393Nonhematologic phenotypes of <em class="gene-name">

11394GATA2</em>

11395 deficiency were present in 51% of patients with MDS who had <em class="gene-name">

11396GATA2</em>

11397 mutations and included deafness (9%), lymphedema/hydrocele (23%), and immunodeficiency (39%).</li>

11398</ul>

11399</div>

11400<p id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1927" tabindex="-1">

11401<em class="gene-name">

11402SAMD9</em>

11403 and <em class="gene-name">

11404SAMD9L</em>

11405 germline mutations are both associated with pediatric MDS cases in which there is an additional loss of all or part of chromosome 7.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1140612</a>

11407,<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

1140813</a>

11409] </p>

11410<p id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1934" tabindex="-1">

11411In 2016, <em class="gene-name">

11412SAMD9</em>

11413 was identified as the cause of the MIRAGE syndrome (myelodysplasia, infection, restriction of growth, adrenal hypoplasia, genital phenotypes, and enteropathy), which is associated with early-onset MDS with monosomy 7.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1141414</a>

11415] Subsequently, mutations in <em class="gene-name">

11416SAMD9L</em>

11417 were identified in patients with ataxia pancytopenia syndrome (ATXPC; <a href="https://www.omim.org/entry/159550" title="https://www.omim.org/entry/159550">

11418OMIM 159550</a>

11419). <em class="gene-name">

11420SAMD9</em>

11421 and <em class="gene-name">

11422SAMD9L</em>

11423 mutations were also identified as the cause of myelodysplasia and leukemia syndrome with monosomy 7 (MLSM7; <a href="https://www.omim.org/entry/252270" title="https://www.omim.org/entry/252270">

11424OMIM 252270</a>

11425),[<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

1142615</a>

11427] a syndrome first identified in phenotypically normal siblings who developed MDS or AML associated with monosomy 7 during childhood.[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

1142816</a>

11429]</p>

11430<div class="pdq-content-list">

11431<ul id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1928">

11432<li>

11433Causative mutations in both <em class="gene-name">

11434SAMD9</em>

11435 and <em class="gene-name">

11436SAMD9L</em>

11437 are gain-of-function mutations and enhance the growth-suppressing activity of <em class="gene-name">

11438SAMD9</em>

11439 and <em class="gene-name">

11440SAMD9L</em>

11441.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1144214</a>

11443,<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

1144416</a>

11445]</li>

11446<li>

11447Both <em class="gene-name">

11448SAMD9</em>

11449 and <em class="gene-name">

11450SAMD9L</em>

11451 are located at chromosome 7q21.2. Cases of MDS in patients with <em class="gene-name">

11452SAMD9</em>

11453 or <em class="gene-name">

11454SAMD9L</em>

11455 mutations often show monosomy 7, with the remaining chromosome 7 having wild-type <em class="gene-name">

11456SAMD9</em>

11457 and <em class="gene-name">

11458SAMD9L</em>

11459. This results in the loss of the enhanced growth-suppressing activity of the mutated gene. </li>

11460<li>

11461Phenotypically normal patients with <em class="gene-name">

11462SAMD9</em>

11463 or <em class="gene-name">

11464SAMD9L</em>

11465 mutations and monosomy 7 may progress to MDS or AML or, alternatively, may show loss of their monosomy 7 with a return of normal hematopoiesis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

1146616</a>

11467] The former outcome is associated with the acquisition of mutations in genes associated with MDS/AML (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

11468ETV6</em>

11469 or <em class="gene-name">

11470SETBP1</em>

11471). The latter outcome is associated with genetic alterations (e.g., revertant mutations or copy-neutral loss of heterozygosity with retention of the wild-type allele) that result in normalization of <em class="gene-name">

11472SAMD9</em>

11473 or <em class="gene-name">

11474SAMD9L</em>

11475 activity. These observations suggest that monitoring patients with <em class="gene-name">

11476SAMD9</em>

11477- or <em class="gene-name">

11478SAMD9L</em>

11479-related monosomy 7, using clinical sequencing for acquired mutations in genes associated with progression to AML, may identify those at high risk of leukemic transformation. Such patients may benefit most from hematopoietic stem cell transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

1148016</a>

11481]</li>

11482</ul>

11483</div>

11484<p id="_sm_CDR0000796536_1935" tabindex="-1">

11485The presence of an isolated monosomy 7 is the most common cytogenetic abnormality, although it does not appear to portend a poor prognosis, compared with its presence in overt AML. However, the presence of monosomy 7 in combination with other cytogenetic abnormalities is associated with a poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.24">

1148624</a>

11487,<a href="#cit/section_8.25">

1148825</a>

11489] The relatively common abnormalities of -Y, 20q-, and 5q- in adults with MDS are rare in childhood MDS. The presence of cytogenetic abnormalities that are found in AML (t(8;21)(q22;q22.1), inv(16)(p13.1;q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22), and APL with <em class="gene-name">

11490PML</em>

11491::<em class="gene-name">

11492RARA</em>

11493 gene fusions) defines disease that should be treated as AML and not MDS, regardless of blast percentage. The World Health Organization (WHO) notes that whether this should also apply to other recurring genetic abnormalities remains controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_8.26">

1149426</a>

11495]</p>

11496</section>

11497<p id="_1305" tabindex="-1">

11498For more information about the World Health Organization (WHO) classification system of MDS, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_30">

11499WHO Classification of Bone Marrow and Peripheral Blood Findings for Myelodysplastic Syndromes</a>

11500 section.</p>

11501</section>

11502<section id="_983">

11503<h3 id="_983_toc">

11504Classification of MDS</h3>

11505<p id="_502" tabindex="-1">

11506The French-American-British (FAB) and WHO classification systems of MDS and MPS have been difficult to apply to pediatric patients. Alternative classification systems for children have been proposed, but none have been uniformly adopted, with the exception of the modified 2008 WHO classification system.[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1150727</a>

11508-<a href="#cit/section_8.31">

1150931</a>

11510] The WHO system [<a href="#cit/section_8.32">

1151132</a>

11512] has been modified for pediatrics.[<a href="#cit/section_8.30">

1151330</a>

11514] For information about the WHO classification schema and diagnostic criteria, see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_872">

11515Table 3</a>

11516 and <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_741">

11517Table 4</a>

11518. The 2016 revisions to the WHO MDS classification system did not affect classification in children.[<a href="#cit/section_8.33">

1151933</a>

11520]</p>

11521<p id="_507" tabindex="-1">

11522The refractory cytopenia subtype represents approximately 50% of all childhood cases of MDS. The presence of an isolated monosomy 7 is the most common cytogenetic abnormality, although it does not appear to portend a poor prognosis compared with its presence in overt AML. However, the presence of monosomy 7 in combination with other cytogenetic abnormalities is associated with a poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.24">

1152324</a>

11524,<a href="#cit/section_8.25">

1152525</a>

11526] In one retrospective analysis, only the revised International Prognostic Scoring System (R-IPSS) very poor&#8211;risk subgroup, defined as having complex cytogenetics (i.e., &gt;3 abnormalities), was found to have a significant adverse prognostic impact on OS and relapse risk after transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_8.34">

1152734</a>

11528] The relatively common abnormalities of -Y, 20q-, and 5q- in adults with MDS are rare in childhood MDS. The presence of cytogenetic abnormalities that are found in AML (t(8;21)(q22;q22.1), inv(16)(p13.1;q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22), and APL with <em class="gene-name">

11529PML</em>

11530::<em class="gene-name">

11531RARA</em>

11532 gene fusions) defines disease that should be treated as AML and not MDS, regardless of blast percentage. The WHO notes that whether this should also apply to other recurring genetic abnormalities remains controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_8.26">

1153326</a>

11534]</p>

11535<p id="_2170" tabindex="-1">

11536The R-IPSS prognostic groups and associated cytogenetic abnormalities include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.34">

1153734</a>

11538]</p>

11539<div class="pdq-content-list">

11540<ul id="_2171">

11541<li>

11542<strong>

11543Very good prognostic group:</strong>

11544 -Y; del(11q).</li>

11545<li>

11546<strong>

11547Good prognostic group:</strong>

11548 Normal; del(5q); del(20q); del(12p); double including del(5q).</li>

11549<li>

11550<strong>

11551Intermediate prognostic group:</strong>

11552 del(7q); +8; i(17q); +19; any other single or double independent clones.</li>

11553<li>

11554<strong>

11555Poor prognostic group:</strong>

11556 -7; inv(3)/t(3q)/del(3q); double including -7/del(7q); complex: 3 abnormalities.</li>

11557<li>

11558<strong>

11559Very poor prognostic group:</strong>

11560 Complex: &gt;3 abnormalities.</li>

11561</ul>

11562</div>

11563<p id="_720" tabindex="-1">

11564The IPSS can help to distinguish low-risk from high-risk MDS, although its utility in children with MDS is more limited than in adults because many characteristics differ between children and adults.[<a href="#cit/section_8.35">

1156535</a>

11566,<a href="#cit/section_8.36">

1156736</a>

11568] The median survival for children with high-risk MDS remains substantially better than adults, and the presence of monosomy 7 in children has not had the same adverse prognostic impact as does the presence in adults with MDS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.37">

1156937</a>

11570]</p>

11571</section>

11572<section id="_984">

11573<h3 id="_984_toc">

11574Treatment of Childhood MDS</h3>

11575<p id="_1159" tabindex="-1">

11576Treatment options for children with MDS include the following:</p>

11577<div class="pdq-content-list">

11578<ol id="_1160">

11579<li>

11580<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1161">

11581HSCT</a>

11582.</li>

11583<li>

11584<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1162">

11585Other therapies</a>

11586.</li>

11587</ol>

11588</div>

11589<section id="_1161">

11590<h4 id="_1161_toc">

11591HSCT</h4>

11592<p id="_508" tabindex="-1">

11593MDS and associated disorders usually involve a primitive hematopoietic stem cell. Thus, allogeneic HSCT is considered to be the optimal approach to treatment for pediatric patients with MDS. Although matched sibling transplantation is preferred, similar survival has been noted with well-matched, unrelated cord blood and haploidentical approaches.[<a href="#cit/section_8.38">

1159438</a>

11595-<a href="#cit/section_8.42">

1159642</a>

11597]</p>

11598<p id="_985" tabindex="-1">

11599When making treatment decisions, some data should be considered. For example, survival as high as 80% has been reported for patients with early-stage MDS who proceeded to transplant within a few months of diagnosis. Additionally, early transplant and not receiving pretransplant chemotherapy have been associated with improved survival in children with MDS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.43">

1160043</a>

11601][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11602Level of evidence C1</a>

11603] Disease-free survival (DFS) rates have been estimated to be between 50% to 70% for pediatric patients with advanced MDS using myeloablative transplant preparative regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_8.41">

1160441</a>

11605,<a href="#cit/section_8.44">

1160644</a>

11607-<a href="#cit/section_8.47">

1160847</a>

11609] While nonmyeloablative preparative transplant regimens are being tested in patients with MDS and AML, such regimens are still investigational for children with these disorders, but may be reasonable in the setting of a clinical trial or when a patient&#8217;s organ function is compromised in such a way that they would not tolerate a myeloablative regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_8.48">

1161048</a>

11611-<a href="#cit/section_8.51">

1161251</a>

11613]; [<a href="#cit/section_8.52">

1161452</a>

11615][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11616Level of evidence C1</a>

11617]</p>

11618<p id="_1189" tabindex="-1">

11619The question of whether chemotherapy should be used in high-risk MDS has been examined.</p>

11620<p id="_1076" tabindex="-1">

11621Evidence (HSCT):</p>

11622<div class="pdq-content-list">

11623<ol id="_1077">

11624<li>

11625An analysis of 37 children with MDS treated on Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster AML protocols 83, 87, and 93 confirmed the induction response of 74% for patients with refractory anemia with excess blasts in transformation and suggested that transplantation was beneficial.[<a href="#cit/section_8.53">

1162653</a>

11627]</li>

11628<li>

11629Another study by the same group showed that with current approaches to HSCT, survival occurred in more than 60% of children with advanced MDS, and outcomes for patients receiving unrelated donor cells were similar to those for patients who received matched-family donor (MFD) cells.[<a href="#cit/section_8.54">

1163054</a>

11631]</li>

11632<li>

11633The Children's Cancer Group 2891 trial accrued patients between 1989 and 1995, including children with

11634MDS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.44">

1163544</a>

11636] There were 77 patients enrolled, including patients with refractory anemia (n = 2), refractory anemia with excess blasts (n = 33),

11637refractory anemia with excess blasts in transformation (n = 26), or AML with antecedent MDS (n = 16). Patients were randomly assigned

11638to receive either standard or intensively timed induction. Subsequently, patients were allocated to

11639allogeneic HSCT if there was a suitable family donor, or

11640randomly assigned to either autologous HSCT or chemotherapy.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11641<ul id="_989">

11642<li>

11643Patients with

11644refractory anemia or refractory anemia with excess blasts had a lower remission rate (45%), and those with refractory anemia with excess blasts in transformation (69%) or AML

11645with history of MDS (81%) had similar remission rates compared with de novo AML (77%).</li>

11646<li>

11647The 6-year survival rates were lower for those with refractory anemia or refractory anemia with excess blasts (28%) and refractory anemia with excess blasts in transformation (30%).</li>

11648<li>

11649Patients with AML and

11650antecedent MDS had a similar outcome to those with de novo AML (50% survival compared with

1165145%).</li>

11652<li>

11653Allogeneic HSCT appeared to improve survival (<em>

11654P</em>

11655 = .08).</li>

11656</ul>

11657</div>

11658</li>

11659</ol>

11660</div>

11661<p id="_510" tabindex="-1">

11662When analyzing these results, it is important to consider that the subtype refractory anemia with excess blasts in transformation is likely to represent patients with overt AML, while refractory anemia and refractory anemia with excess blasts represents MDS. The WHO classification has now omitted the category of refractory anemia with excess blasts in transformation, concluding that this entity was essentially AML.</p>

11663<p id="_1190" tabindex="-1">

11664Because survival after HSCT is improved in children with early forms of MDS (refractory anemia), transplantation before progression to late MDS or AML should be considered. HSCT should especially be considered when transfusions or other treatment are required, as is usually the case in patients with severe symptomatic cytopenias.[<a href="#cit/section_8.41">

1166541</a>

11666,<a href="#cit/section_8.47">

1166747</a>

11668] The 8-year disease-free survival (DFS) rates for children with various stages of MDS has been reported to be 65% for those treated with HLA matched donor transplants and 40% for those treated with mismatched unrelated donor transplants.[<a href="#cit/section_8.47">

1166947</a>

11670][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11671Level of evidence C2</a>

11672] A 3-year DFS rate of 50% was reported with the use of unrelated cord blood donor transplants for children with MDS, when the transplants were done after the year 2001.[<a href="#cit/section_8.55">

1167355</a>

11674][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11675Level of evidence C2</a>

11676]</p>

11677<p id="_721" tabindex="-1">

11678Because MDS in children is often associated with inherited predisposition syndromes, reports of transplantation in small numbers of patients with these disorders have been documented. For example, in patients with Fanconi anemia and AML or advanced MDS, the 5-year overall survival (OS) rate has been reported to be 33% to 55%.[<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

1167956</a>

11680,<a href="#cit/section_8.57">

1168157</a>

11682][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11683Level of evidence C1</a>

11684] Second transplants have also been used in pediatric patients with MDS/MPD who relapse or suffer graft failure. The 3-year OS rates were 33% for those retransplanted after relapse and 57% for those transplanted after initial graft failure.[<a href="#cit/section_8.58">

1168558</a>

11686][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11687Level of evidence C1</a>

11688]</p>

11689<p id="_2104" tabindex="-1">

11690While some patients with inherited predisposition syndromes require significant modification of their transplant approaches because of excess toxicity (e.g., Fanconi anemia), other syndromes have no detectable excessive toxicity associated with the transplant process. Inherited <em class="gene-name">

11691GATA2</em>

11692 is a good example of the latter. One study compared HSCT outcomes of 65 children with <em class="gene-name">

11693GATA2</em>

11694 germline mutations and MDS with the outcomes of 404 children with MDS and wild-type germline <em class="gene-name">

11695GATA2</em>

11696. Disease-free survival, relapse, and nonrelapse mortality were similar in the two populations.[<a href="#cit/section_8.59">

1169759</a>

11698] </p>

11699<p id="_511" tabindex="-1">

11700For patients with clinically significant cytopenias, supportive care that includes transfusions and prophylactic antibiotics are considered standard of care. The use of hematopoietic growth factors can improve the hematopoietic status, but concerns remain that such treatment could accelerate conversion to AML.[<a href="#cit/section_8.60">

1170160</a>

11702]</p>

11703</section>

11704<section id="_1162">

11705<h4 id="_1162_toc">

11706Other therapies</h4>

11707<p id="_1083" tabindex="-1">

11708Other supportive therapies that have been studied include the following:</p>

11709<div class="pdq-content-list">

11710<ul id="_1084">

11711<li>

11712Steroid therapies, including glucocorticoids and androgens, have been tested with mixed results.[<a href="#cit/section_8.61">

1171361</a>

11714]</li>

11715<li>

11716Treatments directed toward scavenging free oxygen radicals with amifostine [<a href="#cit/section_8.62">

1171762</a>

11718,<a href="#cit/section_8.63">

1171963</a>

11720] or the use of differentiation-promoting retinoids,[<a href="#cit/section_8.64">

1172164</a>

11722] DNA methylation inhibitors (e.g., azacitidine and decitabine), and histone deacetylase inhibitors have all shown some response, but no definitive trials in children with MDS have been reported. Azacitidine has been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of MDS in adults on the basis of randomized studies.[<a href="#cit/section_8.65">

1172365</a>

11724] For more information, see the <a href="/types/myeloproliferative/hp/myelodysplastic-treatment-pdq#_254">

11725Disease-Modifying Agents</a>

11726 section in Myelodysplastic Syndromes Treatment.</li>

11727<li>

11728Agents such as lenalidomide, an analog of thalidomide, have been tested based on findings that demonstrated increased activity in the bone marrow of patients with MDS. Lenalidomide has shown the most efficacy in patients with 5q- syndrome, especially those with thrombocytosis, and is now FDA approved for use in adults with this finding.[<a href="#cit/section_8.66">

1172966</a>

11730]</li>

11731<li>

11732Immunosuppression with antithymocyte globulin and/or cyclosporine has also been reported in adults.[<a href="#cit/section_8.66">

1173366</a>

11734,<a href="#cit/section_8.67">

1173567</a>

11736]</li>

11737</ul>

11738</div>

11739</section>

11740</section>

11741<section id="_217">

11742<h3 id="_217_toc">

11743Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation </h3>

11744<p id="_1147" tabindex="-1">

11745Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

11746NCI website</a>

11747. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

11748ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

11749.</p>

11750</section>

11751<section id="_TrialSearch_74_sid_8">

11752<h3 id="_TrialSearch_74_sid_8_toc">

11753Current Clinical Trials</h3>

11754<p id="_TrialSearch_74_22" tabindex="-1">

11755Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

11756advanced clinical trial search</a>

11757 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

11758General information</a>

11759 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

11760</section>

11880[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

11881</li>

11882<li id="section_8.31">

11883Mandel K, Dror Y, Poon A, et al.: A practical, comprehensive classification for pediatric myelodysplastic syndromes: the CCC system. 12033 </section>

12034

12035

12036

12037 <section id="_607">

12038

12039 <h2>

12040Therapy-Related AML and Therapy-Related Myelodysplastic Syndromes</h2>

12041

12042 <div id="_section_607" class="pdq-sections">

12043<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

12044<h6>

12045In This Section</h6>

12046<ul>

12047<li>

12048<a href="#_990_toc">

12049Pathogenesis</a>

12050</li>

12051<li>

12052<a href="#_993_toc">

12053Treatment of t-AML or t-MDS</a>

12054</li>

12055</ul>

12056</nav>

12057<section id="_990">

12058<h3 id="_990_toc">

12059Pathogenesis</h3>

12060<p id="_617" tabindex="-1">

12061The development of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) after treatment with ionizing radiation or chemotherapy, particularly alkylating agents and topoisomerase inhibitors, is termed <em>

12062therapy-related AML</em>

12063 (t-AML) or <em>

12064therapy-related MDS</em>

12065 (t-MDS). In addition to genotoxic exposures, genetic predisposition susceptibilities (such as polymorphisms in drug detoxification and DNA repair pathway components) may contribute to the occurrence of secondary AML/MDS.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

120661</a>

12067-<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

120684</a>

12069]</p>

12070<p id="_991" tabindex="-1">

12071The risk of t-AML or t-MDS is regimen-dependent and often related to the cumulative doses of chemotherapy agents received and the dose and field of radiation administered.[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

120725</a>

12073] Regimens previously used that employed high cumulative doses of either epipodophyllotoxins (e.g., etoposide or teniposide) or alkylating agents (e.g., mechlorethamine, melphalan, busulfan, and cyclophosphamide) induced excessively high rates of t-AML or t-MDS that exceeded 10% in some cases.[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

120745</a>

12075,<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

120766</a>

12077] However, most current chemotherapy regimens that are used to treat childhood cancers have a cumulative incidence of t-AML or t-MDS no greater than 1% to 2%. </p>

12078<p id="_992" tabindex="-1">

12079t-AML or t-MDS resulting from epipodophyllotoxins and other topoisomerase II inhibitors (e.g., anthracyclines) usually occur within 2 years of exposure and are commonly associated with chromosome 11q23 abnormalities,[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

120807</a>

12081] although other subtypes of AML (e.g., acute promyelocytic leukemia) have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_9.8">

120828</a>

12083,<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

120849</a>

12085] t-AML that occurs after exposure to alkylating agents or ionizing radiation often presents 5 to 7 years later and is commonly associated with monosomies or deletions of chromosomes 5 and 7.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

120861</a>

12087,<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

120887</a>

12089]</p>

12090</section>

12091<section id="_993">

12092<h3 id="_993_toc">

12093Treatment of t-AML or t-MDS</h3>

12094<p id="_1191" tabindex="-1">

12095Treatment options for t-AML or t-MDS include the following:</p>

12096<div class="pdq-content-list">

12097<ol id="_1192">

12098<li>

12099Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).</li>

12100</ol>

12101</div>

12102<p id="_609" tabindex="-1">

12103The goal of treatment is to achieve an initial complete remission (CR) using AML-directed regimens and then, usually, to proceed directly to HSCT with the best available donor. However, treatment is challenging because of the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.10">

1210410</a>

12105]</p>

12106<div class="pdq-content-list">

12107<ol id="_610">

12108<li>

12109Increased rates of adverse cytogenetics and subsequent failure to obtain remission with chemotherapy.</li>

12110<li>

12111Comorbidities or limitations related to chemotherapy for the previous malignancy.</li>

12112</ol>

12113</div>

12114<p id="_611" tabindex="-1">

12115Accordingly, CR rates and overall survival (OS) rates are usually lower for patients with t-AML compared with patients with de novo AML.[<a href="#cit/section_9.10">

1211610</a>

12117-<a href="#cit/section_9.12">

1211812</a>

12119] Also, survival for pediatric patients with t-MDS is worse than survival for pediatric patients with MDS not related to previous therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.13">

1212013</a>

12121]</p>

12122<p id="_994" tabindex="-1">

12123Patients with t-MDS-refractory anemia usually have not needed induction chemotherapy before transplant; the role of induction therapy before transplant is controversial in patients with refractory anemia with excess blasts-1.</p>

12124<p id="_995" tabindex="-1">

12125Only a few reports describe the outcome of children undergoing HSCT for t-AML.</p>

12126<p id="_996" tabindex="-1">

12127Evidence (HSCT for t-AML or t-MDS):</p>

12128<div class="pdq-content-list">

12129<ol id="_997">

12130<li>

12131One study described the outcomes of 27 children with t-AML who received related and unrelated donor HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

1213214</a>

12133]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12134<ul id="_998">

12135<li>

12136Three-year OS rates were 18.5% (&#177; 7.5%) and event-free survival (EFS) rates were 18.7% (&#177; 7.5%).</li>

12137<li>

12138Poor survival was mainly the result of very high transplant-related mortality (59.6% &#177; 8.4%).</li>

12139</ul>

12140</div>

12141</li>

12142<li>

12143Another study reported a second retrospective single-center experience of 14 patients with t-AML or t-MDS who underwent transplantation between 1975 and 2007.[<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

1214411</a>

12145]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12146<ul id="_999">

12147<li>

12148 Survival was 29%, but in this review, only 63% of patients diagnosed with t-AML or t-MDS underwent HSCT.</li>

12149</ul>

12150</div>

12151</li>

12152<li>

12153 A multicenter study (CCG-2891) examined outcomes of 24 children with t-AML or t-MDS compared with other children enrolled on the study with de novo AML (n = 898) or MDS (n = 62). Children with t-AML or t-MDS were older and low-risk cytogenetics rarely occurred.[<a href="#cit/section_9.15">

1215415</a>

12155]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12156<ul id="_1000">

12157<li>

12158Although rates of achieving CR and OS at 3 years were worse in the t-AML/t-MDS group (CR, 50% vs. 72%; <em>

12159P</em>

12160 = .016; OS rate, 26% vs. 47%; <em>

12161P</em>

12162 = .007), survival was similar (OS rate, 45% vs. 53%; <em>

12163P</em>

12164 = .87) if patients achieved a CR.</li>

12165</ul>

12166</div>

12167</li>

12168<li>

12169 The importance of remission to survival in these patients is further illustrated by another single-center report of 21 children who underwent HSCT for t-AML or t-MDS between 1994 and 2009. Of the 21 children, 12 had t-AML (11 in CR at the time of transplant), seven had refractory anemia (for whom induction was not done), and two had refractory anemia with excess blasts.[<a href="#cit/section_9.16">

1217016</a>

12171]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12172<ul id="_1001">

12173<li>

12174The survival rate of the entire cohort was 61%. Patients in remission or with refractory anemia had a disease-free survival rate of 66%; for the three patients with more than 5% blasts at the time of HSCT, the survival rate was 0% (<em>

12175P</em>

12176 = .015).</li>

12177</ul>

12178</div>

12179</li>

12180</ol>

12181</div>

12182<p id="_612" tabindex="-1">

12183

12184

12185Because t-AML is rare in children, it is not known whether the significant decrease in transplant-related mortality after unrelated donor HSCT noted over the past several years will translate to improved survival in this population. Patients should be carefully assessed for pre-HSCT morbidities caused by earlier therapies, and treatment approaches should be adapted to give adequate intensity while minimizing transplant-related mortality.

12186</p>

12187</section>
