12259

12260

12261

12262 <section id="_78">

12263

12264 <h2>

12265Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML)</h2>

12266

12267 <div id="_section_78" class="pdq-sections">

12268<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

12269<h6>

12270In This Section</h6>

12271<ul>

12272<li>

12273<a href="#_786_toc">

12274Incidence</a>

12275</li>

12276<li>

12277<a href="#_788_toc">

12278Clinical Presentation and Diagnostic Criteria </a>

12279</li>

12280<li>

12281<a href="#_792_toc">

12282Pathogenesis and Related Syndromes</a>

12283</li>

12284<li>

12285<a href="#_797_toc">

12286Genomics of JMML<ul>

12287<li>

12288<a href="#_sm_CDR0000778658_797_toc">

12289Molecular Features of JMML</a>

12290</li>

12291<li>

12292<a href="#_sm_CDR0000778658_822_toc">

12293Genomic and Molecular Prognostic factors</a>

12294</li>

12295</ul>

12296</a>

12297</li>

12298<li>

12299<a href="#_800_toc">

12300Prognosis (Clinical Factors)</a>

12301</li>

12302<li>

12303<a href="#_803_toc">

12304Treatment of JMML</a>

12305</li>

12306<li>

12307<a href="#_1241_toc">

12308Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation</a>

12309</li>

12310</ul>

12311</nav>

12312<section id="_786">

12313<h3 id="_786_toc">

12314Incidence</h3>

12315<p id="_787" tabindex="-1">

12316Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) is a rare

12317leukemia that occurs approximately ten times less frequently than acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in children, with an annual incidence of about 1 to 2 cases per 1 million people.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

123181</a>

12319] JMML

12320typically presents in young children (median age, approximately 1.8 years) and

12321occurs more commonly in boys (male to female ratio, approximately 2.5:1).</p>

12322</section>

12323<section id="_788">

12324<h3 id="_788_toc">

12325Clinical Presentation and Diagnostic Criteria </h3>

12326<p id="_789" tabindex="-1">

12327 Common clinical features at diagnosis include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

123282</a>

12329]</p>

12330<div class="pdq-content-list">

12331<ul id="_790">

12332<li>

12333Hepatosplenomegaly (97%).</li>

12334<li>

12335Lymphadenopathy (76%).</li>

12336<li>

12337Pallor (64%).</li>

12338<li>

12339Fever (54%).</li>

12340<li>

12341Skin rash (36%).</li>

12342</ul>

12343</div>

12344<p id="_791" tabindex="-1">

12345In children presenting with clinical features suggestive of JMML, current criteria used for a definitive diagnosis are described in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_483">

12346Table 8</a>

12347.[<a href="#cit/section_10.3">

123483</a>

12349]</p>

12350<table id="_483" class="table-default expandable-container">

12351<caption>

12352Table 8. Diagnostic Criteria for Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML) Per the 2016 Revision to World Health Organization Classification</caption>

12353<colgroup>

12354<col width="33.33%">

12355<col width="33.33%">

12356<col width="33.33%">

12357</colgroup>

12358<THead>

12359<tr>

12360<th>

12361Category 1 (All are Required)</th>

12362<th>

12363Category 2 (One is Sufficient)<span class="sup">

12364a</span>

12365</th>

12366<th>

12367Category 3 (Patients Without Genetic Features Must Have the Following in Addition to Category 1<span class="sup">

12368b</span>

12369)</th>

12370</tr>

12371<tr>

12372<th>

12373Clinical and Hematologic Features</th>

12374<th>

12375Genetic Studies</th>

12376<th>

12377Other Features</th>

12378</tr>

12379</THead>

12380<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

12381<tr>

12382<td colspan="3">

12383GM-CSF = granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor; NF1 = neurofibromatosis type 1.</td>

12384</tr>

12385<tr>

12386<td colspan="3">

12387<span class="sup">

12388a</span>

12389Patients who are found to have a category 2 lesion need to meet the criteria in category 1 but do not need to meet the category 3 criteria. Patients who are not found to have a category 2 lesion must meet the category 1 and 3 criteria.</td>

12390</tr>

12391<tr>

12392<td colspan="3">

12393<span class="sup">

12394b</span>

12395Note that only 7% of patients with JMML will NOT present with splenomegaly, but virtually all patients develop splenomegaly within several weeks to months of initial presentation. </td>

12396</tr>

12397</TFoot>

12398<tbody>

12399<tr>

12400<td valign="Middle">

12401Absence of the <em class="gene-name">

12402BCR</em>

12403::<em class="gene-name">

12404ABL1</em>

12405 gene fusion

12406

12407

12408</td>

12409<td>

12410Somatic mutation in <em class="gene-name">

12411KRAS</em>

12412, <em class="gene-name">

12413NRAS</em>

12414, or <em class="gene-name">

12415PTPN11</em>

12416

12417

12418(germline mutations need to be excluded)</td>

12419<td>

12420Monosomy 7 or other chromosomal abnormality, or at least 2 of the criteria listed below:</td>

12421</tr>

12422<tr>

12423<td>

12424&gt;1 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

124259</span>

12426/L circulating monocytes</td>

12427<td>

12428Clinical diagnosis of NF1 or <em class="gene-name">

12429NF1</em>

12430 gene mutation</td>

12431<td>

12432&#8212; Circulating myeloid or erythroid precursors</td>

12433</tr>

12434<tr>

12435<td>

12436&lt;20% blasts in the peripheral blood and bone marrow</td>

12437<td>

12438Germline <em class="gene-name">

12439CBL</em>

12440 mutation and loss of heterozygosity of <em class="gene-name">

12441CBL</em>

12442</td>

12443<td>

12444&#8212; Increased hemoglobin F for age</td>

12445</tr>

12446<tr>

12447<td>

12448Splenomegaly</td>

12449<td>

12450&#160;</td>

12451<td>

12452&#8212; Hyperphosphorylation of STAT5</td>

12453</tr>

12454<tr>

12455<td>

12456&#160;</td>

12457<td>

12458&#160;</td>

12459<td>

12460&#8212; GM-CSF hypersensitivity

12461</td>

12462</tr>

12463</tbody>

12464</table>

12465</section>

12466<section id="_792">

12467<h3 id="_792_toc">

12468Pathogenesis and Related Syndromes</h3>

12469<p id="_512" tabindex="-1">

12470The pathogenesis of JMML has been closely linked to activation of the <em class="gene-name">

12471RAS</em>

12472 oncogene pathway, along with related syndromes (see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_562">

12473Figure 1</a>

12474).[<a href="#cit/section_10.4">

124754</a>

12476,<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

124775</a>

12478] In addition, distinctive RNA expression and DNA methylation patterns have been reported; they are correlated with clinical factors such as age and appear to be associated with prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

124796</a>

12480,<a href="#cit/section_10.7">

124817</a>

12482]</p>

12483<p id="_562" tabindex="-1">

12484<figure id="figure_563" class="image-center">

12485<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/712808.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

12486Enlarge</a>

12487<img id="_563" alt="Schematic diagram showing ligand-stimulated Ras activation, the Ras-Erk pathway, and gene mutations contributing to the neuro-cardio-facio-cutaneous congenital disorders and JMML." title="Schematic diagram showing ligand-stimulated Ras activation, the Ras-Erk pathway, and gene mutations contributing to the neuro-cardio-facio-cutaneous congenital disorders and JMML." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/712808-750.jpg">

12488<figcaption class="caption-container">

12489Figure 1. Schematic diagram showing ligand-stimulated Ras activation, the Ras-Erk pathway, and the gene mutations found to date contributing to the neuro-cardio-facio-cutaneous congenital disorders and JMML. NL/MGCL: Noonan-like/multiple giant cell lesion; CFC: cardia-facio-cutaneous; JMML: juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia. Reprinted from Leukemia Research, 33 (3), Rebecca J. Chan, Todd Cooper, Christian P. Kratz, Brian Weiss, Mignon L. Loh, Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia: A report from the 2nd International JMML Symposium, Pages 355-62, Copyright 2009, with permission from Elsevier.</figcaption>

12490</figure>

12491</p>

12492<p id="_793" tabindex="-1">

12493Children with neurofibromatosis type

124941 (NF1) and Noonan syndrome are at increased risk of developing JMML:[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

124958</a>

12496,<a href="#cit/section_10.9">

124979</a>

12498] </p>

12499<div class="pdq-content-list">

12500<ul id="_794">

12501<li>

12502<strong>

12503NF1.</strong>

12504 Up to 14% of cases of

12505JMML occur in children with NF1.[<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

125062</a>

12507] </li>

12508<li>

12509<strong>

12510Noonan syndrome.</strong>

12511 Noonan syndrome is usually inherited as an autosomal dominant condition but can also arise spontaneously. It is characterized by facial dysmorphism, short stature, webbed neck, neurocognitive abnormalities, and cardiac abnormalities. Germline mutations in <em class="gene-name">

12512PTPN11</em>

12513 are observed in children with Noonan syndrome and in children with JMML.[<a href="#cit/section_10.10">

1251410</a>

12515-<a href="#cit/section_10.12">

1251612</a>

12517] <p id="_795" tabindex="-1">

12518Importantly, some children with Noonan syndrome have a hematologic picture indistinguishable from JMML that self-resolves during infancy, similar to what happens in children with Down syndrome and transient myeloproliferative disorder.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

125195</a>

12520,<a href="#cit/section_10.12">

1252112</a>

12522]</p>

12523<p id="_1193" tabindex="-1">

12524Within a large prospective cohort of 641 patients with Noonan syndrome and a germline <em class="gene-name">

12525PTPN11</em>

12526 mutation, 36 patients (approximately 6%) showed myeloproliferative features, with 20 patients (approximately 3%) meeting the consensus diagnostic criteria for JMML.[<a href="#cit/section_10.12">

1252712</a>

12528] Of the 20 patients meeting the criteria for JMML, 12 patients had severe neonatal manifestations (e.g., life-threatening complications related to congenital heart defects, pleural effusion, leukemia infiltrates, and/or thrombocytopenia), and 10 of 20 patients died during the first month of life. Among the remaining eight patients, none required intensive therapy at diagnosis or during follow-up. All 16 patients with myeloproliferative features that did not meet JMML criteria were alive, with a median follow-up of 3 years, and none of the patients received chemotherapy.</p>

12529</li>

12530</ul>

12531</div>

12532<p id="_796" tabindex="-1">

12533Mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

12534CBL</em>

12535 gene, an E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase that is involved in targeting proteins, particularly tyrosine kinases, for proteasomal degradation occur in 10% to 15% of JMML cases,[<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

1253613</a>

12537,<a href="#cit/section_10.14">

1253814</a>

12539] with many of these cases occurring in children with germline <em class="gene-name">

12540CBL</em>

12541 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

1254215</a>

12543-<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1254417</a>

12545] <em class="gene-name">

12546CBL</em>

12547 germline mutations result in an autosomal dominant developmental disorder that is often characterized by impaired growth, developmental delay, cryptorchidism, and a predisposition to JMML.[<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

1254815</a>

12549,<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1255017</a>

12551] Some individuals with <em class="gene-name">

12552CBL</em>

12553 germline mutations experience spontaneous regression of their JMML but develop vasculitis later in life,[<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

1255415</a>

12555] whereas patients with only somatic <em class="gene-name">

12556CBL</em>

12557 mutations all require therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1255817</a>

12559] JMML arising from germline mutations are clinically indistinguishable from JMML arising from somatic mutations, which necessitates studies on both normal and leukemic tissue.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1256017</a>

12561] <em class="gene-name">

12562CBL</em>

12563 mutations are nearly always mutually exclusive of <em class="gene-name">

12564RAS</em>

12565 and <em class="gene-name">

12566PTPN11</em>

12567 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

1256813</a>

12569]</p>

12570</section>

12571<section id="_797">

12572<h3 id="_797_toc">

12573Genomics of JMML</h3>

12574<section id="_sm_CDR0000778658_797">

12575<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000778658_797_toc">

12576Molecular Features of JMML</h4>

12577<p id="_sm_CDR0000778658_798" tabindex="-1">

12578The genomic landscape of JMML is characterized by mutations in one of five genes of the RAS pathway: <em class="gene-name">

12579NF1</em>

12580, <em class="gene-name">

12581NRAS</em>

12582, <em class="gene-name">

12583KRAS</em>

12584, <em class="gene-name">

12585PTPN11</em>

12586, and <em class="gene-name">

12587CBL</em>

12588.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1258918</a>

12590-<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1259120</a>

12592] In a series of 118 consecutively diagnosed JMML cases with RAS pathway&#8211;activating mutations, <em class="gene-name">

12593PTPN11</em>

12594 was the most commonly mutated gene, accounting for 51% of cases (19% germline and 32% somatic) (see Figure 2).[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1259518</a>

12596] Patients with mutated <em class="gene-name">

12597NRAS</em>

12598 accounted for 19% of cases, and patients with mutated <em class="gene-name">

12599KRAS</em>

12600 accounted for 15% of cases. <em class="gene-name">

12601NF1</em>

12602 mutations accounted for 8% of cases, and <em class="gene-name">

12603CBL</em>

12604 mutations accounted for 11% of cases. Although mutations among these five genes are generally mutually exclusive, 4% to 17% of cases have mutations in two of these RAS pathway genes,[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1260518</a>

12606-<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1260720</a>

12608] a finding that is associated with poorer prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1260918</a>

12610,<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1261120</a>

12612]</p>

12613<p id="_sm_CDR0000778658_799" tabindex="-1">

12614The mutation rate in JMML leukemia cells is very low, but additional mutations beyond those of the five RAS pathway genes described above are observed.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1261518</a>

12616-<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1261720</a>

12618] Secondary genomic alterations are observed for genes of the transcriptional repressor complex PRC2 (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

12619ASXL1</em>

12620 was mutated in 7%&#8211;8% of cases). Some genes associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms in adults are also mutated at low rates in JMML (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

12621SETBP1</em>

12622 was mutated in 6%&#8211;9% of cases).[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1262318</a>

12624-<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1262521</a>

12626] <em class="gene-name">

12627JAK3</em>

12628 mutations are also observed in a small percentage (4%&#8211;12%) of JMML cases.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1262918</a>

12630-<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1263121</a>

12632] Cases with germline <em class="gene-name">

12633PTPN11</em>

12634 and germline <em class="gene-name">

12635CBL</em>

12636 mutations showed low rates of additional mutations (see Figure 2).[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1263718</a>

12638] The presence of mutations beyond disease-defining RAS pathway mutations is associated with an inferior prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1263918</a>

12640,<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

1264119</a>

12642]</p>

12643<p id="_sm_CDR0000778658_817" tabindex="-1">

12644A report describing the genomic landscape of JMML found that 16 of 150 patients (11%) lacked canonical RAS pathway mutations. Among these 16 patients, 3 were observed to have in-frame fusions involving receptor tyrosine kinases (<em class="gene-name">

12645DCTN1</em>

12646::<em class="gene-name">

12647ALK</em>

12648, <em class="gene-name">

12649RANBP2</em>

12650::<em class="gene-name">

12651ALK</em>

12652, and <em class="gene-name">

12653TBL1XR1</em>

12654::<em class="gene-name">

12655ROS1</em>

12656 gene fusions). These patients all had monosomy 7 and were aged 56 months or older. One patient with an <em class="gene-name">

12657ALK</em>

12658 gene fusion was treated with crizotinib plus conventional chemotherapy and achieved a complete molecular remission and proceeded to allogeneic bone marrow transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1265920</a>

12660]</p>

12661<p id="_sm_CDR0000778658_812" tabindex="-1">

12662<figure id="figure_sm_CDR0000778658_813" class="image-center">

12663<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/778293.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

12664Enlarge</a>

12665<img id="_sm_CDR0000778658_813" alt="Chart showing alteration profiles in individual JMML cases." title="Chart showing alteration profiles in individual JMML cases." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/778293-750.jpg">

12666<figcaption class="caption-container">

12667Figure 2. Alteration profiles in individual JMML cases. Germline and somatically acquired alterations with recurring hits in the RAS pathway and PRC2 network are shown for 118 patients with JMML who underwent detailed genetic analysis. Blast excess was defined as a blast count &#8805;10% but &lt;20% of nucleated cells in the bone marrow at diagnosis. Blast crisis was defined as a blast count &#8805;20% of nucleated cells in the bone marrow. NS, Noonan syndrome. Reprinted by permission from Macmillan Publishers Ltd: <a href="http://www.nature.com/ng/index.html" title="http://www.nature.com/ng/index.html">

12668Nature Genetics</a>

12669 (Caye A, Strullu M, Guidez F, et al.: Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia displays mutations in components of the RAS pathway and the PRC2 network. Nat Genet 47 [11]: 1334-40, 2015), copyright (2015).</figcaption>

12670</figure>

12671</p>

12672</section>

12673<section id="_sm_CDR0000778658_822">

12674<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000778658_822_toc">

12675Genomic and Molecular Prognostic factors</h4>

12676<p id="_sm_CDR0000778658_823" tabindex="-1">

12677Several genomic factors affect the prognosis of patients with JMML, including the following:</p>

12678<div class="pdq-content-list">

12679<ol id="_sm_CDR0000778658_824">

12680<li>

12681<strong>

12682Number of non&#8211;RAS pathway mutations.</strong>

12683 A predictor of prognosis for children with JMML is the number of mutations beyond the disease-defining RAS pathway mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1268418</a>

12685,<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

1268619</a>

12687]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12688<ul id="_sm_CDR0000778658_825">

12689<li>

12690One study observed that zero or one somatic alteration (pathogenic mutation or monosomy 7) was identified in 64 patients (65.3%) at diagnosis, whereas two or more alterations were identified in 34 patients (34.7%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

1269119</a>

12692] In multivariate analysis, mutation number (2 or more vs. 0 or 1) maintained significance as a predictor of inferior event-free survival (EFS) and overall survival (OS). A higher proportion of patients diagnosed with two or more alterations were older and male, and these patients also demonstrated a higher rate of monosomy 7 or somatic <em class="gene-name">

12693NF1</em>

12694 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

1269519</a>

12696]</li>

12697<li>

12698Another study observed that approximately 60% of patients had one or more additional mutations beyond their disease-defining RAS pathway mutation. These patients had an inferior OS compared with patients who had no additional mutations (3-year OS rate, 61% vs. 85%, respectively).[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1269918</a>

12700]</li>

12701<li>

12702A third study observed a trend for an inferior OS for patients with two or more mutations compared with patients with zero or one mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1270320</a>

12704]</li>

12705</ul>

12706</div>

12707</li>

12708<li>

12709<strong>

12710RAS pathway double mutations.</strong>

12711 Although mutations in the five canonical RAS pathway genes associated with JMML (<em class="gene-name">

12712NF1</em>

12713, <em class="gene-name">

12714NRAS</em>

12715, <em class="gene-name">

12716KRAS</em>

12717, <em class="gene-name">

12718PTPN11</em>

12719, and <em class="gene-name">

12720CBL</em>

12721) are generally mutually exclusive, 4% to 17% of cases have mutations in two of these RAS pathway genes.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1272218</a>

12723,<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

1272419</a>

12725] This finding has been associated with a poorer prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1272618</a>

12727,<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

1272819</a>

12729]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12730<ul id="_sm_CDR0000778658_826">

12731<li>

12732Two RAS pathway mutations were identified in 11% of JMML patients in one report, and these patients had a significantly inferior EFS rate (14%) compared with patients who had a single RAS pathway mutation (62%). Patients with Noonan syndrome were excluded from the analyses.[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

1273319</a>

12734]</li>

12735<li>

12736Similar findings for RAS pathway mutations were reported in a second study. This study observed that patients with RAS pathway double mutations (15 of 96 patients) had lower survival rates than did patients with either no additional mutations or with additional mutations beyond the RAS pathway mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1273718</a>

12738]</li>

12739</ul>

12740</div>

12741</li>

12742<li>

12743<strong>

12744DNA methylation profile.</strong>

12745 <div class="pdq-content-list">

12746<ul id="_sm_CDR0000778658_827">

12747<li>

12748One study applied DNA methylation profiling to a discovery cohort of 39 patients with JMML and to a validation cohort of 40 patients. Distinctive subsets of JMML with either high, intermediate, or low methylation levels were observed in both cohorts. Patients with the lowest methylation levels had the highest survival rates, and all but 1 of 15 patients experienced spontaneous resolution in the low methylation cohort. High methylation status was associated with lower EFS rates.[<a href="#cit/section_10.22">

1274922</a>

12750]</li>

12751<li>

12752Another study applied DNA methylation profiling to a cohort of 106 patients with JMML. The study observed one subgroup of patients with a hypermethylation profile and one subgroup of patients with a hypomethylation profile. Patients in the hypermethylation group had a significantly lower OS rate than did patients in the hypomethylation group (5-year OS rate, 46% vs. 73%, respectively). Patients in the hypermethylation group also had a significantly poorer 5-year transplant-free survival rate than did patients in the hypomethylation group (2.2%; 95% CI, 0.2%&#8211;10.1% vs. 41.2%; 95% CI, 27.1%&#8211;54.8%). Hypermethylation status was associated with two or more mutations, higher fetal hemoglobin levels, older age, and lower platelet count at diagnosis. All patients with Noonan syndrome were in the hypomethylation group.[<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1275320</a>

12754]</li>

12755<li>

12756A study examined 33 patients with JMML who had <em class="gene-name">

12757CBL</em>

12758 mutations. The study identified 31 patients with low methylation and 2 patients with intermediate methylation. Both of the children with intermediate methylation relapsed after undergoing HSCT. Because treatment, which included observation only, varied among the 31 patients with low methylation, the impact of the methylation profile on therapeutic decisions and outcomes could not be fully assessed. However, the methylation status was not prognostic of spontaneous resolution.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1275917</a>

12760]</li>

12761</ul>

12762</div>

12763</li>

12764<li>

12765<strong>

12766<em class="gene-name">

12767LIN28B</em>

12768 overexpression.</strong>

12769 <em class="gene-name">

12770LIN28B</em>

12771 overexpression, which is present in approximately one-half of children with JMML, identifies a biologically distinctive subset of JMML. LIN28B is an RNA-binding protein that regulates stem cell renewal.[<a href="#cit/section_10.23">

1277223</a>

12773]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12774<ul id="_sm_CDR0000778658_828">

12775<li>

12776<em class="gene-name">

12777LIN28B</em>

12778 overexpression was positively correlated with high blood fetal hemoglobin level and age (both of which are associated with poor prognosis), and it was negatively correlated with presence of monosomy 7 (also associated with inferior prognosis). Although <em class="gene-name">

12779LIN28B</em>

12780 overexpression identifies a subset of patients with increased risk of treatment failure, it was not found to be an independent prognostic factor when other factors such as age and monosomy 7 status are considered.[<a href="#cit/section_10.23">

1278123</a>

12782]</li>

12783<li>

12784Another study also observed a subset of JMML patients with elevated <em class="gene-name">

12785LIN28B</em>

12786 expression. The study identified <em class="gene-name">

12787LIN28B</em>

12788 as the gene for which expression was most strongly associated with hypermethylation status.[<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1278920</a>

12790]</li>

12791</ul>

12792</div>

12793 </li>

12794</ol>

12795</div>

12796</section>

12797</section>

12798<section id="_800">

12799<h3 id="_800_toc">

12800Prognosis (Clinical Factors)</h3>

12801<p id="_801" tabindex="-1">

12802<strong>

12803Age, platelet count, and fetal hemoglobin level after any treatment.</strong>

12804 Historically, more than 90% of patients with JMML died despite the use of chemotherapy;[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1280524</a>

12806] however, with the application of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), survival rates of approximately 50% are now observed.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

1280725</a>

12808] Patients appeared to follow three distinct clinical courses:</p>

12809<div class="pdq-content-list">

12810<ul id="_1332">

12811<li>

12812Rapidly progressive disease and early demise.</li>

12813<li>

12814Transiently stable disease followed by progression and death.</li>

12815<li>

12816Clinical improvement that lasted up to 9 years before progression or, rarely, long-term survival.</li>

12817</ul>

12818</div>

12819<p id="_1333" tabindex="-1">

12820Favorable prognostic factors for survival after any therapy include age younger than 2 years, platelet count greater than 33 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

128219</span>

12822/L, and low age-adjusted fetal hemoglobin levels.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

128231</a>

12824,<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

128252</a>

12826] In contrast, being older than 2 years and having high blood fetal hemoglobin levels at diagnosis are predictors of poor outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

128271</a>

12828,<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

128292</a>

12830]</p>

12831</section>

12832<section id="_803">

12833<h3 id="_803_toc">

12834Treatment of JMML</h3>

12835<p id="_804" tabindex="-1">

12836Treatment options for JMML include the following:</p>

12837<div class="pdq-content-list">

12838<ul id="_805">

12839<li>

12840Hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT).</li>

12841</ul>

12842</div>

12843<p id="_806" tabindex="-1">

12844The role of conventional antileukemia therapy in the treatment of JMML is not defined. Determining the role of specific agents in the treatment of JMML is complicated because of the absence of consensus response criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_10.26">

1284526</a>

12846] Some agents that have shown antileukemia activity against JMML include etoposide, cytarabine, thiopurines (thioguanine and mercaptopurine), isotretinoin, and farnesyl inhibitors, but none of these have been shown to improve outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_10.26">

1284726</a>

12848-<a href="#cit/section_10.30">

1284930</a>

12850]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.31">

1285131</a>

12852][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12853Level of evidence B4</a>

12854]</p>

12855<p id="_807" tabindex="-1">

12856HSCT currently offers the best chance of cure for JMML.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

1285725</a>

12858,<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

1285932</a>

12860-<a href="#cit/section_10.35">

1286135</a>

12862]</p>

12863<p id="_808" tabindex="-1">

12864Evidence (HSCT):</p>

12865<div class="pdq-content-list">

12866<ol id="_809">

12867<li>

12868A report from the European Working Group on Childhood Myelodysplastic Syndromes included 100 transplant recipients at multiple centers treated with a common preparative regimen of busulfan, cyclophosphamide, and melphalan, with or without antithymocyte globulin. Recipients had been treated with varying degrees of pretransplant chemotherapy or differentiating agents, and some patients had splenectomy performed.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

1286925</a>

12870] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12871<ul id="_810">

12872<li>

12873The 5-year event-free survival rate was 55% for children with JMML who underwent HSCT using HLA-identical matched family donor cells and 49% for children with JMML who underwent HSCT using unrelated donor cells.</li>

12874<li>

12875The multivariate analysis showed no effect on survival of previous AML-like chemotherapy versus low-dose chemotherapy or no chemotherapy.</li>

12876<li>

12877 No effect on survival was observed for splenectomy pretransplant or difference in spleen size.</li>

12878<li>

12879Comparison of outcomes on the basis of related versus unrelated donors also found no difference.</li>

12880<li>

12881Only age older than 4 years and sex were shown to be poor prognostic factors for outcome and increased risk of relapse (relative risk [RR], 2.24 [1.07&#8211;4.69]; <em>

12882P</em>

12883 = .032 for older age; RR, 2.22 [1.09&#8211;4.50]; <em>

12884P</em>

12885 = .028 for females).[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

1288625</a>

12887]</li>

12888</ul>

12889</div>

12890</li>

12891<li>

12892Cord blood transplantation results in a 5-year disease-free survival rate of 44%, with improved outcome in children younger than 1.4 years at diagnosis, those with nonmonosomy 7 karyotype, and those receiving 5/6 to 6/6 HLA-matched cord units.[<a href="#cit/section_10.36">

1289336</a>

12894][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12895Level of evidence C2</a>

12896] This suggests that cord blood can provide an additional donor pool for this group of children. </li>

12897<li>

12898The use of reduced-intensity preparative regimens to decrease the adverse side effects of transplantation have also been reported in small numbers of patients, generally for patients ineligible for myeloablative HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.37">

1289937</a>

12900,<a href="#cit/section_10.38">

1290138</a>

12902]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12903<ol id="_1990" class="lower-alpha">

12904<li>

12905The COG conducted a randomized trial in children with JMML that compared a standard-intensity preparative regimen (busulfan/cyclophosphamide/melphalan) with a reduced-intensity regimen (busulfan/fludarabine).[<a href="#cit/section_10.39">

1290639</a>

12907]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12908<ul id="_1991">

12909<li>

12910The trial closed to enrollment early when an interim analysis revealed a higher frequency of relapse/disease persistence (7 of 9 patients) in children who received the reduced-intensity regimen than in children who received the standard-intensity regimen (1 of 6 patients).</li>

12911</ul>

12912</div>

12913</li>

12914</ol>

12915</div>

12916 </li>

12917</ol>

12918</div>

12919<p id="_811" tabindex="-1">

12920Disease recurrence is the primary cause of treatment failure for children with JMML after HSCT and occurs in 30% to 40% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

1292125</a>

12922,<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

1292332</a>

12924,<a href="#cit/section_10.33">

1292533</a>

12926] While the role of donor lymphocyte infusions is uncertain,[<a href="#cit/section_10.40">

1292740</a>

12928] reports indicate that approximately 50% of patients with relapsed JMML can be successfully treated with a second HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.41">

1292941</a>

12930]</p>

12931</section>

12932<section id="_1241">

12933<h3 id="_1241_toc">

12934Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation</h3>

12935<p id="_1242" tabindex="-1">

12936Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

12937NCI website</a>

12938. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

12939ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

12940.</p>

12941<p id="_1243" tabindex="-1">

12942The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

12943<div class="pdq-content-list">

12944<ul id="_1244">

12945<li>

12946<strong>

12947<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03190915">

12948COG-ADVL1521 (NCT03190915)</a>

12949</strong>

12950 (Trametinib in Treating Patients With Relapsed or Refractory JMML)<strong>

12951:</strong>

12952 This trial is evaluating the activity of trametinib (inhibitor of MEK1/2, which is downstream of RAS/MAPK signaling) in pediatric patients with relapsed or refractory JMML. The rationale for studying this agent is based on the finding that nearly all genetic mutations found in JMML lead to aberrant RAS pathway signaling. Eligible patients are those who have relapsed or have persistent disease after intravenous chemotherapy (such as fludarabine or cytarabine) and/or HSCT, but not after low-dose oral chemotherapy (such as mercaptopurine). The primary objective is to determine the response rate of trametinib administered orally once daily in 28-day cycles.</li>

12953</ul>

12954</div>

12955</section>

13107<li id="section_10.38">

13108Koyama M, Nakano T, Takeshita Y, et al.: Successful treatment of JMML with related bone marrow transplantation after reduced-intensity conditioning. Bone Marrow Transplant 36 (5): 453-4; author reply 454, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15968292&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15968292&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13109[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13110</li>

13111<li id="section_10.39">

13112Dvorak CC, Satwani P, Stieglitz E, et al.: Disease burden and conditioning regimens in ASCT1221, a randomized phase II trial in children with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia: A Children's Oncology Group study. Pediatr Blood Cancer 65 (7): e27034, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29528181&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29528181&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13113[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13114</li>

13115<li id="section_10.40">

13116Yoshimi A, Bader P, Matthes-Martin S, et al.: Donor leukocyte infusion after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation in patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia. Leukemia 19 (6): 971-7, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15800672&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15800672&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13117[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13118</li>

13119<li id="section_10.41">

13120Yoshimi A, Mohamed M, Bierings M, et al.: Second allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) results in outcome similar to that of first HSCT for patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia. Leukemia 21 (3): 556-60, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17268527&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17268527&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13121[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13122</li>

13123</ol>

13124</div>

13125

13126 </section>

13127

13128

13129

13130 <section id="_195">

13131

13132 <h2>

13133Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)</h2>

13134

13135 <div id="_section_195" class="pdq-sections">

13136<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

13137<h6>

13138In This Section</h6>

13139<ul>

13140<li>

13141<a href="#_1002_toc">

13142Incidence</a>

13143</li>

13144<li>

13145<a href="#_1004_toc">

13146Molecular Abnormality</a>

13147</li>

13148<li>

13149<a href="#_1006_toc">

13150Clinical Presentation</a>

13151</li>

13152<li>

13153<a href="#_1009_toc">

13154Treatment of CML: Historical Perspective</a>

13155</li>

13156<li>

13157<a href="#_515_toc">

13158Treatment of Adult CML With TKIs</a>

13159</li>

13160<li>

13161<a href="#_519_toc">

13162Treatment of Childhood CML<ul>

13163<li>

13164<a href="#_2121_toc">

13165Discontinuation of TKI therapy</a>

13166</li>

13167<li>

13168<a href="#_1979_toc">

13169Treatment Options under Clinical Evaluation</a>

13170</li>

13171</ul>

13172</a>

13173</li>

13174<li>

13175<a href="#_1080_toc">

13176Treatment of Recurrent or Refractory Childhood CML</a>

13177</li>

13178<li>

13179<a href="#_TrialSearch_195_sid_11_toc">

13180Current Clinical Trials</a>

13181</li>

13182</ul>

13183</nav>

13184<section id="_1002">

13185<h3 id="_1002_toc">

13186Incidence</h3>

13187<p id="_1003" tabindex="-1">

13188Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) accounts for less than 5% of all childhood leukemia, and in the pediatric age range, occurs most commonly in older adolescents.[<a href="#cit/section_11.1">

131891</a>

13190]</p>

13191</section>

13192<section id="_1004">

13193<h3 id="_1004_toc">

13194Molecular Abnormality</h3>

13195<p id="_1005" tabindex="-1">

13196The cytogenetic abnormality most characteristic of CML is the Philadelphia chromosome (Ph), which represents a translocation of chromosomes 9 and 22 (t(9;22)) resulting in a BCR::ABL1 protein fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_11.2">

131972</a>

13198] </p>

13199</section>

13200<section id="_1006">

13201<h3 id="_1006_toc">

13202Clinical Presentation</h3>

13203<p id="_196" tabindex="-1">

13204 CML is characterized by a marked leukocytosis and is often associated with thrombocytosis, sometimes with abnormal platelet function. Bone marrow aspiration or biopsy reveals hypercellularity with relatively normal granulocytic maturation and no significant increase in leukemic blasts. Although reduced leukocyte alkaline phosphatase activity is seen in CML, this is not a specific finding. </p>

13205<p id="_1007" tabindex="-1">

13206CML has the following three clinical phases:</p>

13207<div class="pdq-content-list">

13208<ul id="_1008">

13209<li>

13210<strong>

13211Chronic phase.</strong>

13212 Chronic phase, which lasts for approximately 3 years if untreated, usually presents with symptoms secondary to hyperleukocytosis such as weakness, fever, night sweats, bone pain, respiratory distress, priapism, left upper quadrant pain (splenomegaly), and, rarely, hearing loss and visual disturbances.</li>

13213<li>

13214<strong>

13215Accelerated phase.</strong>

13216 The accelerated phase is characterized by progressive splenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and increased percentage of peripheral and bone marrow blasts, along with accumulation of karyotypic abnormalities in addition to the Ph chromosome.</li>

13217<li>

13218<strong>

13219Blast crisis phase.</strong>

13220 Blast crisis is notable for the bone marrow, showing greater than 20% blasts or chloromatous lesions and a clinical picture that is indistinguishable from acute leukemia. Approximately two-thirds of blast crisis is myeloid, and the remainder is lymphoid, usually of B lineage. Patients in blast crisis will die within a few months.[<a href="#cit/section_11.3">

132213</a>

13222]</li>

13223</ul>

13224</div>

13225</section>

13226<section id="_1009">

13227<h3 id="_1009_toc">

13228Treatment of CML: Historical Perspective</h3>

13229<p id="_328" tabindex="-1">

13230Before the tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) era, allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) was the primary treatment for children with CML. Published reports from this period described survival rates of 70% to 80% when an HLA&#8211;matched-family donor (MFD) was used in the treatment of children in early chronic phase, with lower survival rates when HLA&#8211;matched-unrelated donors were used.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

132314</a>

13232-<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

132336</a>

13234] </p>

13235<p id="_1152" tabindex="-1">

13236Relapse rates were low (less than 20%) when transplant was performed in chronic phase.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

132374</a>

13238,<a href="#cit/section_11.5">

132395</a>

13240] The primary cause of death was treatment-related mortality, which was increased with HLA&#8211;matched-unrelated donors compared with HLA-MFDs in most reports.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

132414</a>

13242,<a href="#cit/section_11.5">

132435</a>

13244] High-resolution DNA matching for HLA alleles appeared to reduce rates of treatment-related mortality, leading to improved outcome for HSCT using unrelated donors.[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

132457</a>

13246]</p>

13247<p id="_1153" tabindex="-1">

13248Compared with transplantation in chronic phase, transplantation in accelerated phase or blast crisis and in second-chronic phase resulted in significantly reduced survival.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

132494</a>

13250-<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

132516</a>

13252] The use of T-lymphocyte depletion to avoid graft-versus-host disease resulted in a higher relapse rate and decreased overall survival (OS),[<a href="#cit/section_11.8">

132538</a>

13254] supporting the contribution of a graft-versus-leukemia effect to favorable outcome after allogeneic HSCT.</p>

13255<p id="_198" tabindex="-1">

13256The introduction of the TKI imatinib as a therapeutic drug targeted at inhibiting the BCR::ABL1 fusion kinase revolutionized the treatment of patients with CML, for both children and adults.[<a href="#cit/section_11.9">

132579</a>

13258] As most data on the use of TKIs for CML is from adult clinical trials, the adult experience is initially described, followed by a description of the more limited experience in children.</p>

13259</section>

13260<section id="_515">

13261<h3 id="_515_toc">

13262Treatment of Adult CML With TKIs</h3>

13263<p id="_516" tabindex="-1">

13264Imatinib is a potent inhibitor of the ABL1 tyrosine kinase, platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) receptors (alpha and beta), and KIT. Imatinib treatment achieves clinical, cytogenetic, and molecular remissions (as defined by the absence of BCR::ABL1 fusion transcripts) in a high proportion of CML patients treated in chronic phase.[<a href="#cit/section_11.10">

1326510</a>

13266] </p>

13267<p id="_1010" tabindex="-1">

13268Evidence (imatinib for adults):</p>

13269<div class="pdq-content-list">

13270<ol id="_1011">

13271<li>

13272Imatinib replaced the use of recombinant interferon alfa in the initial treatment of CML on the basis of the results of a large phase III trial that compared imatinib with interferon plus cytarabine (IRIS).[<a href="#cit/section_11.11">

1327311</a>

13274,<a href="#cit/section_11.12">

1327512</a>

13276]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13277<ul id="_1012">

13278<li>

13279Patients who received imatinib had higher complete cytogenetic response rates (76% vs. 14% at 18 months).[<a href="#cit/section_11.11">

1328011</a>

13281] The rate of treatment failure diminished over time, from 3.3% and 7.5% in the first and second years of imatinib treatment, respectively, to less than 1% by the fifth year of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_11.12">

1328212</a>

13283] </li>

13284<li>

13285After censoring for patients who died from causes unrelated to CML or transplantation, the overall estimated survival rate for patients randomly assigned to imatinib was 95% at 60 months.[<a href="#cit/section_11.12">

1328612</a>

13287]</li>

13288</ul>

13289</div>

13290</li>

13291</ol>

13292</div>

13293<p id="_517" tabindex="-1">

13294Guidelines for imatinib treatment have been developed for adults with CML on the basis of patient response to treatment, including the timing of achieving complete hematologic response, complete cytogenetic response, and major molecular response (defined as attainment of a 3-log reduction in <em class="gene-name">

13295BCR</em>

13296::<em class="gene-name">

13297ABL1</em>

13298 gene fusion/control gene ratio).[<a href="#cit/section_11.13">

1329913</a>

13300-<a href="#cit/section_11.16">

1330116</a>

13302] </p>

13303<p id="_1013" tabindex="-1">

13304Poor adherence is a major reason for loss of complete cytogenetic response and imatinib failure for adult patients with CML on long-term therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.17">

1330517</a>

13306] The identification of <em class="gene-name">

13307BCR</em>

13308::<em class="gene-name">

13309ABL1</em>

13310 kinase domain mutations at the time of failure or of suboptimal response to imatinib treatment also has clinical implications,[<a href="#cit/section_11.18">

1331118</a>

13312] because there are alternative BCR::ABL1 kinase inhibitors (e.g., dasatinib and nilotinib) that maintain their activity against some (but not all) mutations that confer resistance to imatinib.[<a href="#cit/section_11.13">

1331313</a>

13314,<a href="#cit/section_11.19">

1331519</a>

13316,<a href="#cit/section_11.20">

1331720</a>

13318] </p>

13319<p id="_518" tabindex="-1">

13320Two TKIs, dasatinib and nilotinib, have been shown to be effective in patients who have an inadequate response to imatinib, although not in patients with the <em class="gene-name">

13321T315I</em>

13322 mutation. Both dasatinib and nilotinib have also received regulatory approval for the treatment of newly diagnosed chronic-phase CML in adults, on the basis of the following studies: </p>

13323<div class="pdq-content-list">

13324<ul id="_727">

13325<li>

13326<strong>

13327Dasatinib.</strong>

13328 Dasatinib was approved on the basis of a phase III trial that compared dasatinib (100 mg daily) with imatinib (400 mg daily).[<a href="#cit/section_11.21">

1332921</a>

13330] There was no significant difference in progression-free survival (PFS) or OS. However, after 12 months of treatment, dasatinib was associated with a higher rate of complete cytogenetic response (83% vs. 72%, <em>

13331P</em>

13332 = .001) and major molecular response (46% vs. 28%, <em>

13333P</em>

13334 &lt; .0001). Responses were achieved in a shorter time with dasatinib (<em>

13335P</em>

13336 &lt; .0001).</li>

13337<li>

13338<strong>

13339Nilotinib.</strong>

13340 Nilotinib (at a dose of either 300 mg or 400 mg twice daily) was compared with imatinib (400 mg daily) in a phase III trial.[<a href="#cit/section_11.22">

1334122</a>

13342] At 12 months, the rates of complete cytogenetic response were significantly higher for nilotinib (80% for the 300-mg dose and 78% for the 400-mg dose) than were the rates for imatinib (65%) (<em>

13343P</em>

13344 &lt; .001 for both comparisons). Also, nilotinib was associated with higher rates of major molecular response (44% for the 300-mg dose and 43% for the 400-mg dose compared with 22% for imatinib, <em>

13345P</em>

13346 &lt; .001 for both comparisons). The 300-mg twice-daily dose of nilotinib was associated with a more favorable safety profile compared with the 400-mg dose.</li>

13347</ul>

13348</div>

13349<p id="_814" tabindex="-1">

13350Because of the superiority over imatinib in terms of complete cytogenetic response rate and major molecular response rate, both dasatinib and nilotinib are extensively used as first-line therapy in adults with CML. However, despite more rapid responses with dasatinib and nilotinib than with imatinib when used as frontline therapy, PFS and OS appear to be similar for all three agents.[<a href="#cit/section_11.23">

1335123</a>

13352,<a href="#cit/section_11.24">

1335324</a>

13354] Additional follow-up will be required to better define the impact of these agents on long-term PFS and OS.</p>

13355<p id="_815" tabindex="-1">

13356<strong>

13357Bosutinib</strong>

13358 is another TKI that targets the <em class="gene-name">

13359BCR</em>

13360::<em class="gene-name">

13361ABL1</em>

13362 gene fusion and has been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of all phases of CML in adults who show intolerance to or whose disease shows resistance to previous therapy with another TKI. Bosutinib has not been studied in the pediatric population.</p>

13363<p id="_834" tabindex="-1">

13364<strong>

13365Ponatinib</strong>

13366 is a BCR::ABL1 protein fusion inhibitor that is effective against the <em class="gene-name">

13367T315I</em>

13368 mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_11.25">

1336925</a>

13370] Ponatinib induced objective responses in approximately 70% of heavily pretreated adults with chronic-phase CML, with responses observed regardless of the baseline <em class="gene-name">

13371BCR</em>

13372::<em class="gene-name">

13373ABL1</em>

13374 kinase domain mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_11.26">

1337526</a>

13376] Development of ponatinib has been complicated by the high rate of vascular occlusion observed in patients receiving the agent, with arterial and venous thrombosis and occlusions (including myocardial infarction and stroke) occurring in more than 20% of treated patients.[<a href="#cit/section_11.27">

1337727</a>

13378] Ponatinib has not been prospectively studied in the pediatric population.</p>

13379<p id="_816" tabindex="-1">

13380For adult patients with CML who proceed to allogeneic HSCT, there is no evidence that pretransplant imatinib adversely impacts outcome. </p>

13381<p id="_1014" tabindex="-1">

13382Evidence (imatinib followed by HSCT in adults):</p>

13383<div class="pdq-content-list">

13384<ol id="_1015">

13385<li>

13386A retrospective study that compared 145 patients who received imatinib before transplant with a historical cohort of 231 patients showed no difference in early hepatic toxic effects or engraftment delay.[<a href="#cit/section_11.28">

1338728</a>

13388]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13389<ul id="_1163">

13390<li>

13391In addition, OS, disease-free survival, relapse, and nonrelapse mortality were similar between the two cohorts.</li>

13392<li>

13393The only factor associated with poor outcome in the cohort that received imatinib was a poor initial response to imatinib.</li>

13394</ul>

13395</div>

13396</li>

13397<li>

13398Further evidence for a lack of effect of pretransplant imatinib on posttransplant outcomes was supplied by a report from the Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research; this report compared outcomes of 181 pediatric and adult subjects with CML in first chronic phase treated with imatinib before HSCT with that of 657 subjects who did not receive imatinib before HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_11.29">

1339929</a>

13400]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13401<ul id="_1164">

13402<li>

13403Among the patients in first chronic phase, imatinib therapy before HSCT was associated with better OS.</li>

13404</ul>

13405</div>

13406</li>

13407<li>

13408A third report of imatinib followed by allogeneic HSCT supports the efficacy of this transplantation strategy in patients with imatinib failure in first chronic phase.[<a href="#cit/section_11.13">

1340913</a>

13410]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13411<ul id="_1165">

13412<li>

13413The 3-year OS rate was 94% for this group (n = 37), with approximately 90% of patients achieving a complete molecular remission after HSCT.</li>

13414</ul>

13415</div>

13416</li>

13417</ol>

13418</div>

13419<p id="_1016" tabindex="-1">

13420For adult patients treated with a TKI alone (without HSCT), the optimal duration of therapy remains unknown, and most patients continue TKI treatment indefinitely. Studies are ongoing to determine the safety of discontinuing TKI therapy and the criteria most prognostic of sustained remissions after ending TKI therapy.</p>

13421<p id="_1017" tabindex="-1">

13422Evidence (length of imatinib therapy in adults):</p>

13423<div class="pdq-content-list">

13424<ol id="_1018">

13425<li>

13426In an attempt to determine the length of treatment, a prospective study reported on 69 adults treated with imatinib for more than 2 years who had been in a cytogenetic major response for more than 2 years. The patients were monitored monthly and restarted on imatinib if there was evidence of molecular relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_11.30">

1342730</a>

13428]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13429<ul id="_1019">

13430<li>

13431 Of this group, 61% of patients experienced disease relapse, with about 38% still in cytogenetic major response at 24 months.</li>

13432<li>

13433All of the patients who had disease recurrence responded again to the reinitiation of imatinib.</li>

13434</ul>

13435</div>

13436</li>

13437<li>

13438Another study reported on 40 patients with chronic-phase CML who discontinued treatment with imatinib after at least 2 years of sustained undetectable minimal residual disease (MRD) by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).[<a href="#cit/section_11.31">

1343931</a>

13440]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13441<ul id="_1020">

13442<li>

13443At 24 months, the probability of sustained molecular remission for patients no longer receiving imatinib was 47.1%.</li>

13444<li>

13445Most relapses occurred within 4 months of stopping treatment with imatinib, and no relapses beyond 27 months were observed.</li>

13446<li>

13447All patients with molecular relapse demonstrated a favorable response when imatinib was restarted; with a median follow-up of 42 months, no patients had progressive disease or developed the <em class="gene-name">

13448BCR</em>

13449::<em class="gene-name">

13450ABL1</em>

13451 gene fusion.</li>

13452</ul>

13453</div>

13454</li>

13455</ol>

13456</div>

13457<p id="_722" tabindex="-1">

13458 Additional research is required before cessation of imatinib or other <em class="gene-name">

13459BCR</em>

13460::<em class="gene-name">

13461ABL1</em>

13462 targeted therapy for selected patients with CML in molecular remission can be recommended as a standard clinical practice.</p>

13463</section>

13464<section id="_519">

13465<h3 id="_519_toc">

13466Treatment of Childhood CML</h3>

13467<p id="_1078" tabindex="-1">

13468Treatment options for children with CML may include the following:</p>

13469<div class="pdq-content-list">

13470<ol id="_1079">

13471<li>

13472TKI therapy, such as imatinib.</li>

13473</ol>

13474</div>

13475<p id="_542" tabindex="-1">

13476Imatinib has shown a high level of activity in children with CML that is comparable with the activity observed in adults.[<a href="#cit/section_11.32">

1347732</a>

13478-<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

1347936</a>

13480] </p>

13481<p id="_1021" tabindex="-1">

13482Evidence (imatinib in children):</p>

13483<div class="pdq-content-list">

13484<ol id="_1022">

13485<li>

13486In a prospective trial, 44 pediatric patients with newly diagnosed CML were treated with imatinib (260 mg/day).[<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

1348736</a>

13488]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13489<ul id="_1023">

13490<li>

13491The PFS rate at 36 months was 98%.</li>

13492<li>

13493A complete hematologic response was achieved in 98% of the patients.</li>

13494<li>

13495The rate of complete cytogenetic response was 61% and the rate of major molecular response was 31% at 12 months, similar to the rates seen in adult chronic-phase CML patients treated with imatinib. </li>

13496</ul>

13497</div>

13498</li>

13499</ol>

13500</div>

13501<p id="_1024" tabindex="-1">

13502As a result of this high level of activity, it is common to initiate imatinib treatment in children with CML rather than proceeding immediately to allogeneic stem cell transplantation.[<a href="#cit/section_11.37">

1350337</a>

13504] The pharmacokinetics of imatinib in children appears consistent with previous results in adults.[<a href="#cit/section_11.38">

1350538</a>

13506]</p>

13507<p id="_830" tabindex="-1">

13508Doses of imatinib used in phase II trials for children with CML have ranged from 260 mg/m<span class="sup">

135092</span>

13510 to 340 mg/m<span class="sup">

135112</span>

13512, which provide comparable drug exposures as the adult flat-doses of 400 mg to 600 mg.[<a href="#cit/section_11.34">

1351334</a>

13514-<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

1351536</a>

13516] </p>

13517<p id="_1025" tabindex="-1">

13518Evidence (imatinib dose in children):</p>

13519<div class="pdq-content-list">

13520<ol id="_1026">

13521<li>

13522In an Italian study of 47 pediatric patients with chronic-phase CML who were treated with 340 mg/m<span class="sup">

135232</span>

13524 per day of imatinib, complete cytogenetic response was achieved in 91.5% of patients at a median time of 6 months, and the rate of major molecular response at 12 months was 66.6%.[<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

1352536</a>

13526]<p id="_1194" tabindex="-1">

13527Thus, it appears that starting with the higher dose of 340 mg/m<span class="sup">

135282</span>

13529 has superior efficacy and is typically tolerable, with dose adjustment as needed for toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_11.35">

1353035</a>

13531,<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

1353236</a>

13533]</p>

13534</li>

13535<li>

13536Early molecular responses in children have been associated with improved PFS, similar to early molecular response data in adults. Early molecular response was defined as children who had a BCR::ABL1/ABL ratio of &#8804;10% (using a PCR-based MRD measurement) 3 months after starting imatinib.[<a href="#cit/section_11.39">

1353739</a>

13538]</li>

13539</ol>

13540</div>

13541<p id="_1027" tabindex="-1">

13542The monitoring guidelines described above for adults with CML are reasonable to use in children.</p>

13543<p id="_533" tabindex="-1">

13544Imatinib is generally well tolerated in children, with adverse effects generally being mild to moderate and reversible with treatment discontinuation or dose reduction.[<a href="#cit/section_11.34">

1354534</a>

13546,<a href="#cit/section_11.35">

1354735</a>

13548] Growth retardation occurs in most prepubertal children receiving imatinib.[<a href="#cit/section_11.40">

1354940</a>

13550] Children receiving imatinib and experiencing growth impairment may show some catch-up growth during their pubertal growth spurts, but they are at risk of having lower-than-expected adult height, as most patients do not achieve midparental height.[<a href="#cit/section_11.40">

1355140</a>

13552,<a href="#cit/section_11.41">

1355341</a>

13554]</p>

13555<p id="_817" tabindex="-1">

13556There are fewer published data regarding the efficacy and toxicities of the two other TKIs approved by the FDA for use in children with CML&#8212;dasatinib and nilotinib.</p>

13557<p id="_1281" tabindex="-1">

13558Evidence (dasatinib in children):</p>

13559<div class="pdq-content-list">

13560<ol id="_1282">

13561<li>

13562A phase I trial of dasatinib in children showed that drug disposition, tolerability, and efficacy of this agent was similar to that observed in adults.[<a href="#cit/section_11.42">

1356342</a>

13564,<a href="#cit/section_11.43">

1356543</a>

13566]</li>

13567<li>

13568A phase II trial of dasatinib, which included 84 children with newly diagnosed CML in chronic phase, utilized a dose of 60 mg/m<span class="sup">

135692</span>

13570 (tablets) or 72 mg/m<span class="sup">

135712</span>

13572 (oral solution) given to patients once daily.[<a href="#cit/section_11.44">

1357344</a>

13574]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13575<ul id="_1283">

13576<li>

13577Complete cytogenetic response and major molecular response (&#8805;3-log reduction or &#8804;0.1% on the International Scale) were achieved in 92% and 52% of patients, respectively, after 12 months of therapy, with a 4-year PFS rate of 93%.</li>

13578<li>

13579Dasatinib was well tolerated, with very few grade 3 or grade 4 adverse events. No pleural or pericardial effusions or pulmonary complications were observed.</li>

13580</ul>

13581</div>

13582</li>

13583</ol>

13584</div>

13585<p id="_1284" tabindex="-1">

13586Evidence (nilotinib in children):</p>

13587<div class="pdq-content-list">

13588<ol id="_1285">

13589<li>

13590The approval of nilotinib by the FDA in March 2018 for the treatment of children with CML was based on two sponsored trials.[<a href="#cit/section_11.45">

1359145</a>

13592,<a href="#cit/section_11.46">

1359346</a>

13594]

13595<p id="_1992" tabindex="-1">

13596An initial study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01077544">

13597NCT01077544</a>

13598 [CAMN107A2120]) of 11 patients evaluated pharmacokinetic, safety, and preliminary efficacy data; a second study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01844765">

13599NCT01844765</a>

13600 [CAMN107A2203; AAML1321]) of 58 patients evaluated efficacy and safety. Data from both studies were combined for a pooled-data analysis of 69 patients, which included 25 patients with newly diagnosed CML and 44 patients with resistant or intolerant CML. Both studies utilized a dose of 230 mg/m<span class="sup">

136012</span>

13602 given twice daily (rounded to the nearest 50 mg; maximum dose, 400 mg).[<a href="#cit/section_11.46">

1360346</a>

13604]</p>

13605<div class="pdq-content-list">

13606<ul id="_1362">

13607<li>

13608In the phase II trial, 64% of patients with newly diagnosed CML achieved a major molecular response at 1 year.</li>

13609<li>

13610The tolerability of nilotinib in children was similar to that observed in adults. Primary side effects affecting more than 30% of children included headache, fever, and hyperbilirubinemia.</li>

13611<li>

13612Prolongation of QTc interval (defined in this trial as an increase of &gt;30 msec over baseline) is a recognized side effect of nilotinib, and it was observed in 25% of children in these trials. The investigators recommend obtaining an electrocardiogram at baseline, 1 week, periodically afterward, and after dose adjustments.</li>

13613</ul>

13614</div>

13615</li>

13616</ol>

13617</div>

13618<p id="_1240" tabindex="-1">

13619 A safe pediatric dose has not yet been established for other TKIs (e.g., bosutinib and ponatinib).</p>

13620<section id="_2121">

13621<h4 id="_2121_toc">

13622Discontinuation of TKI therapy</h4>

13623<p id="_2122" tabindex="-1">

13624Discontinuation of TKI treatment is an accepted strategy for adults with CML who meet strict criteria related to their duration of treatment and to their response to treatment. Guidelines for discontinuation of TKIs have been developed by both the European LeukemiaNet (ELN) and the U.S. National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN).[<a href="#cit/section_11.47">

1362547</a>

13626,<a href="#cit/section_11.48">

1362748</a>

13628] Key elements for both guidelines include the following:</p>

13629<div class="pdq-content-list">

13630<ul id="_2123">

13631<li>

13632TKI therapy for a minimum duration of 4 to 5 years for ELN and 3 years for NCCN.</li>

13633<li>

13634A minimum duration of deep molecular response (DMR or MR4) (BCR::ABL1 protein transcript level &#8804;0.01% International Scale [IS]) of 2 years for both ELN and NCCN.</li>

13635</ul>

13636</div>

13637<p id="_2124" tabindex="-1">

13638These guidelines specify close monitoring of BCR::ABL1 transcript levels after TKI discontinuation. Loss of major molecular response (MMR or MR3) (BCR::ABL1 transcript level &#8804;0.1% IS) is generally used as the trigger for re-initiation of TKI therapy.</p>

13639<p id="_2125" tabindex="-1">

13640Loss of MMR is most likely to occur within the first 6 months of TKI discontinuation. Loss of MMR occurs much less frequently more than 1 year after TKI discontinuation. A meta-analysis included 3,105 adult patients who initiated a first attempt at TKI discontinuation. The study found that the probability of molecular recurrence was 35% after 0 to 6 months, 8% after 6 to 12 months, 3% after 12 to 18 months, and 3% after 18 to 24 months.[<a href="#cit/section_11.49">

1364149</a>

13642] These results indicated that approximately 50% of adult patients maintained their molecular responses 2 years after TKI discontinuation. Relapses can occur when TKIs have been discontinued for more than 2 years, but these recurrences appear to be infrequent (&lt;2%). Unfavorable outcomes were uncommon when relapses occurred. In addition, 90% of patients re-acquired deep molecular remission after TKI re-initiation.</p>

13643<p id="_2126" tabindex="-1">

13644There is limited data regarding TKI discontinuation in children with CML. This limited experience is explained, in part, by the low incidence of CML in children. In addition, only a minority of children with CML who are treated with TKIs meet the criteria for TKI discontinuation. For example, among patients enrolled on the International Chronic Myeloid Leukemia Pediatric Study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01281735">

13645I-CML-Ped [NCT01281735]</a>

13646), only 9% of children with CML who were treated with TKIs met the criteria for TKI discontinuation.[<a href="#cit/section_11.50">

1364750</a>

13648] Other reports have also supported this trend.[<a href="#cit/section_11.51">

1364951</a>

13650,<a href="#cit/section_11.52">

1365152</a>

13652] Although the small number of children studied is a limitation, it appears that the outcome for TKI discontinuation in children with CML is similar to that of adults. Two of the larger pediatric studies that discuss this topic are summarized below:</p>

13653<div class="pdq-content-list">

13654<ul id="_2127">

13655<li>

13656The Japan Pediatric Leukemia and Lymphoma Study Group (JPSLG) reported on 22 children with CML who met their criteria for TKI discontinuation, which was similar to the NCCN's TKI discontinuation criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_11.52">

1365752</a>

13658] The median age at CML diagnosis was 9 years, and the median age at TKI discontinuation was 16 years. The median duration of TKI therapy exceeded 8 years, and the median duration of MR4 before TKI discontinuation exceeded 4 years. Eleven of 22 children experienced loss of MMR at a median of 90 days after TKI discontinuation. All of these children subsequently regained MR4 after TKI resumption. The treatment-free remission rate at 12 months was 50%, and no relapses were observed beyond 4 months of TKI discontinuation.<p id="_2129" tabindex="-1">

13659TKI withdrawal syndrome is observed in approximately 20% to 30% of adults when TKI therapy is discontinued.[<a href="#cit/section_11.53">

1366053</a>

13661] The syndrome includes musculoskeletal pain that typically develops within 2 months of TKI discontinuation and continues for several months. The JPLSG study did not observe musculoskeletal pain in children after TKI discontinuation.</p>

13662</li>

13663<li>

13664The International Registry of Childhood Chronic Myeloid Leukemia reported on 18 patients with CML who were younger than 18 years at diagnosis. These patients discontinued imatinib after meeting the criteria for TKI discontinuation (i.e., in chronic phase with a sustained DMR to imatinib [MR4; BCR::ABL1 transcript level &#8804;0.01% IS]) for at least 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_11.50">

1366550</a>

13666]<p id="_2130" tabindex="-1">

13667Among the 18 children who stopped taking imatinib, 9 (50%) eventually resumed treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_11.50">

1366850</a>

13669] Seven of these nine patients experienced loss of MMR (BCR::ABL1 transcript level &#8804;0.1% IS). Six of the seven patients regained MR4 within a median of approximately 5 months after TKI re-initiation. The remaining patient achieved MMR after TKI re-initiation. Two additional patients who had a one-log increase in BCR::ABL1 transcript levels, but did not meet the criteria for loss of MMR, were restarted on imatinib by their physicians. For the other nine patients who remained in treatment-free remission, the median follow-up period after imatinib discontinuation was 50 months. TKI withdrawal syndrome was not reported in any patients discontinuing imatinib.</p>

13670</li>

13671</ul>

13672</div>

13673</section>

13674<section id="_1979">

13675<h4 id="_1979_toc">

13676Treatment Options under Clinical Evaluation</h4>

13677<p id="_1980" tabindex="-1">

13678Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

13679NCI website</a>

13680. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

13681ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

13682.</p>

13683<p id="_1981" tabindex="-1">

13684The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

13685<div class="pdq-content-list">

13686<ul id="_1982">

13687<li>

13688<strong>

13689<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03817398">

13690AAML18P1 (NCT03817398)</a>

13691</strong>

13692 (Stopping TKIs in Affecting Treatment-Free Remission in Patients With Chronic-Phase CML)<strong>

13693:</strong>

13694 This COG study is a nonrandomized, prospective, longitudinal study enrolling children who have achieved a deep remission (BCR::ABL1 transcript level of &lt;0.01% by real-time quantitative-polymerase chain reaction of peripheral blood [&gt;MR4, i.e., &gt;4-log reduction]) for at least 2 years after receiving the same TKI for at least 3 years. This trial is examining the incidence of molecular recurrence after discontinuing TKI therapy and the ability of patients to re-enter remission if recurrence occurs.</li>

13695</ul>

13696</div>

13697</section>

13698</section>

13699<section id="_1080">

13700<h3 id="_1080_toc">

13701Treatment of Recurrent or Refractory Childhood CML</h3>

13702<p id="_1081" tabindex="-1">

13703Treatment options for children with recurrent or refractory CML may include the following:</p>

13704<div class="pdq-content-list">

13705<ol id="_1082">

13706<li>

13707Alternative kinase inhibitors such as dasatinib or nilotinib.</li>

13708<li>

13709Allogeneic HSCT.</li>

13710</ol>

13711</div>

13712<p id="_523" tabindex="-1">

13713In children who develop a hematologic or cytogenetic relapse during treatment with imatinib or who have an inadequate initial response to imatinib, determination of <em class="gene-name">

13714BCR</em>

13715::<em class="gene-name">

13716ABL1</em>

13717 kinase domain mutation status should be considered to help guide subsequent therapy. Depending on the patient&#8217;s mutation status, alternative kinase inhibitors such as dasatinib or nilotinib can be considered on the basis of the adult and pediatric experience with these agents.[<a href="#cit/section_11.21">

1371821</a>

13719,<a href="#cit/section_11.22">

1372022</a>

13721,<a href="#cit/section_11.44">

1372244</a>

13723,<a href="#cit/section_11.54">

1372454</a>

13725-<a href="#cit/section_11.56">

1372656</a>

13727]</p>

13728<p id="_1270" tabindex="-1">

13729Evidence (dasatinib in children with resistant or intolerant CML):</p>

13730<div class="pdq-content-list">

13731<ol id="_1271">

13732<li>

13733In a study of 14 children with resistant or intolerant CML, the following results were observed:[<a href="#cit/section_11.44">

1373444</a>

13735]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13736<ul id="_1993">

13737<li>

1373876% of patients were in complete cytogenetic remission, and 41% of patients had a major molecular response after 12 months of dasatinib therapy.</li>

13739<li>

13740The PFS rate was 78% at 48 months.</li>

13741</ul>

13742</div>

13743</li>

13744</ol>

13745</div>

13746<p id="_1272" tabindex="-1">

13747Evidence (nilotinib in children with resistant or intolerant CML):</p>

13748<div class="pdq-content-list">

13749<ol id="_1273">

13750<li>

13751In a study of 44 children with CML who were resistant or intolerant to imatinib or dasatinib, the following results were observed:[<a href="#cit/section_11.45">

1375245</a>

13753]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13754<ul id="_1994">

13755<li>

1375640.7% of patients achieved a major molecular response after 12 months of nilotinib therapy.</li>

13757<li>

13758 After a median of 11.3 months, no patients had experienced disease progression.</li>

13759</ul>

13760</div>

13761</li>

13762</ol>

13763</div>

13764<p id="_1195" tabindex="-1">

13765Dasatinib and nilotinib are active against many <em class="gene-name">

13766BCR</em>

13767::<em class="gene-name">

13768ABL1</em>

13769 gene fusion mutations that confer resistance to imatinib, although the agents are ineffective in patients with the <em class="gene-name">

13770T315I</em>

13771 mutation. In the presence of the <em class="gene-name">

13772T315I</em>

13773 mutation, which is resistant to all FDA-approved kinase inhibitors, an allogeneic transplant should be considered. Ponatinib, the BCR::ABL1 protein fusion inhibitor that is effective against the <em class="gene-name">

13774T315I</em>

13775 mutation in adults, has not been prospectively studied in the pediatric population.</p>

13776<p id="_738" tabindex="-1">

13777The question of whether a pediatric patient with CML should receive an allogeneic transplant when multiple TKIs are available remains unanswered; however, reports suggest that PFS does not improve when using HSCT, compared with the sustained use of imatinib.[<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

1377836</a>

13779] The potential advantages and disadvantages

13780need to be discussed with the patient and family. While HSCT is currently the only known definitive curative therapy for CML, patients discontinuing treatment with TKIs after sustained molecular remissions, who remained in molecular remission, have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_11.31">

1378131</a>

13782] </p>

13783</section>

13784<section id="_TrialSearch_195_sid_11">

13785<h3 id="_TrialSearch_195_sid_11_toc">

13786Current Clinical Trials</h3>

13787<p id="_TrialSearch_195_22" tabindex="-1">

13788Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

13789advanced clinical trial search</a>

13790 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

13791General information</a>

13792 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

13793</section>

13857<li id="section_11.16">

13858Bisen A, Claxton DF: Tyrosine kinase targeted treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia and other myeloproliferative neoplasms. Adv Exp Med Biol 779: 179-96, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23288640&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23288640&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13859[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13860</li>
