14027

14028 <section id="_201">

14029

14030 <h2>

14031Survivorship and Adverse Late Sequelae</h2>

14032

14033 <div id="_section_201" class="pdq-sections">

14034<p id="_202" tabindex="-1">

14035While the issues of long-term complications of cancer and its treatment cross many disease categories, several important issues related to the treatment of myeloid malignancies are worth emphasizing. For more information, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq">

14036Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

14037.</p>

14038<p id="_1196" tabindex="-1">

14039Selected studies of the late effects of AML therapy in adult survivors who were not treated with hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) include the following:</p>

14040<div class="pdq-content-list">

14041<ol id="_1197">

14042<li>

14043Cardiac.<div class="pdq-content-list">

14044<ol id="_1198" class="lower-alpha">

14045<li>

14046The Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) examined 272 survivors of childhood acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who did not undergo an HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_12.1">

140471</a>

14048] <div class="pdq-content-list">

14049<ul id="_1199">

14050<li>

14051This study identified second malignancies (cumulative incidence, 1.7%) and cardiac toxic effects (cumulative incidence, 4.7%) as significant long-term risks.</li>

14052<li>

14053Cardiomyopathy has been reported in 4.3% of survivors of AML based on Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster studies. Of these, 2.5% showed clinical symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_12.2">

140542</a>

14055] </li>

14056</ul>

14057</div>

14058</li>

14059<li>

14060A retrospective study of cardiac function of children treated with United Kingdom Medical Research Council&#8211;based regimens at a median of 13 months after treatment reported a mean detrimental change in left ventricular stroke volume of 8.4% compared with baseline values.[<a href="#cit/section_12.3">

140613</a>

14062]</li>

14063<li>

14064For pediatric patients, the risk of developing early toxicity was 13.7%, and the risk of developing late cardiac toxic effects (defined as 1 year after completing first-line therapy) was 17.4%. Early cardiac toxic effects was a significant predictor of late cardiac toxic effects and the development of clinical cardiomyopathy requiring long-term therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.4">

140654</a>

14066]</li>

14067<li>

14068Retrospective analysis of a single study suggests cardiac risk may be increased in children with Down syndrome,[<a href="#cit/section_12.5">

140695</a>

14070] but prospective studies are required to confirm this finding.</li>

14071</ol>

14072</div>

14073</li>

14074<li>

14075Psychosocial.<div class="pdq-content-list">

14076<ol id="_1200" class="lower-alpha">

14077<li>

14078A Nordic Society for Pediatric Hematology and Oncology retrospective trial of children with AML treated with chemotherapy only at a median follow-up of 11 years, based on self-reported uses of health care services, demonstrated similar health care usage and marital status as their siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_12.6">

140796</a>

14080]</li>

14081<li>

14082A population-based study of survivors of childhood AML who had not undergone an HSCT reported equivalent rates of educational achievement, employment, and marital status compared with siblings. AML survivors were, however, significantly more likely to be receiving prescription drugs, especially for asthma, than were siblings (23% vs. 9%; <em>

14083P</em>

14084 = .03). Chronic fatigue has also been demonstrated to be a significantly more likely adverse late effect in survivors of childhood AML than in survivors of other malignancies.[<a href="#cit/section_12.7">

140857</a>

14086]</li>

14087<li>

14088A CCSS report evaluated survivors of childhood AML treated between 1970 and 1999 (median age at the time of assessment, 30 to 32 years) and compared their outcomes to data from siblings. Survivors who received either intensive chemotherapy consolidation (n = 299) or underwent HSCT (n = 183) had statistically significant worse outcomes than did their siblings in somatic symptom measures (prevalence, 8.4%&#8211;12%), neurocognitive functioning (prevalence, 17.7%&#8211;25.7%), health-related quality-of-life measurements (prevalence, 8.2%&#8211;24.6%), and social attainment measures. In all measures, there was no statistically significant difference in prevalence of problems identified between the two consolidation cohorts.[<a href="#cit/section_12.8">

140898</a>

14090]</li>

14091</ol>

14092</div>

14093</li>

14094</ol>

14095</div>

14096<p id="_723" tabindex="-1">

14097Renal, gastrointestinal, and hepatic late adverse effects have been reported to be rare for children undergoing chemotherapy only for treatment of AML.[<a href="#cit/section_12.9">

140989</a>

14099] </p>

14100<p id="_1201" tabindex="-1">

14101Selected studies of the late effects of AML therapy in adult survivors who were treated with HSCT include the following:</p>

14102<div class="pdq-content-list">

14103<ol id="_1202">

14104<li>

14105In a review from one institution, the highest frequency of adverse long-term sequelae for children treated for AML included the following incidence rates: growth abnormalities (51%), neurocognitive abnormalities (30%), transfusion-acquired hepatitis (28%), infertility (25%), endocrinopathies (16%), restrictive lung disease (20%), chronic graft-versus-host disease (20%), secondary malignancies (14%), and cataracts (12%).[<a href="#cit/section_12.10">

1410610</a>

14107]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14108<ul id="_1203">

14109<li>

14110 Most of these adverse sequelae are the consequence of myeloablative, allogeneic HSCT. Although cardiac abnormalities were reported in 8% of patients, this is an issue that may be particularly relevant with the current use of increased anthracyclines in clinical trials for children with newly diagnosed AML.</li>

14111</ul>

14112</div>

14113</li>

14114<li>

14115Another study examined outcomes for children younger than 3 years with AML or acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_12.11">

1411611</a>

14117] <div class="pdq-content-list">

14118<ul id="_1204">

14119<li>

14120The toxicities reported include growth hormone deficiency (59%), dyslipidemias (59%), hypothyroidism (35%), osteochondromas (24%), and decreased bone mineral density (24%).</li>

14121<li>

14122Two of the 33 patients developed secondary malignancies.</li>

14123<li>

14124 Survivors had average intelligence but frequent attention-deficit problems and fine-movement abnormalities, compared with population controls.</li>

14125</ul>

14126</div>

14127</li>

14128<li>

14129In contrast, The Bone Marrow Transplant Survivor Study compared childhood AML or ALL survivors with siblings using a self-reporting questionnaire.[<a href="#cit/section_12.12">

1413012</a>

14131] The median follow-up was 8.4 years, and 86% of patients received total-body irradiation (TBI) as part of their preparative transplant regimen.<div class="pdq-content-list">

14132<ul id="_1205">

14133<li>

14134Survivors of leukemia who received an HSCT had significantly higher frequencies of several adverse effects, including diabetes, hypothyroidism, osteoporosis, cataracts, osteonecrosis, exercise-induced shortness of breath, neurosensory impairments, and problems with balance, tremor, and weakness than did siblings.</li>

14135<li>

14136The overall assessment of health was significantly decreased in survivors compared with siblings (odds ratio, 2.2; <em>

14137P</em>

14138 = .03).</li>

14139<li>

14140Significant differences were not observed between regimens using TBI compared with chemotherapy only, which mostly included busulfan.</li>

14141<li>

14142The outcomes were similar for patients with AML and ALL, suggesting that the primary cause underlying the adverse late effects was undergoing an HSCT.</li>

14143</ul>

14144</div>

14145</li>

14146<li>

14147A Children's Oncology Group (COG) study using a health-related, quality-of-life comparison reported that 21% of 5-year survivors had a severe or life-threatening chronic health condition; when compared by type of treatment, this percentage was 16% for the chemotherapy-only treated group, 21% for the autologous HSCT treated group, and 33% for those who received an allogeneic HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_12.13">

1414813</a>

14149]</li>

14150<li>

14151

14152

14153A CCSS cohort analysis examined the long-term mortality and health statuses of 856 children (5-year survivors) previously treated for AML, with or without HSCT, between 1970 and 1999.[<a href="#cit/section_12.14">

1415414</a>

14155]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14156<ul id="_2156">

14157<li>

14158 Cumulative rates of grades 3 to 5 chronic health conditions significantly declined among HSCT recipients between the 1970s and 1990s (from 76.1% to 43.5%; <em>

14159P</em>

14160 = .04) but remained stable for chemotherapy-only recipients (from 12.2% to 27.6%; <em>

14161P</em>

14162 = .06). </li>

14163<li>

14164There was a significant decline in cumulative all-cause late mortality over the same time-frame for HSCT recipients (from 38.9% to 8.5%; <em>

14165P</em>

14166 &lt; .0001). This was primarily a result of a reduction in relapse, whereas no significant decline in late mortality was seen in the chemotherapy-only survivors (from 6.8% to 2.6%; <em>

14167P</em>

14168 = .35).</li>

14169<li>

14170 In self-reports, health statuses among all survivors were excellent, very good, or good in 85% of HSCT recipients and in 90% of chemotherapy-only recipients. However, survivors' health statuses in both treatment groups were significantly worse than that of their siblings (HR, 3.8; 95% CI, 2.7&#8211;5.4 vs. HR, 2.6; 95% CI, 1.8&#8211;3.6, respectively). </li>

14171</ul>

14172</div>

14173</li>

14174</ol>

14175</div>

14176<p id="_531" tabindex="-1">

14177New therapeutic approaches to reduce long-term adverse sequelae are needed, especially for reducing the late sequelae associated with myeloablative HSCT.</p>

14178<p id="_532" tabindex="-1">

14179Important resources for details on follow-up and risks for survivors of cancer have been developed, including the COG&#8217;s <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

14180Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

14181 and the National Comprehensive Cancer Network's <a href="https://www.nccn.org/professionals/physician_gls/f_guidelines.asp" title="https://www.nccn.org/professionals/physician_gls/f_guidelines.asp">

14182Guidelines for Acute Myeloid Leukemia</a>

14183. Furthermore, having access to past medical history that can be shared with subsequent medical providers has become increasingly recognized as important for cancer survivors.</p>

14184<h6 do-not-show="toc">

14246 </section>

14247

14248

14249

14250 <section id="_857">

14251

14252 <h2>

14253Changes to This Summary (06/14/2023)</h2>

14254

14255 <div id="_section_857" class="pdq-sections">

14256<p id="_858" tabindex="-1">

14257The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as

14258new information becomes available. This section describes the latest

14259changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

14260<p id="_2163" tabindex="-1">

14261<strong>

14262<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1">

14263General Information About Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)</a>

14264</strong>

14265</p>

14266<p id="_2157" tabindex="-1">

14267Added <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_27">

14268hypodiploidy</a>

14269 as a genetic abnormality associated with an unfavorable prognosis. Also added text to state that hypodiploidy is defined as a modal chromosome number of less than or equal to 45. In a retrospective cohort analysis, the International Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster AML Study Group aimed to characterize hypodiploidy in pediatric patients with AML (cited Hammer et al. as reference 111).</p>

14270<p id="_2158" tabindex="-1">

14271<strong>

14272<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_52">

14273Treatment of Childhood AML</a>

14274</strong>

14275</p>

14276<p id="_2164" tabindex="-1">

14277Added <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_2142">

14278text</a>

14279 about the results of the Children's Oncology Group (COG) AML1031 trial, which showed that sorafenib improved the event-free survival of pediatric patients with de novo AML and high-allelic ratio <em class="gene-name">

14280FLT3</em>

14281 internal tandem duplication mutations (cited Pollard et al. as reference 36).</p>

14282<p id="_2165" tabindex="-1">

14283<strong>

14284<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_62">

14285Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL)</a>

14286</strong>

14287</p>

14288<p id="_2166" tabindex="-1">

14289Added <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1129">

14290text</a>

14291 to state that in the COG AAML1331 trial, patients with standard-risk APL had idarubicin eliminated from the induction cycle. Mitoxantrone, high-dose cytarabine, and idarubicin were eliminated from the consolidation cycles. Mercaptopurine and methotrexate were eliminated from the maintenance cycles. Intrathecal doses of cytarabine were also eliminated.</p>

14292<p id="_2167" tabindex="-1">

14293<strong>

14294<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_74">

14295Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS)</a>

14296</strong>

14297</p>

14298<p id="_2168" tabindex="-1">

14299Added <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_507">

14300text</a>

14301 to state that in one retrospective analysis, only the revised International Prognostic Scoring System (R-IPSS) very poor&#8211;risk subgroup, defined as having complex cytogenetics, was found to have a significant adverse prognostic impact on overall survival and relapse risk after transplant (cited Yamamoto et al. as reference 34).</p>

14302<p id="_2172" tabindex="-1">

14303Added <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_2170">

14304text</a>

14305 about the R-IPSS prognostic groups and associated cytogenetic abnormalities.</p>

14306<p id="_2161" tabindex="-1">

14307<strong>

14308<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_195">

14309Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)</a>

14310</strong>

14311</p>

14312<p id="_2159" tabindex="-1">

14313Added <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_2121">

14314Discontinuation of TKI therapy</a>

14315 as a new subsection.</p>

14316<p id="_2160" tabindex="-1">

14317<strong>

14318<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_201">

14319Survivorship and Adverse Late Sequelae</a>

14320</strong>

14321</p>

14322<p id="_2162" tabindex="-1">

14323Added <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_1202">

14324text</a>

14325 about the results of a

14326

14327Childhood Cancer Survivor Study cohort analysis that examined the long-term mortality and health statuses of 856 children previously treated for AML, with or without hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, between 1970 and 1999 (cited Turcotte et al. as reference 14).</p>

14328<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

14329This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

14330PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

14331, which is

14332editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

14333the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

14334information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

14335maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

14336About This PDQ Summary</a>

14337 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

14338PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

14339 pages.

14340</p>

14341</div>

14342

14343 </section>

14344

14345

14346

14347 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

14348

14349 <h2>

14350About This PDQ Summary</h2>

14351

14352 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

14353<section id="_AboutThis_2">

14354<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

14355Purpose of This Summary</h3>

14356<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

14357This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the treatment of childhood acute myeloid leukemia and other myeloid malignancies. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

14358</section>

14359<section id="_AboutThis_4">

14360<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

14361Reviewers and Updates</h3>

14362<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

14363This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

14364PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

14365, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

14366<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

14367 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

14368<div class="pdq-content-list">

14369<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

14370<li>

14371be discussed at a meeting,</li>

14372<li>

14373be cited with text, or</li>

14374<li>

14375replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

14376</ul>

14377</div>

14378<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

14379Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

14380<p id="" tabindex="-1">

14381The lead reviewers for Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment are:</p>

14382<div class="pdq-content-list">

14383<ul id="">

14384<li>

14385William L. Carroll, MD (Laura and Isaac Perlmutter Cancer Center at NYU Langone)</li>

14386<li>

14387Alan Scott Gamis, MD, MPH (Children's Mercy Hospital)</li>

14388<li>

14389Karen J. Marcus, MD, FACR (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute/Boston Children's Hospital)</li>

14390<li>

14391Jessica Pollard, MD (Dana-Farber/Boston Children's Cancer and Blood Disorders Center)</li>

14392<li>

14393Michael A. Pulsipher, MD (Children's Hospital Los Angeles)</li>

14394<li>

14395Rachel E. Rau, MD (Texas Medical Center)</li>

14396<li>

14397Lewis B. Silverman, MD (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute/Boston Children's Hospital)</li>

14398<li>

14399Malcolm A. Smith, MD, PhD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

14400<li>

14401Sarah K. Tasian, MD (Children's Hospital of Philadelphia)</li>

14402</ul>

14403</div>

14404<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

14405Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

14406Email Us</a>

14407. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

14408</section>

14409<section id="_AboutThis_10">

14410<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

14411Levels of Evidence</h3>

14412<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

14413Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

14414formal evidence ranking system</a>

14415 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

14416</section>

14417<section id="_AboutThis_12">

14418<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

14419Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

14420<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

14421PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

14422<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

14423The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

14424<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

14425PDQ&#174; Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq">

14426https://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq</a>

14427. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389454]</p>

14428<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

14429Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

14430Visuals Online</a>

14431, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

14432

14433</p>

14434</section>

14435<section id="_AboutThis_17">

14436<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

14437Disclaimer</h3>

14438<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

14439Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

14440Managing Cancer Care</a>

14441 page.</p>

14442</section>

14443<section id="_AboutThis_20">

14444<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

14445Contact Us</h3>

14446<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

14447More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

14448Contact Us for Help</a>

14449 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

14450Email Us</a>

14451.</p>

14452</section>

14453</div>
